column2: Dr. James L. O'Leary, a physician and prominent Roman Catholic layman, died on Saturday at the Methodist Hospital of Brooklyn. He was 68 years old and lived at 1655 Flatbush Avenue, Brooklyn.

In a sharp departure, President Ford has moved to make management of the economy a bipartisan policy, in much the same way that foreign affairs has traditionally been. He has done this by scheduling a series of "summit" conferences on inflation involving a wide spectrum of experts,

The trustees of the Penn Central Railroad told Judge John P. Fullam of the Federal District Court in Philadelphia yesterday that the cash flow of the carrier's nontransportation assets amounted to $92.4million last year.

The Reynolds Metal Company and the AlcanAluminum Corporation yesterday announced they were increasing the price of 99.5 per cent primary aluminum ingot to 39 cents a pound from 36 cents, effective today.

Indictments against seven major oil companies, charging them with criminally acting together to restrain competition in the sale of gasoline throughout the metropolitan area, have been voted by a special state grand jury.

For the first time In more than a century, citizens of the nation's capital on Sept. 10 will take the first step in the election of local officials. On that date District-of Columbia voters will select candidates for Mayor and and member City Council from 90 contenders in Democratic and Republican primaries.

Joseph Papp, producer and founder of the New York Shakespeare Festival, has been named Visiting Critic in Directing by the Yale School of Drama for the 1974-75 academic year, it was announced yesterday by Robert Brustein, dean of the school.

Representative Hugh L. Carey reversed himself yesterday and told Howard J. Samuels, his Democratic gubernatorial primary opponent, that he would endorse him should Mr. Samuels win the primary election nextTuesday. Mr. Carey's new statement followed by one day his threat to withhold support. It came Representative Hugh L Carey of Brooklyn, left, listening to Howard J. Samuels, his rival in the contest for Democratic nomination for Governor, during debate at The Times.

In calling for "a real partnership between the academic community and the rest of our society," President Ford has taken an important initiative toward ending an intolerable schism. The break between academia and the Federal Government, which originally. developed during the Johnson Administration 'over the single issue of the war in Vietnam, subsequently deepened into a virulent antagonism in the Nixon years.

Exxon, U.S.A. and the Mobil Oil Corporation announced today they had abandoned the first well drilled on the Destin anticline in the Gulf of Mexico, 40 miles southwest of Panama City, Fla. Drilled to a depth of 10,930 feet, the unproductive well is on a block for which Exxon, Mobil and the Champlin Petroleum Corporation bid $212-million at a government auction.

My answer to the question of whether the United States economy is in a recession is yes, though the full story' is still unfolding.What has happened so far this year bears a strong resemblance to previous recessions.

President Ford may put off until next week a promised decision on conditional leniency for Vietnam war deserters and draft evaders so as to consult again with the Departments of Defense and Justice. James Wagonseller, American Legion head, outside White House yesterday.

The Tolley International Corporation announced today that it had established the first pre-paid legal services program for members of a labor union under terms of an amendment to the Taft-Hartley Act.

These charts, based on information supplied by the National Weather Service, show for the next 30 days expected departures from normal temperatures and from normal precipitation. Normal temperatures for this period for flye key cities are as follows: New York, 68.8; Chicago, 63.6; Denver, 63.0; San Francisco, 63.9; Anchorage, 48.

At the age of 31, John Schmitt is finally leaving home. Schmitt, who was born and raised in the New York area and played his entire college and pro football career here, was traded by the Jets, today to the Green Bay Packers on a conditional basis for the ubiquitous undisclosed future draft choice.

The Naumburg Symphony Orchestra's summer concerts on the Central Park Mall have fallen into a pattern in recent years. The fourth and final program, which takes place on Labor Day, is now regularly devoted to opera, usually one that is rarely performed.

The bear market dropped International Business Machines 81/2 points yesterday to close at 183/2, a new low for the year. The decline represented a loss on I.B.M.'s 146,858,000 shares of about one and a quarter billion dollars on the day.

The New York Stock Exchange yesterday asked the Securities and Exchange Commission for a 7 per cent rise in commissions on all brokerage transactions worth more than $2,000. The exchange had indicated earlier

Amid inflation-related rising costs, pressures for higher salaries and pinched family budgets, religious schools serving nearly three-quarters of a million pupils in the metropolitan New York area and in New Jersey began opening their doors this week for a new school year.

One day in 1923, two of New York's leading merchants boarded a Jersey Central commuter train, but instead of heading for their usual seats, they wandered through the train until they came to the baggage car. Saks Fifth Avenue began with a flourish and its early success was marked by fashionable women waiting each morning for the doors to open

Steel production declined 0.6 per cent to 2.65 million tons in the week ended Aug. 31, compared with the previous week's 2.66 million net. tons, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday.
Things broke a little awkwardly for the Jaclyn Stable's Stulcer at the start of the $28,400 Astarita at Belmont Park yesterday. The filly was first out of the gate according to the charts,
Meet records were broken in eight of nine final events and one preliminary today at the European track and field championships in Rome's Stadio Olimpico.

Pumping in the two pipelines that carry Saudi and Iraqi crude oil to the Lebanese Mediterranean coast is reported to have dropped to about 40 per cent of the pipeline's capacity in the last seven Weeks.

Despina Papadopoulos, wife of the ousted dictator George Papadopoulos, is the first person associated with the military junta, now collapsed, to be prosecuted for illegal activities during her husband's seven-year rule. Despina Papadopoulos

KINGSTON, Jamaica--There -is a continuing and increasingly significant world dialogue about the relationship between the richer and peorer nations. The search for effective development strategies; the desirability of aid programs; the problem of the terms of
President Glafkos Clerides said today that his Government had confiscated hundreds of weapons from illegally armed Greek Cypriotes in recent days.

Secretary of Commerce Frederick B. Dent said today that he expects Congress to pass a favorable trade bill this year, to approve "mostfavored-nation" status for the Soviet Union before its planned adjournment in mid-October and to grant the Export-Import Bank a new charter this month. Frederick B. Dent

The Aces have been North America's most successful and celebrated team for the last five years. Their recent results in national tournaments have not been as good as in the past, but their nonplaying captain, Ira Corn of Dallas, reports that a reorganized Aces' team will be fighting hard for top honors in the coming months.

The union representing 500 lay teachers in Roman Catholic schools in Brooklyn has reached agreement with the Brooklyn Diocese, averting a strike that had been set for Monday. Following day-long negotiations on Tuesday,
Two more of the nation's leading power-equipment suppliers acknowledged yesterday that they had been asking utilities voluntarily to pay more for equipment already on order.

City College yesterday announced the beginning of a $10-million fund-raising campaign, the largest in its history. Dr. Robert E. Marshak, the college president, explained that city and state financing for the college was not expected to rise, so the campaign

It must often seem to producers of musicals that if only you can get the music right, everything else has virtually got to follow, Well, the producers of two London shows have taken care of that aspect; one is using music by

SWEETS The. narrow, bustling streets of Little Italy are taking on an anticipatory quality these days with the San :Gennaro, feast: only one week away. And as usual, one of the focuses of activity is Ferrara, Perhaps the.

The Israeli Army reported today that it had thwarted an Arab terrorist plot to free the Most Rev. Hilarion Capucci, Greek Catholic Archbishop of East Jerusalem, who is in an Israeli jail awaiting trial on charges inevolving the smuggling of weapins to Palestinian guerrillas.
Community representatives from Coney Island expressed their support for a proposed change from industrial to mixed-use zoning in hearings last night before the City Planning Commission.

Members of Local 3 of the In ternational Brotherhood of Teamsters have not returned to work although a Federal judge ordered them on Friday to end their two-month-old strike on public school construction sites.
The median income of United States households rose to $10,500 in 1973, an increase of 8.4 per cent from the year before, but most of the gain was wiped out by inflation, the Census Bureau said today.

Eugene A. Cafiero, group vice president of the North American operations of the Chrysler Corporation, said today that the company was considering raising the price of its average 1975 car by about 8 per cent, or $400.

An official of the State Dormitory Authority said yesterday that the general contractors for the North Academic Center at City College had agreed to try to, use 25 per cent minortiy subcontractors and 50 per cent minority manpower on the $70-million project.
The Senate Democratic lead er, Mike Mansfield, of Montana, said today that the $850,0001 sought for former President Nixon's pension and transition expenses should be "looked at most carefully."

President Ford named Mary Louise Smith today as his choice for chairman of the Republican National Committee. If she is approved by the committee -- and that is regarded as just a formality -- Mrs. Smith, a 59-year-old Iowan, will become the first woman to head the Republican party.

A survey of interest to young prople looking for career opportunities shows that the highest-paying jobs for office workers in the New York area are in computers. The best-paying plant jobs, on the other hand, are as
Leroy C. Curtis, senior partner in the law firm of Hays, Porter, Spanier Curtis, died of cancer last evening at Park West Hospital. He was 57 years old and lived at 229 West 78th Street.

A spokesman for Vice President-designate Nelson A. Rockefeller estimated yesterday that there were "in the neighborhood of 400 F.B.I. agents" Investigating Mr. Rockefeller as part of the detailed scrutiny of his past that embraces his health, his for tune and his academic record at Dartmouth College.

The naming today of George Bush to fill the top American diplomatic job in Peking comes at a time when Secretary of State Kissinger is reported to be satisfied with the development of United States-China relations.

Gustave L. Levy, senior partner of Goldman, Sachs Co., insisted yesterday that the investment firm bore no responsibility in its sales of commercial paper of the Penn Central Transportation Company from August, 1968, to April, 1970. Mr. Levy said that the

Reza Fellah, a director of Iran's National Oil Company, expressed support today for cutbacks in oil production meant to avert price reductions. Reza Fellah, director of Iran's National Oil Company, during speech at the National Press Club in Washington.

The Chicago, Rock Island Pacific Railroad said yesterday it had an agreement to sell 80 of its 20-year-old diesel locomotives to a subsidiary here of, Hugo Stinnes, A. G., the West German machine tool maker.

The United States established formal diplomatic relations with East Germany today, the last' major Western country to do so since the Communist country emerged from relative international isolation three years ago. Herbert Suss, left, representing East Germany, and Arthur A. Hartman, U.S. Assistant Secretary for European Affairs, signing documents at the State Department yesterday that established formal diplomatic relations. John Sherman Cooper, chosen to be first Ambassador to East Germany.

Secretary of Agriculture Earl L. Butz, who will lead the United States delegation to the United Nations World Food Conference in Rome, said today that disappointing crops had limited this country's capacity to promise increased food aid to hungry peoples.

I have found it is a very busy life," Betty Ford said. "I'm very happy, Everyone gas ben so generous and warm." It was the kind of statement that First Ladies are expected to make after their first few weeks in the White House.

Marce Achard of the French Academy who for half a century delighted the audiences of Paris boulevard theaters with his comedies, died here today of diabetes at his home. He was 75 years old. Marcel Achard
Members of the Taxi Drivers Union representing 30,000 employes, last night overwhelmingLy approved a new contract with fleet owners in a meeting at Manhattan Center.

British trade unions voted overwhelmingly today to support the Labor party Government's efforts to curb inflation. Implicit in the resolution adopted at the annual conference of the Trades Union Congress here was an undertaking

Twenty-one economists, representing almost the entire spectrum of economic opinion, will meet here tomorrow in the first of a series of White House conferences on inflation, and there were indications that they might approach unanimity on at least some issues.

In the housekeeping corner of the Lewisboro elementary school kindergarten, Katharine Gill, who wore a red dress and a Band Aid on her chin, Tan into an old friend Todd Prybylski, on the first day of school. In their first day in kindergarten, children romp on a 10-foot-long bean bag

David G. Trager, the United States Attorney for the Eastern District of New York, said he had not yet decided whether to proceed to trial with a Government case against Gerard P. Trotta, the former Public Works Commissioner for the Town of Dyster Bay, L.I.

Twenty-one economists, representing almost the entire spectrum of economic opinion, will meet here tomorrow in the first of a series of White House conferences on inflation, and there were indications that they might approach unanimity on at least some issues.

Carter Campbell, a defensive end, has obtained an early release from the Cleveland Browns of the National Football League in time to join the New York Stars of th World Football League this weekend, exactly halfway through the Stars' season. Carter Campbell

Record sales and earnings were reported yesterday by the H. J. Heinz Company for its first fiscal quarter ended July 31. R. Burt Gookin, vice chairman, said operating margins improved, principally from "our ability to control fixed manufacturing and administrative costs during a period when other costs were increasing rapidly."
The Federal Reserve Board announced today a technical change in bank reserverequirements, that could have a slight easing effect in the Reserve's currently very tight monetary policy.

Testimony ended today in the Wounded Knee Indian trial, which began Jan. 7, After 150 witnesses and more than four million words of testimony, the case is scheduled to go to the jury a week from tomorrow.
When President Ford introduced the new chairman of the Council of Economic Advisers to his Cabinet, virtually the first words out of Alan Greenspan's mouth were, "Don't expect miracles."

Gen. Fred C. Weyand, the last commander of American forces in South Vietnam, is expected to assume the burden of rebuilding a post-Vietnam Army from Gen. Creighton W. Abrams, the Army Chief of Staff, who died early this morning.
Italy's balance of payments was in the black for the first month in a long time in July, registering a surplus of $354.4-million, according to preliminary figures released today by the Bank of Italy.

The defeat of Lester Maddox in the run-off election for the Democratic nomination for Governor of Georgia by George Busbee, the moderate majority leader of the State House of Representatives, marks continuation of a healthy political trend in the South. It also seems to end one of that section's ugliest and most ludicrous political careers.

Edward M. carey, the man who has financed a substantial portion of the gubernatorial primary campaign of Representative Hugh L. Carey, his brother, has built a sizable business for himself in the last 27 years, one that has earned him the nickname of "the oil baron" of'New York City.

HOW TO MAKE SAUERKRAUT FROM FRESH CABBAGE 50 pounds white cabbage 1 pound pure granulated salt (noniodized). 1. Remove and discard the outer leaves and any other bruised or otherwise blemished leaves of the cabbage.
Bill Beutel, a co-anchorman on WABC-TV's local "Eyewitness News," has been selected to be host of the ABC-TV network's new morning show, "AM America," which will have its premiere early next year.

A prominent Jewish-movement activist, suffering from a heart condition, was dragged from his bed by policemen early this morning and arrested on grounds that he refused to work, his wife charged today.

To the Editor: Sugar prices are at an all-time high and every indication for the balance of this year is that they will maintain this level or go even higher, Many sugar producers are very quick to say that because Of the defeat of the Sugar Act by Congress this year the price of sugar is spiraling.

The choreography for the polonaise in the Metropolitan Opera's new production of Mussorgsky's "Boris Godunov" will be staged by George Balanchine. The assignment is the first at the Metropolitan for Mr. Balanchine since 1953,
A suit filed in District Court here seeks to invalidate the State Game Commission's liberal hunting season for cougars in New Mexico.

A barracks mate of George Washington Dean, a recently retired military policeman whose body was found in a water-filled ditch south of Fort Dix, was charged with murder in a complaint filed in Federal District Court in Trenton. The suspect, Kenneth Harold Woodson, who retired from the Army last Saturday, was accused of murdering Mr. Dean in Mr. Woodson's apartment in the M.P. barracks in which the two men lived at Fort Dix.

Jimmy Connors of the United States and. Evonne Goolagong of Australia have sued the French Lawn Tennis Federation for $200,000 damages apiece because they were banned from the French open championship in June. There was no indication of a hearing date for the quit which was filed by attorneys in Paris.

Official 'hearings resume today on five controversial plans for the dilapidated West Side Highway while civic, plarnning and business groups are trying to agree on an expressway of "reasonable" size as a sixth.

After becoming accustomed to decency, integrity and tempered judgment in the Manhattan District Attorney's office during the three decades of Frank Hogan's distinguished career, New Yorkers are suddenly faced with sorting out the issues in a sharply contested race for that job.
An apparent attempt by Scottish nationalists to remove the Stone of Scone, the ancient Scottish coronation stone, from Westminster Abbey was foiled early this morning. Stone in Coronation Chair

" These riots are the best thing that could have happened to us," a member of the Hispanic Emergency Council said today. The council is working with Mayor Kenneth A. Gibson on ways of preventing a continuation of the rioting and looting that has gone on for three days in the Puerto Rican community here.

Calling the 1973-74 session of the State Legislature "a "major disappointment for the cause of women's right." the New York Women's Lobby yesterday issued ratings for all incumbent legislators, including an 18-member "honor roll" and a 29-member "dishonor roll."

A tough, swearing, cigarThomping, hell-for-leather battlefield commander, a man of legendary exploits in World War I, Gen. Creighton W. Abrams capped a brilliant military career in the frustrating and diplomatically sensitive post of commander of United States forces in Vietnam. Gen. Creighton W. Abrams
Haiti became today the fourth Caribbean nation to announce renegotiation of its income from bauxite mined by the major United States and Canadian aluminum companies.

Unless New York State settles for a smaller piece of the pie, Connecticut is prepared to use New Jersey horse races for its offtrack betting operation. However, New York race tracks have begun last-ditch efforts to reach a compromise that could block the switch to-Jersey.

The Ford Administration has narrowly avoided a crisis with the black leadership on Capitol Hill by blocking at the last minute an effort to force the resignation of Barbara M. Watson, the State Department's highest-ranking black official.

Ramsey Clark yesterday urged a United States policy of economic aid plus "invincible armament" for Israel. He was Immediately attacked as "hypocritical" by Lee Alexander, his rival in the Democratic primary for the United States Senate,

The Hous,ton Oilers take John Matuszak and the Houston Texans to court tomorrow in their cross-town professional football contract dispute. Matuszak, the National Football League's No. 1 draft pick in 1973, jumped from the Oilers to the Texans of the World Football League last week for a reported $1-million contract.

The Stanley Cup champion Philadelphia Flyers have been sued for a million dollars by a former goalie, Michel Belhumeur, who charged they failed to pay him $23,500 in playoff dividends. Belhumeur, who played last season with the Richmond Robins, the Flyers' top .farm club,

South Vietnam has presented a note to the Cambodian Government protesting oil exploration in contested waters, Government sources said today.
Murray B. Peppard, a professor of German at Amherst College, who had been chief of the department of German, was found dead Tuesday of a gunshot wound at his home in Pelham, Mass.

Michele Sindona, the Italian financier who holds a 22 per cent interest in the troubled Franklin National Bank, has sold the Banca General di Credito, the Corriere della Sera of Milan reported today. Michele Sindona

Europeans are watching the antiinflation maneuvers of the Ford Administration with more than usual interest because of their worry that new policies in Washington may lead the world into a prolonged slump.

The Fire Department has been ordered to return personnel transferred after. last November's firemen's strike to their original companies. The directive to the Fire Department was made public yesterday by Eric Schmertz,
According to Western intelligence reports, North Vietnam is getting increased economic aid from China, the Soviet Union and Eastern European countries, but with new strings attached.

An insurgent Queens Democratic candidate for the Assembly was identified yesterday as the state committeeman to whom a payoff was allegedly made by the campaign manager for Assemblyman Antonio G. Olivieri. Antonio G. Olivieri denying any "vote-buying" in his campaign.

In his first and only endorsements in the primary races, Mayor Beame yesterday announced his support for Judge Harold A. Stevens and Justice Lawrence H. Cooke, who are seeking the two Democratic nominations to serve on the state Court of Appeals.

The finance ministers and central hank governors of the United States and four other leading industrial countries will meet at an undisclosed place in Europe, reportedly in France during the coming weekend.

Former President Richard M. Nixon faces a very threatening legal future but is in good spirits and will start making speeches and writing books after the November elections, according to his daughter, Julie and her husband, David Eisen hower.

President Ford named George Bush, the Republican National Chairman, to be the United States envoy to China as he announced his first major changes in key diplomatic, political and economic posts. Kenneth Rush, economic counselor to former President Nixon, who has continued in his post under Mr. Ford, was nominated to be Ambassador to France.
United States Representative Ella T. Grasso declared today that she would not approve a state income tax in Connecticut if she was elected Governor in November.

Albert E. Bollengier, vice president and controller of W. R. Grace Co., Inc., died Tuesday evening, apparently of a heart attack, at his home in Larchmont, N. Y. He was 61 years old.
Wallace A. Ross, executive director of the International Advertising Association here, died Monady at Norwalk Hospital in Connecticut. He was 52 years old and lived in Westport, Conn.

The New York Giants' gamble on Rich Glover ended yesterday, when the former Nebraska All-America was cut, along with another college superstar,. Tom' Gatewood, and a World Football League signee, John Douglas.

EL BATAN, Mexico - Plant breeders have long dreamed of combining the most desirable characteristics from a variety of agricultural crops into a single "super plant' that could resist insects, survive droughts and still produce large yields of highly nutritious food.

A military court sentenced a lawyer to 10 years in prison today for having violated presidential decrees that forbade dissidence while he was defending clients on charges of violating the same decrees.

Although 33 members of the Democratic-dominated City Council-all but the ten Councilmen-at-Large-are up for re-election this year as a result of a court-ordered reapportionment, relatively few face serious primary challenges. Among these are two incumbent Democrats who merit special consideration because of their integrity and because they have demonstrated an independence too rarely seen in this leadership-run body.

The Nationay Academy of Sciences, after a year's study, has concluded that the accumulated evidence, although incomplete, supports the air quality standards that were set by the Environmental Protection Agency for pollutants emitted by automobiles.

Preston Gomez did it again. For the second time in five seasons, Gomez, the manager of the Houston Astros, removed a pitcher working on a no-hitter but trailing by a run when he replaced Don Wilson with a pinch-hitter in the eighth inring against the Cincinnati Reds tonight.

A 51-year-old woman was found strangled yesterday in her apartment in Forest Hills, Queens, after a nephew and her employer reported her missing, according to the police.

While there are many new regulations affecting the labeling of foods, there is still no foolproof path to knowledgeable buying of canned fruits and vegetables. Although the labels for almost all of these foods list the net weight, this is very little help in knowing how much product is actually in the can.
About the only eager investors in Wall Street yesterday were in the Treasury securities market, where prices were marked up across the board.

Andrew F. Brimmer, who resigned after eight and a half years as a member of the board of governors of the Federal Reserve System, will be nominated as a director of E.I. du Pont de Nemours Co., Inc. Irving S. Shapiro, chairman of the board, announced yesterday.
Portugal's Foreign Minister and leaders of the Mozambique rebels will meet here tomorrow to arrange independence for the territory in southeast Africa.
It may take two to three years before the position of the United States assets of the closed Bankhaus I.D. Herstatt have been clarified, the provisional receiver, Walter Reiss, said today.

The first day of school ended early for the teen-agers of East Meadow today-about 'half an hour after it began. When the students realized that the first teacher strike in district history had made a normal schedule impossible, they swarmed past their picketing teachers, wishing it were a better day for the beach.

Marie Ames Byrd, widow of Rear Adn. Richard E. Byrd, the polar explorer and aviator, died yesterday at Massachusetts General Hospital. She was 85 years old. Marie Ames Byrd and her husband, Rear Adm. Richard E. Byrd, in 1956, the year before the admiral died.

A young man who menaced an Eastern Airlines pilot with a razor, a rusty nail and an ax surrendered meekly today after a tense four-hour hijacking atlempt on a runway at Logan In. international Airport here.

Chuck Wepner retrained his "American heavyweight title" with' an 11th-' round technical knockout of Terry Hinke of Hayward, Calif, last night in the Salt Palace. Wepner knocked Hinke down three times in the 11th round of the 12-round bout before the referee called the fight.

The second Torneo Internacional de Ajedrez in Lanzarote, Grand Canary Islands, resulted In another triumph for Miguel Quinteros. The Argentine grandmaster took first prize with six victories and four draws despite a smashing fifthround defeat by Silvino Garcia, a Cuban international master.

It was Fan Appreciation Night at Yonkers Raceway tonight but the degree of appreciation shown by some of the 20,584 spectators who went through the turnstiles free without even a furtive look behind was questionable.

Charles O. Miller, the Federal Governments senior aircraft accident investigator, resigned yesterday and said that steps by the White House to tighten control over his agency, the National Transportation Safety Board, had disrupted efforts to improve safety in air transportation.

Dr. John Thomas Baldwin Jr. of William and Mary College, Williamsburg, Va., a botanist who was instrumental in the discovery of natural sources of cortisone, died Tuesday at his home in Williamsburg. 'He was 63 years old.

The Odd Couple of publishing will start its first joint advertising venture in midmonth. The New Republic and the National Review for the last five years have been offering a discount to advertisers who advertise at both extremes of the political-publishing spectrum. Now they will be promoting that fact.
The most controversial of the city's superagencies, the ofteninvestigated Human Resources Administration, would be split in two under a proposal made public yesterday by Mayor Beame.

Apparently it's all he needs. But for a manager of the New York Yankees, it's the barest of props. Ralph Houk needed chewing tobacco, Casey Stengel needed an audience.

Brother Albian Anthony Moon, professor of classics and world literature at Manhattan College since 1949, died yesterday at St. Clare's Hospital He was 66 years old.

Donizetti's "Anna Bolena, like the other "Tudor Queen" operas being presented this season by the New York City Opera, is one of those Janusfaced works that look both. back at the undiluted bll canto tradition of Bellini and ahead to the heavier vocal and dramatic style of Verdi.

John P. Spaulding, president of Scholastic Magazines, Inc., died yesterday of cancer in a hospital in Wolfeboro, N.H., near his summer home in Center Harbor, N.H. He was 51 years old and lived at 29 Bayberry Road, Armonk, N.Y. John P. Spaulding

Bill Moyers and Harry Reasner won 1974 Emmy Awards last night as outstanding television news broadcasters. The National Academy of Television Arts and Sciences Awards were announced in a televised ceremony, held in the grand ballroom of the New York Hilton Hotel.
After a bitter three-year battle, a City Council committee yesterday made final a financial-disclosure bill for elected city officials and high-salaried city employes.

One of two furloughed women inmates who had failed to return to the Clinton Farms Reformatory in Hunterdon County was found hiding late yesterday in a closet in the home here of a female corrections officer at the reformatory.

President Ford named Mary Louise Smith today as his choice for chairman of the Republican National Committee. If she is approved by the committee -- and that is regarded as just a formality -- Mrs. Smith, a 59-year-old Iowan, will become the first woman to head the Republican party.

Radio emissions from objects billions of light years away are being used in an effort to record-in fractions of an inchthe kind of warping of the California landscape that is believed to precede major earthquakes.

Twenty-one economists, representing almost the entire spectrum of economic opinion, will meet here tomorrow in the first of a series of White House conferences on inflation, and there were indications that they might approach unanimity on at least some issues. George Bush, chosen to head U.S. mission to China, with Mary Louise Smith, whom President Ford recommended as Mr. Bush's successor as G.O.P. head, in Washington.

Furney Jeffreys, an octogenarian who pioneered synchronized swimming in New Jersey back in the 1930's has refused to become landlocked during his retirement at this seashore community. For over 30 years, Jeffreys has informally entertained patrons of Jenkinson's Pavilion Pool by performing a variety of stunts utilized by synchronized swimmers.
Jerry Brown has moved his imported fabrics uptown from Hester Street to a site more convenient for his clientele, many of whom patronize such places as Henri Bendel and Bergdorf Goodman.

Bob Blumenstock, left, of International Measurements Committee, and Olin Stephens, designer of the Courageous, contemplating deck layout after Australians, who stole aboard at night, discovered what they feel may be illegal positioning of winch-drums.
Commodities futures prices fell their limits early in trading on the Chicago Board of Trade but rallied to close mixed yesterday.

The Federal Reserve sold the equivalent of nearly $100million of West German marks, Belgian francs and Dutch guilders during June and July to prop up the value of the dollar, the Federal.. Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday in its semiannual summary of its activity in the foreign-exchange market.

Chuck Wepner retained his "American heavyweight title" with an 11thround technical knockout of Terry Hinke of Hayward, Calif., last night in the Salt Palace. Wepner - knocked Hinke down three times in the' 11th round of the 12-round bout before the referee called the fight.
The Democratic primary campaigns of Hugh L. Carey and Howard J. Samuels were reported yesterday to be running at substantial deficitsunusual for rival candidates in a primary campaign.

The discovery of a mass grave in a Turkish village near Famagusta, containing more than eighty bodies of civilians, including children, who were obviously executed in cold blood, is only one more reminder of the Cyprus tragedy's grim dimensions. Given the long antagonism between Greek and Turk, on Cyprus and elsewhere, excesses were inevitable and atrocities were probable on both sides, once large-scale shooting erupted on the unhappy island.

Norway and the Soviet Union are to begin talks in October on dividing up the offshore waters north of Norway for oil exploration. The Arctic waters north of the 70th Parallel are an extension of the southern Norwegian continental shelf where large quantities of oil have been found.
India's lower house of Parliament overwhelmingly approved today Prime Minister Indira Gandhi's decision to place Sikkim, the small Himalayan protectorate, under Indian sovereignty.

The British Caribbean team has taken a stranglehold on the international tuna cup match being held this week in watrs off Cape St. Mary. A monster bluefin gave in to Bill Lawrence after a 50-minute battle early in the day.

Two of the three candidates for the Democratic nomination for Lieutenant Governor answered a broad range of questions last night from members of the National Organization for Women and guests at a candidates' night at Jimmy's restaurant in Manhattan.
Nevada voters sifted through the results today of their primary elections and seemed stunned by what they had done.

In slightly stepped-up trading, prices dropped sharply across a broad front yesterday on the American Stock Exchange as traders found little in the news that could be construed as bullish. Similar conditions prevailed in the over-the-counter market.

The Boston Red Sox (or is it Dead Sox?)) lost to the Baltimore Orioles last night, 6-0, and also lost their undisputed hold on first place in the American League's Eastern Division. Tim Blackwell of the Red Sox falling away from the plate, and losing the ball as Bobby Grich of the Orioles scored from third on a grounder to short by Earl Williams.

After the kind of series John Milner had here, it's hard to believe he doesn't like Wrigley Field, where the Mets defeated the Chicago Cubs today, 4-2, to sweep their three-game series and increase their winning streak to seven games.
Interested in buying a rural college campus? Now could be the time to invest, because the TompkinsCortland Community College campus in the village of Groton is up for sale.

The United States heavyweight eight scored the most stunning upset in the preliminary heats as the world rowing championships opened today on Lake Rotsee.
A Walker County grand' jury today indicted seven persons on capital murder charges in the attempted escape of three inmates from the Huntsville State Penitentiary and the death of a woman hostage.

South Korea's Cho-OYuen broke Japan's swimming monopoly and North Korean marksmen and weight lifters won six gold medals today in the Asian Games.

The Standard Oil Company of California said yesterday that it was cutting all of its gasoline prices by one-half cent a gallon. A day earlier the Gulf Oil Corporation raised its prices by seven-tenths of a cent.

Three Hamilton County commissioners have been jailed briefly by a judge who was angry because his wife had not been paid two weeks' salary as a court reporter. Judge Edward F. New Jr. of Hamilton Circuit Court yesterday ordered Sheriff Larry Cook to. arrest the three. for contempt of court and to hold them without bond until Eve New was paid $301.06.

EAST HAMPTON, L.I. -- Random thoughts for the end of summer: Who steals my store-bought tomatoes steals trash; who steals my hand-processed tomatoes steals gold. Although there has been some recent rain, rarely can we remember a time of such prolonged drought as we've endured the last few months.
Nassau County police issued an alarm today for 37-year-old John Burks, a Freeport bartender, who was named as a suspect in the shotgun slaying last night of his father and his estranged wife.

An off-duty patrolman shot and killed a suspected holdup man in an exchange of fire last night. According to the police, the shooting took place as four armed men were making their escape from the Swiftway Super Market at 617 Lenox Avennue near West 140th Street.
Joseph Diaco, one of two men charged with attempting to bribe the Mayor of Fort Lee last May, today asked Federal Judge Frederick B. Lacey to disqualify himself from presiding over his trial.
President and Mrs. Ford received a standing ovation tonight as they stood spotlighted in the Presidential box while attending a musical at the Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts.

Both Reno Sweeney, the West 13th Street supper club, and Anita O'Day, the singer, are trying something new this week. Reno Sweeney is dipping a tentative toe into jazz programing for the first time with a bill comprising Miss O'Day and Hugh Brodie, a saxophonist and singer, while Miss O'Day is moving out of her customary jazz-club setting.
A Federal appeals court has been asked to rule on whether a $1.1-million telephone bill owed by the Democratic National Committee should be subject to court action.

Henry Saltman, principal for the last five years of Theodore Roosevelt High School, 500 East Fordham Road, the Bronx, died yesterday at Mount Vernon (N.Y.) Hospital. He suffered a heart attack last Friday. Mr. Saltman was 65 years

Europeans are watching the antiinflation maneuvers of the Ford Administration with more than usual interest because of their worry that new policies in Washington may lead the world into a prolonged slump.

The Board of Education yesterday appointed three members to the school system's controversy-beset Board of Examiners, including the first two blacks to become regular members since that body was established in 1898. Julius F. Rubin, left, Ethel Fitzgerald and Clarence C. Holmes were named to the Board of Examiners.

Mayor Ronnie Thompson of Macon was finally declared the winner late today in the contest to choose a Republican to run for the Georgia governorship this fall against the moderate Democrat who defeated Lieut. Gov. Lester G. Maddox yesterday.

Floyd Layne, a star who rose and fell at City College, is returning 23 years later as the Beavers' basketball coach. Layne, a wiry backcourt man and floor general of the City team that won the 194950 National Invitation Tournament and National Collegiate Athletic Association championship, was later involved in the widespread college basketball "fix" scandal.

In another move toward the new style that has characterized Presisent Valery Giscard d'Estaing's first three months in office, the Cabinet decided today to hold its next meeting in the city of Lyons, 300 miles south of Paris.

The 24th Pugwash Conference on Science and World Affairs issued a call today for a world meeting of' nuclear and militarily powerful nations on disarmament. Some of the 120 participants said it was the first unanimous worldwide appeal in the history of the conferences.

Secretary of the Interior Rogers C. B. Morton has denied the use of Federal land to Evel Knievel, who was hoping to use a patch of it as a landing strip when he attempts to vault the Snake River Canyon on Sunday in a rocket-propelled motorcycle.

President Juan Maria Bordaberry indicated today that the ban on political activity would not be lifted in the foreseeable future. Mr. Bordaberry has ruled with military backing since he dissolved Parliament last year.
The National Football League player strike was blamed by the Philadelphia Eagles today for a projected $200,000 loss in six preseason games this year.

Seven major oil companiesTexaco, Shell, Exxon, Gulf, Sunoco, Amoco and Mobilpleaded not guilty yesterday as indictments were formally presented charging them with criminal violations of the state's antitrust laws.

The retirement, effective Oct. 1, of State Budget Director Walter Wechsler after 35 years of state-government service was announced by Governor Byrne. He said Mr. Wechsler's knowledge and experience would be missed. The Governor did not name a successor to the $42,500-ayear job, but there has been speculation about Deputy State Treasurer Clifford Goldman. As budget director,

A player who opens the bidding in a minor suit and hears his partner respond in a major often has a choice between rebidding his suit and supporting partner with a three-card holding. Most players - perhaps because they, prefer to be declarerare too eager to rebid their own suit and too cautious about raising.
The commodity spot market price index of foodstuffs and industrial materials fell to 230.6 from 236.3 last week.

State auditors going over a sampling of nursing-home accounts have reported $4,623,288 in unwarranted claims to Medicaid. These ran the gamut from the debatable to the apparently fraudulent, and from the petty to the exorbitant.

The principle of sanctity of states, large and small--a principle imbedded in the United Nations Charter and long championed by India among others-has been rudely violated by New Delhi's decision virtually to annex her tiny Himalayan protectorate, Sikkim.

Democratic legislative leaders disclosed here today that the Byrne administration's proposal for a $300-million bond issue for highway construction and railroads in New Jersey faced the prospect of defeat when the Legislature was to reconvene here Monday.
Government troops have driven several hundred Moslem rebels out of a town on the. southern island of Mindanao, ending eight days of fighting in the area, the Defense Department announced today.

Government reports showed yesterday that businessmen were holding to plans for a substantial increase in capital spending this year and that the rate of growth in consumer credit expanded in July. Paper, iron and steel and mining are among the industries spending more for new plants and equipment

of the original Sons of the Pioneers singing group, who played in many films with Roy Rogers and Gene Autry, died yesterday at the age of 57, apparently of a heart attack.

Wilt Chamberlain has been negotiating with the. New York Knicks, through intermediaries, and although no agreement has been concluded, it is still possible that the 38-year-old giant center may resume his playing career with them this season.

German and American officials in Bonn said that the United States had sought the reaction of its 14 NATO allies to the possible appointment of Gen. Alexander M. Haig Jr. as supreme commander of the alliance. Bonn, according to a West German Government source, has no objection.
Secretary General Waldheim of the United Nations warned yesterday that profound economic and social problems were threatening the world with a "crisis of extraordinary dimensions."

Employes of all 17 foreign airlines operating to and from Lisbon began a strike early today aimed at cutting almost all the country's air links with the outside world.

Compensation of corporate chief executives took the biggest jump in five years in 1973, as profits grew by the biggest percentages in 20 years, McKinsey Co., management consultants, reported yesterday.
The state of Florida filed charges today against one of its biggest condominium developers in an effort to break controversial recreation leases that cost consumers millions of dollars a year.

Senator Thomas F. Eagleton said today that President Ford was being deliberately kept "uninformed" by his foreign affairs advisers of a legal obligation to cut off military aid to Turkey.

Congress declared today that it wants Smokey Bear sent home when he dies. Smokey, the symbol of a campaign against forest fires, is spending his dotage at Washington's zoo. A younger bear lives nearby, ready to take over the symbolic duties.

Dr. John L. S. Holloman Jr., president of the city's Health and Hospitals Corporation, said yesterday that Mayor Beame was not "responsible for the delays in the audit negotiations" between the corporation and the city's voluntary hospitals.
Renee G. Weiler, wife of Theodore R. Weiler, president of the Boar's Head Provision Company, meat processors with headquarters in Brooklyn, died Wednesday.

Sales of new cars, down by 20 per cen or more all year, regained some of the lost ground in August although domestic dealers still reported deliveries were off 2.6 per cent for the month.

While Robert M. Morgenthau and Richard H. Kuh have been accusing each other of a poor record on civil liberties, some civil libertarians here are saying that on such issues a choice between the two contenders for Manhattan District Attorney is a choice between "the lesser of two evils."

The Tories are blaming the Socialists and the Socialists are blaming the Tories, and both are blaming the crisis on world prices of oil and other essentials beyond their control.

Alan Greenspan, the new chairman of the President's Council of Economic Advisers, said today that he foresaw a "flattened" economy in the months ahead, with some increase in unemployment, but saw no reason for extreme pessimism about the economic outlook. The British Army last night handed back control of street lighting in the border village of Newry to local electricity officials, at the demand of the Irish Republican Army, the Secretary of State for Northern Ireland announced.

An outpatient of the Bronx Psychiatric Center, formerly the Bronx State Hospital, was being held yesterday for sodomy and the attempted murder of a 13-year-old Bronx boy who was stabbed repeatedly with a screwdriver.

The Federal Energy Administration proposed today technical changes in its petroleum pricecontrol rules .that it said "look toward eventual decontrol of petroleum prices."

Shoppers outside Marks Spencer on Oxford Street in London. British consumers have become more reluctant to spend and are worried by an upswing in unemployment.

Officials of the Law.Enforcement Assistance Administration met with Mayor Beame yesterday to explore the possibility of their providing Federal funds to develop programs aimed at preventing rape and improving the treatment of rape victims here.

The ocean liner has become a rare bird in New York harbor. No longer do battleships anchor In line in mid-Hudson. The procession of ships seems shorter, as seen from the cross-bay ferry.

Charles W. Yukl, who is accused of murdering an aspiring actress in Greenwich Village last month, yesterday was found competent to stand trial. Mr. Yukl was examined by two psychiatrists who found that he was capable of understanding the proceedings against him and was able to assist in his own defense.

The West German offer of a $2-billion loan to Italy was not unique and was meant to demonstrate that Bonn approved of and supported the Italian Government's new economic policy, Chancellor Helmut Schmidt said in a television interview.

The price of rice has doubled in the last year, despite record high domestic production last season, because severe shortages in importing countries have made the export market more lucrative, according to market experts.

Jim Ferriell, bathed in obscurity most of his professional career, and Lyn Lott, a tour rookie, carded threeunder-par 67's today for a one-stroke lead after the first round of the rainy $100,000 Southern open golf tournament.
The two units of young soldiers--one Greek Cypriote, the other Turkish Cyprioteface each other in official hostility across the cease-fire line that divides this capital.

Sears, Roebuck Co., the nation's largest merchandising organization, reported yesterday that sales for the five weeks ended Aug. 31 totaled $1.4-billion, up 6.8 per cent from the year-earlier level. For the 31 weeks ended Aug. 31, Sears sales rose 7.3 per cent to $7.5-billion.
A group of Agriculture Department experts was called home from the Soviet Union last week because the Russians refused to approve a requested visit to survey major grain areas.

To the Editor: The rehabilitation of mandatory wage-price controls is urgent, for we cannot stop inflation without them. Wage-price controls served us well In World War II. Some of the same conditions existed then as in recent years. We experienced a considerable excess of demand over supply, serious shortages and the makings of a wageprice spiral. Joe Gilliam, making a. bid to unseat Terry Bradshaw as Pittsburgh's No. 1 quarterback, threw two touchdown passes tonight to spur the Steelers to a 41-15 National Football League victory over the Dallas Cowboys.

The United States has sounded out its 14 NATO allies in Brussels on the naming of Gen. Alexander M. Haig Jr. as supreme commander of the alliance and of United States forces in Europe, according to German and American officials here.
A United States trade official assured his Soviet counterparts today that President Ford was pressing for swift enactment of legislation to grant an improvement of trade terms to the Soviet Union.
The president of the Fiat Motor Company said today that the participation of Communists in the Italian government would lead to a "rapid withdrawal of our country from the Western world."

Operators of four Manhattan hotels allegedly used by prostitutes and their customers were arrested yesterday and charged with a variety of criminal charges including promoting prostitution and maintaining a nuisance.

Prices on the American Stock Exchange and the over-thecounter market rose yesterday as investors displayed optimism because of a number of announcements believed to be bullish. These included a lowering by the Federal Reserve Board of the amount of money that banks are required to hold in reserve against some large certificates of deposit and a report of higher expenditures-for plant and equipment by industry in the second quarter.

The New York Giants have another unfinished home. Before leaving late this afternoon for tomorrow night's final exhibition game at Buffalo (Channel 11, 8 P.M.), players and coaches assembled for their first glimpse of what will be the club's new training headquarters for the regular season, at Pace University.

A proposal that United States citizens be permitted to fight for Israel without risking loss of citizenship was made yesterday by Abraham Hirschfeld as he campaigned in Yiddish and English on the sidewalks of the diamond district.

German and American officials in Bonn said that the United States had sought the reaction of its 14 NATO allies to the possible appointment of Gen. Alexander M. Haig Jr. as supreme commander of the alliance. Bonn, according to a West German Government source, has no objection. The Dutch, however, are reported trying to organize opposition to the appointment. [1:5.]
A Federal judge has ordered the police here to remove the arrest records of thousands of persons detained during a 1971 antiwar demonstration and also to refund any bail money.

In his first batch of major diplomatic assignments, President Ford has made respectable but hardly inspired choices. He has 'shown a tendency to go outside the career Foreign Service for new ambassadors,' a tendency that will be more pronounced if he proceeds with his expected nomination of Senator J. William Fulbright as Ambassador to Britain and Peter M. Flanigan, former White House adviser on international economic affairs, as Ambassador to Spain.
Subaru of Amer;ca Inc., announced a $400 price cut on its two-door, $2,997 sedan yesterday, saying the move was "being made in the best interest of our company."

New York department stores chalked up sizable dollar gains in August, a survey of The New York Times showed yesterday. Stores in the city proper increased their sates by 13.5 per cent from August, 1973, while stores in the metropolitan area as a whole went ahead by 8.4 per cent.
George Hodges Owen, a retired Foreign Service officer, died Tuesday at his home in Washington. He was 62 years old.

qualified in the repechages today in four of five events for the semifinals of the world rowing championship. With those that qualified yesterday included theeightoared boat, the United States oarsmen have spots in 10 of Saturday's 11 semifinal races.
The Franklin National Bank lost $35-million in deposits in the week ended Wednesday, figures released by the New York Clearing House Association disclosed yesterday.

A Red Cross center that provides transit facilities for Soviet Jews emigrating to Israel has been moved from a rural location to a building in Viennato the immediate outcry of residents who say it is a sePurity risk to the neighborhood.

Gerald Ford has been in office only a month and already the nation is demonstrating once again its tendency to hand over its problems to the President, demand his "leadership" and expect him to provide a solution. To some extent this tendency is natural and unavoidable; but the recent past suggests that it has its dangers.

The director of the Arms Control and Disarmament Agency said today that a nuclear war could destroy the ozone layer in the stratosphere, which protects all living things from the sun's ultraviolet radiation.

Samora Machel, head of the Mozambique Liberation Front, sat down here today with Foreign Minister Mario Soares of Portugal to put the finishing touches to an independence settlement that would end 10 years of guerrilla warfare in Mozambique. Samora Machel, president of the Mozambique Liberation Front, speaking earlier this week about talks in Lusaka, Zambia, where he met yesterday with Foreign Minister Mario Soares of Portugal. Rear Adm. Gordon Rowe, a pioneer in naval aviation, died Tuesday at the age of 78. Admiral Rowe graduated from the United States Naval Academy in 1918 and was a pilot on the aircraft carrier Langley, America's first carrier.

Harry Partch, a free spirit among American composers who invented his own musical scales and his own outlandish instruments, was found dead Tuesday in his apartment in San Diego, Calif. He was 73 Harry Partch
Virginia Knauer, President Ford's consumer affairs adviser, announced today that her office would produce a series of public service radio shows designed to help Americans deal with inflation.

After a six-month recess, the United. States and the Soviet Union will renew their talks on limitations of strategic nuclear weapons in two weeks, officials said today. The date will be announced by the White House tomorrow.

State auditors going over a sampling of nursing-home accounts have reported $4,623,288 in unwarranted claims to Medicaid. These ran the gamut from the debatable to the apparently fraudulent, and from the petty to the exorbitant.

A group of lay Catholics vesterday accused the Jesuit leadership here of attempting to oust without a hearing a local priest who baptized the baby of a Massachusetts mother who supported the right of women to decide on abortion.

Rican man died today at Martland Hospital of a "massive skull fracture" suffered Monday at. about the time clubwielding policemen were clearing Puerto Rican demonstrators from in front of City Hall and chasing them down Broad Street.

Arthur F. Burns, left, Federal Reserve Board chairman, and William Fenner, center, and Gary Seevers, members of the President's Council of EconomicAdvisers.

Business loan demand, bolstered again by heavy borrowing by gas and electric utilities, increased sharply at major New York banks in the week ended Wednesday, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday.
Wallace Edward.Rowling was chosen today as the next Prime Minister of New Zealand to succeed Norman E. Kirk, who died last Saturday.
Elizabeth Courtney, a dressmaker to film stars for more than 40 years, died yesterday of cancer, She was 69 years old.

A prominent Jewish academician yesterday challenged the concept that Israel was central in the cultural life of Jews. Dr. Jacob Neusner, professor of religious studies at Brown University, contended that Israel, as the center of Jewish scholarship, "is curiously unproductive" as he drew a contrast between the "actual achievements" of American and modern Israeli scholars.

Favorable economic developments helped the stock market yesterday register its biggest advance in almost a month in much lighter trading.

Daniel Mingues Jr., 17 years old, was sentenced yesterday by Supreme Court Justice Joseph A. Martinis to an indeterminate sentence in the September, 1972, mugging murder of Prof. Wolfgang Friedmann of Columbia University, an international-law specialist.

Leonard Bernstein and the New York Philharmonic captivated an audience here last night. MONTGOMERY, Ala.-Although it is largely intuitive so far, it strikes me that Gerald R. Ford's major political achievement during his first dazzling days in office has been to quietly remove Gov. George Wallace permanently from the scene as a major force in American Presidential politics.

Prime Minister Harold Wilson opened his campaign for the general election expected next month with a plea for British unity in place of the divisions that have been so conspicuous here over the last year. Speaking this afternoon to the annual conference of the Prime Minister Harold Wilson addressing union leaders in Brighton yesterday. He called for national unity.
Farm commodity futures moved with little clear purpose yesterday on the Chicago Board of Trade, but closed generally higher.

Economists meeting yesterday, clockwise from top left: Walter E. Hoadley, Bank of America; David L. Grove, I.B.M.; Beryl Sprinkel of Chicago; Otto Eckstein, Harvard.

Pan American World Airways and Trans World Airlines, both financially hard pressed, said yesterday that they were ready to discuss a merger. William M. Crilly, executive vice president at Pan Am, is leaving his post.

On his weekly stroll last light, Mayor Beame toured a sidewalk minifair, was toasted ?y a rock band and was conronted, mildly, by a woman earful of street crime and the future of her neighborhood.

A Paterson, N. J., bakery that was the lowest bidder for a contract to supply bread and rolls to New York City public schools sued yesterday in State Supreme Court in Manhattan to compel the Board of Education to accept its offer.

A State Department of Education hearing examiner withheld judgment today on a challenge to the policy of the South River Board of Education to require written physical-education tests for high school girls but not boys.
Serious crimes rose 6 per cent in the United States last year, with the biggest increases in suburbs and rural areas, the Federal Bureau of Investigation reported today.
Foreign Minister George Mavros began a tour of Western Europe today, hoping to attract political and economic support for the civilian Government that took power in Greece six weeks ago.

President Ford intends to appoint Peter M. Flanigan, a prominent figure in the Nixon Administration, as Ambassador to Spain, and he has offered Senator J.W. Fulbright the Ambassadorship in London, an authoritative Administration offacial said today.
Cancellation of an $873-million natural-gas supply contract between the Pacific Interstate Transmission Company of Los Angeles and the Pan-Alberta Gas, Ltd., of Canada was announced yesterday.
John D. Ehrlichman's request that the Watergate cover-up trial be postponed until sometime next year was denied today by Associate Justice William 0. Douglas of the Supreme Court.

Senator Hubert H. Humphrey said in Peking last night that a high Chinese official had informed a visiting United States Congressional delegation that the condition of Chou En-lai, China's 76-year-old Premier, had worsened since midsummer.

Loneliness and psychological desolation in a variety of styles gave a somewhat somber tone to the New York Dance Festival at the Delacorte Theater on Wednesday evening. But if the outlook was bleak, the performing of it wasn't.

A calm year appears in store for American higher education, but the joy of administrators at the prospect of continued tranquility is tempered by apprehension over an economic climate that is having a growing influence on academic decision-making.
Residents along the coast of the Gulf of Mexico from Louisiana to Florida kept vigil today to learn where Hurricane Carmen would come ashore.

Billy Kilmer hit Charley Taylor on a 15-yard touchdown pass tonight to give the Washington Redskins a 7-6 victory over the Baltimore Colts in a raindrenched windup of their exhibition season.

William M. Crilly, whose resignation as a director and an executive vice president of Pan American World Airways was announced Thursday, said yesterday that the reason he decided to leave the company was that a diversification program he headed could no longer be pursued because of Pan Am's severe financial problems.

Mrs. Ellen Tuck French Guest, long prominent in Newport and New York society, died yesterday at her Newport home at 11 Berkley Avenue. She was 58 years old.
Some Federal clean-air standards may be too tough, but the effect of relaxing them is not fully known, the National Academy of Sciences said today.

The Standard Poor's Corporation said yesterday it had lowered its rating on Kaufman Broad, Inc., commercial paper to A-3 from A-2. The action, according to Standard Poor, reflected deterioration in the company's earnings coverage and asset protection.

Kuwait, one of the richest Middle East oil countries, offered today to pay the equivalent of $246-million for a British commercial real estate company in potentially the largest Arab investment disclosed so far in the Western world.

The Chrysler Corporation said today that its cost had gone up an average of $71 a vehicle a month this year and warned that it would need "several" price increases on its 1975 models, indicating the first could be as much as $500.
The Standard Oil Company (Ohio) announced that effective today it would reduce by 2 cnets a gallon the price of gasoline at its company-operated stations and on gasoline sold to dealers.
The French Foreign Minister, Jean Sauvagnargues, will pay an official visit to Israel Oct. 31 and Nov. 1, it was announced here today.

To end chaotic conditions and long lines of weary recipients at the many city welfare centers, Mayor Beame yesterday ordered that 800 caseworkers be hired, that work days be extended and that centers be opened for half a day on Saturdays.

The contempt convictions of three "Chicago 7" defendants and their chief lawyer, William M. Kunstler, were upheld today by the United States Court of Appeals for the Seventh Circuit. The court agreed that Mr. Kunstler had made "a vicious personal attack on the judge."

With Billie Jean King already home a winner and wilting to see who her opponent would be in the final of the women's singles, the rains interceded yesterday in the United States Open tennis championships.

What a difference a year makes. The Boonton Bears of the semipro New York Football League are perfect examples of that old bromide. At this time a year ago Coach Alex Longo's Bears were the defending champions of the league's Gotham Conference. They had also captured conference titles in three of the preceding four campaigns. So the optimism they held going into the 1973 season didn't appear out of line.
William H. Merrill, head of the "plumbers" unit for the Watergate prosecutor, Leon Jaworski, resigned today to return to private law practice in Detroit.

Vice President-designate Nelson A. Rockefeller spent a busy day today, meeting twice with the Secretary of State, once with President Ford, and once with the chairman of the Atomic Energy Commission.

Portugal and the guerrilla movement of Mozambique will sign an independence agreement today. It will end Portugal's 400year-old sovereignty over the East African territory and will mark the end of a 10-year guerrilla war against the Portuguese. [1:8.]
Three armed robbers switching getaway cars after a $31,000 bank robbery in Jackson Heights, Queens, yesterday commandeered a station wagon with a two-foot high electioneering sign yesterday.
The Ford Administration's two top economic officials expressed opposition today to the suggestions of some economists that the nation's money supply should be expanded.
The New York Giants, who have been trying to discover their proud past, found themselves .buried by history tonight in a 23-17 sudden-death defeat to the Buffalo Bills.

Israel won its first gold medal of the seventh Asian Games today, making another slight crack in Japan's swimming monopoly, but Japanese swimmers, gymnasts and shooters still accounted for a healthy share of gold medals.

There was a widespread feeling here today that yesterday's "pre summit" meeting of economists with President Ford had been useful and a success, even though it would not solve the naNews tion's economic ?? problems.

The sum of $20,000 in cash which Mrs. Helen D. Bentley, the Federal Maritime Commission chairman, carried to the Nixon campaign in 1972 originated with a Greek shipping owner, according to Senate Watergate committee files.

Three men have been charged in connection with the Federal Bureau of Investigation's recovery yesterday of 12,500 pair of panty hose, nylons and other undergarments bearing the J. C. Penney label. They were stolen from an interstate truck shipment, the bureau said. The F.B.I. identified the suspects as Howard Colburn Jr., 44 years old, a former National City councilman; Oscar' Gomez, 28, of San Diego, and Spencer Cosner, 31, of Jamul.

In a remarkable display of cheek, the Patrolmen's Benevolent Association has been testing the public's integrity on the ground that the Police Department has been testing that of the patrolmen. It is hard to say which is the more dismaying, the wrong-headedness of the comparison or the audacity of Ken McFeeley, the union's newly-elected president, in making himself an assessor of the public's ethics.
Mattel, Inc., the nation's largest toy producer, which has had large deficits in each of the last three years, onnounced yesterday that earnings for two years may have been misstated.
Representative Ogden R. Reid, who unsuccessfully sought the Democratic nomination for Governor, called yesterday for the nomination of Representative Hugh L. Carey in the primary on Tuesday.
An unusual study has found "glaring disparity" in sentencing by 50 Federal judges in New York, Connecticut and Vermont.
PARIS, Sept. 6--Greece will seek full membership in the European Common Market and closer political ties with Western Europe, Foreign Minister George Mavros said at a press conference here today.

Dr. Jeremy Musher, professor of chemistry at YeshivaUniversity's Belfer Graduate School of Science and a research authority on the structure and bonding of molecules, died yesterday at New York Hospital of cancer and complications from pneumonia; He was 38 years old and lived at 55 Central Park West.

James Guilford Swinnerton, originator of one of the country's earliest comic strips, who in later life turned to serious painting, died Thursday in a Palm Springs hospital in California of complications resulting from a broken leg. He was 98 years old.
The State Department of Higher Education announced today the formation of a committee to study the possible need for higher tuition at state colleges and related problems.

The Carnegie Corporation of New York, a foundation whose activities have mainly been in education, has made a gift of $250,000 to WNET/13 to help finance the public station's move to new quarters at what is now the Henry Hudson Hotel on West 57th Street.
A fit and eager United States squad prepared today for a move into the finals of the world rowing championships. Dick Dunham, a team official, said: "This is where we separate the men from the boys."

A Manhattan grand jury indicted,Charles W. Yuki yesterday. on charges that he murdered- Karin Schlegel, a 23year-old aspiring actress, by strangling her with a necktie in Greenwich Village. Her body was found on Aug. 21. Acting State Supreme Court Justice George Roberts.held Mr. Yuki, 39 years old, without bail, after arraignment on the murder indictment. Mr. Yuki pleaded not guilty to the charge.
Larry Nelson carded a three-under-par 67 today for a 135 total and a one-shot lead at the halfway mark of the $100,000 Southern open golf tournament.

The director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation. Clarence M. Kelley, branded tonight as "patently false, absolutely ridiculous" reports that the agency was "promiscuously involved in electronic wiretaps."

To the Editor: Democrats in several Congressional districts in New York State are electing delegates in the upcoming primary to a first charter convention to be held in December in Kansas City. This is an important convention, but unfortunately it is not receiving much attention. The convention will attempt to write the first constitution for a major party, which will set the rules for governing the party.

Denouncing a defense motion that contended he was prejudiced, Federal District Court Judge Frederick B. Lacey refused today to disqualify himself from presiding over the trial of two men charged with- attempting to bribe the Mayor of Fort Lee.

Bony Hampton Peace Jr., honorary chairman of The Greenville News-Piedmont Company, died yesterday following surgery. He was 68 years old. He and his brother; the late Roger C. Peace, developed their father's commercial printing company into The Greenville News-Piedmont Company.
Form held true at the Tuxedo Park Kennel Club's fixture at Lyndhurst today, when Ch. Sunnybrook Spot On, was named best of 1,321 dogs.
Bad luck and bad weather obliterated the Stars last night as they ended the first half of their first World Football League campaign.

To end chaotic conditions and long lines of weary recipients at the many city welfare centers, Mayor Beame yesterday ordered that 800 caseworkers be hired, that work days be extended and that centers be opened for half a day on Saturdays.

The Ethiopian military today accused Emperor Haile Selassie of having diverted money from a state brewery, newspapers here reported. It was the first time the 82year-old Emperor has been directly accused of wrongdoing since the military opened. a drive against official corruption seven months ago.

Democratic voters in Tuesday's primary again will have to consult a Rosetta (or should it be called a Frank Rossetti?) stone to figure out the judicial choices. In the State Supreme Court races, they will be "voting" for candidates whose names--literally--do not appear on the ballot. For the Civil Court, they are asked to vote in ghost "municipal districts" although Municipal Courts no longer exist in the city.

The International Paper Company, which is trying to acquire the General Crude Oil Company for $278-million, announced yesterday that it had reached an agreement for an other $145-million acquisition of timberland and lumber mills in Arkansas.

Portugal and the guerrilla movement of Mozambique will sign an independence agreement today. It will end Portugal's 400year-old sovereignty over the East African territory and will mark the end of a 10-year guerrilla war against the Portuguese. [1:8.] Kuwait and Saudi Arabia have joined other Arab countries seeking investments for the rapidly growing accumulation of funds arising from the recent quadrupling of oil prices.
The Paszamant family has decided to rebuild on the ashes of its winery here after a twin tragedy raised doubts that the 40-year-old enterprise would continue in business.

Futures prices of farm prodducts closed mixed yesterday on the Chicago Board of Trade. Suybeans and soymeal were lower; corn was higher, as were iced broilers, oats and soybean oil, while wheat prices were irregular.

Premier Bulent Ecevit indicated today that Turkey could begin Withdrawing her invasion forces from Cyprus if the United Nations arranged safe passage for Turkish Cypriotes from Greek Cypriote territory to the Turkish-occupied north.

As if to put a new shine on the tarnished adage that what goes up must come down again, Tiffany Co. disclosed yesterday that it is cutting all silver prices in its silver department by 10 per cent, effective Monday.

Lou Brock got two hits in four times at bat, knocked in a run, scored another and went two for three in thefts on the basepaths tonight to spark the St. Louis Cardinals to a 3-0 victory over New York that snapped the Mets' sevengame winning streak.
Israeli troops broke into several houses in a southern Lebanese town early today looking for Palestinian commandos, according to reports from residents of the area.

With less than a week before the opening of his election campaign, Governor Wilson yesterday released a net-worth statement, reporting that he and his wife have a total of $632,580.14 in assets, and no liabilities.

Social Democrats, U.S.A., descendants of the Socialist party, began their national convention here yesterday pledging to work with.. the trade union movement and the Democratic party to achieve socialist goals.

Random House plans to raise the retail price of James A. Michener's best-selling "Cennial" by $1.55-from $10.95 to $12.50-because of inflationary pressures that have struck the book trade, an executive of the publishing house said yesterday.

"Common sense revolts against the notion that we are already in the middle of anything that could meaningfully be called a recession," Francis H. Schott, vice president and economist of the Equitable Life Assurance Society, said yesterday.
Otto Kruger, who had performed on the stage and in radio, television and motion pictures since 1905, died today of a stroke on his 89th birthday.
Reginald H. Jones, chairman of the General Electric Company, called here today for tightened fiscal restraint combined with a loosening of monetary restraint in order to avoid a deep recession.

The Bowater Corporation, Ltd., the world's largest paper company, showed a consolidated net profit in the first half this year of $29.4-million, up 23.3 per cent from $24-million in the initial six months of last year.

The Association of American Railroads said today that freight traffic on United States railroads during the latest week totaled an estimated 16.8 billion ton miles, 2.3 per cent below the corresponding week a year ago. Carloadings in the same week totaled 538,213 cars,
Three Latin - American countries today formally proposed to the Organization of American States that the group consider lifting its decade-old political and economic sanctions against Cuba.
Premier Kim Jong Pil publicly expressed regret today over the ransacking of the Japanese Embassy by about 200 demonstrators and promised compensation for damages.

Kuwait, one of the richest Middle East oil countries, offered today to pay the equivalent of $246-million for a British commercial real estate company in potentially the largest Arab investment disclosed so far in the Western world.

Rosenthal described Western Union yesterday as a "reluctant messenger" when it came to consumer telegraph service and proposed that Congress consider shifting telegram service to the United States Postal Serivice unless Western Union and the Federal Communications Commission undertook extensive reforms.

President Ford announced today that the Soviet-American talks on limiting strategic nuclear arms would resume on Sept. 18. A White House spokesman added that the American negotiators will "have an agreed position" by the time they return to Geneva. But that position according to a number of Administration officials, is likely to be a statement of general principles, 'objectives and approaches rather than a concrete proposal.

Thomas V. Tozzi, a retired Bronx lawyer and civic leader, died yesterday at Montefiore Hospital in the Bronx following a stroke. He was 73 years old and lived at 2400 Sedgwick Avenue, the Bronx, and in Fort Lauderdale. Fla.
The United Brands Company announced yesterday it had resumed shipments of bananas from Panama after a six-week stoppage caused by the effort of the Panamanian Government to levy a box export tax.

Rain is forecast for the Metropolitan area and most of the Northeast today. Rain and thundershowers will continue from the lower Mississippi and Ohio Valleys to the Atlantic Coasts. Showers will be scattered from 'the upper Mississippi Valley into the western lake region, and showers will also be scattered throughout the southern Rockies. The Pacific Coast and other parts of the country will be clear to partly cloudy.
