Joseph SatKin, the owner of a large number of apartment buildings in Passaic, and two co-defendants go on trial today in Superior Court in Newark in the murder of a woman and three children in a Passaic fire last year.

Democratic politicians in the metropolitan area--especially those running for offices in tomorrow's primary-reacted yesterday to President Ford's decision to pardon former President Nixon with expressions of outrage and indignation.

Stanley S. Keyser, president of the Consolidated Cigar Corporation of New York from 1959 until his retirement in 1966, died Friday in Doctors Hospital. He was 74 years old and lived at 150 East 77th Street.

Nolan Ryan almost matched his unpublicized record of 100.9 miles an hour for a pitched baseball last night and said he didn't care for the scientific scrutiny of his pitches. "I don't like to do it because it takes too much away from my concentration," the California Angel strike-out king said after beating the Chicago White Sox, 3-1.

President Ford's granting of a pardon to former President Nixon has raised the hopes for clemency of two Watergate burglars.

Portugal today ordered her forces in Mozambique to move against dissident rightists who have seized key points in Lourenco Marques and are challenging Mozambique's independence agreement with Portugal.

Premier Bulent Ecevit is considering withdrawing paratroops from Cyprus to open the way for talks with Greece on the island's future, informed sources said today. Mr. Ecevit met today with members of the main opposition parties, reportedly to get their approval.

Following are the candidates in contests for Democratic, Republican, Conservative and Liberal party nominations for public office in tomorrow's primary here. Unoppossed candidates are nominated automatically, and their names will not appear on the ballot. Asterisks *denote incumbents.

Stanley Wolder, senior partner in Wolder Gross, a law firm at 521 Fifth Avenue specializing in patent, trademark, copyright and scientific law, died yesterday after a long illness at New York Hospital. He was 61 years old and lived in Liberty, N.Y.

A Trans World Airlines jet bound for the United States with 88 persons aboard crashed today in the stormy Ionian Sea off Greece. The Greek Civil Aviation Authority said there appeared to be no survivors.
A survey for Newsweek magazine three days before President Ford granted Richard M. Nixon a pardon indicated 58 per cent of those polled were opposed to granting the former President amnesty.

Cafeteria dining is on the way out, although this is scarcely the talk of Paris, or 'the lament of Sutton Place. The day of the tray is giving way to fast food in New York, and another local institution is punching out its last checks.

In their last two debates yesterday, the two contenders for the Democratic gubernatorial nomination traded familiar charges, added a few new ones, shook hands and agreed that there was little more for them to do than to wait for the votes to decide at the polls tomorrow.
The Treasury Department announced today that Government regulations pertaining to private ownership of gold currently forbid trading in gold futures.
East Germany set two world records on the concluding day of the European track and field championships before a crowd of more than 60,000 in Rome's Stadio Olimpico today.

The defensive ends, Fred Dryer and Jack Youngblood, teamed up on a 54yard play today to give the Los Angeles Rams their first touchdown in a 17-7 National Football League exhibition victory over the San Francisco 49ers.

In accepting this pardon, I hope that his compassionate act will contribute to lifting the burden of Watergate from our country.

The Adirondack, the only passenger train operating over the tracks of the Delaware Hudson Railway, roared into the station here today at 4:05 P.M. It had left Montreal at 9:30 A.M. and was due in New York City at 7:50 P.M.
In lengthening shadows cast by the century-old copper beech trees at Lyndhurst, a national historic landmark, a. Great Dane triumphed in one of the country's most prestigious dog shows today.

The United States Senate has scheduled confirmation hearings for later this month on the nomination of Gov. Thomas J. Meskill of Connecticut to fill a long-vacant seat on the Federal Court of Appeals, Second Circuit. This appears to indicate that Mr. Meskill has cleared a review of his case by President Ford. And Mr. Meskill's sponsor, Senator Lowell P. Weicker Jr., Republican of Connecticut,

Oil-exporting countries are likely to decide to raise the price of crude oil 14 per cent during their meeting in Vienna Thursday, Venezuela's Hydrocarbons Minister, Valentin Hernandez, said here today.
The Portobello Road Fair was a scene of curb-to-curb people yesterday morning, hours before Mayor Beame arrived to open officially the British-accented and boisterous antiques extravaganza.

Diaries are no longer dear; as the invention of the telephone began the decline of letter-writing, the invention of the tape recorder has led to the atrophy of the personal diary. Many of us record our words but few of us record our thoughts.

Cleon Jones, suffering from a sore knee the last couple of weeks, went in to play left field for the Mets in the eighth inning.... The Mets announced they had purchased Brock Pemberton, a first baseman, and Nino Espinosa, a right-handed hurler, from their Victoria farm in the Texas League. Pemberton, a 20-year-old switch-hitter, batted .322 for Victoria, which completed a three-game sweep of the league playoffs Saturday night.

An Indonesia Airways plane that crashed killing more than two dozen people yesterday was apparently caught by a strong gust of wind that blew it off the airport approach and into an abandoned house where it burst into flames, Indonesia's Communications Minister, Emil Salim, said today.
AUBURN, N. Y.-The business card that Mike Peduto hands out proudly to identify himself as executive vice president of the Auburn and Cayuga County Chamber of Commerce has gone bilingual.

District Attorney Richard H. Kuh of Manhattan took time out from bicycling with his wife and two children in Central Park yesterday to make public a proposal for tougher penalties for 15-year-old killers.

The National Association of Purchasing Management's August indicators all point to a deepening recession involving deteriorating business activity, a slowdown in new orders and production, and signs the nation faces increasing unemployment, The Associated Press reports.

The Boston Red Sox scrambled back into a tie for the lead in the American League Eastern Division yesterday after the Yankees were beaten by the Detroit Tigers. Meanwhile the Baltimore Orioles missed a chance to share the lead when their 10-game winning streak was broken by the Cleveland Indians.
Israel and Lebanese artillery exchanged fire today after an incursion by Israeli forces across the border, military headquarters 'here reported tonight. There was no mention of casualties.

NEW ROCHELLE, N. Y., -- "During the past several months, a serious problem has developed in New Rochelle," Police Commissioner William G. Hegerty told the City Council the other day. "It's a problem experienced by many other municipalities, and one that is defying a valid solution."
The final concert of the 1974 Schaefer Music Festival in Central Park - the most successful season to date, according to a stage announcement was not without its touch of drama Saturday.

Dr. Kirby Smith Howlett Jr., a specialist in pulmonary diseases and former superintendent and medical director of Laurel Heights Hospital in Shelton, Conn., died yesterday at his home in Heritage Village, Southbury, Conn. He was 70 ears old.

High Federal Reserve officials have gone out of their way to point out, for the first time, that the Reserve's highly restrictive monetary policy has already been eased to a significant degree, and they add that no "substantial" further easing is to be expected.

Richard Nixon became the thirty-seventh President of the United States on January 20, 1969, and was re-elected in 1972 for a second term by the electors of forty-nine of the fifty states. His term in office continued until his resignation on August 9, 1974.
Hurricane Carmen' sputtered out in the plains of western Louisiana this afternoon, after causing one death and heavily damaging the sugar cane crop.

The New York area's rock 'n' roll summer came to an ebullient end today at an 11-hour, four-act extravaganza at the Roosevelt Raceway here. The 80,000 who attended made the event the area's largest rock concert of the summer.

ASTRACHAN--Irving. The Faculty of Stuyvesant High School would like to express their sorrow at the passing of Irving Astrachan, beloved teacher administrator for over forty years. He will always be remembered by his friends his students.

If there is a better bowling league in the country than the Paramus Eastern Classic, Tony Lakawicz would like to know about it. Twenty teams, with many of the leading names in pro bowling on their rosters, will open the Eastern Classic's 22d season tomorrow night on the Paramus Bowling alleys.

6-9 A.M., WNCN. Flute Concerto No. 6, Vivaldi; Les Eolides, Franck; Quartet in F, (K. 370), Mozart; Nocturne in C minor, Chopin; Overture to Orlando, Handel; Trio in B flat, Beethoven. 10:06-Noon, WQXR: The Listening Room. Robert Sherman, host. Stanislaus Skrowaczewski, conductor, guest.
WILDWOOD -- Despite an anxious winter because of the gasoline shortage, New Jersey's resort industry drew record crowds to the shore for the 1974 season.

The American League's Eastern Division Pennant race took another turn yesterday and it was not one that bodes immediate benefit for the Yankees. New York was shelled, 11-3, at Shea Stadium by the Detroit Tigers while the Red Sox were topping the Milwaukee Brewers in Boston.
Seventy to 80 persons who attended a Little League dinner were being treated for suspected food poisoning late today, the police said.

State environmental officials disclosed yesterday that the levels of automotive pollution in New Jersey, described last year as nearly the worst in the nation, dropped by 45 to 99 per cent in the first six months of 1974 in comparison with the first six months of 1.973.

Senator William Proxmire, Democrat of Wisconsin, said today that Pan American World Airways fust either live or die in the free-market system. He urged the Civil Aeronautics Board to reject the airline's request for a $10.2million monthly subsidy.

A police officer was shot in the leg yesterday by one of four men in a car he and his partner had stopped in the Bronx to question about an earlier crime. The injured policeman was Officer John DeNicola.

In an effort to recapture some of the business lost from the decline in common-stock trading, the American Stock Exchange this week is likely to approve trading in Treasury bills and Government securities in small enough denominations to appeal to public investors.

Janet Currie Wood, daugnter of Mr. and Mrs. Clyde A. Wood of Missoula, Mont., was married there yesterday afternoon to John Scott Farley, son of Mr. and Mrs. Adrian M. Farley Jr. of Greenwich, Conn. The Rev. Carl Schroer performed the ceremony in the University Congregational Church.
The New York Federal Reserve Bank says the over-all price situation in the United States remains "unrelentingly dismal."

The West German central bank will announce the formation of a consortium next Thursday to help an estimated 100 small private German banks to get through a severe liquidity crisis caused by months of tight-money policies here.

A few hours after President Ford's pardon of his predecessor was announced yesterday, Mr. and Mrs. Wilson Wainwright of Olean, N.Y., were strolling in Foley Square in lower Manhattan, looking at the public buildings.

Ronnie Peterson 'of Sweden, upsetting the favored Ferraris on their home track, drove his Lotus to victory by less than a second in the Italian Grand Prix today and the race for the world championship got even closer.

Dr. Robin Wallace, race committee chairman of the Ida Lewis Yacht Club here, had a good idea. It was his proposal to match the five 12Meter yachts left over following the nomination of Courageous and Southern Cross to sail for the America's Cup beginning on Tuesday.

A contract with the Food Retailers Association that will give 6,000 members of Local 342 of the Amalgamated Meat Cutters Union increases of $60 to $79 a week over a threeyear contract as well as other benefits was ratified yesterday at the union's headquarters at 166-18 Hillside Avenue, Jamaica. Queens.

In giving former President Nixon an inappropriate and premature grant of clemency, President Ford has affronted the Constitution and the American system of justice. It is a profoundly unwise, divisive and unjust act. Like many lesser public figures who have commented at various stages of the long Watergate controversy, President Ford has sadly confused his responsibilities to the Republic and his understandable sentiments toward one who has inflicted grave damage upon the body politic.

After a seven-week summer recess, the Legislature returns to work in Trenton today to resume deliberations on taxes and school financing and to deal with some lesser problems. Before the regular session gets under way, both houses will hold a special tribute to Joseph A. Gannon, executive director of the State Assembly, who died last week in a car crash.
Dr. Charles A. R. Connor, a specialist in cardiovascular diseases, died yesterday in St. Clare's Hospital after a brief illness. He was 68 years old and lived here.

A three-man, three-woman jury was selected here yesterday to decide whether Goldman, Sachs Co., a leading dealer in promissory notes of major corporations-commonly known as commercial paper--should be made to return $3-million to three companies to whom it had sold commercial paper in the Penn Central Transportation Company.
Evel Knievel and his entourage left Idaho today, leaving this farming community to clean up the debris left in his wake.
The Ford Motor Company said today it was delaying until later in the week setting firm prices for 1975 model cars and trucks.

The Department of the Public Advocate filed suit today against a state regulation requiring 12month residency in New Jersey for eligibility to take a Civil. Service test.

The Polaroid Coct portion said today it would introduce a lower-priced version of its SX-70 camera later this month. The instant- picture camera will have a list price of $149.95. The SX-70 model now, on the market lists for $180.

A staff report for the Senate Select Committee on Nutrition today criticized the United States for using a large portion of its food aid for political purposes and called on the United States to take the lead at the upcoming World Food Conference in efforts to alleviate human suffering.

Rioting in a suburb in the last few days has heightened tensions in the slum belt that rings Rome, laid City Hall open to charges of sloppy administration and widened the Drift between the Communist party and militant ultraleftist groups.

The New York Stock Exchange predicted yesterday that the United States could fall short by about $650-billion in the funds it is expected to need between now and 1985 to pay for new homes, plants, transportation facilities and other major investments.
Policemen firing tear-gas shells today blocked an attempt by angry demonstrators to march on the Japanese Embassy.
Twelve first editions of Henrik Ibsen's works were stolen today from Ibsen House in the town of Skien, the Norwegian radio reported, together with a rare English work, Harrison's History of London.

The West German Government has granted Greece about $70-million in development aid to be spread over the next three years, a spokesman announced today.

The New York Yankees won their first game in Fenway Park in more than a year tonight when they overpowered the Boston Red Sox, 6-3, and regained sole possession of first place with 22 games left to play.
City authorities said today that they planned to relocate a Red Cross transit camp for Soviet Jews to minimize the risk of Arab guerrilla attacks that might endanger families living near by.

The academic year got off to a generally tranquil start yesterday in most of the city's 966 public schools as nearly 1.1 million pupils showed up, many of them buzzing with excitement.

Strikes by teachers in two Nassau County school districts continued today after negotiations over the weekend failed to resolve contract disputes.

Vice President Rauf Denktash, the leader of the Turkish Cypriote community, today predicted a virtual economic take-over of Greek assets in northern Cyprus, but added that non-Greek foreign interests and foreign-owned property would not be touched.

A Superior Court judge today agreed to delay the murder trial of Joseph Satkin, a Passaic County landlord, and two co-defendants after one of the prosecutors told the court that the co-defendants had given statements regarding the case. The prosecutor requested immunity for the two people.
The weights assignments for the 11 horses in the $250,000 Marlboro Cup at Belmont Park on Saturday were revealed yesterday by the New York Racing Association. Kenny Noe.

The calendar said "yes" and the weather said "no," but it wasn't really a contest. The calendar won, as it was bound to do with fashion involved. A lot of women were dying to show off their ew fall outfits and they did.

Third-seeded Dick Stockton of Dallas demonstrated today that he possesses an excellent memory as well as a good tennis game. He defeated Butch Seewagen of Bayside, Queens, 6-1, 6-2 in the first round of the Perspectus Tennis Classic at the Bradford Bath and Beach Club.

A railroad worker indicted for absconding with $50,000 in ransoms money raised by the father of John Calzadilla, who was kidnapped last March 6, pleaded guilty to a lesser charge today and promised to pay back $3,900 he spent.
Senator Edward M. Kennedy was driven from the speakers' stand of an antischool-busing rally here today as he sought to calm a hostile, booing crowd of parents.

Fire swept through a nursing home early today, killing six elderly women and the 11-year-old son of the home's owners, the police said. Five persons survived the blaze, including the owners and an employee.

A dispute over whether the special state prosecutor, Maurice H. Nadjari, exceeded his jurisdiction in the handling of the investigation of the city Cultural Affairs Commissioner, Irving Goldman, has erupted in Mr. Nadjari's office.

Dr. Clarence Senior, a former member of the New York City Board of Education and an expert on migration, died here last night of a cerebral hemor. rhage. He was 71 years old. Dr. Senior, who had lived here since his retirement from Brooklyn College in 1968, was stricken in his home on a mountaintop outside the town of Rio Grande.
Citing inflation in the cost of delivering medical services, the Health Insurance Plan of Greater New York asked yesterday for an average 11.1 per cent premium increase in the next 12 months.

A panel of six electronics experts, assembled by the United States District Court to study White House tape recordings, has been disbanded by the court but may be kept at work by the special Watergate prosecutor, Leon Jaworski..

The eight-month long Democratic gubernatorial primary campaign ended last night with the candidates making their final appearances at clubhouse rallies but with the real campaigning going on behind the scenes with massive telephone, and personal canvassing operations designed to get out the vote.

The New York Yankees today announced the acquisition of Alex Johnson, the 1970 American League batting champion, from the Texas Rangers. Johnson, a 31-year-old. outfielder, was used primarily as a designated hitter this season.

Twelve years ago the Chichester Festival Theater opened its doors. First under Laurence Olivier and then, three years later, under John Clements, the Festival grew and flourished.

Jerald F. terHorst's abrupt departure from the Ford Administration is a refreshing throwback to a simpler time in American political life. First of the President's appointees, Mr. terHorst chose to give up a new and heady job as White House press secretary rather than to temporize with his principles.

Far from writing "The End" on the tragedy of Watergate, President Ford's sweeping pardon of former President Nixon has only muddied further the ambiguities and uncertainties left in the wake of that whole lamentable episode. A more divisive and distasteful outcome could scarcely be imagined.
More than 100 taxicab drivers gathered in Brooklyn yesterday to pay tribute to a murdered colleague and express outrage over what they regard as lack of public concern for their safety.

J. F. terHorst's abrupt resignation as Presidential press secretary was described today by close friends as having been prompted, at least in part, by his feeling that he had been misled by certain White House officials.

Dr. Choi Doo Sun, a former Premier, newspaper publisher and until two years ago president of the Korean Red Cross, died yesterday at his home in Seoul. He was 80 years old.
Parents at a school in the Bronx and a school in Queens, rate because construction work had not been completed, kept their children home yesterday.
Investors' continued concern about the economy and over President Ford's decision to pardon Richard M. Nixon sent the stock market down sharply yesterday in slow trading.

The pardon President Ford gave Richard M. Nixon has not ended the former President's legal problems, but it may have in directly improved the outlook for a number of his former associates, both in and out of Prison.

The Federal Power Commission proposed today to let small producers of natural gas charge 50 per cent more than the national ceiling price for large producers. The price now is 43 cents a thousand cubic feet.

The city sold $600-million in revenue anticipation notes yesterday at an average interest rate of 8.437 per cent, which was slightly below the record of 8.586 per cent interest on an $800-million note sale last July 17. Yesterday's notes were awarded to a syndicate headed by First National City Bank and the Chase Manhattan Bank.

Clifton High's football team was unbeaten and untied last year en route to a record-breaking season that extended its winning streak to 19 games, the longest current victory string in New Jersey schoolboy football. The Passaic County squad, regarded as the state's best in 1973 by many observers, treated Coach Bill Vander Closter to a second consecutive perfect season in impressive fashion.

Three hundred foreign academics and other intellectuals have signed a protest condemning the Indian Government's detention of political prisoners. The protest is considered unusual because India has largely viewed academics and foreign intellectuals as traditional sup porters of the nation's enduring struggle to deal democratcally with the fundamental problems of poverty and popu lation.
Prices on the American Stock Exchange and in the over-thecounter market dropped yesterday as traders showed little inclination to view the pardon of former President Richard M. Nixon as bullish news.

The European Security Conference resumed full-scale negotiations here today after a sixweek recess. Senior diplomats from 35 countries met in a subcommittee to work out basic principles to guide relations between countries.

In a dispute that could lead to further hearings, the State Department declared today that it was standing by the testimony of senior officials who previously had asserted at Congressional hearings that the United States had not intervened in the internal affairs of Chile after the election of President Salvador Allende Gossens.

Sept. 9-Verrazzano College opened for its first academic year here today with 42 students, eight full-time faculty members, five buildings, two dormitories and a conviction that there is room in the American' educational spectrum for an old-fashioned small liberal arts college.

Former President Nixon successfully beat back White House efforts to have him make a full and revealing statement of his role in the Watergate affair in conjunction with his pardon, reliable sources disclosed today.

Dr. Reldar Sognnaes, acknowledged as one of the world's foremost "dental detectives," will report in London today that he has conclusive evidence that Martin Bormann, Hitler's one-time right-hand man, is dead and not hiding in Argentina. Dr. Sognnaes, professor of oral biology and anatomy at the University of California, Los Angeles, will tell the world congress of the International Dental Federation that Bormann committed suicide in Berlin in 1945 by biting a cyanide capsule.

The first official explanation of the trouble on last month's Soyuz 15 spaceflight was made here today by the commander of Soviet astronaut training. A new automatic, remote controlled docking system failed and prevented the craft from linking with the Salyut space station, he said.

Premier Yitzhak Rabin of Israel will arrive tomorrow for consultations with President Ford and other officials that, the United States hopes, will accelerate the pace of Arab-Israeli negotiations toward a Middle East settlement.

The Animal Protection Institute, a national animal welfare organization, has offered a $5,000 reward for information leading to the arrest and conviction of persons promoting dog fights in Illinois, where a grand jury is investigating the illegal practice.

The Missouri Pacific System, of St. Louis, said it had selected seven companies to build freight cars and diesel locomotives for a $100-million equipment order. Involved are 3,000 freight cars and 80 diesel locomotives, the largest single order in its history, the railroad said.

The trial of former State Treasurer. Joseph M. McCrane Jr. on charges of tax fraud allegedly committed during the 1969 campaign of former. Gov. William T. Cahill is scheduled to begin here tomorrow in Federal District Court.
A former narcotics chief of Chile's Federal police was charged here yesterday with accepting more than $500,000 in an alleged conspiracy to smuggle cocaine into the United States.

Prices improved yesterday in the corporate, Government and tax-exempt bond markets in what dealers described as a response to the move last week by the Federal Reserve Board to provide a moderate easing in the credit markets.

Senator Edward M. Kennedy proposed today that China be included in all future arms control negotiations between the United States and the Soviet Union.

Amtrak, the national rail passenger system, sent Congress a five-year plan yesterday for high-speed service between major cities that includes raising the average speed in the Boston-New York-Washington corridor to 110 miles an hour.

An expert panel on nitrites and nitrates issued final rec commendations to the Department of Agriculture yesterday, suggesting that these widely used food additives be restricted and in some cases banned.

Several persons who have recently visited former President Richard M. Nixon cast doubt today on reports that he is in poor health, one of the reasons cited by President Ford yesterday in granting Mr. Nixon an unconditional pardon.

Some Democrats in Congress sought today. to reopen formal proceedings to impeach former President Richard M. Nixon, but Representative Peter W. Rodino Jr., chairman of the House Judiciary Committee, declared that "impeachment is dead."

James Napoli, reputed to be one of the five leading Mafia chieftains in the metropolitan area, pleaded guilty yesterday to criminal contempt before a Manhattan grand jury that five years ago was investigating the fixing of fights at Madison Square Garden. Supreme Court Justice Burton B. Roberts told Mr. Napoli he intended to sentence him to up to nine months in prison and a possible fine of $1.000.
Japan's governing Liberal Democratic party, after years of spending money as if the party coffers had no bottoms, is in a financial crisis.
Special election telephone numbers, both for general information and for reporting violations of Federal election laws, have been set up for voters in today's primary.

The death last month of a key state witness led yesterday to the dismissal of criminal charges against four former Hudson County officials. Superior Court Judge Samuel A. Larner dismissed the indictment when the Prosecutor's office said it was unable to proceed. The case fell apart on Aug. 26 with the death of John J. Marinan Sr., a Jersey City penal director.

Former Mayor John V. Lindsay has written a 300-page manuscript of a political novel with a main character who is a handsome, Lindsayesque Congressman struggling to preserve civil liberties, well-placed publishing informants said last night.

The Roundabout Theater Company, which has won recognition as one of New York's outstanding repertory institutions, has leased the RKO 23d Street Cinema, and is converting it into a legitimate theater.

Jubilant white settlers and a coalition of black politicians strengthened their grip on this city today. They formally urged Portuguese officials to modify an agreement made Saturday to give control of this African territory to a black insurgent movement, the Front for the Liberation of Mozambique.

At first glance it looked like the most heavily guarded art show in the city. As it turned out, however, the men and women in uniform were the artists themselves. They were standing proudly with their work yesterday morning as an exhibit called "Cop Art '74" opened at Police Plaza in lower Manhattan.

The Communists and Socialists of San Marino, the world's smallest Republic, made slight gains in yesterday's general election at the expense of the Christian Democrats and Social Democrats. Each of those two parties lost two seats.
The Senate approved today the first revision of the United States copyright law since 1909 after killing proposed royalties for performing artists whose recordings are played on radio and jukeboxes.

Generating Unit Canceled; 6 Delayed A regional electric-utility group in Pennsylvania and Ohio announced yesterday cancellation of one major generating station and postponement of six others by one to two years. The five utilities known as the Central Area Power Coordination (CAPCO.) Group, said the Changes would mean a reduction of more than $700million in the 1975-1979 period.

Dr. , a member of the faculty of Rockefeller University for 28 years and an authority on protein chemistry, died of cancer early yesterday at New York Hospital. She was 62 years old and lived at 155 East 93d Street.

Manhattan Cable Television, Inc. (formerly Sterling Manhattan), the system that serves the lower half of Manhattan, has begun testing its first paytelevision service before offering it to certain subscribers later this month.
News of the Presidential pardon for Richard M. Nixon was printed on front pages around the world today, but comment was relatively sparse and mixed.

As jubilant white settlers-many of whom were heavily armed-and a coalition of black politicians strengthened their grip on Lourengo Marques, the capital of Mozambique, they formally urged Portuguese officials to modify an agreement made Saturday to give control of the African territory to the black insurgent movement. [1:4.]
The recommendations of The Times on candidates in today's Democratic primary election are recapitulated below. Candidates whose names are followed by an asterisk are incumbents.
The 53,000 volumes of Yale University's Art and Architecture Library are to be moved to a new site later this week because of the health threat posed by asbestos particles falling from the ceiling.

AFTERGUARD--The "brain trust" aboard a racing yacht, including the helmsman, relief helmsman, navigator and tactician. BACK-The wind backs when it shifts counterclockwise. BACKSTAY-Wire rope supporting the mast from after (i.e.: rear) part of a yacht. BACKWIND--Disturbing breeze created on sails by deflection of wind from sails of another yacht.

In explaining his decision to grant an unconditional pardon to Richard Nixon, President Ford fell back on the popular explanation that "the buck stops here." The trouble with the application of Harry Truman's famous definition of Presidential responsibil. ity to the case at hand is that the buck had not yet reached its proper stopping place in the Oval Office.

The head of Hadassah, the largest voluntary women's group in the country, sharply rejected today the concept that American women were "an oppressed minority." She said they were a majority whose influence was being felt in the nation's political social welfare and cultural life.

The playoff of a playoff ended this morning as Lee Trevino beat Gary Player by one stroke to win the World Series of Golf. Having run out of daylight after five playoff holes last night, the Texan and the
William L. Nassau Jr., who won the United States National Senior Tennis championship at Forest Hills in 1942, died yesterday at his home in Paoli, Pa. He was 78 years old.

Walter C. Crocco, retired vice president of the Story KellySmith Company, newspaper representatives, died Sunday in Valley Hospital,Ridgewood, N.J. He was 78 years old and lived at 148 Claremont Road, Ridgewood.
The trial of Representative Bertram L. Podell of Brooklyn on charges of conspiracy, bribery, conflict of interest and perjury will begin tomorrow, the Federal judge in the case said yesterday.

The Jersey Central Power and Light Company has been ordered by a Federal judge to protect newly hired minority workers in preference to union members with seniority, in a proposed layoff of 200 employes. The decision was handed down last week by United States District Judge Vincent P. Biunno. An attorney for the unions said today that the decision would be appealed.

Completion of the world's largest hydroelectric power dam is being hindered by some perennial problems of the Soviet construction industry, including inadequate living conditions, a high labor turnover and shortage of working equipment.

The Senate voted 41 to 8 today to override Gov. Milton Shapp's veto of a bill that would require a woman to obtain her husband's consent before receiving an abortion. The House must now vote the measure.

Nelson A. Rockefeller, who! said last week that he believed! former President Richard M. Nixon should be treated like any other citizen, said yester day that President Ford's pardon of the former President was "an act of conscience, compassion and courage."
The Federal energy administrator, John Sawhill, predicted today that shortages of coal and natural gas in the near future could lead to further unemployment.

The City Center Joffrey Ballet will present three new productions during its fourweek fall season at the City Center. The New York premiere of Leonide Massine's "Pulcinella" will take place opening night, Oct. 9. The
A French tourist reported yesterday that a $30,000, 12-carat diamond brooch and other jewels had been stolen from her room in the Summit Hotel, apparently while she was at Bear Mountain Sunday.

The people who gave the world Mickey Mouse said today that they would attempt to help the nation's cities cope with their mass-transit problems.

Citing the growing amount of foreign money available to buy American companies and the depressed price of many cortporate securities in the United States, the Securities and Exchange Commission today announced that it had begun an investigation of corporation takeovers.

Two 15-year-old girls living in the Children's Center at Fifth Avenue and East 104th Street were arrested yesterday and charged with having set fire Sunday night to a third-floor dormitory at the center.
After a year's suspension The New York Dance Festival completed its 12th and eminently successful year at Delacorte Theater Sunday evening. Mime, ethnic,

Former President Nixon successfully beat back White House efforts to have him make a full and revealing statement of his role in the Watergate affair in conjunction with his pardon, reliable sources disclosed today.
Former President Richard M. Nixon, faced with possible disciplinary action by the state bar of California, plans to resign his bar membership soon, one of his attorneys said today.

The appointment of Donald H. Eisenberg, acting executive vice president of the New York City Health and Hospitals Corporation, as the new superintendent of the Nassau County Medical Center, was announced today by County Executive Ralph G. Caso.
Western central bank authorities sought ways today to lift public confidence in the banking system following reverses suffered by dozens of banks in the last nine months.
Persistence, as well as. skill, plays an important role in successful fishing, and none knows this better than Dr. Einar F. Grell of New York.

The United States Government is reportedly threatening to stop delivery of uranium fuel to India unless New Delhi offers assurances that such material will not be used for additional nuclear tests. Although the Atomic Energy Commission denies that any deliveries have actually been withheld thus far, the apparent new policy
There must be tens of thousands of investors who have been rewarded by putting their faith in gold shares in a bear market that offers few havens.

Dr. Hugo S. DeLuca of 325 Hunter Street, Woodbury, N. J., an orthopedic surgeon, died Sunday at the University of Pennsylvania Hospital, Philadelphia, following surgery. He was 44 years old.

Senator Warren G. Magnuson, head of a committee that handles airline legislation, was credited with raising $9,450 from a dozen airline executives for the Democratic party in 1972, according to court documents.
A chief aide to Leon Jaworski, the special Watergate prosecuter, gave notice today that he was resigning in what was an apparent protest over the pardon given by President Ford to Richard M. Nixon.

Jimmy Connors, overwhelmingly, and Billie Jean King, excruciatingly, became the United States Open tennis champions yesterday. The title was the first for Connors and the fourth for Mrs. King at Forest Hills.
Elvin Bishop and Average White Band, two white groups who opened at the Bottom Line, West Fourth Street on Sunday, are both locked firmly into black music. Mr. Bishon, from

Three Latin-American countries cited "profound changes" in the international situation in calling on the Organization of American States today to lift political and economic sanctions against Cuba. The Permanent Council of the organization, consisting of ambassadors of the 23 active members, met to hear a formal presentation of a note submitted by Colombia, Costa Rica and Venezuela and an accompanying draft resolution calling for the ending of the sanctions imposed in July, 1964.

President Ford said today that the energy crisis had made it clear that the nation must give high priority to building mass transit systems that people want to use, but he said that $1 11-billion in spending over the next six years was the most he would approve.

The Pittsburgh Steelers traded an All-Pro guard, Bruce Van Dyke,' to the Green Bay Packers' today for' an undisclosed 1976 draft choice. Van Dyke, 30 years old, suffered a calf injury in the Steelers' third preseason game and has not played or practided since.

BASEBALL NEW YORK-Bought Alex Johnson, outfield, on waivers from Texas. PHILADELPHIA (NL)-Recalled Tom Under. wood, left-handed pitcher; Ursklne Thom. ason, right-handed pitcher, and Mike Rogodzinski, outfielder, from Toledo farm club. CLEVELAND (AL)--Signed Glen Galli, second baseman, for Reno farm club next year.

The Spanish translation on today's primary ballot, the first bilingual ballot in the city's history, is so full of mistakes that Spanish-speaking voters may be confused or seriously misled by badly translated voting instructions that. in one case, say exactly the opposite of the English original.

S. Lytton Scott, founder and retired partner of the accounting firm of Scott Mickelson, died yesterday of cancer at his home in River House, 435 East 52d Street. He was 71 years old. Mr. Scott was a graduate of St. Paul's School and Yale University, where he played varsity baseball and was captain of the squash team for two years.
Israel charged today that Syria had advanced her front-line positions on the Golan Heights into the United Nations buffer zone between the Israeli and Syrian lines.

, formerly president of the Citizens' Committee for Children of New York and chairman of the State Department's Conference on Racism and American Education, died Sunday at SloanKettering Memorial Hospital for Cancer and Allied Diseases. She was 54 years old and lived at 733 Park Avenue.

The State Senate today gave final legislative approval to a $200million green-acres bond issue the largest in the state's history. The measure, approved 32 to 3, is expected to be signed into law quickly by Governor Byrne and will be offered to the voters in a referendum on the Nov. 5 ballot.
Thirteen persons died and 24 have been injured in floods and landslides as a typhoon lashed southwestern Japan.with heavy rain, the police said today.

Maj. Rose McMahon, mother of John F. McMahon, the commander-in-chief of the Volunteers of America, a national social. welfare organization, died yesterday at the home of her son at 12 Elaine Terrace, Yonkers. She was 92 years old.

Some of the nation's leading economists applauded yester day the recent moves by the Federal Reserve Board to ease monetary policy slightly. But the experts-several of whom attended President Ford's presummit inflation meeting last week-differed sharply on how much further the central bank should loosen policy.

Avnet, Inc., reported yesterday record results for the fiscal year ended June 30 and the highest sales and earnings for the final three months of the year for any quarter in its history. Mrs. John W. Dean 3d called on President Ford today to demonstrate the same compassion for her husband that Mr. Ford showed in pardoning Richard M. Nixon.

Official monetary reserves held by nine oil-producing countries rose to $24.9-billion in July from June's $22.7billion, according to International Monetary Fund statistics released today. In May reserves of the same countries (Algeria, Ecuador, Indonesia, Iran, Iraq, Kuwait, Libya, Nigeria and Venezuela) stood at $19.5-billion.
CALCUTTA, India-M. K. Sen Gupta recently faced a difficult decision: Should his 2-year-old child be given milk every day, or should it be given to his 73-year-old father, who is a diabetic?

President Ford postponed today his announcement of a plan to deal with Vietnam-War draft evaders and deserters. The White House staff had been saying for more than a week that the President would probably announce his program on Sept. 10-tomorrow.
The Lockheed Aircraft Corporation, Burbank, Calif., announced last night its net earnings for the second quarter and for the six months ended on June 30, both showing gains.

A Swiss foreignexchange dealer at the Lugano branch of Lloyds Bank International has been arrested on charges of disloyal management and falsifying and supressing documents, the Public Prosecutor said today.

The eight-month long Democratic gubernatorial primary campaign ended last night with the candidates making their final appearances at clubhouse rallies but with the real campaigning going on behind the scenes with massive telephone, and personal canvassing operations designed to get out the vote.

The Somerset County Prosecutor, Stephen Champi, said today that his office had not yet determined how or why two local men, who were friends, had been shot and killed here yesterday.
Senator Edward M. Kennedy was driven from the speakers' stand of an antischool-busing rally here today as he sought to calm a hostile, booing crowd of parents.

The American League's proposal to play approximately 15 regular-season games in Washington next year will not be put into effect, it was announced yesterday by Lee MacPhail, the league president. "I am disappointed that what we thought was a novel approach for providing major-league baseball for the nation's capital could not be worked Out," MacPhail said.

James W. Robertson Sr., a lawyer who retired two years ago from the legal staff of the Pepsico Company of New York after 30 years of service, died yesterday at St. Peter's Medical. Center, New Brunswick, N. J. He was 6.1 years old and lived at 1355 Kearney Drive, North Brunswick.

The Trans World Airlines Jet that crashed off Greece Sunday had suddenly pitched upward and rocked its wings before plunging into the stormy waters of the lonian Sea, according to initial reports from the pilot of another airliner.

The state's three major utilities have requested a total of $597.4-million in rate increases since the beginning of last year. The Jersey Central Power and Light Company, which was awarded an Increase of $23.6-miliion on an interim basis last May, has asked the Board of Public Utility Commissioners to approve another $33.1-million rate increase this month.

Mortimer J. Abramowitz, Superintendent of Great Neck schools, denied charges of "insubordination, incompetence and neglect of duty" to tumultuous applause from a crowd of more than 1,500 people at the Board of Education meeting here tonight at the Great Neck North Senior High School.
As the contenders in the Democratic primary directed their final blows at one another, Governor Wilson yesterday prepared for the main contest with some quiet road work.
The Ashland Petroleum Company said yesterday it would cut its gasoline price by a cent a gallon, effective today.
Newton M. Poyer, a Bronx Civil Court judge who was indicted last December on charges of conspiracy to fix a murder case, has resigned, effective Saturday, law-enforcement sources revealed yesterday.
The former president of the lower house of Ethiopia's Parliament was accused today of having suppressed news of the famine last year in which some 100,000 people died.

Cortes W. Randell, who created a campus marketing venture that captivated Wall Street in the nineteen-sixties, has quietly pleaded guilty to four counts of stock fraud, The Associated Press reported yesterday.

The Essex County Prosecutor, Joseph P. Lordi, said today he was substantially expanding the investigation of disturbances that grew out of a clash between the police and members of the city's Hispanic community last week.

If fans had forgotten that Billie Jean King, spearhead of World Team Tennis, publisher of WomenSports magazine and women's lib activist, was also a great tennis player they were reminded of it yesterday when she won the final of the United States Open.

A railroad worker indicted for absconding with $50,000 in ransom money raised by the father of John Calzadilla, who was kidnapped last March 6, pleaded guilty to a lesser charge today and promised to pay back $3,900 he spent.
Ron Johnson worked out with the New York Giants for the first time, but said his final farewell after being' cut by the National Football League team.

A bill intended to curtail abortions that are not necessary to save a woman's life or health became Pennsylvania law today when the House voted 157-37 to override Gov. Milton J. Shapp's veto of the measure.

It wasn't Forest Hills, but the first outdoor Garcia Youth tennis tournament held recently at Princeton University had some similarity to the United States Open championships. It was a showcase for young players who had' made outstanding records in inter-community play throughout New Jersey during the summer, and some of them looked as if they could become future stars.

A boycott of a Lower East Side school by parents protesting the removal of the school's co-principals, both open supporters of Luis Fuentes, lost some steam yesterday as 550 of the 1,150 enrolled pupils showed up for classes.
The Department of Commerce will stage its first major commercial exhibition in Austria on goods for environment protection next month, and United States Embassy spokesman said today.

There was solid, bipartisan opposition in Congress today to the idea of a blanket Presidential pardon for onetime aides of Richard M. Nixon who have been charged with Watergate offenses.

President Salvador Allende Gossens of Chile refused to fly into exile during the military coup which brought his death on Sept. 11, 1973, according to tape recordings of conversations between the leaders of the coup.

Scientists reported today that they had deciphered and synthesized most and perhaps all of the code that governs the turning on of the hereditary instructions in a gene.

A North Hempstead, L.I., town ordinance prohibiting barmaids, waitresses and female entertainers from appearing in certain public establishments with bare breasts was struck down yesterday by a Federal judge in Brooklyn.

A five-judge panel of the Appellate Division's Second Department has voted unanimonly to disbar Michael M. D'Auria, a former State Supreme Court justice in Nassau County who resigned from the bench in 1971 after the Court on the Judiciary began investigating him.

Prices fell again yesterday in lethargic trading on the American Stock Exchange and in the over-the-counter market as the anticipated after Labor Day pickup failed to materialize.
Lou Brock stole second base in the seventh inning of theCardinals' game against the Philadelphia Phillies tonight and set a major league record of 105 stolen bases for one season.
The Senate passed a $3.1-billion bill today to extend for four years Federal aid for neighborhood health centers, community mental health centers and migrant health centers.

The Securities and Exchange Commission has filed suit in Federal court alleging Standard Resources, Inc., of Carson City, Nev., used "schemes, devices and artifices to defraud," in connection with the sale of more than 300,000 shares of common stock.

"The conditions are now ripe for a return flow" of American manufacturers who went abroad to produce goods to export back to this country Robert W. Sarnoff, chairman of the RCA Corporation, said yesterday at a union convention in Kansas City.

President Ferdinand E. Marcos said today that the chiefs of the Philippine armed forces had made a pact with him at the time they instituted martial law almost two years ago that they would always submit to a civilian head of state.

Representative Hugh L. Carey scored a surprisingly easy victory over Howard J. Samuels yesterday to win the Democratic gubernatorial nomination. Mr. Carey will oppose Governor Wilson in November.

The Federal Government has sued the Norfolk Shipbuilding and Drydock Corporation, asking damages that could exceed $7-million for what the Navy contends were losses stemming from illegal practices.

Real-estate industry leaders anr observers in the metropolitan area expressed shock yesterday over the indictments of Investors Funding Corporation and four of its top officers. But they appeared to be disturbed more by the breadth of the alleged offenses than by the handing up of the indictments.

United States Representative Ella T. Grasso proposed today a number of controls for soaring electricity rates, including a requirement that all electric. utilities add two public representatives to their board of directors.

The New Jersey Public Broadcasting network has offered 30 minutes of primeevening television time to each of the 58 candidates in the state running for seats in the United States Congress.

Silva Zalmanson, freed after having served four years in a Soviet prison camp for attempted hijacking, received a tumultous welcome when she landed at Ben Gurion International Airport here today.

The New York Yankees carried their revival to new dramatic heights tonight when they tied the Boston Red Sox in the ninth inning and defeated them in the 12th on a home run by Alex Johnson in his first day as a member of the cast.

The Riordan quadruplets, two of them receiving what doctors called ventilatory, or plumenary assistance, were reported in guarded condition today and doctors said the next 72 hours would be critical for them.
A freshman, State Representative, Edward P. Beard of Cranston, upset the incumbent United States Representatives, Robert O. Tiernan, today in Rhode Island's Second District Democratic primary.
The Securities and Exchange Commission filed suit today in Federal District Court charging U.S. Tank Car Corporation of Seattle and its president with multimillion - dollar fraud.

The Nixon pardon is profoundly disturbing for what it forecasts about the Ford Presidency. The decision itself, the way it was arrived at, the quality of the persons the President chose to advise him, and the thought processes which he disclosed in his statement of explanation all bode ill for his future conduct in office.

Kurt Waldheim, the United Nations Secretary General, blamed Turkish and Greek political leaders today for relying too heavily on the presence of the United Nations peace-keeping force on Cyprus instead of working for a political settlement on the island.

Officials in both the Pentagon and the State Department are debating whether American nuclear warheads should be left in Greece. Officials agree that legally they should have been removed when the Greeks withdrew from the military command of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization.
The selection of the North American team for the 1975 world team championship was determined strictly by the results of playoff matches in Washington at the beginning of the month.
Bane or bonanza? That was the question raised here today by a panel of consumeraffairs specialists about that new wave in the supermarkets, the computerized checkout counter.

The Metropolitan Transportation Authority announced yesterday that work would start this week on construction of high-level platforms at 11 stations in the city on the Penn Central's Harlem and Hudson commuter lines.

With unusually strong backto-school business ringing in their cash registers, boys' wear merchants from cities throughout the country have been in New York for the last three days preparing for the spring season.
The United States has undertaken a review of its entire Cuban policy in the. light of recent signs that Premier Castro is interested in starting a dialogue with this country.

Henry Schwartz, a 17-yearold Bronx honor student who was stabbed to death last July as he tried to recover a bicycle that thieves had taken from a younger boy, was honored by the Police Department yesterday with a public service citation.

To the Editor: It will be surprising if the unseemly haste and absolute nature of President Ford's decision to pardon Mr. Nixon-before any charges had been brought and before any trial-do not prove to be a momentous political mistake.

Prime Minister Indira Gandhi climbed atop a platform on the beach here last night and told thousands of South Indians that the nation was facing "tremendous difficulties" but that the democratic system would endure.

A convicted killer threatened a State Supreme Court justice yesterday after the young man had been sentenced to from 25 years to. life imprisonment for the 1973 murder of a Roman Catholic priest in Queens.

White settlers in Mozambique gave up organized resistance to Portugal's decision to hand over the government to a black guerrilla movement. A short-lived show of defiance by white crowds collapsed suddenly in the face of rising back anger, vented in rioting and blockage of the highway to South Africa. [Page 1, Column 1.]

The New York Stars begin the second half of their World Football League season tonight (WOR, Channel 9, 10:30 P.M.) in Portland against the Storm. The Stars, winners of six of their last eight games, have a 6-4 won-lost record. They beat Portland, 38-16, last month. Portland has won its last two games after losing seven of its first eight games.

Leonid I. Brezhnev, the Soviet leader, today met separately with senior representatives of two nonaligned countries with which the Soviet Union has been cultivating closer ties.

Former United States Attorney Robert M. Morgenthau overwhelmingly won the Democratic nomination for District Attorney of New York County yesterday over Richard H. Kuh, who has held the job since Governor Wilson appointed him on Feb. 13.

The Dallas Police Department has told its uniformed officers that they may not arrest alleged prostitutes under the city loitering ordinance. But they can make arrests under a state law banning prostitution.
President Ford welcomed Premier Yitzhak Rabin of Israel to the White House today with a strong public pledge that the United States remained "committed to Israel's survival and security."
A 29-year-old inmate scaled three walls under the cover of a heavy morning fog today and became the first person to escape from Connecticut's maximum security prison, authorities reported.
The Department of Agriculture proposed today a new grading plan for beef that could lead consumers to eat leaner cuts and save millions of bushels of costly feed grains each year.

The new chairman of the Council of Economic Advisers said today the Administration must fight inflation by cutting Government borrowing, tightening the money supply and aiming for a Federal budget surplus.
Arthur T. Roth, chairman of the Bank of Suffolk County, said yesterday that his board of directors had withdrawn its offer to merge with the First National Bank of Glen Head.
"It was 19 years ago to the day when we fled Turkey after a night of terror, leaving behind our business, our house and our son," the old woman recalled.
The Writers Guild of America-East has instructed five of its members not to work for WNET/13 on "The Adams Chronicle, 1750-1900," a 4-million bicentennial series funded by the National Endowment.
Harris, Upham Co., one ofin Wall Street's larger retail brokerage houses, eliminated eight of 81 offices in recent weeks. in an effort to reduce costs.

"He's the hottest property I've seen in 35 years," said Anson Isaacson of Chicago, who is handling licensing agreements for Evel Knievel, motorcyclist turned parachutist over the Snake River Canyon in Idaho.

Robert Cox, last surviving member of the original Keystone Kops, died Sunday at the age of 79. Mr. Cox, who had lived here since 1951, appeared in nearly 300 "one-reelers" in the four years he worked at Mack Sen nett's Keystone Studio in Los Angeles.
History was made at the quarterly meeting of the American Kennel Club yesterday when three women took their places as delegates.

These days, some mothers go into kindergartens demanding that their five-year-olds be taught to read instead of making a visit to a firehouse or that they learn to add figures instead of playing house.

NEW HAVEN-Welcome to the burdens which this largely permissive university imposes on you. A little regimentation might be welcome. As a wise teacher of mine once said, "If the trains didn't run on time, more people would miss them."
Michael S. Dukakis, a Democrat repredenting the "new politics," won the right tonight to challenge incumbent Republican Francis W. Sargent for the governorship.
There are two dance companies in Israel. The older and betterknown is the Batsheva Dance Company, which has been seen twice in New York. It was founded by the Baroness Batsheva de Rothschild.

As Democrats were voting for their candidate for Governor throughout the state, Governor Wilson, the incumbent Republican, was in Brooklyn yesterday to cut a ribbon opening the new treatment and health-care center at Wyckoff Heights Hospital.

Roger Taylor, Britain's top player, showed signs of having recovered from an elbow injury that has plagued him more than four months as he defeated Bill Brown of San Luis Obispo, Calif., 7-5, 6-3, in the first round of the $50,000 Prospectus tennis tournament at the Bradford Bath and Tennis Club.

Western monetary authorities, in a move to shore up financial confidence and prevent a collapse of the international banking structure, announced today that "means are available and will be used if and when necessary" to help banks that get into trouble through no fault of their own.

Governor Reubin Askew, one of the South's "new breed" politicians, won a runaway victory today in the.Democratic primary in his bid to become the state's first Governor to serve consecutive four-year terms.
China's leading economic official urged developing countries today to use petroleum and other raw materials as weapons of commercial warfare against the United States and the Soviet Union.

Eight months after taking office, Mayor Beame has announced plans to fulfill his campaign promise to dismantle three of the ten superagencies created by his predecessor, John V. Lindsay, in an attempt to make New York's sprawling bureaucracy more manageable.

James Cagney, the ruthless killer in "Pubiic Enemy" and other celluloid classics, is a man of peace who is not gratified by the spectacle of one man punching another man's brains loose. However, he grew up on 73d Street in New York playing baseball and football and basketball, and he understands that man is a competitive animal. He does not walk the worn path and campaign for the abolition of boxing.
President Ford is studying the possibility of pardoning those persons convicted or accused of crimes in the Watergate and related scandals, a Presidential spokesman said today.

Ten thousand demonstrators converged on the Japanese Embassy today for the second day in succession, but the police again fired tear gas to drive them back. The crowds made several futile attempts to break through the lines guarding the embassy, but the cordons held.
Ramsey Clark, a softspoken Texas liberal, was one of the most admired and denounced men in Washington during his service as Attorney General in the administration of Lyndon B. Johnson.
Over the last five years, New York City has lost almost a third of a million jobs, with the number of people employed here as of June falling to only slightly more than 3.5 million,

Olga Baclanova, the Russianborn stage and motion-picture actress, died Friday at Vevey, Switzerland, She was 74 years old. Miss Baclanova, a graduate of the Moscow Art Theater, came to this country in 1926

David Thompson, the all-American from North Carolina State, tossed in 30 points tonight, leading the United States All-Stars to an 82-72 victory over the Soviet Union national team in the final game of their six-game basketball series.
City officials threatened disciplinary action today against 300 firemen calling in sick to protest pay and working conditions. The officials said the city had adequate manpower to meet emergencies.
Britain's chief financial officer predicted t today that British inflation, recently running at 17 percent a year, would remain in double figures for at least two more years and perhaps longer.
Frank A. Bennack Jr., publisher since 1967 of the Hearstowned San Antonio Light, was named general manager of newspapers today by the Hearst Corporation.
The Cincinnati Reds kept pace with the Dodgers last night by beating the San Diego Padres, 5-2, in Riverfront Stadium behind the six-hit pitching of Don Gullet.

Sanders Associates, producer of electronics equipment and systems, reported yesterday huge losses for the quarter and fiscal year ended. July 31 and blamed the deficits on "monopolistic marketing practices" by the International Business Machines Corporation.

In the face of a low turnout in the Democratic party primary yesterday, the organizations of the two candidates for Governor rode herd all day on husge get-out-the-vote drives --and found that they often had to rely on their own volunteers s as local party captains lagged in their efforts.

Dennis Paul O'Connor, formerly Mayor of Hartford and a state attorney general, died Monday at his home in Hartford. He was 81 years old, Mr. O'Connor was named state attorney general in 1938 by former Gov. Wilbur Cross to fill an unexpired term.

COUGH COUGH Her name is Violetta, and she has appeared in a lot of versions of the story known mostly as "Camille." But it's hard to imagine a more bizarre rendition than the one presented by the Ridiculous Theatrical Company at the Evergreen Theater (477-0504), 53 East 11th Street. For this "Camille" stars Charles Ludlam in a drag performance that takes plenty of spoofing shots and yet handles the story very seriously.

Mrs. Steven Peterson of Columbus, Miss., mailed a birthday gift to her mother, Mrs. William Gilter of Omaha. After wrapping it, Mrs. Peterson wrote on the bottom of the package: "Happy Birthday, Mom."

New York is, of course, one of the world's biggest package deals of tension, conflict and often, to our amazement, tenderness. In all this there is an amalgam of bewilderment and confusion that makes tragedy comic and, sometimes, comedy tragic.
Senator Joseph Zaretzki, the Democratic leader in the State Senate since 1957, last night conceded defeat to Assemblyman Franz S. Leichter in his bid for renomination to a 14th term.

The new Ford Granada will carry a base price of $3,698 for two doors and $3,756 for four doors and the new Mercury Monarch a starting price of $3,764 and $3,822 respectively officials of the Ford Motor Company announced today.
The Defense Department has proposed a more lenient policy to permit servicewomen who become pregnant to remain on active duty.
Like a drape falling from a statue at a sculpture unveiling, the opening leg of an opening America's Cup race usually makes everything clear in a hurry.
The Lockheed Aircraft Corporation is to build and operate an aircraft maintenance and repair plant in Greece, sources in the Ministry of Coordination said today.

The Gunter Guillaume spy scandal, which forced Willy Brandt to give up his chancellorship to Helmut Schmidt last spring, is coming back to haunt the Government coalition at summer's end.

The Food and Drug Administration has told Abbott Laboratories that further proof of safety will be required before the company can resume marketing the artificial sweetener cyclamate that was ordered off the market in 1969.
Nearly 100 whitesided dolphins have died after becoming trapped in a small cove on the west side of Dennys Bay here.
The Association of Legal Aid attorneys, following a breakdown in contract negotiations early this morning, voted 193 to 143 to strike the Legal Aid Society today.

In the British accent that became familiar to countless listeners to debates at the United Nations, the politicianturned-educator analyzed the world body yesterday as a forum "for the expostion of policies, not an agency for the preservation of security."

The horrendous implications of President Ford's untimely pardon for Richard Nixon are finally becoming apparent to the White House. The official disclosure that the President is now considering pardons for all those convicted or accused of Watergate-related crimes underscores the peril his rash action poses for every concept of justice, law and leadership in this democracy.

Five partners in the defunct stock brokerage firm of Orvis Brothers Co. were indicted yesterday on charges that they had falsified the company's records, overstated its capital and used securities owned by customers to obtain bank loans for the company.
The Exxon Corporation confirmed here yesterday that it is "in the final stages" of negotiations with Libya for the possible leasing of new exploration areas under a production-sharing plan.
An absence of favorable economic news yesterday continued to depress stock prices for the second consecutive session, although the trading pace increased slightly.

The America's Cup is safe, quite safe. Southern Cross, the most expensive yacht ever to challenge for the 123-year-old trophy, proved to be a dud today as Courageous, the defender, trounced the Australian vessel in the first race of the series by 4 minutes 54 seconds.
President Anwar elSadat indicated today that he planned to open the Suez Canal to shipping even if the Israelis refused to withdraw further from their positions in the Sinai Peninsula.

Britain was said today to be "extremely disturbed" by reports that Jordan has secretly sold British-supplied weapons to South Africa, and London has taken up the matter with King Hussein and his Government.
A jury of five women and seven men was selected today to hear the Federal Court trial of former State Treasurer Joseph M. McCrane on charges he conspired to violate campaign laws.
Channels 13 and 21, through the facilities of the Public Broadcasting Service, will provide live television today of the White House conference on inflation, starting at 9:30 A.M.

A principal spokesman for the Department of Defense during much of the war in Vietnam, Jerry W. Friedheim, is resigning to become spokesman and Congressional lobbyist for Amtrak, the public corporation that runs the country's passenger rail lines.
The White House counsel, Philip W. Buchen, said today that the granting of a pardon to former President Richard M. Nixon "can imply guilt-there is no other reason for granting 'a pardon."

WRVR-FM radio will present a new fall line-up of shows for its evening "Festival of Oldtime Radio" beginning Sept. 16. The new schedule includes the original radio productions of "Tarzan," "The Whistler," "The Life of Riley," "The Great Gildersleeve," "You Bet Your Life" starring Groucho Marx, "Can You Top This?" and "The Haunting Hour.
A network allegedly responsible for distributing all illegal amphetamine tablets in this country has been broken, Federa drug officials said last night.
There was solid, bipartisan opposition in Congress today to the idea of a blanket presidential pardon for onetime aides of Richard M. Nixon who have been charged with Watergate offenses.

Following are excerpts from a memorandum submitted to the Watergate special rosecutor on Sept., 4 by Herbert J. Miller Jr. arguing in behalf of former President Richard M. Nixon against any move to indict Mr. Nixon. The memorandum was released by the White House today.

Off-duty policemen in this Camden County community demonstrated today at the four main entrances to the community in support of a demand for an 11 per cent pay increase, plus additional fringe benefits.

The New York Giants continued their summer shake-up today by cutting seven more players from last year's team, including Charlie Evans, the Players Association representative, and Rocky Thompson, the No. 1 draft choice three years ago.
Sarah Corcoran, a retired teacher, died yesterday in Lawrence Hospital, Bronxville, N.Y. She lived at 35 Parkview Avenue, Bronxville.
Representatives Louis C. Wyman of New Hampshire and Richard W. Mallary of Vermont won Republican nominations tonight to succeed, respectively, Senators Norris Cotton and George D. Aiken.

The Montreal Expos ended their losing streak at seven games last night by beating the Mets, 6-4, at Shea Stadium. However, the Mets staged a ninth-inning uprising that came close to changing the outcome.

With billions in military sales at stake, the United States is making a determined effort to retain its position as the dominant supplier of arms to Saudi Arabia against competition from Britain, France and other Western nations.

Portugal today formally recognized the independence of the Republic of Guinea-Bissau. As President Antonio de Spinola signed a document of independence, five centuries of colonial rule ended in the small West African territory that until today was officially known as Portuguese Guinea.

Federal campaign laws that require political parties to disclose the names of their contributors violate constitutional guarantees of privacy and freedom of association, the American Civil Liberties Union charged today.

Henry F. O'Brien, the regular party candidate, overwhelmingly defeated Frederic Block, the challenger, in the Suffolk County Democratic primary for District Attorney tonight to run against the Republican incumbent.

If a gently flared skirt that stops immediately below the knees is revolutionary, then it's time to man the barricades. Of course, designers embarking on their next season on Seventh Avenue aren't expecting brickbats.

A young American concert violinist who recently shared top honors in the Moscow Tchaikovsky competition will become the first visiting artist to perform in the White House since President Ford took office.

PITTSBURGH - Most Americans would like to believe that the war in Indochina is over. It is an unlanced boil on the national conscience--there are too many wheelchairs in sight, too many empty places at the dinner table to forget entirely-but as a nation we would prefer to consider the problems of inflation and the reconstituting of honest government than the problems of atrocity; war crimes and guilt.

The planet Jupiter is a spinning ball of liquid hydrogen with a turbulent interior and raging atmospheric storms. And the mysterious Great Red Spot on the planet may be the vortex o. a 25,000-mile-long tornado that has been towering above Jupiter's cloud belt for hundreds of years.

Gary Hart, who managed Senator George McGovern's 1972 Presiidential campaign, took an early lead tonight over two rivals, in a close race for the Democratic nomination for senator in Colorado's primary election.

Larry Costello, coach of the Milwaukee Bucks, signed a multiyear contract yesterday to remain with the National Basketball Association club.

Dr. Hubert E. Risser, a mineral economist who, had been a special adviser and assistant to the director of the United States Geological Survey, died Friday of cancer at his home in Reston, Va. He was 60 years old.
Retail sales rose further in Au gust after a strong gain in July the Commerce Department re ported today.

Melchior Wankowicz, a PolishAmerican writer who had been a controversial figure in Poland, died today, the Polish Press Agency reported. He was 82 years old.

Ramsey Clark, the Democrat whose insurgent candidacy was treated as a curiosity at the party convention, upset the party leaders' choice yesterday and won the primary nomination to oppose Senator Jacob K. Javits in November.

The Treasury announced today a surprise reduction of its weekly bill offering for next week and probably the following week as well. The result could put a little less pressure on shortterm interest rates, particularly rates on Treasury bills themselves.

The former Speaker of Connecticut's House of Representatives, William R. Ratchford of Danbury, captured a Democratic nomination for Congress tonight in a runaway primary election victory over Frank Santaguida, the party leader in Waterbury and the choice of the Democratic Congressional convention last July.

The beleaguered Franklin National Bank, which has lost more than $1.5-billion in deposits since its financial problems were disclosed last May, said yesterday that it could no longer afford its executive headquarters in midtown Manhattan.
Military maneuvers were conducted by Israel today on the Golan Heights for the first time since the war with the Arabs last year.

Investors Funding Corporation of New York and four of its top officials were indicted today by a Federal grand jury on charges of authorizing payments of $1.4-million in bribes to try to win approval of plans for a $250-million high-rise commercial project near the George Washington Bridge in Fort Lee.

George Mavros, the Greek Foreign Minister, said in an informal conversation here today that he expected to meet with Secretary of State Kissinger in the United States later this month to discuss a possible new American initiative in the Cyprus crisis.

Betsy Levitt, director of public relations at Kenyon Eckhardt, Inc., the advertising agency, was married here yesterday to Alan D. Cohn, a widower and partner of Wertheim Co., Inc., investment bankers.

The sale of controlling interest in The Washington-Star News to Joe L. Allbritton, a Houston barker, was postponed today because of a dispute over a union contract.

A woman who pleaded guilty to income-tax evasion must do nate 30 days of community work" as her penalty. Federal Judge Robert C Zampano imposed the penalty yesterday on Ida Ginsburg, 56 years old, and also ordered he to pay a $5,000 fine.

Following are excerpts from a letter that Fernando Arrabal sent to Generalissimo Francisco Franco, and that, he said, was never answered. Pain pervades not only your life as a politician and soldier, but even your recreation. You paint shipwrecks; your favorite sport is slaughtering rabbits, doves, fish. Your biography is full of corpses . . .in Africa, in Asturias, during the Civil War and after ... an entire life covered with the decay of death.

Claudius James Giesick, 26 years old, of San Antonio, accused of plotting the death of his New Jersey bride while honeymooning in New Orleans, will plead guilty to manslaughter and testify against an alleged accomplice in the case, according to Mr. Giesick's lawyer.

V. S. Chauhan won India's first gold medal and set an Asian Games decathlon record with 7,395 points today. Chauhan pulled away from Junichi Onitsuka of Japan in the decathlon's last of 10 events over two days-a 1,500meter run. He went into the event trailing by 69 points but finished third to Onitsuka's sixth. Chauhan's time was 4 minutes 36.24 seconds.

Talks between high Indian and Pakistani officials for restoration of travel facilities and telecommunications between their countries started today in Islamabad after a break of about three months.

If there was a prize for the best defensive play of the year Steve Goldberg of Marietta, Ga., would be a strong candidate for it. He would submit the diagramed deal, played in the recent Internation Team Trials in Washington.
Political espionage and slurs based on race, sex, religion and ethnic background are prohibited in a Fair Campaign Code adopted today by the State Board of Elections.
The Metropolitan Opera's tour of Japan next spring will cost about $2-million, and tickets to its performances there will be priced from $23 to $53.
A market letter that sent gold stocks tumbling this week represented a quick change of views by E. George Schaefer, who had been reccmmending gold and silver issues since 1971.
Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz yesterday made proposals for protecting and strengthening the rights of people trying to collect-on judgments granted in Small Claims Courts.
A former narcotics prosecutor, accused of giving a small quantity of the drug Quaalude to two colleagues, won dismissal of his indictment yesterday in State Supreme Court here.

Prime Minister Indira Gandhi and het advisers have come under increasingly bitter criticism as result of the intensifying food crisis in India. Economists, agricultural spe cialists, politicians and journal lists maintain that the Govern ment has bungled the situation by failing to develop coherent policies, concentrating on hea vy industry and relying on food imports.
