All soybean futures contracts on the Chicago Board of Trade jumped the daily permissible 20-cent-a-bushel limit yesterday, responding to the Department of Agriculture's crop report released after the close of trading Wednesday.

To the Editor: A middle ground between wageprice controls and the upward spiraling of wages and prices should be explored. The use of price anchors is a middle ground which has not yet been advocated or explored in the current discussions about policies to meet inflation.

of Ethiopia, who has been wielding nearly absolute power longer than any other living head of state, was gradually stripped of all of his prerogatives over the last six months by an anonymous group of army captains and majors, and has lately been leading a ghost-like existence.

Former President Richard M Nixon is suffering from spreading phlebitis in his left leg that apparently has wor sened since last Sunday, wh?? he was pardoned by Presiden Ford. But the emotional state o Mr. Nixon is not known.

Contrary to widely circulated reports, State Senator Mary Anne Krupsak, who won the Democratic nomination for Lieutenant Governor in Tuesday's primary, is not the first woman to carry a major party designation for statewide office in New York.
B. Duryea, the Assembly Speaker, began an assault on the Democrats today, identifying them as feeders of inflation, in an effort to keep them from gaining. majority power in the November elections.

Federal officials said yesterday that New York City could expect to get enough money to put several thousand unentployed people to work immediately under the expanded public service employment program President Ford announced Wednesday.

Three years ago today, 39 inmates and correction officers died in a police assault at the Attica State Correctional Facility made necessary because the Governor of New York State, Nelson A. Rockefeller, believed that it would be an abuse of executive power to grant the inmates immunity from prosecution for their part in the uprising.

Emperor Haile Selassie of Ethiopia, who ruled his country for 58 years, was deposed peacefully by the military. He was taken from his palace in Addis Ababa to army headquarters and later reportedly to a palace outside the capital for his "personal safety." He had been progressively stripped of his absoute powers amid charges of corruption against his government. [1:8.]

A running back, Jim Ford, scored twice on 1- yard runs and the New York defense did the rest as the Stars defeated Portland 34-15, tonight for their second World Football League victory over the Storm this season.

The Senate yesterday formally approved the nominations of Shirley Temple Black to be Ambassador to Ghana and John Sherman Coopers the former Senator, to be the first United States Ambassador to East Germany.

Chancellor Helmut Schmidt will break with tradition and go to Moscow at the end of October to meet the Soviet leaders before having met with the United States President, Foreign Minister Hans-Dietrich Genscher said last night.
Strawberries and harn and eggs were the featured items at a Belmont Park brunch yesterday morning held to provide the backdrop for the annual chore of picking post positions

Foreign Minister Kim Dong Jo of South Korea and Ambassador Torao Ushiroku of Japan are nearly at an impasse in their negotiations over Japan's position on the attempted assassination of President Park Chung Hee of South Korea on Aug. 15, authoritative Korean sources said tonight.
The new Portuguese High Commissioner, who was appointed to oversee the dissolution of Portuguese imperialism in eastern Africa, conferred today with of ficials of the local colonial administration.

The chairman of the Texas Railroad Commission, which regulates oil and gas in Texas, has warned Federal officials that the diversion of natural gas to national pipelines from state lines would not solve power shortages
The California Anels sold Frank Robinson, the only man ever to win the most valuable player award in both leagues, to the Cleveland Indians today for the $20,000 waiver price.
Bearish economic news caused stock prices to plunge yesterday in accelerated trading as the Dow Jones industrial average finished at its lowest closing level in more than four years.

The Justice Department disclosed today that it had given the first National City Bank permission to participate in any plans the financially troubled Franklin National Bank has for selling outstanding loans and commitments.

Local conservationists fear that the world-renowed Jamaica Bay Wildlife Refuge may be on the verge of destruction as a result of what they view as the Federal Government's mismanagement and misdirected priorities.

The St. Louis Cardinals, proving that they don't need a lot of rest to win games, came back last night after a 7-hour-4-minute, 25-inning 4-3 victory over the Mets Wednesday night, produced their biggest run output of the season in a 12-5 victory at Shea Stadium and swept the two-game series.
Crown Prince Asfa Wossen learned from a radio news broadcast today that he had been named King of Ethiopia to succeed his deposed father, Emperor Haile Selassie, a spokesman for the Prince said here.
A ruling by state Supreme Court Justice John C. Marbach today dealt a severe blow to the third attempt by some residents of Purchase to secede from the Town of Harrison.

Lincoln Hospital, a 65-year-old municipal institution serving the south Bronx, has been stripped of its accreditation by a national commission that found what physicians termed shockingg conditions" of overcrowding and inadequate facilities.

Elizabeth Fincke Brown, a member of the immigration and naturalization assistance section of the continuing education department of the Stamford public schools, died Wednesday of a heart attack, while visiting relatives in Lebanon, Pa.
A Far-Off Place by Laurens van der Post (Morrow, $7.95). A bushman and his wife help two young whites escape terrorists in South Africa.

Rockthrowing, jeering crowds in South Boston marred the start today of a busing program designed to integrate Boston's public schools, and tonight Mayor Kevin H. White banned any gatherings in the streets of the troubled section.

The 72-year-old Cathedral School, adjacent to the Cathedral of St. John the Divine, went coed yesterday. According to a spokesman for the school, at 1047 Amsterdam Avenue, opening day went off without a hitch.

The New York and American Stock Exchanges announced yesterday they would extend their trading hours by half an hour to 4 P.M. in the hope that it might attract more business to the sagging stock markets.
Ministers of the world's major oil exporting countries discussed today a new tax on foreign oil company exports, that would consolidate the present high level of petroleum prices.

The House Ways and Means Committee, yielding to the appeals of the securities industry, voted today to reduce greatly the tax on some capital gains. The new formula adopted by the committee would bring the greatest benefits to those who had the largest increases in the value of stock or other property that they had bought at least five years ago.

The Justice Department is considering a proposal from the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation for the divestiture of Avis, Inc., as required under a consent decree negotiated three years ago.

Clement Greenberg, the renowned art critic who is also an executor of the estate of David Smith, an artist regarded by many experts as the greatest of American sculptors, acknowledged yesterday that he had personally authorized changes in the visual appearance of certain Smith sculptures aftter the artist's death in 1965.
A "master plan for the arts" is being prepared to marshal and develop all of New Jersey's cultural resources, it was disclosed today.

The 12 indictments unsealed today by the Essex County Prosecutor's office contained 64 counts ranging from first-degree murder to receiving stolen-goods against 30 men accused of being involved in a robbery ring that has operated in New Jersey and Pennsylvania for the last several years.

The commodity spot market price index of foodstuffs and industrial materials fell slightly to 229.6 from 230.6 last week. The index compiled by the Bureau of Labor Statistics stood at 193.6 on Sept. 11, 1973.
The jury in the Wounded Knee trial adjourned tonight without reaching a verdict in the widely publicized case, and told the court that it would resume deliberations at 9:30 A.M. tomorrow.
Federal authorities said today that they were protecting three Puerto Rican farm workers whose lives were in danger because they had testified about conditions in migrant camps in South Jersey.

Two reporters for The Indianapolis Star, both members of a newspaper team that has been investigating police and political corruption in Marion County for over a year, were indicted today by a local grand jury on charges of conspiring to bribe a policeman.
A coalition of industry groups affected by the severe depression in housing construction and sales presented to skeptical Government officials today a ninepoint rescue program.

Nelson A. Rockefeller was reported yesterday to have given Congress an estimate of $33-million as his immediate personal worth.
Striking Legal Aid Society lawyers offered to return to work yesterday if the society's management agreed to submit the disputed contract issues to binding arbitration. But the offer was rejected.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 12--The chief architect of the first proposed reorganization of committees of the House of Representatives since 1946 appealed today to the House Rules Committee to send the long-delayed issue to the House floor for final action.
New York Congressman, Benjamin S. Rosenthal, today strongly criticized United States policies in the eastern Mediterranean, declaring that Washington "shares responsibility" for the crisis in Cyprus.
Premier Kakuei Tanaka left Japan today for a 16-day tour of Mexico, f Brazil and Canada that will also include a brief stopover in Washington for a meeting with t President Ford.

Miriam Young, whose book "Mother Wore Tights" became one of the first of a Hollywood supermusical, died of cancer yesterday at her home in Lake Katonah, N. Y. She was 62 years old.
More women are running for office this year than in the past, and they are achieving more successes.

Lawyers for the Houston Texans and John Matuszak said they had appealed today the temporary injunction that is keeping Matuszak from playing for the World Football League team, but the W.F.L. season could end before the appeal is completed. The Texans' attorney, Bill Pakalka, said the Texans had appealed the injunction ruling by State District Judge Arthur Lesher to the Texas Court of Civil Appeals.

Daniel P. Moynihan, ambassador to India, has privately warned Secretary of State Kissinger that recent reports of Central Intelligence Agency activities in Chile have confirmed Prime Minister Indira Gandhi's "worst suspicions and genuine fears" about American policy toward India.

The production of grain-fed beef continued to declinesharply in August, but total meat production remained on the rise, the Department of Agriculture announced today.

Edward J. Ostrander, one of five men convicted in a rockthrowing incident that killed a York County truck driver during the national truckers' strike last January, has been sentenced to 10 years in Federal prison.

Rose Koch, president of the Republic Container Corporation since the death of her husband, Louis, in 1958, died Thursday at the home of her daughter in Neponsit, L.I. She was 85 years old and lived at 200 Central Park South.
The Wilmington Coal Mine, described by its manager as the last coal mine in northern Illinois, closed yesterday after 47 years of operation in Kankakee County.

The rate of inflation appears to be easing slightly for industrial nations, but the United States was among those continuing to show an increase, the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development reported today.

Blanche Schnitzer Dickinson, economist and marketing consultant, died Monday at a medical center in Pitssfield, Mass. She was 70 years old and lived in Washington. Her husband Melville D. Dickinson died in 1954.
The State Division of Human Rights has ruled that all Little League chapters in the state must allow girls to play on their teams.
Witnesses at a public hearing today underscored the fears of state officials that New Jersey could face a critical natural-gas shortage this winter.
A prominent Republican strategist, Dr. Gaylond B. Parkinson, has been arrested on a sex perversion charge, the police said yesterday.

A 19-year-old Connecticut youth was arrested today in the murder of a 24year-old woman whose body was found on the edge of a collegee parking lot in Torringion.

Talks resumed yesterday under a news blackout in an effort to end the 33-day-old bus strike in four southern California counties. More than 700 mechanics walked off their jobs Aug. 12 in a wage and fringe benefits dispute.
Domestic car sales climbed by 13.4% per cent in early September, the best performance for the period in recent years and only the third time in 1974 that sales have topped the 1973 levels.

There will be no telecast of the New York Giants' regular-season home opener against the Washington Redskins tomorrow at Yale Bowl. Ray Walsh, general manager of the Giants, said about 48,000 tickets had been sold for the game, well below the 70,000-seat capacity of the stadium. Walsh said tickets still remained for the other six Giant home games.

The staff of the Public Service Commission said that the Consolidated Edison Company, far from being on the verge of receivership, was making money, a profitable trend having set in last May. According to the staff's findings, in July the company's income was '$50-million, or $12-million more than it had projected.

A soviet olympic star, Vladimir Laniugin, surged into the lead in the world three-day equestrian championships at Burghley House today while West Germany led in the team event. United States riders were close behind the leaders.

The Nastase's drive toward the $10,000 top prize in the Perspectus Tournament was stalled by a thunderstorm midway through his quarterfinal match with Ray Ruffels of Australia tonight at the Bradford Bath and Tennis Club.
A juror in the Wounded Knee trial became seriously ill today, forcing a suspension in the jury's deliberations and raising 'the possibility of a mistrial in the eight-month case.

Joel Dolkart, a partner in Simpson, Thacher Bartlett, one of the city's most prominent law firms, has been dismissed by that firm and by Gulf Western Industries, one of Simpson, Thacher's most important clients-of which he was a director and general counsel--because he "had apparently appropriated for his own benefit, certain fees paid to [Simpson, Thacher]."

It was a revival meeting, a session of prayer, a moment of theater, but officially it was graduation day yesterday for 32 ex-convicts who had completed 13.weeks of job training through the cooperation of city, state and Federal agencies and 10 private corporations.
Walter Greenwood, author of "Love on the Dole," a best-selling novel of the nineteen-thirties, was found dead at his home here today. He was 71 years old.

On the surface, it looks like fiery 1963, the last year of President Ngo Dinh Diem. With disquieting regularity, desperate men are dousing them selves with gasoline and burning to death on the streets of Saigon.

The staff of the Public'Service Commission said yesterday that the Consolidated Edison Company, far from being on the verge of receivership, was making money, a profitable trend having set in last May. According to the staff's findings, in July the company's income was $50-million, or $12 - million more than it had projected.
A suit seeking $100-million in damages was filed in Federal District Court here yesterday by lawyers for prisoners from the State Correctional Facility at Attica.

Some 500 persons attended an auction here today for inner-city land and housing that netted nearly $200,000 and disaproved fears that the four days of disturbances last week would frighten buyers away.

An influential monthly journal here has disclosed some Soviet scientific concern about the possible environmental hazard created by the TU-144 supersonic transport being developed by the Soviet Union.

Frank Sinatra will be accompanied on a nine-city tour next month by Woody Herman and his orchestra, Pat Henry, a comedian, and the Veterans, an acrobatic comedy troupe from Stockholm. The tour will start Oct. 2 in Boston.

Ten plant scientists from mainland China-the third of several scholarly delegations to viist the United States this year-joined more than 2,000 Illinois farmers on a tour of crop production research on the University of Illinois' South Farm yesterday.

The Homler Credit Union extends to the entire Bard Family our sincerest condolence at the untimely and most tragic passing of the son and grandson of our former treasurer lack Bard.
The chairman of the Federal Trade Commission, Lewis A. Engman, said yesterday that the commission would step up its enforcement of antitrust laws as a means of reducing inflation.

The Food and Drug Administration announced today the recall of an overthe-counter eye drop preparation called Prefrin-Z, saying that some purchasers of the drops may have gotten boxes containing a potent anesthetic eye drop product.

Now there is a date certain: One week from Monday, at 10 AM., Nelson A. Rockefeller will have to start answering questions-all those questions about his money, his policies and politics, and again his money.

Fog spoiled a great afternoon for yacht racing today and the third race of the America's Cup had to be postponed. Southern Cross, the challenger from Australia, and Courageous, the defender leading by two victories to none, will attempt to race tomorrow with weather conditions more promising.

Having suffered from battle fatigue following their disheartening 25-inning defeat by the Cardinals early Thursday morning and having been shell-shocked by the same Redbirds, 12-5, that night, the Mets showed early signs of a quick recovery last night.

One of the few regular visitors, to the desert resorts of the Coachella Valley at this time of year is the sloping wall of smog that spills through the San Gorgonio Pass at nightfall like a ghostly reminder of the Indian legends in which dead spirits walk the awesome brow of the San Jacinto Mountains.

Eugene Fodor offered an exuberantly played program of encores last night at the White House as entertainment for the first state dinner during Gerald R. Ford's Presidency at which an artist was invited to perform.

-If last Saturday's game with Oakland, the final exhibition encounter, had been a dress rehearsal, the Jets' show would have been closed before it opened. If it had been military maneuvers for a war, the war would have called off.
Government employes removed Government records and gave them to a United States official for use in his defense on bribery and perjury charges, a House committee has been told.

His income exceeded $400,000 last year because he was the first jockey with mounts that earned more than $4-million in a year. Laffit Pincay Jr. is expected to make that much money again this year, but not without a certain measure of self-denial.

Dr. David Sashin, an orthopedic surgeon with offices in Manhattan and Great Neck, L. I., died at North Shore Hospital, Manhasset, L. I., on Wednesday. He was 74 years old and lived at 14 Pinetree Lane, Roslyn Heights, L. I.
Bert R. J. Hassell, an aviation pioneer, who held Pilot's License No. 20, died yesterday at Rockford Memorial Hospital. He was 80 years old.

The City Manager of Long Beach warned today that his city was about $2-million in the red and might not be able to meet its payroll for the balance of the fiscal year. Richard J. Bowen, the City Manager of this South Shore seaside city, issued a six-page, single-spaced letter to the 580 municipal employes, explaining the fiscal difficulty and asking for their cooperation.

Washington, Sept. 13 (AP)--Government auditors have ruled that the General Services Administration had no authority to spend money for former President Richard M. Nixon's transition to private life without first getting on appropriation from Congress.
Five Canadian trawlers have been seized off the coast of Waeshington for allegedly fishing illegally within United States territorial waters. the Coast Guard announced today.
Mets vs. Chicago Cubs, at Shea Stadium, Roosevelt Avenue and 126th Street, Flushing Meadow, Queens, 2:15 P.M. (Television-Channel 9, 2:10 P.M.) (Radio-WHN, 2:15 P.M.) Yankees vs. Tigers, at Detroit.
The crew of the liner France defied the Government today and continued its occupation of the ship as unions organized a worldwide strike by French seamen on Monday and Tuesday.

All the major petroleum-exporting countries except Saudi Arabia agreed today to a tax increase of nearly 5 per cent on oil exports by foreign oil companies. The tax increase, amounting to a rise of 33 cents a barrel in government revenues in the Persian Gulf, could further increase oil prices to consumers if the oil companies do not absorb the tax.

The State Division of Human Rights has ruled that all Little League chapters in the state must allow girls to play on their teams. In an order signed last Monday, the national Little League organization agreed to force its local chapters not to discriminate on the basis of sex in league participation, with penalties up to and including revocation of chapter charters.

A Navy scientist seeking to develop an optical memory system for computers has stumbled on a scheme that his colleagues believe could increase the chances of finding a downed flier to 99.8 per cent, even in total darkness.
Escorted by police motorcycles, buses carried 25 black students to South Boston High School today as most of the city went peacefully through its second day of court-ordered integration.

William E. Colby, Director of Central intelligence, said today that there would be no "major impact" on the nation's security if the United States ceased all cloak - and - dagger operations against foreign countries.

The stock market plunged yesterday in active trading, sending the Dow Jones industrial average to its lowest closing level in almost 12 years. The sell-off was across the board, with the biggest declines again suffered by the glamour, blue-chip and drug stocks.

Refusing to recognize a Justice Department plea-bargain agreement with Jake Jacobsen, former attorney for the Associated Milk Producers, Inc., Judge Robert M. Hill of United States District Court said today that it would not be in the interest of justice to drop bribery charges against Mr. Jacobsen.

The Right Rev. Stuart Yarworth Blanch, a farmer's son who was a navigator in the Royal Air Force during World War II, was today appointed Archbishop of York, the second highest post in the Church of England.

Former Gov. William T. Cahill and his State Attorney General appeared today as witnesses in a hearing on a motion seeking a new trial for Paul J. Sherwin, once the Cahill administration's Secretary of State, who was convicted two years ago on highway bid-rigging and kickback charges.

A driver who had never before raced on an oval course won the pole position and the Indianapolis 500 winner was the slowest in qualifying for tomorrow's first race in the International Race of Champions series.

Elizabeth L. Reff and Maurice Sieradzki, counsel to Borough President Percy E. Sutton of Manhattan, were married yesterday evening at the Regency Hotel, State Supreme Court Justice Burton B. Roberts performed the ceremony.

BONN--a conflict is brewing between Rudolph Leiding, head of the giant Volkswagen company, and other members of the company's board of directors about whether to build an assembly plant in the United States. Consequently a decision is not expected this year.

The General Electric Company has been awarded two contracts totaling $31.9-million by the Pentagon. One is for the design, manufacturing and installation of generators on the Columbia River in Washington State. The other is for $9-million from the Air Force for engines for the T-2E aircraft program.

One of the least popular characters in any bridge club is the Result Merchant. His first reaction to any post-mortem problem is to say: "You could have made it if you had played ..." or, "If you had bid so-and-so it would have turned out better."

Washington, Sept. 13--With a brass band as an opener and a musical comedy as a finale, Defense Secretary James R. Schlesinger spent the day today trying to prevail upon four European defense ministers to buy an American fighter plane.

A playback of a cockpit recorder aboard the Eastern Air Lines jetliner, that crashed Wednesday indicated no "abnormalities," the chief investigator said today.

Hours before President Nixon made his resignation speech on Aug. 8, his attorney, James D. St. Clair, asked H. R. Haldeman's attorneys to send over a package containing proposals for general pardons, according to informed sources.

Bob Bruno of Pelham captured the 59th Metropoliton open championship today with a 54-hole total of 209, seven strokes under par. In winning the first prize of $2,500, the 40-year-old Pelham pro posted cards of 70, 68 and 71 over the par-72, 6,711-yard Middle Bay Club course.
United States experts discern serious dangers in the military situation developing in the Middle East, but at the moment they do not view the immediate future as somberly as do the Israelis.

The Federal Energy Administrator, John C. Sawhill, said today that a number of oil companies had overcharged consumers by $100-million in 1974 under a regulation that let them recover twice their costs for ome crude oil.
The Columbia Broadcast System is about to market a decoder that will enable the many owners of stereophonic recordd players to reproduce sound on four Patents loudspeakers instead of two.
The District Attorney's office said yesterday that a 26-yearold former, convict had "unequivocally" implicated himself in 11 murders of women on the West Side during the last two years.

Chicago Today, afternoon sister of The Chicago Tribune, ceased publication today with a final issue that carried a letter from President Ford on the front page.

Several pieces of concrete, one of them 10 by 4 feet in size, fell onto northbound lanes of the Franklin D. Roosevelt Drive about 3:15 A.M. yesterday near an, overpass at 58th Street. Highways Department crewmen, who closed the lanes until 4:20 A.M. to clean up the debris, reported that the oncrete pieces were about two inches thick and had fallen from a reinforced concrete structure overhead.
Some 6,0000 state and local governments may face delays of three months or more in receiving millions of dollars in Federal revenue-sharing aid because they have not filed the proper forms.

Archie Griffin of Ohio State, Tony Dorsett of Pittsburgh, Anthony Davis of Southern California, Tony Davis of Nebraska, Mike Esposito of Boston College and many others will start carrying footballs today when most major college teams begin what is expected to be another big year for running backs. A few of the major teams started last week, while Notre Dame and Georgia Tech played Monday night before a national television audience.

Export interest in soybean oil developed during trading on the Chicago Board of Trade yesterday, resulting in a sharp rise in soybean futures prices and an increase of the permissible ly limit for most soybean oil contracts.
Brokers who deal in commodity futures will be required under new Federal regulations to keep their customers advised monthly on how they are doing in the market.

President Ford built mass-transit boosters up to a jarring letdown in Pittsburgh the other day when he told transportation experts there that last winter's energy crisis had driven home the message that "we must make major progress in improving urban transit." Most of the President's subsequent remarks made it painfully evident that this transit message had failed to penetrate the White House with any real sense of urgency.

Participants in the White House Conference on food and agriculture here today agreed that there was little they could do, wanted to do or dared do at the farm level to reduce rising prices to the consumer.

The International Paper Company announced yesterday that it had reached an agreement in principle with the United States Steel Corporation for the acquisition of 50,000 acres of timberland owned by U. S. Steel in Baldwin County in Alabama.

In approving an agreement which recognized former President Nixon's title to his White House tapes and documents, President Ford and his legal advisers followed a questionable precedent when it would have been most appropriate to re-examine it.

A Federal judge closed the books yesterday on a bizarre case of the bungled kidnapping of a bookmaker by sentencing a 21-year-old Bronx woman to a year in jail. Two men accomplices had been sentenced earlier, and two others were murdered' in the last few months.
Mets vs. Chicago Cubs, at Shea Stadium, Roosevelt Avenue and 126th Street, Flushing Meadow, Queens, 2:15 P.M. (Television-Channel 9, 2:10 P.M.) (Radio-WHN, 2:15 P.M.) Yankees vs. Tigers, at Detroit.

Former President Richard M. Nixon's physician, Air Force Major Gen. Walter Tkach, said late yesterday that Mr. Nixon had suffered a new attack of painful phlebitis in his left leg and that a new blood clot had formed.
All the major petroleum-exporting countries except Saudi Arabia agreed today to a tax increase of nearly 5 per cent on oil exports by foreign oil companies.

For the first time in his six years as head baseball coach at Fairleigh Dickinson University, graduation last June presented a major problem to John Orsino. Last spring, the Knights compiled a 22-9 won-lost record, the most successful in their history. Helping the team achieve that success were seven seniors who have to be replaced.

With a brass band as an opener and a musical comedy as a finale, Defense Secretary James R. Schlesinger spent the day today trying to prevail upon ,four European defense ministers to buy an American fighter plane.

The head of the New Jersey Lottery will meet next Thursday in Washington with a top Justice Department official for his second discussion there in two weeks on'Federal lottery laws. The director, Charles. C.

President Ford has told a politi- d cal associate that he will dismiss James Keogh from his post as director of the United States Information Agency, the associate said today. There was no indication when the President would act.
The nation's mutual savings banks lost a record of $800million in savings last month as depositors withdrew their money to reinvest in higheryielding securities.

To the Editor: In the aftermath of Watergate, the initial mood has been one of conciliation and cooperation. It seems highly desirable for the President to give as much momentum as possible to this prevailing mood in the hope that we can regain a greater sense of national unity and purpose. A step in this direction is the "summit conference" on the economy.
The Kuwait Investment Office has purchased more interest in the St. Martins Property Corporation, it was announced here today.
Browning Fifth Avenue, Inc., the men's clothing chain, plans to close two or three of its 10 stores in the metropolitan New York area but will continue to operate its Fifth Avenue store.

Three armed members of a Japanese terrorist organization seized part of the French Embassy here yesterday and threatened to kill the Ambassador and eight other hostages one by one unless a comrade was freed from prison in France.

Industrial production declined 0.4 per cent in August, the Federal Reserve Board reported today. The drop was the first significant downturn in this key indicator of economic activity since the energy shortage period of last winter and spring.

Dr. Asa Liggett Lincom, a New York physician who also had been professor of clinical medicine at Cornell University Medical College, died yesterday at his home in North Salem, Mass. He was 83 years old.

Lois Lenski, author and illustrator of children's books for more than 40 years, died Wednesday at her home in Tarpon Springs, Fla. She was 80 years old. Miss Lenski was the widow of Arthur S. Covey, a muralist, who died in 1960.

The cold, the hex and the gopher ball slowed the Yankee pennant express tonight as tile New Yorkers lost, 6-3, to the Detroit Tigers. The last-place Tigers have won 11 of the 16 games played between the teams this season.

A rana conservation organlzation based here announced today that it had obtained an action to buy 38,000 acres of a salt manufacturer's property for $18.5-million that would almost double the size of the San Francisco Bay National Wildlife Refuge' and make it the largest publicly owned rban refuge in the world.
An attorney for former President Richard M. Nixon has formally objected to a subpoena seeking materials from Mr. Nixon in connection woth a Billy Graham Day rally here nearly three years ago.

Julie Nixon Eisenhower, the younger daughter of former President Richard M. Nixon, will substitute for Barbara Walters as moderator of the syndicated television series "Not for Women Only" during one of the three weeks Miss Walters will be absent.

Representative Lester Wolff charged today that "forces are at work" within the State Department to impede Congres- t sional efforts to cut off aid h to Turkey if she goes ahead y with her decision to resume o cultivation of opium poppies.
Something funny happened to women in 1950. They got roughed up, in art, in quite a new way, and an ancient, misleading, perfunctory dignity was withdrawn from them.

Missouri's Republican challenger for a United States Senate seat, former Representative Thomas B. Curtis, said today he would pay Senator Thomas F. Eagleton $2,500 if Mr. Eagleton would debate him. Mr.

Some years ago a colleague of mine, a reporter, was sent to the Maryland Penitentiary to witness the hanging of three felons, two of whom were black. The white man was hanged first, which prompted my colleague to note in his story that in Maryland, even on the gallows, the white man went first.

BONN-a conflict is brewing between Rudolph Leiding, head of the giant Volkswagen company, and other members of the company's board of directors about whether to build an assembly plant in the United States.

William E. Simon, Secretary of the Treasury, said today he expects inflation to continue at about current rates for the rest of the year, thereby establishing a virtual consensus among top Administration economic advisers that little relief is in sight.
A bomb exploded in a restaurant near the national police headquarters in central Madrid today, killing at least 12 people and inturing more than 40.

Britain has agreed to buy 85,000 tons of sugar from Guyana at [Pound]140 ($323) a ton. A statement yesterday by the Foreign Affairs Ministry indicated that the British Government had accepted the terms of a $27.5-million deal worked out here last Monday by Prime Minister Forbes Burnham and Britain's Minister for Agriculture, Federick Peart.

Mayor Beame's announcement Thursday that his carefully drawn $11.1-billion expense budget, not yet three months old, was being thrown off balance badly by inflation and a turndown in the economy raises the question of how good he and his advisers are as econnmic forecasters.
One year ago, the City Clerk's office in Manhattan refused to marry George Davis, then 26 years old, and Lorianne Young, then 18, because neither of the would-he bride's parents were present.

Alfonse M. D'Amato, Supervisor of the Town of Hempstead, said that a two-month investigation by his staff into five major supermarket chains in the Hempstead area had disclosed as many as five price markings on the same package,
Prices continued to slide yesterday on the American Stock Exchange and in the over-thecounter market as investors remained unconvinced that there was anything bullish in the economy at this time.

The Rutgers University board of governors today approved a $75,000 allocation for developing five campus pubs. The action came after the city withdrew its efforts earlier this week to tax two proposed pubs at the Rutgers and Douglass College campuses here.

The Democratic judicial convention this evening in New York will choose four new candidates to run for the Supreme Court in the First Judicial District (Manhattan and the Bronx) and probably redesignate a fifth whose term is expiring. Is this convention, if it can be called that, for real?

Money is hardly a strange commodity to the 11 horses invited to compete in today's Marlboro Cup at Belmont Park. A total of $3,582,432 has been earned by the elected particiAt the pants, a financial Race background quite in keeping with Tracks the rich purse structure being offered in the second running of the 1 1/8-mile handicap.

Swirling down to the mangrove swamps and mudflats, huge flocks of birds have been arriving at Kooragang Island in an annual migration from the Northern Hemisphere that is believed to have been taking place for thousands of years.

The Arab countries presented a formal request tonight that the United Nations General Assembly, which is scheduled to open next Tuesday, consider the question of Palestine as a separate item on its agenda.

A small advance contingent of black guerrilla troops of the Front for the Liberation of Mozambique arrived today and promptly had lunch with tough Portuguese marines who had fought the Frelimo troops in a long guerrilla war.

Lawyers for three Watergate defendants, John N. Mitchell, H. R. Haldeman and John D. Ehrlichman, plan to appeal Judge John J. Sirica's refusal yesterday to dismiss the indictments against them or delay the cover-up trial, now slated to begin Oct. 1.

The International Paper Company announced yesterday that it had reached an agreement in principle with the United States Steel Corporation for the acquisition of 50,000 acres of timberland owned by U. S. Steel in Baldwin County in Alabama.
Senator Jacob K. Javits denied yesterday that he had "let down" his supporters by directing the New York reelection campaign of former President Richard M. Nixon two years ago.

The French Government has taken up a new cause in the struggle for financial order in the world by urging the United States, most recently at last weekend's gathering of Finance Ministers, to reduce its short-term interest rates, according to informed French sources.

Former President Richard M. Nixon's physician, Air Force Major Gen. Walter Tkach, said late yesterday that Mr. Nixon had suffered a new attack of painful phlebitis in his left leg and that a new blood clot had formed. Mr. Nixon rejected the advice of his doctors and family that he enter hospital.

Hie Nastase's drive toward the $10,000 top prize in the Perspectus Tournament was stalled by a thunderstorm midway through is quarterfinal match with Ray Ruffels of Australia tonight at the Bradford Bath and Tennis Club.

Presidential spokesmen declined today for the sixth straight day to say specifically how reports of former President Richard M. Nixon's poor health figured in the President's decision to pardon Mr. Nixon only a few days after Mr. Ford had indicated he would await legal process before making a decision.

Emanuel Ax, 25 years old, of New York, has been named winner of the first prize of $5,000 in the Artur Rubinstein International Piano Competition. Mr. Rubinstein, the 88-year-old virtuoso, was one of the judges, and he gave Mr. Ax a bear hug after the winners were announced last night.

Three armed members of a Japanese tourist organization seized part of the French Embassy here yesterday and threatened to kill the Ambassador and eight other hostages one by one unless a comrade was freed from prison in France.
Doug Kotar has this strange grin that has puzzled coaches from high school to the pros. Tomorrow, the New York Giants hope it will puzzle Coach George Allen of the Washington Redskins.
More than 50 persons were injured, seven seriously, Friday when one elevated commuter AND train hit the rear of a second train on which a passenger pulled an emergency cord.

The modest space allocated by the Jewish Museum for its temporary exhibition "The Binding of Isaac," has been extremely well used. The show, depicting Abraham's near-sacrifite of his son, a Biblical passage that will be read on Wednesday when gatherings in synagogues celebrate Rosh haShanah, is to remain in the lobby of the museum, Fifth Avenue at 92d Street, through this month.

A conference of mayors from big, medium and small cities adopted the suggestion of Mayor Beame of New York today to mount an intensive broad-based effort in Washington for more mass transit operating subsidies.

LONDON-The other day, when this newspaper invited me to write a short piece on more or less any subject, I declined. I was struggling with a new children's book, I said, and I find it difficult to switch over from one thing to another. But I had no sooner replaced the receiver when I began to have second thoughts.

Merchants in the vicinity of the North Ward, whose shops were hit by four days of fires and looting last week, voiced apprehension today about Mayor Kenneth A. Gibson's approval of a demonstration planned for the area tomorrow.
Wayne Bishop, former chief field investigator for the Senate Select Watergate Committee, was found dead of a heart attack in his apartment today. He was 54 years old.

"This was the missing link in my career as a driver and I'm looking forward to working with our team to come up with a competitive Formula I," said Mark Donohue yesterday as he announced that he would be coming out of an agonizing eight months' retirement to go behind the wheel in the Canadian Grand Prix next week in Roger Penske's new Formula I car.

Presidential spokesmen declined today for the sixth straight day to say specifically how reports of former President Richard M. Nixon's poor health figured in the President's decision to pardon Mr. Nixon only a few days after Mr. Ford. had indicated he would await legal process before making a decision.
Stock prices plunged yesterday in active trading, pushing the Dow Jones industrial average down 14.55 points to 627.19, its lowest closing level in almost 12 years. Details on Page 35.

The Consolidated Edison Company reduced power by 5 per cent to 200,000 customers in Manhattan south of 42d Street yesterday between 1:34 P.M. and 4:55 P.M., causing air-conditioners and elevators to operate at lower efficiency on a day when the temperature reached a high of 88 degrees at 2:20 P.M.
Ethiopia's provisional military government today withdrew tanks from the streets and relaxed some of the restrictions imposed yesterday as Emperor Haile Selassie was removed.

President Ford met today with nearly 30 black Republicans and told them that they "have a friend in the White House." As a follow-up to an earlier meeting with members ot the Congressional Black Caucus, Mr. Ford conferred with the Republican group in an effort to set up machinery for channeling policy and political recomnendations from blacks into the White House.
A two-day-old fire burning through the $27-million luxury liner Cunard Ambassador, was contained late today but was not quite extinguished, a Coast Guard spokesman said.

A sophomore running back, Glenn Murphy, scored from the 1-yard line at 5 minutes 43 seconds of the second period to pace Boston University to a 7-6 Yankee Conference football victory over the University of Maine tonight.
The American Motors Corporation said today that more than 20,000 Jeep vehicles were being recalled because of a suspension system problem that had resulted in three minor accidents.
Erik Bruhn, who danced his way to world fame in ballet, made his debut as an actor last night playing a wild-eyed Samurai in Akiro Kurosawa's "Rashomon" to generally favorable reviews.

Washington (2-4) at Giants (2-4). George Allen has never lost an opening game or any game to Giants. Bill Arnsparger would like to surprise in debut. Redskins by 7 points. Jets (2-4) at Kansas City (3-3). Aerial duel between Joe Namath and Len Dawson. Chiefs by 5.

Administration sources said today that President Ford's conditional amnesty plan would require repatriated war resisters to spend between six and 24 months in alternative service. Mr. Ford will issue his amnesty program next week, these sources said.

Former Gov. William T. Cahill and his State Attorney General appeared today as witnesses in a hearing on a motion seeking a new trial for Paul J. Sherwin, once the Cahill administration's Secretary of State, who was convicted two years ago on highway bid-rigging and kickback charges.
The Franklin National Bank said yesterday it had shelved at least temporarily a proposal to sell about $125-million worth of loans to a group of banks led by the First National City Bank in New York.

The French Government has taken up a yesterday new cause in the struggle for financial order in the world by urging the United States, most recently at last weekend's gathering of Finance Ministers, to reduce its short-term interest rates, according to informed French sources.

A probable underground nuclear explosion in the Kazakhstan area of the Soviet Union was recorded at seismological observatories in Sweden and Norway this morning, a spokesman for Stockholm's Uppsala seismological Institute said.

Britain has agreed to buy 85,000 tons of sugar from Guyana at [Pound]140 ($323) a ton. A statement yesterday by the Foreign Affairs Ministry indicated that the British Government had accepted the terms of a $27.5-million deal worked out here last Monday by Prime Minister Forbes Burnham and Britai's Minister for Agriculture, Federick Peart.

Modern art will make its appearance on a French coin. According to Finance Minister Jean-Pierre Fourcade, France's new 10-franc piece--the equivalent of about $2--will be the first coin in Europe designed by a major contemporary painter since the Renaissance, when Leonardo da Vinci designed money for the'Duchy of Milan.
They tried to be. like Evel Knievel, who tried to fly over the Snake River, but they landed abruptly in Babies Hospital at - Columbia Presbyterian Medical Center.
The Manhattan District Attorneys office said yesterday that a 26-year-old former convict had "unequivocally" implicated himself in 11 murders of women on the West Side during the last two years.

Robert Drouhin, head of the prestigious Burgundy firm of Joseph Drouhin, showed up in New York last week to discuss his own wines, the wines of Burgundy in general, and to offer a few of his wines for a tasting at the Wine Writers' Circle.

George Eliot Leighton, vice president of the Fiduciary Trust Company of New York until his retirement in 1962, died, apparently of a heart attack, while driving in Fairfield, Conn., on Thursday. He was 80 years old and lived in Fairfield.

The Commerce Department said today that the ferrous scrap export quota will be 2.1 million tons in the fourth quarter, unchanged from three previous quarters. The department said about 1.9 million tolls will be allocated under the same formulas used previously to countries in proportion to their use of United States ferrous scrap between 1970 and 1973.

The United States Catholic Conference today gave its support to a Congressional amendment to deny most-favorednation trading status to the Soviet Union. The Most Rev. James S. A partial exchange of prisoners between Greek and Turkish Cypriotes will begin Monday, a United Nations spokesman said today. The date was set at a meeting here this morning between President Glafkos Clerides, leader of the Greek Cypriote community, and Vice President Rauf Denktash, the Turkish Cypriote leader.
The Franklin National Bank said yesterday it had shelved at least temporarily a proposal to sell about $125-million worth of loans to a group of banks led by the First National City Bank in New York.
Browning Fifth Avenue, Inc., the men's clothing chain, plans to close two or three of its 10 stores in the metropolitan New York area but will continue to operate its Fifth Avenue store.

The Agency for International Development announced today that It had pledged $3-million more for relief assistance to refugees in Cyprus. This almost doubles previous United States aid to the Cypriote refugees, which totaled $3.6-million.

I., while having luncheon It Christie's, at present headquarters for America's Cup buffs.

Tiffany Co. is introducing a new green gemstone from East Africa that is even more brilliant and durable than an emerald. The stone, called tsavorite (pronounced SAV-o-rite) was discovered in Tanzania in 1967 by Campbell Bridges, a Scottish geologist.

State Supreme Court Justice Dominic S, Rinaldi was assured of re-election when he was nominated yesterday by the Democratic and Republican parties in Brooklyn and Staten Island at their judicial conventions.

The University of Southern California dedicated today the site of the new Arnold Southern berg Institute on the 100th anniversary of the composer's birth. Schoenberg died at the age of 77 in Los Angeles in 1951, leaving a vast musical legacy valued at $3-million.
Jane Blalock, on a misty, cold day, shot a sparkling 69 today and captured the first-round lead in the $40,000 Charity golf classic.

The White House has halted the planned turnover to former President Richard M. Nixon of his tapes and records because the special Watergate prosecutor's office argued that the material was necessary for the continuing investigation of the Watergate conspiracy, an informed source said today.

The fall party season got under way with a roar Thursday night when about 500 revelers from the worlds of fashion, society and show business gathered to honor Stevie Wonder, the blind rock star, and to eat what was billed as "soul food,"

Eight of the nation's largest chemical companies, include ing E. I. du Pont de Nemours Co. and the Allied Chemical Company, plan to plead no defense to a Federal criminal charge that they fixed prices in the $480-million dye industry, attorneys for the companies said today.
Dr. Ernest Cadman Colwell, president of the University of Chicago from 1945 to 1951, died of leukemia at a hospital in Orlando yesterday. He was 73 years old.

A State Superior Court jury convicted an East Orange man yesterday on charges of taking part in the murder of a Black Muslim leader, James Shabazz, in the driveway of the victim's Newark home a year ago. The defendant was Richard Lawton, 20 years old. Mr. Lawton was the 10th person found guilty in the case. Two others are awaiting trials. Mr. Lawton was convicted of first-degree murder and conspiracy.

President and Mrs. Ford forsook the air-conditioning of the White House tonight to join in a sweltering party convened to honor the President's official photographer, David H. Kinnerly. The Fords stayed for almost two hours.
Frank Armani, whose defense of Robert Garrow focused public attention on the issue of lawyers' ethics, will prepare Mr. Garrow's appeal of the murder conviction.

A truck driver was shot and wounded today in a wave of violence caused by new school textbooks that allegedly defame religion, morality and patriotism. "We need help," said Kanawha County Sheriff Kemp Mellon, whose 50-man force tried, to contend with roving pickets yelling "burn those filthy books."

School Chancellor Irving Anker last night reinstated, "for r the time being," two co-principals of Public School 188 on the Lower East Side, where parents demonstrated and boycotted-the school this week to protest the removal of the two men.

Premier Yitzhak Rabin of Israel concluded four days of talks with President Ford today and asserted that Israel and the United States were agreed on how to proceed in Middle East diplomacy and on the need to keep Israel militarily strong.
The man who is a suspect in the murder of 11 West Side women is a former convict and drug addict who has been drifting from one cheap hotel to another in the city for the last four years.

Julian Davis, who had been a gold miner and a poet, picturing the lore of the days of hunting for gold, died last Friday in his native Cripple Creek, Colo., where he lived most of his life. He was 72 years old.
The nation's mutual savings banks lost a record of $800million in savings last month as depositors withdrew their money to reinvest in higheryielding securities.

Governor Wilson told New York City policemen today that abolition of the death penIty was a mistake Speaking at the annual convention of the Patrolmen's Benevolent Association, the Governor said he had "pushed for and got the death penalty that applies to the killing of policemen." The audience heered.

Striking Legal Aid Society lawyers yesterday renewed their efforts to submit contract issues in their three-day-old strike to binding arbitration-a position rejected on Thursday by the society's management, which offered to submit the dispute to mediation.

Maj. Gen. Robert Melville Danford, U.S.A., retired, commandant of the New York City Patrol Corps during World War II and chief of field artillery of the Army at his retirement in 1942, died Thursday at Stamford (Conn.) Hospital. He was 95 years old and lived on Contentment Island Road, Darien, Conn.

The treasurer of Florida's Hialeah Park Racecourse testified today that at the behest of former New Jersey Treasurer Joseph M. McCrane Jr., the track sent a Cherry Hill public relations concern two $1,000 checks in 1969 for services the company never performed.

Andrea Dunham, a partner and executive vice president of Dunham Marcus, Inc., a venture marketing concern here, and Michael Robert Burt, a senior vice president of Norman Craig Kummel, Inc., an advertising agency, were married yesterday afternoon in the State Suite of the Plaza. Assessing his chances in the fall elections, Governor Wilson said yesterday that "I approach them with confidence."

GERALD TARACK is a violinist, but more important, and far more unusual, he is a freelance concertmaster-the only one curently pursuing the craft with consistency and, success in New York. Mr. Tarack not only has the field to himself but, much in the manner of a soloist, he is often singled out, both by concertgoers and critics, for his abilities as a fiddler as well as a concertmaster.

MOOSE, Wyo.--Moaning through the jagged teeth of the magnificent Tetons, a vigorous southwest wind ruffled the sparkling surface of the Snake River, and before me, at the foot of an island gravel bar, was a long, deep pool that cried to be fished.

Kyra Schutt Hawkins of Syosset, L. I., widow of Ashton W. Hawkins, an investment banker, was married yesterday noon to Charles V. Hickox of Old Westbury, L. I., a widower and retired insurance broker.

In the 10th year of Joe Namath and the first of Charley Winner, the -Jets open the season against the Kansas City Chiefs tomorrow, hoping to prevent the threat of a poor season from becoming a reality.

"The cynics say that it's because we've been without power, but the fact remains that there were no women in policy-making positions involved in Watergate."

Two employes of Deltown Foods, Inc., a major milk distributor, denied at a formal hearing here today that it had ever harassed an independent milk dealer who had underbid it for a big milk contract in Westchester County.

Banks and other savings institutions are beginning to offer homeowners big discounts if they make full or partial prepayments on their mortgages. Generally those with mortgages can get as much as $5 knocked off their debt for $4 cash.

The Who beat the What? The New England Patriots--that's who--beat the world champions, the Miami Dol phins, 34-24, today to open the National Football League season on a stunning note. Despite being upended by Miami's Lloyd Mumphord, Mack Herron of the Patriots scored a touchdown.

Thousands of Roman Catholics today protested in the city of Hue against alleged government corruption and the behavior of the police who dispersed a rally last week.
If Johnny Miller were a betting man, he would have lost two wagers. But even he did not anticipate how close the finish of the World open would be--a four-man playoff that went to two extra holes.
The state police are investgating the murder of an elderly Hamilton Township woman whose body was discovered in a shallow grave over the weekend.

Soviet authorities used bulldozers, dump trucks and water-spraying trucks to break up an unofficial, nonconformist art exhibition in suburban Moscow. A crowd of several hundred persons ran for cover when dump trucks and bulldozers overran what had been announced as the Soviet Union's first autumn outdoor art show.

Defense attorneys in the Wounded Knee trial asked Judge Fred J. Nichol in Federal District Court last night to dismiss charges against two American Indian leaders, Russell C. Means and Dennis J. Banks, because of what they termed "misconduct" of prosecutors and of Government investigators and witnesses.

The charred luxury liners Cunard Ambassador, ravaged by fire for two days last week, tied up at the Key West Naval Station today and insurance investigators immediately hoarded her to begin an evaluation of damages.

The Japanese Red Army, three of whose members are holding hostages at the French Embassy in the Hague, threatened today to retaliate with more terrorism if any more of its members were imprisoned . .

Agostino Novella, Communist trade union leader and a former member of Parliament, died last night after a long illness. He was 68 years old.
Nolan Ryan won his 20th game with a three-hitter, pitching the California Angels to a 6-2 victory over the Chicago White Sox today.

School officials, fearful of further violence by Fundamentalist critics of supposedly "filthy," "anti-God" and "unAmerican" textbooks in the Kanawha County public schools, postponed tonight for at least another day the resumption of classes for 44,500 pupils in the West Virginia capital.

Priscilla Meyer and William Trousdale, professors at Wesleyan University, were married yesterday. The Rev. William Roberts performed the Congregational ceremony at the bridegroom's home in Middletown, Conn.

Mrs. Donald Spicer, immediate past president-general of the Daughters of the American Revolution, died Friday at the age of 71. She lived in suburban McLean, Va.

Carl F. Greenway, a former general partner and vice president of the investment banking firm of Spencer Trask Co. and former president of the MetrOpolitan Opera Club, died Friday of cancer in Los Angeles. He was 57 years old and had lived here until he moved this year to the West Coast.
Radnor H, owned by Mr. and Mrs. Neal Eustace of Stonington, Conn., and handled by Melanie Smith, scored the only clean round in the jumpoff 'and captured the Nassau Grand Prix today.

Al Unser won the Norton 250-mile Championship Car race today and was lucky his mirrors were dirty. He didn't have to see the race. What went on behind him at Michigan International Raceway was probably a good reason many fans stayed home to watch professional football on television.
Two women hostages were released early today by the Japanese terrorists who have been in control of the French Embassy since Friday afternoon.

Jean B. Levin of Livingston, N.J., and Bernard L. Albert of Paterson, N.J., were married yesterday afternoon at the home of the bride's sister and brother-in-law, Dr. and Mrs. Walter Nudelman, in South Orange, N.J. Rabbi Ely Pilchik of Short Hills officiated.

In view of the considerable popularity of bridge among American adults, the lack of encouragement given to teenage players at school is distinctlyodd. Former President Richard M. Nixon remained secluded yesterday at his San Clemente, Calif., estate instead of a hospital, as his doctors had recommended, amid growing concern and controversy over the true state of his physical and mental health. Dr. Walter R. Tkach

The Teachers Association and various student groups called today for the court-martial of Haile Selassie, the deposed Emperor, but a spokesman for the Armed Forces Committee turned down the demands as premature and against the country's interests.

LUCKNOW, India--Ram Sunder Lal Yadav barely speaks now. He walks with a limp and his right arm is lame. His eyes bulge. "I am still so frightened," he said slowly. "I don't sleep. I can't eat. I should be dead. The doctor said I should be dead." Ram Sunder Lal Yadav was beaten in attack on untouchables in July in Uttar Pradesh, India.
William Hubben, an authority on the Quaker faith and editor of the Friends Journal from 1955 to 1963, died Sept. 8 in the Germantown Hospital in Philadelphia. He was 78 years old.

LONDON--Although nearly all of Britain's best-knowi playwrights (Harold Pinter is a notable exception) have contributed new plays to the current London season, the Establishment theater has, very healthy regard for the value of classic revivals.

The controversy over the pardon has until now kept attention away from a related matter: the agreement made with Richard M. Nixon on the handling of the papers . and tapes accumulated while he was in the White House. It is an astonishing legal document.

The indictment of two Indianapolis Star reporters who investigated alleged corruption within the city police represents "a dangerous threat to the First Amendment," officers of two national editors' associations said yesterday.

Israeli fighter bombers struck today at targets in southeast Lebanon, killing one civilian and wounding two others, the Ministry of Defense said in a communique. The dead man was identified as Fuad Abou Saleh, the mukhtar, or local leader, of Hasbaya, which is the largest township of the region, known as the Arkub, on the slopes of Mount Hermon.

Julian Breen, director of the department of budget and finance of the American Jewish Joint Distribution Committee, a relief agency aiding Jews overseas, died yesterday at his home in Geneva. He was 62 years old.

In the title story of "The Camberwell Beauty," a young antique dealer falls in love with the adopted daughter of another antique dealer, only to see her married off to a third elderly dealer who keeps her locked up and simply looks at her each night with the lust of a porcelain collector.

Harness racing has a new glamour boy in 19-year-old Peter Haughton, son of hall of fame reinsman, Bill Hauhgton. Gen. Alexander M. Haig Jr, says he expects his imminent departure from the White House post once held by H. R. Haldeman to be followed by the resignation of Kenneth R. Cole Jr., who succeeded John D. Ehrlichman as domestic policy coordinator.

The Q-38 bus, which will link Rego Park and Oakland Gardens in Queens, will make its first trip at 6:30 A.M. today. According to Metropolitan Transportation Authority officials, the bus, which will operate along Horace Harding Expressway, will give commuters in Northeast Queens access to shopping facilities and the subway line along Queens Boulevard.

Sandra Haynie shot four birdies in a five-hole span, overtook Jane Blalock with a record 66 today and defended her victory of last year in the $40,000 Ladies Professional Golf Association charity classic.

With Chou En-lai on the sidelines in failing health, the emphasis in Peking seems to be on forestalling conflict over key leadership positions by making it plain that no one person is going to inherit the authority the Premier wielded.
Ingmar Bergman's "Scenes From a Marriage," starring the incomparable Liv Ullmann and Erland Josephson as lovers who don't always know it, is the first major film event of the autumn season.

Alan Hrabosky is one of the least known of the St. Louis Cardinals. Most people even have trouble pronouncing his name (ruh-BOS-skee), but the 25-yearold Cards' left-hander has become a big man in the St. Louis stretch bid for the National League Eastern Division title.

ADAMS--Thecla M. (nee Kaylor), on Sept. 12, 1974, devoted wife of the late George M Adams, stepmother of George, Jr., in Japan and Leland, Peoria, Ill. Funeral Mass and interment was held in St. Michael's Church and Cemetery in Loretto, Pa., on Sept. 16, 1974. Contributions to UNICEF.
Joe Ferguson's 13-yard pass to Ahmad Rashad with 26 seconds to play tonight rallied Buffalo to a 21-20 victory over the Oakland Raiders in a National Football League opener.

Amid a growing controversy over the Rev. Sun Myung Moon and his well-publicized appearance at Madison Square Garden tomorrow, some religious leaders and parents are organizing opposition to the 55year-old Korean evangelist.

Two elderly women being checked as possible victims of a suspect in several West Side murders have turned up alive, Detective Lieut. James F. Gallagher, commanding the Fourth Homicide Squad, said yesterday.

Cesar Geronimo, Dave Con; cepcion and Johnny Bench drove in two runs apiece tonight and the Cincinnati Reds walloped the San Diego Padres, 9-2.

The fatal shooting of a 14year-old Brownsville boy by a police officer who had been called to check out a reported burglary in the Brooklyn neighborhood late Sunday evening was under investigation by the Brooklyn District Attorney's office yesterday.

The Ronson Corporation, maker of cigarette lighters and other products, announced yesterday that the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit in New York had granted a stay of a United States District Court order that permitted Liquifin, S.p.A., of Italy to name two directors to the Ronson Board.

The House Judiciary Committee, in its confirmation hearings on Nelson A. Rockefeller, is belived likely to examine not only the dollars-and-cents figures of his and his family's fortunes but also the implications of this economic and political power on his eligibility for the Vice-Presidency.

The staff of a Senate Foreign Relations subcommittee has recommended that contempt of Congress charges be placed against Richard Helms, former director of Central Intelligence, and three retired Nixon Administration officials because of their allegedly misleading Senate testimony on Chile last year, highly reliable Congressional suorces said today.

President Ford tonight publicly declared his support for the clandestine use of the Central Intelligence Agency "to help implement foreign policy and protect national security," but he denied that the C.I.A. had been involved in the Chilean coup d'etat last year.

A Long Island bank is expected to provide up to $1-miltion in personal, interest-free loans to this' city's municipal employes because the city is $2-million in the red and unable to meet its payroll.

Ethiopian soldiers today blocked attempts by about a thousand university students to demonstrate for an immediate return to civilian rule and for a speedy court martial and conviction of the deposed Emperor, Haile Selassie.

The Persian capital today celebrated the 33d anniversary of Shah Mohammed Riza Pahlevi's accession to the throne and the fresh, satisfying victories of Iran over her neighbors in the Asian Games sports competition.

President Ford said emphatically tonight that he had made "no deal" with former President Richard M. Nixon and insisted that the major reason for his decision to pardon him was "to heal the nation."
The White House announced today that telephone inquiries about terms of the new clemency program for draft evaders or military deserters should be directed to the following:
A British Cabinet minister said tonight that tourists who had lost the equivalent of $19-million when the Court Line travel group went bankrupt are to have their money refunded in full.

The State Department of Education began an investigation today of a $2.1-million deficit incurred by the school district here and of why the matter was concealed from community residents for nearly three years.
LONDON-Richard Wagner demands four nights of our lives with his operatic epic, "Der Ring des Nibelungen," and many people regard it as time well invested. But three nights for a farce?

Members of Congress were generally pleased with President Ford's announcement today offering a conditional amnesty for draft evaders and military deserters, but, away from Capitol Hill, there were many vocal critics of the plan.

A jury of seven men and five women was selected yesterday for the trial of Representative Bertram L. Podell on charges that the Brooklyn Democrat took $41,350 in bribes to help a Florida airline obtain a route to the Bahamas.

Officials in charge of administering President Ford's amnesty program said today that draft evaders and military deserters would be permitted to select the form of alternative service they wished to perform and to find their own jobs, subject to approval by their state Selective Service directors.

French seamen today began a 48 hour strike in support of the rebel crew of the liner France, who have been occupying the ship for the last five days in protest against Government plans to take her lout of service.

Chanting bands of white youths roamed the streets of South. Boston today, protesting court-ordered integration of the area's schools. But the buses carrying increased - although still small -- numbers of black students into the neighborhood came and went without serious incident, in contrast to last week's stonings.
The Justice Department today gave the New York State Lottery a clean bill of health, and exempted the lottery from a planned Federal crackdown.

Motions have been filed to dismiss charges against Peter Leonard, indicted for starting the June 30 fire that killed 24 persons in a Port Chester discotheque. Mr. Leonard's attorney, Stephen J. Pittari. said today.

After all the challenges to the Clean Air Act and all the attempts by the automobile industry to condemn that' law's alleged "excesses," the National Academy of Sciences now finds its emissions standards amply justified on the grounds of public health.
The police in Paris still had-no clue today whether a grenade thrown in a Left Bank luxury shopping center yesterday afternoon was "a political crime, an act of vengeance or the work of a madman."
The trial of a rare legal action by the Securities and Exchange Commission against a financial journalist opens on Tuesday in the Federal District Court here.

Dr. Forrest C, (Phog) Allen, who coached basketball at the University of Kansas for nearly four decades and fought to add that sport to the Olympic Games' slate, died today. He was 88 years old and lived here.
Despite skyrocketing material costs, one major producer of penny gum is determined to keep the price at one penny each.

Three defendants in the Watergate cover-up case appealed today United States Disstrict Judge John J. Sirica's denial of their request for a further delay in their trial, citing publicity about the pardon of former President Richard M. Nixon.
The head of the city's Rent Guidelines Board said yesterday that the board would meet soon to consider whether rent-rise limits it recently announced for 400,000 apartments were too high.

The Senate unanimously approved legislation today for Federal regulation of dealers in municipal securities. The bill, which goes to the House of Representatives, require broker-dealers who handle only municipal securities to register with the Securities and Exchange Commission for the first time.

Forty of the nation's business leaders attending a White House-sponsored conference on inflation strongly expressed support today for the Administration's call for balanced budgets and cuts in Federal spending.
Prices on the Amex continued to decline yesterday but those in the over-the-counter market closed mixed as traders appeared to be doing considerable short covering.

Mary Louise Smith says she is a moderate-conservative. But she supports the equal rights amendment, was one of the co-conveners of Iowa's first women's political caucus, has taken a liberal stand on abortion and is a member of Planned Parenthood.
Consumers Union said yesterday that it had rated the Firestone 500 Steel Belt tire "not acceptable" because the treads of seven of nine samples had separated in high-speed durability tests.
President Ford offered conditional amnesty today to thousands of Vietnam era draft evaders and military deserters who agree to work for up to two years in public service jobs.

State Senator Roy M. Goodman, Republican of Manhattan, said yesterday that greater control must be exercised over juvenile offenders in view of the weekend murder of a taxi driver by two teenagers who had previous police records.

Any time between 1358 and 1416 it was a pretty good thing to be Jean, Duke of Berry. He was never actually King of France; but he was successively the son, the brother and the uncle of the man on whose desk the buck stopped. At the age of 18 he was in control of one-third of the country.

Recent suggestions that the cost of environmental reforms might be contributing significantly to inflation were emphatically contradicted without dissent here today at a Federal conference on resources, the environment and inflation.

Saudi Arabia, long the chief proponent of lower crude-oil prices among the petroleumexporting nations, is raising her price--arid may have already raised it-at the very time that she has been advocating price reduction.
President Ford announced today the appointment of Gen. Alexander M. Haig Jr., the White House chief of staff, as Supreme Allied Commander in Europe.

Reductions in fuel, oil and copper prices were offset, yesterday by a warning from the Agriculture Department that candy bar prices in vending machines are excepted to be lifted 'by 5 cents to 20 cents each.

The White House chief of staff, Gen, Alexander M. Haig Jr., after being advised of the "alarming state" of Richard M.. Nixon's health, was reliably reported today to have persuaded President Ford to reverse his publicly stated position and grant an immediate pardon to the former President.

Ten members of a gang known as "the Bronx robbery squad" have been arrested by detectives of the Police Department's Bronx robbery squad and charged with a series of armed robberies in the Bronx, District Attorney Mario Merola said yesterday.

The unconditional preventive pardon that President Ford extended to Richard Nixon is not really relevant to the conditional, half-hearted, half-punitive amnesty Mr. Ford has offered to Vietnam war draft evaders and deserters. The Nixon pardon makes the amnesty plan look worse; but it does not really make it worse.

Lawrence V. Kelly, an opera impresario, died yesterday of cancer in Kansas City, Mo. He was 46 years old. With a background that involved music and business, Mr. Kelly found an outlet for his combined talents in opera management.

The International Finance Corporation, the World Bank subsidiary that invests in productive enterprises in less developed countries, reported today a record total of $203.4-million of investments in the fiscal year ended June 30.

HYDERABAD, India--In the minds of many Westerners Islam is identified with Arabs and the Middle East. Actually, the Moslem world stretches from Morocco to the southern Philippines, and its numerical center of gravity is here on the Indian subcontinent.
Charles C. Carena, executives Director of the New Jersey Lottery, will go to Washington this week to discuss legal questions Federal officials have raised about state lotteries.
