" How many bats you need?" Bill Kane, the Yankees' traveling secretary, asked Elliott Maddox yesterday. "Enough for the playoffs and World Series," Maddox answered.

Steel production for the week ended Sept. 14 rose by 2.2 per tent to 2,731,000 tons, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday. This raised the weekly production index to 111.9, which compared with the 109.6 of a week ago when output totaled 2,673,000 tons.
To prevent depletion of United States agricultural supplies, large exports of wheat and certain other products must be reported daily to the United States Government beginning this week.

They are a strange bunch, these New York Yankees. They were 50-to-1 shots when the baseball season began. They go to work every day in somebody else's park. They play for a manager who was dismissed at the height of a pennant race in Pittsburgh last September, and who was second choice in New York after Ralph Houk left and Dick Williams escaped. And half of them languished someplace else last season without distinction.
India is prepared to give assurances that no nuclear fuel obtained from the United States will be used for conducting atomic explosions, a spokesman for the Atomic Energy Commission said today.

As Supreme Allied Commander in Europe, Gen. Alexander M. Haig Jr. will assume responsibilities that are more extensive geographically and more complex militarily than those of any national commanders in the, North Atlantic Treaty Organization.

Classrooms were reported full today as Springfield elementary schools began as integration program requiring the busing of both white and black children. Busing had been fought by local officials for nine years,
Senator Harrison A. Williams Jr. announced today that he had introduced legislation to make the practice of dogfighting a Federal crime.
A late technical recovery yesterday ended the stock market's five-session losing streak and stocks finished slightly higher in the heaviest turnover in more than three months.

New Jersey has become the first state to adopt its own official symbol for the 1976 Bicentennial celebration. The design won out over four other finalist entries submitted to readers of the state's newspapers in a special referendum sponsored by the New Jersey Bicentennial Commission.

Even today, a Monday when men and boys are supposed to be back at their sober pursuits, the unmistakable boom of a shotgun can be heard once or twice an hour from the vicinity of Carlskin Spring, up on Weber Mountain.

Contract talks between the United Automobile Workers and the American Motors Corporation broke off today and 15,000 U.A.W. members went on strike. Talks adjourned after an allnight bargaining session.
MOOSE, Wyo. -- To one who has done most of his trout fishing on Eastern streams, Wyoming's Snake River is awesome.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 16--President Ford offered conditional amnesty today to thousands of Vietnam era draft evaders and military deserters who agree to work for up to two years in public service jobs.

At a preliminary hearing here today, Superior Court Judge Charles A. Rizzi found probable cause to believe that the overseer of a migrant-labor crew committed atrocious assault and battery on Assemblyman Byron M. Baer, Bergen County Democrat, and Alex Morisey, executive director of the Farm Workers Corporation of New Jersey.

The State Environmental Protection Department estimated today that it would cost $12.2billion to pay for a thorough program of water pollution control through 1990. The estimate was revised sharply upward from last year when the department said it would cost $3.5-billion to finance the state's needs.

Sir John Montague Brocklebank, former board chairman of Cunard Steamship Company and who at one time ran a million-ton shipping group with 80 ships, died last Friday at his home in Malta.He was 59 years old.

The strike of Legal Aid Society staff lawyers ended its sixth day with both management and the union unable to agree on what form further negotiations would take. The strikers, members of the Association of Legal Aid Attorneys for the City of New York, the bargaining agent that represents 567 staff lawyers, continued to picket courthouses. But Justice David Ross, citywide administrative judge, said the courts were maintaining "a normal rate of productivity."

The New York State Controller, Arthur Levitt, said that New York City's Health and Hospitals Corporation was continuing to lose millions of dollars by failing to administer properly its contracts with affiliated voluntary hospitals.

The series that Canadians are calling Super Summit II starts tonight at Quebec City with Team Canada, composed of World Hockey Association players, facing the Soviet Union. All eight games in the series-four in Canada, four in the U.S.S.R.-will be televised here on one-hour delayed tape over Channel 13. Tonight's game will be shown at 9 o'clock.

A Federal grand jury indicted two present Mercer County officials and a former one today on charges of extorting $31,346 from contractors since 1968.

Four persons were killed in a wave of bombings and other terrorist acts today, the 19th anniversary of the coup that overthrew President Juan Domingo Peron in 1955.
Anatoly Karpov and Viktor Korchnoi agreed to a draw here tonight in the first game of their chess match to decide the challenger-or the successorto Bobby Fischer, the world champion.

Superior Court Judge W. Thomas McGann today ruled that state troopers providing security at the trial of nine men linked to organized crime ap-, pear in plainclothes rather in uniform.

The postponement of the Muhammad Ali-George Foreman heavyweight championship fight yesterday had no immediate effect on the sale of tickets at the metropolitan area closed-circuit television outlets, a spot check revealed.
Little signs of their slow growth as an expansion team were evident today as the New York Islanders - starting year No. 3 -- opened their hockey training camp here for the 1974-75 season.

"I still think I can lick any light-heavyweight in the world, but it's too much of a mental thing to fight the World Boxing Association and the World Boxing Council, too," said Foster, who is 34 years old.

New York is not all bad news. Even as the Franklin Savings Bank prepares to demolish its fine stone palazzo in an act of real estate vandalism that diminishes an already tarnished neighborhood, the McGraw-Hill Building farther along West 42d Street will be saved.
It was Courageous in another rout today of Southern Cross, the challenger for the America's Cup, on an afternoon that left no excuses.

Premier Bulent Ecevit said today he would resign in the next few days. A source close to the Premier described the resignation plan as a move to hold an early election to capitalize on the success of his policy of intervention in Cyprus.

George Foreman suffered a freakish cut over his right eye during a sparring session this afternoon, forcing the Government to postpone late tonight the heavyweight championship fight against Muhammad Ali scheduled for Sept. 25 here.

Some 50 officials of the Mozambique Liberation Front flew here today from Dar es Salaam to take over the reins of power from the Portuguese authorities.

Yields declined sharply on Treasury bills auctioned today in both the 91-day and 180-day maturities.

President Ford tonight publicly declared his support for the clandestine use of the Central Intelligence Agency "to help implement foreign policy and protect national security," but he denied that the C.I.A. had been involved in the Chilean coup d'etat last year.

Rogers C. B. Morton, the Secretary of the Interior, said today that the Federall Government might have to keep price controls on domestic crude oil for "two years for more" because of the danger that the international oil cartel would drive up a wholly unregulated price.

The fatal shooting of a 14year-old Brownsville boy by a police officer who had been called to check out a reported burglary in the Brooklyn neighborhood late Sunday evening was under investigation by the Brooklyn District Attorney's office yesterday.

Becker Junior College in Leicester have agreed to merge by next July. According to their presidents, Lloyd Van Bushkirk of Becker and Henry C. Borger of Leicester, it will be several years before any major changes take place.

Expectation turned to resignation here today for hundreds of Australians who came half way around the world in the hope of seeing Southern Cross win the America's Cup. It now appears they won't see their challenger win anything.

A 28-year-old mental patient who had been placed in isolation after setting fire in his hospital room set a second fire and then fell to his death from a fifth-story window at Bronx State Hospital yesterday.
J. William H. Mencke, who retired 12 years ago as manager of operations of the Getty Oil Company here, died yesterday at Overlook Hospital, Summity N. J. He was 78 years old.

The Federal Advisory Council, a group of leading private bankers that advises the Federal Reserve Board, issued today a set of guidelines to govern bank lending at a time of tight money such as the present.
With the temperature in the low 50's, the Montreal Expos gave the New York Mets a cold welcome tonight by topping them, 3-2, in the opener of a double-header.

M. W. Armistead 3d, president of Landmark Commucations, Inc., Norfolk, Va,, was installed today as president of the Southern Newspaper Publishers Association during its convention here.

Societe Framatome, the French licensee of the Westinghouse Electric Corporation, will take part in the construction of two nuclear power plants in Belgium, estimated to cost well over $100-million.

Edward Quinn Field, a former vice president of the Insurance Company of North America died Saturday in Hartford where he was visiting relatives, apparently of a heart attack. He was 68 years old and lived at 405 Edgewood Avenue Westfield, N. J.

This is done according to Islamic principles of slaughter - with a sharp knife, the chicken's head pointing toward Mecca, and while the participants repeat the words "In the name of Allah, the great bone."

Investigation of a race-fixing scheme at Pocono Downs resulted today in the suspension of five jockeys and a trainer indefinitely from all state racing activities.

Summit High School, nestled in the rolling hills of New Jersey's Watchung Mountains, sends athletes to major colleges and then on to professional leagues with surprising consistency. In his 18 seasons as head coach, Howard Anderson has found some talented football players.

A municipal court today imposed 15day prison terms and fines on four artists and a photographer friend on charges of petty hooliganism for resisting bands of vigilantes who broke up an outdoor nonconformist art show yesterday.
With sheriffs deputies assuring protection against violence in a protest over textbooks, public school authorities announced today that classes would resume here tomorrow after a two-day suspension.

State Attorney General William F. Hyland said today that his office had reopened an investigation into alleged criminal fraud involving the financing of former Gov. William T. Cahill's 1969 Republican gubernatorial campaign.

Governor Byrne signed a bill today appropriating $12-million to continue the safe arid clean neighborhoods program in 24 cities and towns in New Jersey. The program, begun last year, enables cities to upgrade certain municipal services ard make neighborhood improvements.

Jim Barr's seven-hit pitching and home runs by Bobby Bonds' and GaryThomasson led the San Francisco Giants to a 4-2 victory over the Atlanta Braves today.

The agenda of the 29th General Assembly of the United Nations contains a record total of 113 items. Overlapping programs in high schools and colleges are wasting the time of many students as well as often boring them, the State Board of Regents has declared in a new policy statement.

This fall there will be a traffic jam on Broadway. Almost all the theaters are booked-with new shows or with holdovers from last season. "It's in unusual phenomenon," said a representative of the League of New York Theaters.

Alan Bond, the muchcriticized owner of Southern Cross, became a model of graciousness tonight as he congratulated the men of Courageous for a "tremendous effort" in their defense of the America's Cup.
Julie Nixon Eisenhower, the former President's younger daughter, said here yesterday that her father may soon be entering a hospital for treatment 'of the flare-up of his chronic phlebitis.

" I became involved with the Spinners about a year ago," said Colleen Bingham, as she sat at a rickety card table in the back room of the Shelburne Spinners' little factory. "I saw them demonstrating at a fair," she continued.
A world championship for 12-Meter yachts was an-. nounced tonight by Alan Bond, whose America's Cup challenger, Southern Cross, was routed by Courageous.
The School Board here has rescinded a resolution requiring weekly reports from the special counsel investigating allegations of misconduct the District Superintendent.

Foreign Minister Abdelaziz Bouteflika of Algeria yesterday won unanimous election as president of the 29th General Assembly of the United Nation and, in a militant acceptance speech at the opening session, called for self-determination of the Palestinian people. Without mentioning Israel by name, he said optimism about the Middle East was not warranted as long as "the conquered territories have not been returned." [Page 1, Column 2-3.
Japan has arranged to borrow $1-billion from a major Middle East oilproducing nation, believed to be Saudi Arabia, to cover her soaring oil import costs, it was reported here today.

Claudia Morgan, an actress who appeared in starring and prominently featured roles in more than three dozen Broadway plays, including-' The Man Who Came to Dinner" and '"Ten Little Indians," died yesterday. She was 62 years old and lived at 50 East 83d Street.

The Greek Art Theater has leased for 10 years the old Cafe Society at 1 Sheridan Square for the presentation in English of ancient and modern Greek plays, it has been announced by George Arkas, executive director of the theater group.

The heart of President Ford's message to the United Nations General Assembly was familiar but timely: all 138 member nations are part of a world whose -high degree of interdependence is dramatized by the food and energy crises-problems that can be resolved by international cooperation or "made unmanageable on the basis of confrontation."

Jordan Brown, a New York ad man, opened a "nobounce" checking account here two years ago with the First National City Bank. It permits him to write checkswithin specified limits-eyen it he does not have the funds in his account to cover them.

President Ford, in his first address to the United Nations, urged the adoption of a "global strategy for food and energy." He pledged American cooperation with a proposed worldwide system of food reserves and announced that the United States this year will increase funds for food shipments to needy nations. Mr. Ford also called upon the oil-producing nations to define their policy without imposing unacceptable burdens on the international monetary and trade system. [1:8.]

The American Telephone and Telegraph Company reported yesterday records in its operating revenues for the third fiscal quarter as well as in both operating revenues and net income for the 12 months ended Aug. 31.

The greatest problem in the National Hockey League," expounded Brad Park, the New York Rangers' captain, "is a shortage of good defensemen. But not here." Brad Park, during a break in practice at Kitchener, Ontario, said Rangers were rich in defensemen this year.

Bidding two-suited hands is always a problem when the opponents have opened the bidding, since the owner, of the two-suiter cannot rely on having two chances to bid at a low level. Many ingenious conventions have been devised to solve this problem, and the most famous of them is the unusual no-trump.
The Senate passed today a $33billion appropriation bill that includes provisions to restrict Federal funds for abortions and for school busing.
Gulf and Western Industries, In., moved yesterday to solidify its hold on the Brown Company, in which it already has a majority interest, by exercising its warrants to purchase additional shares.

What appeared to be an extreme right-wing organization under the name Group for the Defense of Europe claimed responsibility today for the grenade attack on a Paris drugstore Sunday in which two people were killed and 25 injured.
A warning to breeders of giant schnauzers has been issued by Friedrich Machauer of Wiesenstal, West Germany, who was at Ravenna, Ohio, to judge the Giant Schnauzer
You are the..President's press secretary. You are privy to a secret which, if revealed, would force the President into premature action. A reporter with a small piece of the secret asks you about it.
Art dealers along Madison Avenue between 57th and 75th Streets, the heart of New York's gallery center, said yesterday that there had been a rash of burglaries of art objects in recent weeks.

In his first public appearance since he suffered an accidental cut over his right eye on Monday, George Foreman said today that only he would decide when he would be well enough to defend his world heavyweight boxing title against Muhammad All. George Foreman at news session in N'Sele, Zaire.
Hank Aaron said good-bye to San Francisco with his 732d career homer and a run-scoring single today in leading the Atlanta Braves to a 4-2 victory over the Giants.

Caught in the squeeze between an estimated total of 380,000 free tickets and only 20,000 seats, thousands of ticketholders were turned away from last night's appearance of the Rev. Sun Myung Moon at Madison Square Garden, while the others led a stampede to hear the man many regard as the Messiah.

MOOSE, Wyo.--Inside the tipi's towering, slanting cone the brilliant midafternoon sunlight was' diffused and softened by the white canvas, creating a gloaming fit for talk and relaxation. Reginald and Gladys Laubin outside tipi in.Moose, Wyo.

Calvin Jackson, who is said by the 'police to have "implicated himself" in the murder of at least nine. women, was arrested in Manhattan 10 months ago on felonious robbery and burglary charges that could have sent him to prison for 15 years, an examination of court records disclosed yesterday.
The Senate passed and sent to the House today legislation that gives coastal states a share of Federal offshore oil revenue. The vote was 64 to 23.

The Federal Energy Administration is expected to adopt within the next day or two, a lobbying regulation under which the names of all those seeking to influence policy in meetings with top officials would be logged and made public.
The Indian Jews of Cochin concluded a melancholy observance of the New Year today. Their community has dwindled. Their young men have emigrated and their young women are without husbands.

Sanitation police officers issued summonses yesterday to five followers of the Rev. Sun Myung Moon for putting up posters on public property - specifically, the Queens Boulevard overpass over the Long Island Rail Road yards at Skillman Avenue in Long Island City, Queens.
Doris Day, the actress, won a $22-million judgment today against a lawyer she had accused of defrauding her and her late husband, Martin Melcher, of millions of dollars.

An overflow crowd filled Madison Square Garden last night and the police said thousands were turned away from the 20,000-seat amphitheatre as the Rev. Sun Myung Moon appeared in the culmination of his huge promotion campaign.
Britons will elect a new House of Commons Oct. 10, the, Government announced today. It will be the first time in 50 years that two general elections have been held in a year.

American and Soviet negotiators today resumed their talks on the limitation of strategic arms after a sixmonth recess. They have been instructed to reach a comprehensive accord in 1975 to last for an initial period of 10 years.

Alice Higgins, a writer for Sports Illustrated magazine for more than 18 years who earlier had been with Life magazine, died yesterday after a long illness at New York Hospital. She was 50 years old and lived in this city, Alice Higgins
In 1848 the very first serious suggestion for the establishment in London of a British National Theater was put forward by a London publisher, Effingham Wilson.

Police units stood outside buildings of the University of Buenos Aires today to back the Government appointment of a conservative interim rector who is expected to end the left-wing leadership in Argentina's most important university,
Congress should keep its hands off the Food and Drug Administration's plans to regulate the vitamin industry, Alexander M. Schmidt, the Commissioner of Food and Drugs, said today. At the same time,

A failure in Viktor Korchnoi's analytical preparation resulted in his smashing defeat at the hands of Anatoly Karpov in the second game of their final Candidates Match here in the House of Unions tonight.

Inflation has been having a devastatingg impact" on the poor, according to a number of experts, and this calls for more Government spending to improve welfare grants and unemployment insurance or to create jobs.

In the early morning darkness of Aug. 9, the bedside telephone rang in the Washington, D. C., apartment of Representative Samuel L. Devine, and he groped for the receiver. Representative Samuel L. Devine, left, during campaign visit to the Ohio Packing Company in Columbus. Frances Ryan, Democrat, is opposing Mr. Devine.

The Federal Trade Commission said today it would attempt to force the automobile companies to base fuel economy claims on tests that would enable consumers to compare their cars with other models and to take into consideration their own driving habits.
Ford Administration officials say the Pentagon is negotiating an agreement for cash sales of communications and other equipment to Iran, with the deal expected to total at least $4-billion.

Although he says his back is still sore, Joe Namath took his usual turns at quarterback in practice yesterday and the Jet's head coach, Charley Winner, still has him scheduled to start in Chicago on Sunday.

India told the International Atomic Energy Agency here today that she was "totally opposed to the development of nuclear weapons" but that she reserved the right to pursue an independent nuclear-research policy.
The Xerox Corporation announced today that 'it was postponing construction of its planned headquarters building here in an economy move.

Calvin Jackson, who is said by the police to have "implicated himself" in the murder of at least nine women, was arrested in Manhattan 10 months ago on felonious robbery and burglary charges that could have sent him to prison for 15 years, an examination of court records disclosed yesterday.
Team Canada's 3-3 tie with the Soviet national hockey team last night at Quebec City was, as Samuel Johnson said of second marriages, a triumph of hope over experience.

A bearded young man with shoulder-length black hair, sunglasses, a floppy white hat and a corncob pipe clenched in his teeth climbed the steps of City Hall yesterday and walked unnoticed past policemen and city employes. The United States Government has sent a legal official to West Berlin to investigate the response by the United States Army to a lawsuit charging its intelligence agents with illegal surveillance of American citizens.

A Soviet newspaper charged today that former Ambassador Foy D. Kohler and elements of the United States press were trying "to discredit in advance" the joint Soviet-American space launching set for next July by citing difficulties in the Soviet space program.

The General Atomic Company announced yesterday at San Diego, that the Southwestern Public Service Company was planning to take the lead in construction of the nation's first nuclear power plant that would use a gas-cooled breeder reactor.

The House Ways and Means Committee approved procedures today that would win tax advantages for. bank holding companies required under a 1970 law to divest either their bank or their controlled corporations.

The white boycott of newly integrated public schools in Boston eased for a second day today as attendance inched higher. Robert Armstead of Boston's Technical Patrol Force, which guarded busloads of students, shared a light moment yesterday with residents of South Boston.

Two of the country's great orchestras, the Boston Symphony and the Philadelphia, have decided to desert Avery Fisher Hall at Lincoln Center and return to Carnegie Hall. They will give all their New York City concerts in the 83-year-old hall on West 57th Street, beginning with the 1975-76 season.
Dr. Michele A. R. Raia, a retired surgeon who practiced in Brooklyn, died Tuesday at Coney Island Hospital. He was 79 years old and lived at 1720 West 11th Street.

Federal officials said today the future of the Franklin National Bank is still unsettled, although several possibilities are under discussion, The Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, one of three Federal agencies working on the Franklin situation,

The director general of the International Air Transport Association predicted today that there would be further airline fare increases this year. Knut Hanmarskjold said fastrising fuel prices and worldwide inflation already had caused "unprecedented major fare increases,

Subscription prices for the Metropolitan Opera's Saturday matinee series of Wagner's four "Ring" operas this season will range from a top of $140 for choice Orchestra and Grand Tier seats to $30 for Family Circle seats.

A failure in Viktor Korchnoi's analytical preparation resulted in his smashing defeat at the hands of Anatoly Karpov in the second game of their final Candidates Match here in the House of Unions tonight.

The Towers Nursing Home, for many years the target of investigations and allegations of scandal, has been declared ineligible for Medicaid because of violations of the Federal firesafety code. The Towers Nursing Home at 106th Street and Central Park West
Secretary of State Kissinger delivers tomorrow his long-expected defense of efforts by the Nixon and Ford Administrations to improve relations with the Soviet Union.

Sweden's parliamentary ombudsman, Bertil Wennergren, strolled with mild interest yesterday through that persistent New York City scene-a horde of demonstrators near the United Nations headquarters-and observed that things were about the same at home. A panel of three Federal judges has upheld a lowercourt ruling approving construction of a 14-mile stretch of Route 7 between Danbury and New Milford in Connecticut. The Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit ruled in a 2-1 decision that the Federal funds involved in the $34,5-million project were not sufficient to warrant Federal action.
Martin B. Steinthal, a retired manufacturer of aviation safety gear, died Tuesday in his home at 812 Park Avenue. He was 66 years old.

James J. Flood, who was vice president and director of marketing for the J. Walter Thompson Company, the advertising agency, at his retirement in 1965, died Tuesday at South Nassau Community Hospital in Oceanside, L.I. He was 73 years old and lived at 793 East Carl Avenue, Baldwin, L.I.
Team Canada's 3-3 tie with' the Soviet national hockey team last night at Quebec City was, as Samuel Johnson said of second marriages, a triumph, of' hope over experience.

The New York Philharmonic, seeming none the worse for its recent 30,000mile, five-week tour of New Zealand, Australia and Japan, opened its 133d season here with its traditional gala benefit concert. Together with a preconcert dinner party, it benefited the PhilharmonicSymphony Society of New York by $61,000.

With commendable perseverance, a bipartisan majority of the Senate plans a fourth attempt today to break a technical filibuster to prevent establishment of a Federal consumer advocacy agency. This minimal step toward protection of consumer interests has already been approved overwhelmingly in the House, and opposition to it has eroded significantly even in the Senate, where closure was defeated last month by only three votes.

Haughton was the name of the game at thedraw-yesterday for the Yonkers Trot, which will have its 20th running at Yonkers Raceway on Saturday night. Stanley Dancer and his wife, Rachel, reacting after she drew'Post Position No. 8 for Nevele Diamond. Dancer will be driving the horse in the Yonkers Trot Saturday night.
Union employes at Woodlawn Cemetery in the Bronx voted yesterday to authorize their negotiating committee to call a strike, if necessary, in an effort to get wage and benefit improvements.

The New York IsYork Islanders' team physician, Dr. Jeffrey Minkoff, remembers well the team's disastrous first season three years ago. "I walked in in the middle of what I considered a catastrophe," said the physician who was at the hockey training camp here early this.week to check out the players.

President Ford called on all countries of the world today to join' in a "global strategy for food and energy." Mayor Beame formed an interagency economic office yesterday to relocate merchants and manufacturers displaced by urban renewal and other government projects.
The 933 men who produced asbestos insulation at a Paterson, N. J., plant in the nineteenforties came home each day from the dusty factory covered with asbestos fibers.

The end of the grim vigil at the French Embassy in The Hague cannot take the eyes of the world off the three Japanese terrorists who held 12 persons, including French Ambassador Jacques Senard, captive--nine of them for four interminable days. The fact that all the hostages have now been released physically unhurt hardly minimizes this latest criminal act by international outlaws.
The grim picture in the homebuilding sector of the nation's economy worsened further in August, the Commerce Department reported today.

A 30-year-old furrier was fatally wounded Tuesday night by a gunman who had commandeered an elevator in a building at Seventh Avenue and 28th Street and was systematically robbing passengers as they stepped into the car.

The Senate put off until tomorrow action that had been scheduled for today on legislation renewing the Export-Import Bank. The delay was arranged as key Senators worked out a compromise that would reduce the amount of money the bank would be authorized to extend over a four-year period from $30-billion to $25-billion.

When Billy Haughton drove in the first Adios Stake at The Meadows near Washington, Pa., he and his small son, Peter, stayed with Delvin and Mary Lib Miller at Meadow Lands Farm nearby.
Oren Lee Staley, president of the Natonal Farmers Organization, said last night that nearly $1-million in commitments were phoned to the rup's offices here yesterday.
President Ford has submitted a list of 22 names of holdover nominations made by President Nixon and has asked the Senate to confirm the choices.

Clicking projectors, spinning reels, glaring lamps and quiet sound booths line the Media Equipment Resource Center at 4 Rivington Street on the Lower East Side, a panorama of splicing, snipping, screening, filming, recording, and synchronizing, it is a place were qualified New York residents and groups borrow film, videotape and sound equipment free of charge.

The financially troubled National Farmers Organization today agreed to cease sales of securities and notes in exchange for the postponement of a Federal lawsuit charging it with fraudulent sales and dealings.
Hurricane Fifi struck a powerful side blow at the tiny Swan Islands in the northwestern Caribbean today and moved toward the northern coast of Honduras.

Portugal, which has just borrowed $150-million in the Eurodollar market, faces serious economic problems arising from independence for her African territories, 30 per cent-plus inflation and the possible return of her workers abroad and colonials, an authoritative survey showed today. Haggling over prices at a market in Cascais. Portugal is faced with a high inflation rate and dislocations in its labor force if colonials go to the homeland.
Medical experts testified today that the use of oral antidiabetic drugs was increasing in the United States despite studies that seriously questioned their safety and effectiveness.

Governor Byrne and the Democratic leadership in both houses of the State Legislature were reported tonight to have reached agreement on a measure that would extend the public financing of gubernatorial elections to the major parties' primaries.
Fred Gomez Carrasco was killed with his own gun during an escape attempt from the Texas State. Prison, according to a ballistics report presented to the Walker County, grand jury yesterday.

The nation's soaring oil-import bill and other flows of money associated with the international oil situation sent the United States's "basic" balance of payments into a deficit of $2.7billion in the second quarter, the Commerce Department reported today.

Three self-ordained ministers, leading a protest over the use of some public school textbooks, were arrested here today for defying a court order to end mass demonstrations at school headquarters.

The great luxury ship France is being pulled out of service immediately, the French Line announced here tonight. A final trans-Atlantic round trip and two gala cruises that were to have taken place before the planned retirement date of Oct. 25 have been canceled.

Rob Davis hit Greg Latta with a 21-yard touchdown pass with 17 seconds remaining tonight to give the Florida Blazers a 24-21 victory over the Philadelphia Bells in a World Football League game.

President Ford urged the Senate today to uphold his decision to defer a pay increase for Federal employes, saying it would be a vital anti-inflation action.
The Shah of Iran, who makes no secret of his intention to transform this country Into a world power, left here today on the most extensive tour he has ever made of nations to the east of his kingdom.

The City Health Department has released the names of 20 more restaurants and food No stores cited as violators of the Health Code after their owners failed to correct infractions that persisted through two inspections.

Bill Curry, president of the National Football League Players' Association and twice an All-Pro, was activated by the Los Angeles Rams yesterday. The 235pound center recently was released by the Houston Oilers.

The delegates discussing education at the two-day anti-inflation conference that starts this morning at the Department of Health, Education and Welfare in Washington can be expected to plead that their funds be left untouched by any cutbacks made to combat inflation.

Governor,Byrne and the Democratic leadership in both houses of the State Legislature were reported tonight to have reached agreement on a measure that would extend the public financing of gubernatorial elections to the major parties' primaries.

Four Japanese terrorists turned themselves over to Palestinian guerrillas here today and relinquished $300,000 received for the release of hostages held in a four-day occupation of the French Embassy in the Netherlands.

Hundreds of Brownsville residents marched silently yesterday afternoon to the funeral home where Claude Reese Jr., the 14-year-old who was killed Sunday by a policeman's bullet, lay in a coffin. Edna Best, for many years a popular actress on the London stage died today in a Geneva clinic She was 74 years old. Her most famous part was as Tessa in the dramatized version of Margaret Kennedy's "The Constant Nymph," produced here in 1926 with first Noel Coward and later Sir John Gielgud playing opposite her. The state's Welfare Inspector General, William F. Meyers, charged yesterday that there was a "serious problem of nonpayment of rent by welfare recipients" here and that the Beame Administration was ignoring the matter.

The Public Service Electric and Gas Company said yesterday it planned to cut $688million from its construction budget through 1978. This would reduce planned outlays to $1.9-billion over the 1974-1978 period.

The largest trifecta payoff in Chicago history, $53,687, was posted at Hawthorne today when Soft Melody, Magic Fool and Feisty Boy finished one-two-three in the ninth race.

Carey, the Democratic candidate for Governor, offering him a copy of the 1974 state Republican platform and assuring him "there was absolutely no need to use campaign trickery in an attempt to get" it.

A Soviet editor advised the Arab counties, today that the only way to win concessions from Israel was by close cooperation with Moscow and remind. ed the Arabs of the effective. ness of their oil embargo last winter against the West.

Brenda Vaccaro stars in "The Streets of San Francisco," tonight at 9 on Channel 7.
The stock market turned in a mixed performance in light trading yesterday. as the Dow Jones. industrial average rose slightly, although declines outnumbered gains by a narrow margin.
John B. Martin, who had been on the staff of The City Record, the official journal of the City of New York, for some 61 years, died Tuesday in a nursing home in Newark Del. He was 84 years old.'

Officers of Knight Newspapers, Inc. and Ridder Publications, Inc., signed a merger agreement today. The merger was approved earlier in the day by the Knight Board of Directors at a meeting in Detroit and the Ridder Board at a meeting in St. Paul.
Four minority stockholders of The Village Voice, including the author Norman Mailer, filed a suit yesterday seeking $3-million in damages because of the sale of The Voice to New York magazine.

The State Court of Appeals ruled yesterday that Norman D. Archer, a former assistant Queens district attorney, could be tried on state charges similar to those on which he was convicted by a Federal jury 20 months ago.

A surging throng of some 600 Greek sympathizers seeking to bring their complaints on United States policy in Cyprus within earshot of President Ford-who spoke to the General Assembly todayposed the major security problem for the scores of city policemen and Secret Servicemen deployed around the United Nations complex.

Without even attempting to anticipate the result of the current grand jury investigation into the fatal shooting of 14-year-old Claude Reese Jr. 'by a police officer on Sunday, it is fair to observe that the story has a profoundly depressing familiarity.

Joseph F. Mattice, the former Mayor of Asbury Park and for nearly 40 years the ruling power in the city's Democratic party, was charged yesterday in an 87-count indictment alleging a plot to control the Asbury Park Democratic committee. The indictment was announced in Trenton by Attorney General William F. Hyland, who said it also named a former Asbury Park building inspector, Theodore Griffin, 68 years old.

James Keogh, director of the United States Information Agency, said today that President Ford had called him to declare that there was "not a scintilla of truth" to a report that the President intended to dismiss him.
An Osaka textile company has failed in what is believed to be Japan's second largest postwar corporate bankruptcy.

State Attorney General William F. Hyland today recommended a six-year extension of New Jersey's wiretapping law, but with changes designed to minimize the abuse of privacy and insure "the civil rights of our citizens."

During the last few months the world food crisis has develped from what once seemed to be another exaggerated doomsday forecast to a reality A mother sitting with her child by a road in Cooch Behar in famine-stricken northeastern India yesterday.

There has been little response in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut in the last" two days to President Ford's conditional amnesty offer to Vietnamwar draft evaders and deserters. Nearly all of those who did call for information refused to give their names, and most of the calls came from women.
Ten of the 18 paintings seized by young vigilantes and plainclothesmen at a nonconformist art show last Sunday have been returned to the artists and their friends.

Barbara Keating, the Conservative party's candidate for the United States Senate, called yesterday for the adoption of a Constitutional amendment to ban forced busing for the purposes of racial integration.

Between inflation and budget cuts by Congress, the Defense Department finds itself more than $1l-billion short of funds to carry out its planned procurement of weapons and materials, Pentagon officials said today.

The Ford Administration, after rejecting a Pan American World Airways request for a $10.2million monthly Federal subsidy, announced today an alternative seven-part plan aimed at aiding the distressed airline. Transportation Secretary Claude S. Brinegar during his news conference in Washington yesterday.

In the wake of charges that private armies were being prepared in Lebanon for action against Palestinian guerrillas, the Government announced today that all licenses for the carrying of firearms by civilians had been canceled.

The University of Texas' coach, Darrell Royal, said today he had no comment on the dismissal of three football players despite a story in the student newspaper that the players were, suspected of smoking marijuana. "I have no comment," he said. "It was for disciplinary reasons. It is personal between me and the boys."
Nearby deliveries of wheat, corn and soybeans closed slightly lower or about unchanged yesterday on the Chicago Board of Trade. Some selling followed President Ford's speech at the United Nations.
The cost of feeding a family continued to rise here last Week as food prices, led by sugar and margarine, rose for the 11th consecutive week, according to the city's Department of Consumer Affairs.

The emotional and financial impact of inflation on the elderly, the poor, the handicapped and the young will be the focus of a two-day meeting starting tomorrow as one of the Ford Administration's anti - inflation conferences. '
Still another request has been made to delay the start of the Watergate cover-up conspiracy trial Oct. 1, this time citing the health of a potential witness - Richard M. Nixon.
A relatively rare operation to separate Siamese twins was completed in about eight hours today by a team of 23 doctors and nurses at Children's Hospital.

Net income of Levi Strauss Co. climbed to $13-million, of $1.20 a share, in the quarter ended Aug. 25 from $7.1-million or 65 cents a share, in the corn parable period last year. Sales in the quarter rose to $257million from $190.4-million in 1973,

Dr. I. Arthur Mirsky, a psychoanalyst who earned a wide reputation for his work in psychosomatic medicine and for his clinical studies of diabetes and peptic ulcers, died Monday at the hospital-of the University of California at Los Angeles School of Medicine. He was 67 years old.

President Ford, in his first address to the United Nations, urged the adoption of a "global strategy for food and energy." He pledged American cooperation with a proposed worldwide system of food reserves and announced that the United States this year will increase funds for food shipments to needy nations.
Conservative and Orthodox Jews last evening concluded their observance of Rosh haShanah, the start of the new Hebrew year, 5735:

Willis Reed made it official yesterday. While the Knick players shuttled between the medical office on the fifth floor of Madison Square Garden and St. Clare's Hospital for their physical examinations earlier in the day, Reed called an end to his 10-year National Basketball Association playing career. Willis Reed talking with Coach Red Holzman after the Knicks' center announced his retirement yesterday.
David Boren, a young Rhodes Scholar with two political upsets behind him, set out today to fulfill his pledge to sweep the Old Guard out of state politics.

PORTLAND, Maine The New England Association of Boxing Commissioners has agreed to recognize New England championships in 11 classes and to award championship belts to the winners in each class.

The French Ambassador to the Netherlands, who was held with eight other hostages by Japanese terrorists at his embassy here for four days, said today that he believed that the terrorists would have killed the captives if their demands had not been met. Jacques Senard, French Ambassador to The Hague, and his wife at their residence yesterday as he described the four-day ordeal.

Typographical Union No. 6 and the city's three major daily newspapers, The Daily News, The New York Post and The New York Times, were presented special certificates of appreciation yesterday, signed by Mayor Beame, for successfully negotiating an 11-year labor agreement.

A Government statement today said the creation of a civilian provisional Government now was unacceptable to the Armed Forces Committee of military officers and enlisted men, who ousted Emperor Haile Selassie after 44 years of feudal rule in this ancient African kingdom.
An Osaka textile company has failed in what is believed to be Japan's second largest postwar corporate bankruptcy.
Thousands of military deserters will be able to return to the United States and receive undesirable discharges without performing any alternative service, Government officials said today.

Mrs. Pierre Elliott Trudeau, the 26-year-old wife of the Canadian Prime Minister, said yesterday that "I'm under psychiatric care for severe emotional stress, but I'm recovering." Margaret Trudeau talking to newsmen yesterday

Mrs. Bela Kun, widow of the founder of the Communist-style Hungarian Republic of Councils' in 1919 and herself a lifelong fighter for Communism, died at the age of 84, the Hungarian news agency, M.T.I. reported yesterday.
Officers of Knight Newspapers, Inc. and Ridder Publications, Inc., signed a merger agreement today.
A Brazilian air force transport plane exploded and crashed on takeoff at Ponta Pora in southeast Brazil today, killing all but one of 23 officers aboard, an army spokesman said here;

The Vice President-designate, Nelson A. Rockefeller, has advised Congressional leaders that he will include trusts shared with other members of his family in a revised statement of his financial holdings. an aide said today.

If financial contributions were votes, Senator Jacob K. Javits, New York Republican-Liberal, and Senator Abraham A. Ribicoff, Connecticut Democrat, would virtually bury their opponents under a landslide, it was indicated by reports filed this week with the Senate.

The Montreal Expos scored a double knockout of Jon Matlack and Tom Seaver tonight, held the Mets scoreless over the last 17 innings and eliminated the New Yorkers from the divisional race by sweeping a twilight-night double-header 3-2 and 4-0.

William T. Conklin, deputy majority leader of the State Senate, today called the floating home mortgage interest rates proposed by the State Banking Department "a roller coaster ride for the homeowner."

Dr. Timothy Leary's son and two of his closest friends held a news conference here today to denounce Dr. Leary, who is now serving a 20-year jail sentence on various drug charges, for agreeing to testify against his former colleagues to the Federal authorities.
With the exception of two tenants on the second floor, the 19-story State Harlem Office Building has been empty since its official dedication on May 20.

Premier Bulent Ecevit, who became a hero to many Turks for having ordered the invasion of Cyprus in July, resigned today. He expects to form a caretaker Government and call early elections.

An overflow crowd filled Madison Square Garden last night and the police said thousands were turned away from the 20,000-seat amphitheatre as the Rev. Sun Myung Moon appeared in the culmination his huge promotion campaign.

Four Japanese terrorists turned themselves over to Palestinian guerrillas here today and relinquished $300,000 received. for the release of hostages held in a four-day occupation of the French Embassy in the Netherlands.

Governor Wilson, who until now had declined to comment on President Ford's decision to pardon former President Richard M. Nixon, said today that the pardon was "premature." Governor Wilson talking to a worker at the General Electric Company's plant in Schenectady during an upstate campaign swing yesterday.

Between inflation and budget cuts by Congress, the Defense Department finds itself more than $11-billion short of funds to carry out its planned procurement of weapons and materials, Pentagon officials said today.
Israeli gunners fired mortars at suspected Arab guerrilla concentrations in Lebanon today in what a military source described as- "routine preventive shelling."
Portugal's military Government banned the ultraright 'Portuguese National party today, raided and closed its! headquarters in Oporto and seized the records there.

The Philippine Supreme Court has upheld as constitutional the assumption of emergency powers by President Ferdinand E, Marcos two years ago.

Secretary of State Kissinger announced today that he and President Ford would personally brief five House and Senate leaders tomorrow on the scope of the Central Intelligence Agency's covert operations.
Billie Jean King used just 35 minutes to sweep to victory over Ingrid Bentzer of Sweden, 6-0, 6-0, today in the second round of a $50,000 tournament on the women's professional tennis tour.

CABARET One of the more successful cabarets opens its fall season this evening with a singer and a group that does comic sketches in a pleasant format at reasonable prices. The place is the Little Hippodrome, 227 East 56th Street (755-1820), which started out not long ago as a dinner theater.

A 60-year-old Bronx grocer who had been held up five times in the three years he has owned his store shot and killed an armed holdup man there yesterday morning with a licensed gun he had bought for self-protection.

Assemblyman Jesse Gray of Harlem, who was .defeated in the Democratic primary, started legal action yesterday to void the election on the ground that the "voting was permeated with fraud and irregularities."

Handle With Care set national and world records in winning the $45,558 Jugette today in Grand Circuit harness racing at the Delaware County Fairgrounds.

James J. Needham, chairman of the New York Stock Exchange, urged yesterday that the United States welcome foreign investment to help ease capital shortages. James J. They were in Washington for a Senate subcommittee hearing.
President Ford plans to campaign for Republican candidates in the Western states for several days next month and may take a swing through the South.
Wage increases averaging 16 cents an hour will become effective Monday for 900,000 hourly and salaried auto workers in the United States and Canada.

A television news-magazine that has been described by its guiding force as tabloidy and noisy"--and that will incorporate elements of the old comedy series, "Laugh-In" - has been scheduled by NBC-TV for a late Saturday nighttime slot at four-week intervals.

To the Editor: The public outcry following Mr. Ford's pardon has been even more appalling than the act itself. While I agree that his move was preemptive and potentially dangerous to our system of justice, the indignation must be examined in its myopia.
The Byrne administration's $300million transportation bond issue was approved by the State Senate this evening.

Kristina Young Wright, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Walter Alan Wright of Montclair and Monmouth Beach, N.J., was married yesterday morning to Thomas Coulter Viviano, son of Mr. and Mrs. Bartholomew Joseph Viviano of Plainfield, N.J.

ippines, Sept. 19 - Emmet James Kay, the American civilian pilot who was freed in Laos yesterday by the pro-Communist Pathet Lao, said today that he had been treated as "a very important person" during his 16 months of captivity.

Four top officers of Investors Funding Corporation of New York were released in $100,000 bond each today after they pleaded not guilty to charges that they had authorized $1.4 - million in bribes to try to win support for a $250-million high-rise project near the George Washington Bridge in Fort Lee.
The commodity spot market price index of foodstuff and industrial materials fell to 229.4 from 229.6 last week. The index compiled by the Bureau of Labor Statistics stood at 195.6 on Sept. 18, 1973.

Net income of Distillers Corporation-Seagrams, Ltd., rose to $26,016,000; or 75 cents a share, in the fourth fiscal quarter ended July 31 from $23,529,000, or 67 cents a share, in the period a year earlier, the company announced yesterday.

Puerto Rico's most wanted fugitive was trailed to a remote corner of the Bronx and captured yesterday. District Attorney Mario Merola said the detectives, assigned to his office, had arrested the fugitive, Antonio Iglesias, 29 years old, who broke out of the Rio Piedras state prison last November.
The House Ways and Means Committee reversed today an earlier decision and decided to permit investors in real estate ventures to keep the special tax advantages they have now.
Nearly one out of five Westchester shoppers who ask their butcher to grind a piece of top-quality beef are likely to get a cheaper grade of meat in return, according to a recent investigation here.

While President Ford and Secretary of State Kissinger conferred today with nine Congressional leaders over UnitedStates intelligence practices, two Senators introduced a bill to reform and broaden legislative control of the intelligence community.

Eight of this weekend's National 'Football League games are sold out and will be available for local television, the N.F.L. announced yesterday.

Norway told its partners in the 12-nation oil consumers group today that it could not give definite approval to the almost completed oil-sharing plan until the measure is debated in its Parliament next month.

Bache Co., Inc., the broker age firm, reported yesterday that it lost $1.02-million in the fiscal quarter ended July 31 although it showed a profit of $257,000, or 4 cents a share, for the year ended on that date.

Representative Bertram L. Podell was described by the prosecution at his bribery trial yesterday as "a United States Congressman who agreed to sell the influence of his office for money."

Short interest on the New York Stock Exchange for the month ended Sept. 13 decreased to 18,192,212 shares from 19,274,124. The exchange said the new figure was the lowest since Jan. 15 of this year when the short interest totaled 17,490,934 shares.

The National Labor Relations Board opens hearings in New York today inquiring into the mortality rate among player representatives in the National Football League. The player rep is the shop steward, the team's delegate to the sport's labor union, and he has a shorter, shakier life expectancy than the second lieutenant in a combat infantry outfit. There are 26 player reps.
Nearly 200 Portuguese soldiers were unexpectedly freed today by Frelimo, the Mozambique Libberation Front, which will soon assume control of this Portuguese territory.

Both corporate profits and the gross national product were revised downward today by the Commerce Department, largely because of the technical effect of the takeover by Saudi Arabia of 60 per cent of the ownership of Aramco, the oil-producing company, in that country.

Frightened by a series of murders on their block which came to light only after the recent arrest of a suspect, more than 200 residents of West 77th Street, opposite the American Museum of Natural History, met at their local-police station last night to ask why they had not been told of the murders as they occurred over the last two years so they could better protect themselves.

Suffering from the inflation-and-recession problem in an advanced form, Britain heads into its second general election this year with the prospect for stronger national leadership distinctly discouraging.

A bill to establish a city ombudsman was enthusiastically supported yesterday by a parade of witnesses at a city Council hearing yesterday. But it appeared that the legislation was in grave trouble within the Charter and Governmental Operations Committee, which conducted the hearing.

Governor Byrne vetoed today a bill permitting motorcyclists on the Garden State Parkway, but asked the New Jersey Highway Authority to develop a "reasonable trial period" for motorcycle use to determine its safety.

The politico-economic crisis in West Europe-marked by inflation, oil-payments deficits, rising unemployment, falling governments and a growing danger of social violence-has made concerted action by the Common Market's nine member countries both more difficult and more necessary. So far, the difficulties have prevailed.

Vice President-designate Nelson A. Rockefeller, saying he was acting to counter what he termed "incomplete and therefore misleading data" leaked to the press, reported today that his net worth and that of his wife totaled $62.5-million,

Either he has been conned by the C.I.A. into grossly misleading the American people and giving his approval to international gangsterism; or he did it on his own.

Almost as if by stealth, Congress is in the process of repealing around-the-year Daylight Saving Time. When the plan was adopted last fall, the principal argument was that it would save electricity-and therefore fuel. The same reasoning prompted its wartime introduction in this country and in Western Europe, where several countries made it a permanent arrangement.

Four Jewish scientists today voiced fears that a compromise package on Soviet emigration being worked out in Washington by Senator Henry M. Jackson might still leave the Kremlin free to block legitimate emigrants by using exaggerated definitions of national security.
Siamese twin girls successfully separated in a comflex operation were reported. doing extremely well today, but doctors were concerned about their emotional recovery.

State Education Commissioner Fred G. Burke decided today that a 10th-grade student who is practicing five hours a day to make the United States Women's Olympic figure skating team should not be required by local school officials to perform rigorous physical .education exercises as well.

A Federal crime-fighting agency, the Law Enforcement Assistance Administration, has quietly rehired its former chief, Donald Santarelli, who resigned earlier this year after criticizing President Nixon's handling of the Watergate scandal.

Tom Seaver, baseball's highest-paid pitcher, probably will do no more pitching for the New York Mets this season.

Killed were Perley Stoddard Sr., 47 years old; his wife, Joice Billie, 48; their son, Rick 16, all of Barnstead, N.H., and the pilot, Charles F. Nutting of Concord, N.H. All were burned beyond recognition, the police said.

Dr. Clarence A. Mills, a pioneer environmentalist who campaigned for an anti-smoke law, died Tuesday at the age of 81.

The Wilson campaign characterized Representative Hugh L. Carey as "ultraliberal" yesterday, denouncing the Democrat as "hysterical Hugh" and accusing him of appealing to the emotions and prejudices" of voters.

Pearl Halpern, who served from 1950 to 1965 as president of. Dress Makers Local 22, In international Ladies Garmernt d Workers Union, died yesterday at the Workmen's Circle Home d for the Aged in the Bronx. She o was 90 years old and lived at A 330 West 28th Street.
Four horses saddled by different trainers were drugged in recent races at Belmont Park, and racing investigators are known to be looking for a suspected fixer.

The Amritraj brothers split their singles matches today as India gained a 1-1 standoff with the Soviet Union on the opening day of their interzone Davis Cup tennis semifinal at Poona in western India.

Hooked rugs, those fuzzy fabric pictures of Staffordshire-like cocker spaniels, flowers in pots, Biblical lions and scenes of rural America, have, at long last, been resurrected from collectors' attics aNd museum storerooms for a major exhibition.

World sugar futures jumped the penny a pound limit yesterday in the three nearest deliveries, following some earlymorning selling. The upswing was attributed to some talk about labor unrest in Argentina and talk that Spain might have to import up to 200,000 tons of sugar.

Siamese twin girls separated Wednesday in a rare operation were reported today to be doing extremely well. The Senate Foreign Relations Committee has presented an adverse report on a proposal to extend United States jurisdiction over coastal fishing to two hundred miles, in flagrant violation of existing international law. The Senate would do well to abide by this committee's decision rather than that of the Commerce Committee, which has given the bill its support.

An appeals court ruled yesterday that the family of a migrant worker was entitled to compensation benefits for his automobile death on a Bridgeton farm. Imelda Marcos, wife of President Ferdinand E. Marcos, flew to Peking today to open a new era in relations with China. The President, meanwhile, stressed the need for a continued United States military presence in Asia.

Like hundreds of other young men in the country, StevenFord, the President's youngest son, has technically violated the law by failing to register with his local draft board on time. By law, he was required to report to his draft board not it later than 30 days after his 18th birthday.

LONDON-Six months after war was renewed last spring between Kurdish rebels in northern Iraq and the forces of the Arab government in Baghdad, fighting between the two has reached a new peak of violence. Paul D. Robinson, creator of the cartoon strip "Etta Kett," which appeared in 50 newspapers across the country more than 40 years, died Saturday at Mountainside Hospital in Montclair, N.J. He was 76 years old and lived at 14 Hillbury New Road, Essex Fells, N.J.

On a September day in 1862, near Antietam Creek in Maryland, 23,000 Americans died in the bloodiest battle of the Civil War. Many wars and casualties later, another battle is in progress to save this historic region from the new commercial sharpshooters-hamburger and pizza stands, purveyors of plastic rifles and fake MiniE balls,

Consumers are even less inclined to spend money now than they were in the trough of the 1970 recession, the Conference Board, a nonprofit business research organization, reported today. Further, the board said, consumer confidence in the economy has dipped slightly under the low of four years ago.

Rabbi Baruch Korff, who led a campaign to keep Mr, Nixon in office, announced here today the formation of an international "Nixon Justice Fund" to raise money to pay for the former President's legal expenses,

George Harrison, the former Beatle, has scheduled a seven-week concert tour of 27 cities starting Nov. 2, a spokesman said last night. Mr. Harrison has not given a concert since the one for Bangladesh in 1971 at Madison Square Garden.

A Torah scroll was carried yesterday under a wedding canopy lifted aloft by four members of the Sutton Place Synagogue as the 75-year old Orthodox congregation consecrated its groundbreaking for a new house of worship on East 51st Street.

Allen Jackson Greenougn, a lifelong railroader who presided over the Pennsylvania Railroad in its final years, died Saturday of cancer at St. Luke's Hospital. He was 69 years old and maintained homes in North Salem, N.Y., and County Clare, Ireland. Allen J. Greenougn

Egypt and Syria failed today in an effort to persuade King Hussein of Jordan and the Palestine Liberation Organization, the guerrilla organization, to adopt a common stand in readiness for United States attempts to achieve another round of military disengagement between Israel and the Arab countries.
The Justice Department says that the grand-jury system no longer serves to protect individuals against zealous prosecutors, but that it should not be abolished.

Alfred Bingham was. both happy and sad today. He learned that his son, Stephen M. Bingham, a 32-yearold lawyer charged with murder and under indictment in California on charges of smuggling a weapon to George Jackson, the black revolutionary author, was definitely alive.

Possibly because Count Basie has seemed to reduce the art of leading a big jazz band to the casual flick of a finger on the piano keyboard, he has rarely received as much recognition as he should for his contributions to jazz.
The veteran actor Walter Brennan, who won three Academy Awards, died Saturday night after a long battle with emphysema. He was 80 years old. Walter, Brennan

Emerson Fittipaldi won the Canadian Grand Prix today despite Mario Andretti and moved into a tie with Clay Regazzoni in the world driver standing with one race remaining. Emerson Fittipaldi after winning the Canadian Grand Prix at Mosport.

A 74-year-old Bronx man was killed yesterday evening on a walkway beside the Major Deegan Expressway when a driver in a northbound lane suffered a fatal heart attack and lost control of his car, the police reported.

The Soviet Nationals and Team Canada, whose international hockey series is now deadlocked at a victory for each team and one tie, move to Vancouver tomorrow night for their fourth and final game in Canada before the action shifts to Moscow. The Soviet team, powered by Aleksandr Yakushev, downed Team Canada, 8-5, yesterday in Winnipeg. The Canadians won the second game in Toronto, 4-1, and the series opener, in Quebec City, was a 3-3 tie.
Miller Barber cruised to a front-running threestroke victory today in the Ohio Kings Island open, while Jack Nicklaus failed to make a move in the tournament he figured to dominate.
Jill G. Altman and Lawrence Tarr were married yesterday, at noon at the Greentree Country Club in New Rochelle, N.Y., by Rabbi H. Leonard Poller of the Larchmont (N.Y.) Temple.

Robert Strauss, the genial chairman of the Democratic National Committee, hasn't called me yet to ask how the Democrats should go about winning the 1976 Presidential election. But if he does call, and I expect he will, it is comforting to know that I am ready with the answer.

For its new concert series at Barnard College, Dance Uptown is presenting many of its programs in an outdoor setting. Rain forced Saturday night's offerings into the Minor Latham Playhouse but the four choreographers represented provided an evening of interest.

When the Legislature authorized a $2 surcharge on the state's automobile insurance policyholders the other day, to cover the liabilities of the insolvent Gateway Insurance Company, it appears that it left some room for variables in the assessment.
All sorts of events are being taken these days to signify the death of the nineteen-sixties, and Joe Cocker's concert Saturday night at the Academy of Music works as well as any.

Annie Lander Green, a vice president and sales representative of the Adams Group, book publishers here, and an executive with publishing houses here for many years, died Thursday at her home in TV, Weathersfield Center, Vt.

Organized labor In New York State, whose support was split three ways in the primary election, appears to be rallying behind Representative Hugh L. Carey, the Democratic nominee for Governor, in increasingly substantial numbers.

The calls came in slowly at first. The voices were often tense and untrusting, revealing men and occasionally women who were hesitant to give real names or addresses and sometimes suspicious of the conditional amnesty offered by President Ford.
The Defense Department has begun a serious study of whether: to reduce the United States' large stockpile of nuclear weapons in Western Europe.
The Metropolitan Opera has agreed to a three-year plan to improve minority job opportunities in all categories, onstage and backstage.

Seven narcotics dealers, including two major French heroin smugglers, escaped from the Federal House of Detention on West Street here yesterday af- M ternoon in what authorities described as a well-planned, well-executed operation that suggested the complicity of prison personnel.

A group of nonconformist artists whose outdoor exhibition was broken up by trucks and bulldozers a week ago has decided against accepting official approval for a showing next Saturday, one of the artists, Oskar Rabin, said today.

In an apparent case of mistaken identity, a 22-year-old Brooklyn youth was shot in the eye by a police officer early yesterday as he sat in a car with three other unarmed companions in Washington Heights.
Maurice Strong, the Canadian head of the Nairobi-based United Nations Environment Program, arrived here tonight as a guest of China's new Environment Protection Office.

The mass cremation of bodies of people killed in the hurricane that swept Honduras was ordered by rescue officials to prevent epidemics. It was officially estimated that 5,000 people were killed and 60,000 made homeless. The Honduran Army said that 2,700 bodies had been burned or buried at Choloma, a commercial center in the banana zone, and 1,000 at the port of La Ceiba. [1:8.]

Nicolas Moldavan, a violist who played in the Lenox, Flonzaley, Stradivarius and Coolidge Quartets during a career of more than four decades in this country, died Saturday of cancer at the New York Hospital.

-Six days after having been upset in their opener at Buffalo, the Oakland Raiders reestablished themselves as the team to beat in the Western Division of the American Football Conference by beating the Kansas City Chiefs today, 27-7.

Sylvia Soule Moore, wire of the Rev. Charles O. Moore, rector of St. Giles's Episcopal Church in Northbrook, IIIl., and former priest in charge at the Church of the Resurrection here, died of cancer Saturday in Northbrook. She was 40 years old.

Emerson Fittipaldi won the Canadian Grand Prix today despite Mario Andretti and moved into a tie with Clay Regazzoni in the world driver standing with one race remaining. Never before has the final Formula One race decided the world championship. Emerson Fittipaldi after winning the Canadian 'Grand Prix at Mosport.

In an apparent case of mistaken identity, a 22-year-old Brooklyn youth was shot in the eye by a police officer early yesterday as he sat in a car with three other unarmed companions in Washington Heights.

Japan's first nuclear powered ship, the Mutsu, has been drifting off the Pacific cost of Japan for the last three weeks unable to find a port For this cotmry, which experienced the world's only atomic bombings, the 8,214-ton freighter committed a cardinal sin-her nuclear reactor leaked.
Elections were held today for nearly onethird the members of France's respected but relatively uninfluential Senate. They produced what appeared to be a slight shift toward the left.
A full investigation of the steam explosion that rocked Park Avenue at 78th Street was pledged yesterday by Environmental Protection Administrator Robert A. Low, acting at the request of Mayor Beame.

The Honduras Emergency Committee issued an appeal yesterday for food, clothing, medicine, and other supplies to aid more than 50,000 persons left homeless in the wake of the hurricane designated Fifi.

Second-hand plays by the defender represent an area in which many go astray. Players know that in general they should play second-hand low, but they pick the wrong moments to breach this old whist rule. What makes it more difficult is that secondhand plays must be made quite promptly to avoid giving useful information to the declarer.

The Federal Energy Administration has scaled back sharply its estimate of how much the public overpaid for oil and gasoline as a result of a. regulation that let refiners recover twice certain costs on some crude oil.

Construction of a White House swimming pool is scheduled to start about Oct. 1 so it can be completed for President Ford to use by the end of the year.

New Jersey's public-school children continue to show marked deficiencies in mathematics and reading skills, acccrding to one interpretation of preliminary scores from the second round of controversial statewide achievement tests administered by the state's Department of Education.

Plans for an informal "Big Five" meeting on world economic ills were being made today following a White House meeting between President Ford and Premier Kakuei Tanaka of Japan.
A group of American draft evaders and deserters, opening what they hope will become a worldwide campaign, spent the weekend here planning a boycott of President Ford's conditional amnesty program.

Doug Wilkins has a tough act to follow: himself. He has coached Mountain Lakes to 17 consecutive victories but faces the difficult task of replacing 18 seniors from last season's undefeated team, which won nine games and the Colonial Hills Conference championship. The team also has been Group 1, Section 2, state champion for the last two years.

Vice President-designate Nelson A. Rockefeller, arriving for the start tomorrow morning of his confirmation hearings, said again today that he would be "delighted" to do whatever Congress asked to resolve any potential conflict of interestincluding placing his holdings in a blind trust.

"They're bums," said one. Geryl E. Fish at Veteran's Administration Hospital in Washington. He feels amnesty should be "unconditional-no strings, no nothing." He was wounded in Vietnam.

Teachers and the Freehold Regional Board of Education reached a contract agreement today, paving the way for the district's high-school students to return to their classrooms.

The Bolshoi Ballet - or rather the Stars of the Bolshoi Ballet - have departed. They wound up their brief season over the weekend but true to form, novelties were being pulled out of the toeshoe until the very last.

The New York Rangers won their opening exhibition game today, but the National Hockey League's new rules suffered a setback. The official arrival time was set for 5:59 A.M. this morning, even though daylight will still outlast the dark by a few minutes here until Wednesday-at least as far as the official sunrise and sunset schedules are concerned.

To the Editor: The continuing debate over the issue of "One China" or 'TWO Chinas" (recent letters of Professor Wilbur, Professor Fairbank and Mr. Kreps) finds proponents of all sides predictably overlooking a point of central importance: that the overwhelming majority of the population of Taiwan has had no substantial connection with the mainland for centuries.

Nixon and his daughter, Julie Nixon Eisenhower, arriving in a heavily guarded area of Memorial Hospital Medical Center in Long Beach, Calif.
Bow Bridge, the 115-yearold structure that almost fell into the Central Park Lake six years ago, was dedicated in its restored and refurbished form.

Printers at The Washington Star-News and The Washington Post have approved new sixyear contracts providing lifetime jobs for regular members and giving the newspapers the right to proceed with automation of their print shops.

A pilots strike that idled 9,200, workers and grounded Braniff International Airlines planes for two days ended today and a company spokesman said that all flights were on normal schedules.
Robert Marshak, president of City College, announced Sunday that the Federal Government had awarded a $400,000 grant to the college's controversial new accelerated medical-training programs.

Jessica Bunker Valentine, former librarian at the University of North Carolina and Bryn Mawr College, died Sunday night at Chester County Hospital, West Chester, Pa. She was 73 years old and lived at Kendal-at-Longwood, a retirement home in Kennett Square, Pa.

The First Women's Bank, which was supposed to open its doors at 111 East 57th Street this month, has obtained a 90day extension from the New York State Banking Department to help it raise necessary capital.

The Soviet Union scored two goals with only four minutes remaining tonight to tie Team Canada, 5-5, despite a Bobby Hull's three goals in the opening period.

Volkswagen laid off 46,500 workers today for a week in a production cutback in its-six West German plants. It, was the sixth layoff this year, -all because of lagging sales. Ford also laid off German workers.

A major accounting firm is taking a limited step toward auditing quarterly corporate reports. Coopers Lybrand, one of the Big Eight firms of the accounting profession, proposed yesterday that it review--but not audit formally--quarterly corporate financial statements before they are published.

President Ford and Secretary of State Kissinger said yesterday that continued high oil prices set by producing countries involved the risk of a world depression and, the President added, the "breakdown of world order and safety."

The city sold $800-million in short-term revenueanticipation notes yesterday at an average interest rate of 7.447 per cent--almost 1 percentage point lower than at the last sale two weeks ago. High school students walked out of classes in the Charlestown section of this city today as Boston entered its second full week of a court-ordered school integration plan.

No final decision on toll increases on the New Jersey Turnpike will be Iade before next. month or without giving the public a chance to express its views, officials announced today.

The Republic National Life Insurance Company of Dallas said today it had signed a consent order agreeing to cease alleged excessive real estate loans. In the consent order, Republic admitted no guilt.
The Greek Government today restored freedom of action to all political parties in Greece and legalized the Communist party, outlawed since it tried to seize power in an armed Tebelion in 1947.

Senator Edward M. Kennedy's statement renouncing any intention to run for President in the foreseeable future has elicited a strong sigh of relief throughout the country. There is little question that his decision was right and that it did remove some very real and very serious national anxieties. Senator Kennedy's stated reason for his decision-his responsibilities to his family-is no doubt genuine and must be respected.

The Justice Department said yesterday it, was investigating the failure of the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation to divest itself of Avis, Inc., and Levitt Sons, Inc., as required under a controversial 1971 antitrust settlement.

The Portchester Water Works Company pressed its request for a 43 per cent rate increase at a Public Service Commission hearing here today. The company's request, submitted last August, affects its Port Chester, Rye and Rye Town customers, who already pay the second-highest rate in the country and are fighting the move.

Senator Edward M. Kennedy's withdrawal from the 1976 Presidential race, forcing roughly half the nation's Democrats to find a new first choice, created a vacuum at the center of his party today in time for a dozen or more candidates to take a run at national leadership.

Assemblyman Andrew J. Stein, alleging a "cold-blooded scheme" by at least one undertaker here to engage in "bodysnatching" and to defraud the city of money for burial costs, said yesterday that he would introduce legislation to regulate the funeral industry.
' One of Britain's leading real estate companies has recommended to its shareholders that they agree to a deal that would bring about the first take-over of a major British company by oil-rich Arabs.

Monday night football scored again over television across the nation tonight as the Philadelphia Eagles upset the Dallas Cowboys, 13-10.
