Demolition and development have been the natural processes of New York. For some it has meant profit and dynamism, for others the loss of their homes and way of life. The loss has been great for the city, too, in terms of neighborhoods and services, but it was not until recently that the relationship between community health and the city's survival was perceived as anything more than a set of real estate transactions.

The peace treaty between British trade unions and the' Labor party Government showed signs of strain today as negotiations to end an unauthorized strike at one of the nation's largest companies broke down. Some 1,800 workers on strike at two plants of the Ford Motor Company, Ltd., refused to Return to their jobs and kept all. Ford production in Britain halted.

Secretary of Agriculture Earl L. Butz let India know as recently as last week that this country would be receptive to a request for food aid only to have the suggestion turned aside, a Government aide said today.
A former airline chief testified yesterday that his company had tried to bribe a Bahamian official before It obtained the help of Representative Bertram L. Podell of Brooklyn.

The First National City Bank said yesterday it was raising fees on new and/or additional standby and revolving credits to large corporate borrower by one-quarter of a percentage point, effective immediately.

Officials of the Greater Greensboro open golf tournament have added $5,000 to the title purse of the 1975 event and raised the top prize $1,000 to $45,000, making the event the sixth richest professional golfers' association event in the nation.
Senate Republican leader Hugh Scott criticized the three major television networks today for not providing live coverage of hearings on Nelson A. Rockefeller's Vice-Presidential confirnation.

Francis A. Hanofee, the Sullivan County Clerk and for the last 13 years chairman of the Sullivan County Democratic Committee, died Sunday evening at Robert Packer Hospital, Sayre, Pa. He Was 59 years old.

Michel Carrega of France set a world record in trap shooting and the Soviet Union won two more gold medals today to maintain its lead on the fourth day of the world shooting championships. Carrega, the 1972 Olympic silver medalist, fired 199 of a possible 200 during the three days of the trap event to beat 185 competitors from 36 countries for the gold medal.

The leaders of two major landlord groups yesterday turned over to Mayor Beame's staff the deeds to five South Bronx apartment buildings that, the landlord. leaders said, were "in very good condition and virtually violation-free" put had to be abandoned by their owners because harsh rent control and inflation made them financial losses.

The city's Environmental Protection Administrator yesterday made public a list of political candidates who he said were "the 12 most flagrant violators" of city rules against placing campaign posters on public property.

The New York Yankees tripped over the supposedly fallen Boston Red. Sox last night dropped both halves of a critical double-header and tumbled out of first place with only six games left in the American League's Eastern free-for-all.

Will the warnings of the danger of world depression and a breakdown of "world order and safety," issued this week by President Ford and Secretary of State Kissinger to the oilexporting countries, cause them to cut their prices enough to restore balance to the world economy?

Richard S. Salant, president of CBS News, yesterday defehded the network's decision not to provide live coverage of Congressional hearings on the confirmation of Nelson A. Rockefeller as Vice President.

Led by a sharp decline of 3 per cent in fresh-produce prices, the wholesale prices paid by the city for its fresh fruits and vegetables declined 0.9 per cent for the last two weeks in September, according to the Municipal Service Administration.

Telesat Canada, the corporation that owns and operates the Canadian domestic satellite system, has bought for $100,000 Teleprompter's experimental mobile earth station to transmit live TV programs to a remote location in northern Quebec.

STAGE WORK With Broadway theater in perennial disarray, at least by reputation, producers Off and Off Off Broadway are engaging in unusual ways to bring to the public new plays by young directors. Such is the case with Direct Theater, a young nonprofit company working out of a complex at 455 West 43d Street (765-2117).

Former President Richard M. Nixon doctor said today that he had begun giving his patient drugs to present formation of new blood clots in the phlebitisdamaged. veins of his left leg and to help existing blood clots heal.

China and the Philippines, which do not have diplomatic relations, have concluded an informal trade agreement. The accord, under which China is to buy raw materials and sell oil, came during the current visit to Peking of a special envoy from Manila, Imelda Marcos, wife of the Philippine President, Ferdinand E. Marcos.

Students registering at the new Butte College in a rural area north of here have been told not to panic if they are bitten by a rattlesnake. The 5,000-student campus opened for the first time yesterday.

The Treasury auctioned $2billion of two-year notes yesterday at an average rate of 8.34 per cent as..Treasury securities trading in the seccondary, market fell in price following their recent strong runup. Credit The moves in the Markets secondary market were attributed to profit taking by dealers.
The Senate Government Operations Committee approved today three pieces of legislation designed to preserve Government custody of former President Richard M. Nixon's tapes and papers.
Vast supplies of food, medicine and clothing have been arriving from abroad for victims of last week's hurricane, but they are not reaching the needy fast enough.
Increased concern over inflation and profit taking in the blue-chip and glamour stocks sent the stock market into a broad retreat yesterday in the lightest trading in more than a month.
A threatened teachers strike was averted tonight when the United Teachers of New Rochelle decided to resume negotiations with the school board.
A convicted felon testified under a grant of immunity here today that he had been paid $700 to set a fire on May 11, 1973, that resulted in the death of a woman and three children.

Foreign Minister Jean Sauvagnargues of France said today that delegates to the United Nations and their governments seemed "apprehensive about the implicit threats" contained in American statements about the world energy situation.
Israel intends to draft specific political and territorial proposals-including maps-in preparation for her next round of negotiations with her Arab neighbors, a senior Government official said today.
Domestic new-car sales declined 5.6 per cent to an estimated 190,000 units in the Sept. 11-20 period from 201,447 units a year earlier.
6-7 A.M., WNYC-FM: Sunrise Symphony. Symphony No. 73, Haydn; Horn Concerto No. 4, Mozart; Waverley Overture, Berlioz. 9:06-10, WQXR: Piano Personalities. Robert Casadesus. Miroirs, Ravel.

In a move aimed at increasing available manpower, Israel's chief of staff announced today that a senior officer would be sent to the United States to begin arrangements for classifying Israelis living there for military reserve duty.

Room-watching, that game decor-hungry New Yorkers love, was played with gusto at Bloomingdale's last night. Hundreds of oglers paid $15 to charity for the pleasure of previewing the store's latest pronouncements on what's new in decorating.

Mayor Paul T. Jordan has ordered the Police Department to investigate an incident at a tavern in a predominantly Hispanic neighborhood in which four young Puerto Rican men were allegedly beaten by the police and then were arrested on assault charges.

Because of the state's high unemployment rate, the New Jersey unemployment insurance fund will be bankrupt within a matter of months and Trenton, for the first time, will have to borrow from the Federal Government to pay unemployment benefits to the state's jobless, high state officials disclosed today.

LOVE FEAST. By . 248 pages. Atheneum. $7.95. Maybe I'm getting dyspeptic or something, but "Love Feast," the concluding volume of 's comic religious trilogy, didn't satisfy me the way that the earlier novels, "Lion Country" and "Open Heart" did. It's a little puzzling,
The Tennessee. Valley Authority, confronted with a critical power shortage, called today for a voluntary 20 per cent cutback in the use of electricity throughout the sevenstate area it serves.

The affairs of the Greatet New York Bridge Association are surprisingly complex, involving as they do some 7,000 individual members, 100 clubs and 14 tournaments in New York City, Nassau County and Suffolk County.
Meets at 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M. to hear Honduras, Denmark, Laos, Canada, Bangladesh, Ireland, Philippines, East Germany, Sweden, and Nicaragua in general debate.

Guild members at The Inquirer and The Daily News, two of the city's three daily newspapers, accepted a new 131/2-month contract tonight. Wage increases under the new. contract, which expires Nov. 8, 1975, range from $11.50 for those earning $170 to $32 for those over $380.

In his second day before the Senate Rules Committee, Vice President-designate Nelson A. Rockefeller defended today his role in the Attica, N.Y., prison revolt in 1971 and explained his views on subjects ranging from mass transit to the disposition of the Nixon tapes.

EDGARTOWN, Mass.-Senator Edward Kennedy of Massachusetts said that he pulled out of the 1976 Presidential election campaign because of his responsibilities to his family-and this is widely accepted as true-but obviously there were political considerations as well.

There was a biting chill in the air early this morning as men and women farmworkers climbed down from the old yellow bus that had brought them from South Jersey to the Middlesex County workhouse here.
The Chase Manhattan Mortgage and Realty Trust announced yesterday that it was phasing out its $125-million commercial-paper operation by Oct. 31.

The qualities that make two performers a good team are sometimes elusive, but in the case of Ronny Whyte and Travis Hudson, who have moved into the St. Regis Room of the St. Regis-Sheraton, the basic reason seems to be that they need each other.

BRAMOVITZ-Isaac, beloved husband of Mary. Devoted father of Estelle A. Sussman, loving grandfather of Donna Hirsh field and Jeff. Cherished great-grandfather. Services Wednesday, 11:45 A.M. at "The Riverside " 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave.

The Chock Full o'Nuts Corporation said yesterday that while it would report an operating profit for its fiscal year ended July 31, it would also have a $7.3-million writedown of its securities portfolio. The portfolio of more than $18-million contains about $17-million in utilities securities.
The General Motors Corporation announced today it was indefinitely delaying plans to introduce the rotary engine because It was unable to get the power plant to meet all antipollution standards.

College students skiing in the Catskills or listening to a lecture on a hotel veranda there will have an opportunity to earn college credits in an unusual educational program announced today by Adelphi University.

The Orthodox Jewish Satmar Hasidic sect of Brooklyn has been given $300,000 by the Government to help its members set up small businesses, in a grant that the United States Department of Commerce called unusual yesterday.
Tom Dempsey, the irascible clubfooted kicker, provided the big boot in another incredulous Monday evening television production as the Philadelphia Eagles upset the Dallas Cowboys, 13-10, last night.
A Congressional committee approved legislation today designed to improve the housing situation from the viewpoints of the people who build new housing and the people who want to buy it.
Al Kaline's 3,000th base hit in the fourth inning tonight brought a pennant race and the Baltimore Orioles-Detroit Tigers game to a tumultuous standstill.

A distraught man brandishing a knife was shot and killed early yesterday by one of four policemen who had surrounded hi..?? in the hallway outside his mother's apartment in the East New York section of Brooklyn.
Judge John J. Sirica will rule Monday on whether transcripts of tape recordings may be used by jurors in the Watergate cover-up trial to supplement recorded voices heard on head- f phones.

Roger McGuinn, who seems firmly settled into his solo career by now, opened a twonight stand at the Bottom Line Monday night, and offered an evening of rock that didn't quite match up to his past accomplishments.

An undercover police officer trying to infiltrate an extortion gang was abducted by its members at gunpoint yesterday, touching off a tense, threehour surveillance and rescue operation that ended when the policeman was taken from his captors.

Wealthy antiwar Democrats who helped the 1972 Presidential campaigns of Senators Ed.. mund S. Muskie and George McGovern will gather here next week to plan liberal strategy for the 1976 Democratic National Convention.
Ente Nazionale Idrocerburi, the Italian state-owned hydrocarbons corporation, has announced completion of the laying of what is termed the world's deepest submarine pipeline.
The Museum of Modern Art has joined the list of those who have gone to court to obtain paintings of the late Mark Rothko, one of the leading abstract-expressionist painters of the 20th century.
The outlook for world grain production, with governments already worried over increasing hunger, has grown worse in the last month, the Department of Agriculture reported today.

The hard new line Washington is taking in public about oil prices charged by foreign countries reflects disappointment and frustration that the United States' campaign to bring about price reductions has failed, and failed conspicuously.

The United States Chamber of Commerce and its Bulgarian counterpart signed an agreement today establishing a new Bulgarian-United States economic council, aimed at expanding trade and other economic relations between the two countries.
The Senate overwhelmingly approved, today legislation designed to induce medical and dental schools to designate 25 per cent of their students for future service in medically underserved areas.

Representative Benjamin S. Rosenthal, a New York Democrat who has devoted himself to the cause of the consumer, warns Western Union patrons that a telegram is not worth the $7.45 it now costs, including the $3 delivery charge. Patrons of the utility's decaying service will have no trouble getting this message even if they get no other.

The t Moscow city authorities ac- f ceded today to the request t of a group of nonconformist artists to hold an outdoor exhibition at noon on Sun- t day, instead of Saturday, and gave them their choice of site.

In his eloquent if gloomy resume before the United Nations General Assembly of the threats to world stability, Secretary of State Kissinger emphasized a point often overlooked: problems that have been at least manageable through the postwar period--local rivalries, economic conflicts, the spread of nuclear knowledge--now threaten to become uncontrollable.

The El Paso Company announced here today that it has filed a formal application with the Federal Power Commission for approval of a controversial "all-American" $6-billion project to bring Alaskan natural gas to the lower 48 states.

President Ford announced to day a new program to take career criminals "out of circulation." In his first "law and order' speech since becoming President in August, Mr. Ford told the International Association ol Chiefs of Police that the fight against violent crimes was a major item on his agenda.

Copper prices rose yesterday on news from Chile that the Government was studying ways of limiting exports of the metal to lift prices. Copper for October delivery closed at 66 1/10 cents a pound, up from 63 cents. The contract only last May 6 sold at $1.31.

European financial interests--S G. Warburg Co., Ltd., and Cie, Financiere de Paris et des Pays-Bas--have invested $20-million in A. G. Becker Co., Inc., the New York investment banking concern, Paul R. Judy, board chairman of Becker, said yesterday.
The United States Chamber of Commerce and itsBulgarian counterpart have signed an agreement establishing a new BulgarianUnited States economiccouncil to promote trade. Details on Page 55.

ROME--Observers like to point out that political instability is one of the causes of the transitoriness of Italian Governments. None of them, in fact, have lasted more than a year since the end of World War II.

The New York Yankees tripped over the supposedly fallen Boston Red. Sox last night dropped both halves of a critical double-header and tumbled out of first place with only six games left in the, American League's Eastern free-for-all.

With each passing week, uncertainty increases about filling, in any definitive way, the large, serious remaining gaps in the Watergate story. President Ford's pre-emptive pardon and Special Prosecutor Leon Jaworski's doubts about including a detailed analysis of the evidence against former President Nixon in his final report to Congress are enormous obstacles to developing answers to the many unanswered questions. Meanwhile,

Yom Kippur, the most sacred day on the. Hebrew calendar, begins at sundown today. The holiday, known as the Day of Atonement, is devoted to a 24-hour period of fasting, self-evaluation, prayer and repentence.

Ramsey Clark, the Democratic candidate for United States Senator, suggested yesterday that Social Security benefits for those in metropolitan areas where the cost of living exceeded the national average be increased "to equalize this disparity."
The trial in a patrenity suit against Representative Mario Biaggi by a former campaign worker began yesterday in a closed session at Family Court.

The New York Stock Exchange got a somewhat cool reception today when it formally presented to the Securities and Exchange Commission its proposal for an 8 per cent increase in the sales commission on all but the smallest and largest securities transactions.

The preservation of jobs in shipping and related industries emerged yesterday as the top priority among government officials, civic groups, members of local planning boards and others who met to discuss comprehensive planning for the city's 578 miles of waterfront.

Robert Abrams, the Democratic nominee for State Attorney General, today accused Louis J. Lefkowitz of being "an apologist for the Establishment" who in 18 years as Attorney General had "failed to adequately defend the public interest."

The state's three largest cities--New York, Buffalo and Rochester - yesterday challenged the constitutionality of the state's education aid formula, charging that under it the large cities have been arbitrarily shortchanged.

It is daredevil time again, and Malcolm S. Forbes, the president of Forbes magazine, said yesterday that in a few months he would cross the Atlantic Ocean in a balloon. He did not say exactly why he wanted to do this, and he even denied that he was a daredevil. In fact, he said, "the odds that we make it are better than the odds that you make it safely across Park Avenue."

Donald Rumsfeld, named today to succeed Gen. Alexander M. Haig Jr., but not to replace him as White House chief of staff, is take-charge personality who has a knack for getting close to Presidents and for getting himself out of dead-end political situations.
The Pittsburgh Pirates regained first place in the National League East, which they last held on Sept. 13, by beating the St. Louis Cardinals again tonight, 7-3, before a subdued crowd of 37,107.

The New York Stars apparently have received permission from the World football League to move their franchise to Charlotte, N. C. There were mounting indications here and in North Carolina last night that the switch would be formally announced this morning.

The Orthodox Jewish Satmar Hasidic sect of Brooklyn has been given $300,000 by the Government to help its members set up small businesses, in a grant that the United States Department of Commerce called unusual yesterday.

In a display of candor, Prime Minister Pierre Elliott Trudeau of Canada announced yesterday that he had changed his mind and would not address the United Nations General Assembly during its current session, for the simple reason that he has nothing important enough to say.

Paul Samanchik, a former New Jersey amateur champion, and Agnes Guard, of North Jersey, captured the 11th Metropolitan Golf Association mixed Pinehurst championship today following a playoff over the par-72, 6,350yard Plandome course.

Israeli Air Force jets attacking today in southern Lebanon encountered opposition from Strela ground-to-air missiles, a military source said tonight. It was believed to be the first time that the missiles, which the Soviet Union supplied to the Egyptian and Syrian armies, have been fired from Lebanese territory.

Lots of young women are "daddy's girls," prized and cultivated by their doting fathers. Catherine Malfitano, a 26-year-old soprano from the Upper West Side whose career is burgeoning fast, fits that pattern neatly, but in a very special way.
Two suspects in a burglary were killed .and a third was seriously wounded yesterday in a shootout with the police at a toll-booth on the Connecticut Turnpike in Greenwich.

Four members of what the police described as a gang of professional kidnappers who preyed on major narcotics dealers were arrested here yesterday in connection with an. August abduction case in which a Bronx bus driver took only a few hours to produce $131,000 to ransom his 21year-old nephew.

Since this is the time of year-when the manager of a club not in contention can afford to look at a rookie pitcher, Yogi Berra of the Mets called on Hank Webb to oppose the Philadelphia Phillies tonight in the opener of a three-game series.

The Mexican Embassy here said today that it had granted asylum to a former rector of the University of Buenos Aires whe, according to friends, received a death threat from a right-wing terrorist group.

A Federal grand jury today indicted a suspended Ho-Ho-Kus lawyer on charges of having obtained, with the help of the president of a Jersey City bank $1.75-million worth of "financially unsound" loans and, overdrafts over a threevear period.

As the Ford Administration's program to curb inflation heads for a two-day conference in Washington Friday and Saturday, it appears that a number of potential obstacles that the President and his aides had feared might disrupt a series of preliminary meetings have been surmounted.
Amid reports that the New York franchise will move to Charlotte, N. C., the Stars took on the Detroit .Wheels at Downing Stadium, Randalls Island, last night in a World Football League game.

Soviet and American delegations declared today that a favorable climate for expanded tourism existed and they set up a joint working group to promote it. But in 10 days of talks the delegations did not achieve a full breakthrough that would enable the signing of construction and management contracts for large American hotel chains in the Soviet Union.

Ray Billows of Poughkeepsie, 60 years old, took the second-round lead in the New York State senior men's golf championship at the Grossinger Country Club today with a one-over-par 72 for a total of 152.

Leaster Smith, the former common-law wife of John Clutchette, one of the Soledad Brothers has been sentenced to six years in Federal prison as the "Robin Hood bandit" who held up 10 banks and gave some of the loot to the poor.
Bloomingdale's, the New York department store that has. rarely. used television in the past, is now planning to become a regular television advertiser.
As John HICKS pulled out to lead the blocking for his first power sweep of the regular season, Manny Sistrunk reached across the line and yanked at Hicks's face mask, which snapped his head back.
A three-day music festival of African and black American music--Zaire '74-ended here just before 6 A.M. today with disappointing cash receipts hut claims by its producers of "fantastic success."

Hezekiah (Kiah) L. Sayles Jr., a former associate of Joe Louis, the boxer, and of Jackie Robinson, the baseball player, died Friday of cancer in the Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center. He was 56 years old.
Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko of the Soviet Union today vigorously championed the improvement in Soviet-American relations and insisted it had led to solid accomplishments.

The Madison Square Garden Corporation returned to profitability in the first fiscal quarter to Aug. 31 as revenues rose, the New York-based entertainment company reported yesterday.

Flushing Meadow Park badly needs a friend. The proponents of a Grand Prix racetrack-a nice, quiet, contemplative sport - have trained their guns on Flushing Meadow after receiving a rebuff from the city on Central Park, which they would have considered the ideal location for car racing.

Mayor Kevin H. White said tonight that it was an "impossible and improper burden" to charge the city's police with implementing the controversial school busing plan ordered here by the Federal District Court.

The body of a man reported missing when an Exxon pier collapsed last Friday in Bayonne, N.J., was recovered yesterday in the waters off Staten Island , the police reported. He was identified tentatively as Aaron Brokaw, 32 years old.

Eva Haym Simons, widow of Dr. Hans Simons, a president of the New School for Social Research, died Sunday at the Riverdale Nursing Home in the Bronx. She was 77 years old and lived at 85 Landscape Avenue, Yonkers.

, a retired director and senior vice president of the Turner Construction Company, died yesterday in Lawrence Hospital, Bronxville, N. Y. He was 69 years old and lived in the Rivermere Apartments, Bronxville.

How do a basketball player and a swimmer react at a school with no basketball and, swimming teams? Why, they learn how to row a boat. Janet Youngholm, a basketball player from Springfield, Mass., and Carol Brown, a swimmer from Lake Forest, Ill., arrived as freshmen on the Princeton campus in 1971, and found that school offered only three varisty sports for women: tennis, field hockey and crew.

The New York Stars apparently have received permission from the World Football League to move their franchise to Charlotte, N. C. There were mounting indications here and in North Carolina last night that the switch would be formally announced this morning.

Riding shotgun without ammunition on the price-wage front is the dismal assignment President Ford has given to Prof. Albert E. Rees of Princeton, his choice to head the powerless new Council on Wage and Price Stability. Whether Professor Rees can make anything at all of the job depends in large measure on-how deep a commitment- the President himself displays in the use of White House influence to restrain inflationary price and wage movements.
Crown Prince Asfa Wossen called today for a parliamentary form of government in Ethiopia under a new constitution reflecting the "legitimate will and aspirations" of the entire nation.

Harold W. Webb, a retired Columbia University physics professor, died Monday at the Veterans Administration Hospital, East Orange, N.J. He was 90 years old and lived at 328 Westview Avenue, Leonia, N.J.

With appropriate gratitude, ABC-TV is giving the starring role on its 200th "Movie of the Week," tonight at 8:30, to the character that has made possible so many movies of the week and action-adventure series: the automobile.

Peter Korol of the Soviet Union swept top honors in the lightweight competition today at the 28th world weight lifting championships, totaling 671 pounds in the snatch and the jerk. Korol, a 33-year-old Ukrainian army officer, defeated 17 others to become the first athlete in the four-day-old competition to win gold medals in a class for the snatch, the jerk and the combined total.
Some of the small, expert foreign chamber ensembles that visit here never seem to get beyond the 18th century as far as repertory is concerned. The Camerata Bariloche fortunately does.

Almost 20,000, or about 10 per cent, of the nation's gasoline stations were forced out of business between June 30, 1973 and June 30, 1974 according to a, private, but authoritative survey of the country's retail distribution.

Albert Shanker, the newly elected president of the American Federation of Teachers, proposed today a three-pronged program to improve educational services for young and old while helping to solve the problem of increasing unemploymerit among teachers.
The House Government Operations Committee unanimously approved today a bill to give private citizens protection against the Government's computer information banks.

The National News Council yesterday found unwarranted a charge by the United States Ambassador to South Vietnam, Graham A. Martin, that an article in The New York Times on aid to South Vietnam "contained numerous inaccuracies and half-truths."
The Garden City Board of Education has voted unanimously to suspend indefinitely Dr. John P. Gainey, the district superintendent, because of his unauthorized use of a school vehicle.

Charles D. Ravenel, the brightest star to rise on the-South Carolina political horizon in years, refused today to withdraw from the 1974 Governor's race, despite yesterday's State Supreme Court finding that he did not meet residency requirements.

, honorary national president of American Mizrachi Women, the major women's Zionist organization in this country, died Monday evening at her home, 850 East 17th Street, Brooklyn. She was 87 years old.

Betty Ford, who yearned not to be First Lady, only a good wife and mother, donned one of her most attractive suits today and ventured into the political arena for the first time as a national celebrity.

The 39-year-old revue returns to Madison Square Garden tomorrow and one of the special features for youngsters will be the choreographing of "Sesame Street" on ice. Nine characters taken from the television show will appear.

The retail cost of a year's supply of farm-produced groceries jumped $25 in August to a record annual rate of $1,751 for a typical household, figures released today by the Agriculture Department showed.
Senator Henry Bellmon, Republican of Oklahoma, announced today that President Ford would make a political campaign visit Oct. 22 on a trip also scheduled to take the President to Tennessee and Ohio.

The House of Representatives, ignoring the pleas of its own leaders and Secretary of State Kissinger, voted 307 to 90 yesterday to suspend military aid to Turkey until "substantial progress" is made toward a Cyprus. settlement. The cutoff was appended to an otherwise routine measure and sent to the Senate, which last week urged President Ford to halt the aid to Turkey.[l:8.]
A smiling face came on the screen. "I'm the little man who lives in the scoreboard," the animated figure said. "I am the Net Nut. I am the Islander Guy. I am the voice of Nassau Coliseum."
The "Tomorrow" show with host Tom Snyder will move from Los Angeles to New York City beginning Dec. 3, the president of NBC television announced tonight.
" Regular gasoline - 49 cents a gallon," said the sign yesterday at the Little Falls Friendly Service Station on the eastbound lane of Route 46 in Little Falls, N.J.

Because of the state's high unemployment rate, the New Jersey unemployment insurance fund will be bankrupt within a matter of months and Trenton, for the first time, will have to borrow from the Federal Government to pay unemployment benefits to the state's jobless high state officials disclosed today.

Saudi Arabia hopes to complete negotiations leading to the full take-over of the Arabian American Oil Company by the end of this year, Rawleigh Warner Jr., chairman of the Mobil Oil Corporation, said at a news conference here today. Mr. Warner declined to comment on the terms being negotiated by Saudi Arabia and four oil companies.

THE SUDDEN WEALTH OF THE POOR PEOPLE OF KOMBACH, a German film by Volker Schlondorff, at the Regency Theater. EARLY SPRING, a Japanese film by Yasujiro Ozu, at the New Yorker Theater. THE MUTATIONS, starring Donald Pleasence, directed by. Jack Cardiff, at neighborhood theaters.
The Senate overwhelmingly approved today legislation designed to induce medical and dental schools to designate 25 per cent of their students for future service in medically underserved areas.

After a honeymoon with the new Administration of President Ford, the Soviet press has embarked on an upswing in anti-American propaganda described by the United States embassy as the strongest in a year or more.

Abdel Rahman Khene, Secretary General of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries, denied reports yesterday that OPEC had already decided to raise crude oil prices by 12 per cent as of Jan. 1.

The House of Representatives, ignoring the pleas of its own leaders and Secretary of State Kissinger, voted 307 to 90 yesterday to suspend military aid to Turkey until "substantial progress" is made toward a Cyprus settlement.

India and Portugal announced agreement today to re-establish diplomatic relations, interrupted since Indian forces invaded Goa in 1961. A joint statement by Foreign Ministers Swaran Singh of India and Mario Soares of Portugal said. details would be worked out in the immediate future.

MOSCOW - The husband of the leader of the women's mountaineering team that perished in a storm atop Lenin Peak in August climbed the 23,400-foot mountain himself to recover his wife's body and bury her and seven companions there.

Ford Administration official, preparing for Friday's so-called summit meeting on inflation, are saying the same thing they said before 12 preliminary conferences an dover a hundred hours of debate: There are no quick solutions to the nation's economic problems.

The Firestone Tire and Rubber Company announced yesterday in Akron, Ohio, that it was raising its quarterly dividend to 27 1/2 cents from 25 cents, dividend is payable Oct. 21 to shareholders of record Oct. 4, and makes the new indicated annual rate $1.10 per share.

President Carlos Andres Perez of Venezuela charges that many of the developing countries have become impoverished because of the need to hand over larger amounts of oil, food and resources to obtain machinery and other manufactured goods.

The House of Representatives, rejecting appeals from its own leaders and from Secretary of State Kissinger, voted overwhelmingly today to cut off military aid to Turkey until substantial progress had been achieved toward a military settlement on Cyprus.

The Eastman Kodak Company yesterday confirmed a report that it had increased prices last Friday on a wide range of commercial films and photographic papers. Products for use by amateur photographers were not affected.
The Senate Government Operations Committee approved today three pieces of legislation designed to preserve Government custody of former President Richard M. Nixon's tapes and papers.

Robert Rauschenberg, one of the country's most important modern painters, can still remember when ... when he left Port Arthur, Tex.... when he earned living expenses working as a window display man . . . when "$50 meant more to me than $50,000 does now."
The Pittsburgh Pirates regained first place in the National League East, which they last held on Sept. 13, by beating the St. Louis Cardinals again tonight, 7-3, before a subdued crowd of 37,107.
The musical comedy was not invented on Broadway, as some popular historians seem to think, but was thriving at least seven centuries ago in the time of Adam de la Halle.

Nelson A. Rockefeller, the Vice President-designate, who has an estate in Pocantico Hills, N. Y., a Washington mansion and a ranch in Venezuela, may be violating a cardinal rule of the monied class-dipping into capital.
WASHINGTON - The huge bronze fountain isn't finished, the trees in the garden still wear burlap covers, and the art installation is a long way from complete.

Leading authorities of the American Psychiatric Association said today that the New York State mental-health system was among the worst in the country and that similar agencies in all other states were working poorly.
A sparse crowd of 4,220 watched the New York Stars trounce the Detroit Wheels, 37-7, in Downing Stadium, Randalls Island, last night without knowing that this was the Stars' final game in New York.

A state appeal court ruled yesterday that former Secretary of State Paul J. Sherwin could remain free at least until Friday while he appealed a recent denial of a new trial. Mr. Sherwin faces a one-to-two-year sentence on a 1972 bribery-conspiracy conviction for trying to influence the awarding of a highway contract in return for a $10,000 contribution to the state Republican party.

Foreign Minister Jean Sauvagnargues of France said today that delegates to the United Nations and their governments seemed "apprehensive about the implicit threats" contained in American statements about the world energy situation.

" We're not going to be telling you when to shoot and when not to shoot," a police instructor reminds the 29,000 active city policemen, from rookie to Chief Inspector, who each year take the department's requiredd one- day firearms refresher course.

Prices on the American Stock Exchange and in the over-thecounter market fell yesterday, mostly on profit taking after a three-day rise. The Amex market value index closed off 1 to 66, after reaching a high of 67.06 and a low of 65.70.
Federal and state authorities are investigating allegations of corruption in the awarding of contracts by the Long Island State Park Commission.
The Australian Government announced today that it was devaluing its dollar by 12 per cent.

Cornelia Ames Reagan, who as Cornelia Ames had been a fashion artist for 40 years, died on Sept. 14, apparently of a heart attack, at her home in Jocotepec, Mexico. She was 73 years old and lived also at 55 East Ninth Street.
Alternate side-of-the-street parking regulations will be suspended tomorrow for the Jewish holy day of Yom Kippur, the Day of Atonement, the Department of Traffic announced will be suspended:
Calvin Jackson, who is said to have implicated himself in the murders of 11 women on West 77th Street, has been ruled "not fit" to stand trial at this time by two court-appointed psychiatrists.

MOSCOW - The husband of the leader of the women's mountaineering team that perished in a storm atop Lenin Peak in August climbed the 23,400-foot mountain himself to recover his wife's body and bury her and seven companions there.

CAT ON A HOT TIN ROOF, a play by Tenessee williams. Directed by Michael Kahn; settings by john Conk-lin; costumes by jane Greenwood; lighting by Mare B. Weiss; stage manager, Edward Dimond. The American National Theater and Academy presents the American Shakespeare Theater, Michael Kahn, artistic director, production. At the ANTA Theater, 245 West 52d street.
The Senate, having been told that cuts made in the Pentagon budget would not imperil the nation's security, approved and sent to the White House today an $82.5-billion defense appropriations bill.

A court order yesterday forestalled a shift Friday from the city's income guidelines for day care to the state's more restrictive limitations. The order, which effects about 5,000 children in the city's 430 day-care centers and 1,500 family day-care homes, was issued by Justice Constance Baker Motley in the Southern District of United States District Court.

The Kaiser Steel Corporation has agreed in principle to import semi-finished steel from a group of Japanese mills, finish it and sell it on the United States market. About 160,000 tons are to be imported in the next two years by Kaiser.
AGES OF MAN 1 Anthropology is a field not long for this world, some people say, because primitive societies are succumbing more and more to the traumatic effects of modernism.
The County Executive's office announced today that the A. P. supermarket chain had agreed to participate in a fivemonth -old program offering discounts to the elderly.

In an apparent reversal of his earlier reported position, Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz announced yesterday that he is, in fact, conducting an, investigation into the adulteration of milk by the Dairylea cooperative from 1967 to 1973.

The White House was reported yesterday to be considering the appointment of Louis H. Roddis Jr., the No. 2 man at the Consolidated Edison Company of New York, to be the No. 2 man in the Federal Energy Administration.
The controversy over issuing Connecticut state troopers a more powerful revolver erupted again today following the first shooting in which the new pistols were used.

A retired official of the Civil Aeronautics Board testified yesterday that Representative Bertram L. Podell had urged the C.A.B to help a small Florida airline obtain approval of a route to the Bahamas.
Joseph L. Allbritton, a millionaire banker from Texas, has been named chairman of the board and chief executiv officer of The Washington StarNews.

South African police, using dogs, tonight dispersed a crowd of 700 blacks and some white students who were gathering in Durban to attend an illegal rally in support of the Front for the Liberation of Mozambique.

The Federal Bureau of Investigation is conducting an inquiry aimed at pinpointing the source of "leaks" of classified Information from its Watergate files to newsmen, a bureau spokesman confirmed today.
George Foreman, the world heavyweight boxing champion, said late tonight that he would definitely defend his title here against Muhammad Ali on the night of Oct. 29, New York time.

Three 14-year-olds who told the police they were leaders of a youth gang were arrested on arson charges last night after allegedly setting fire to the roof of adjacent stores in the West Farms section of the Bronx.

Testimony before a House subcommittee today portrayed an oil industry executive who was on loan to the Treasury Deapartment as actively involved in shaping oil and propane regulations, despite a department memorandum intended to keep him from running afoul of the conflict-of-interest statutes.
George Foreman, the world heavyweight boxing champion, said late tonight that he would definitely defend his title here against Muhammad Ali on the night of Oct. 29, New York time.

A piece of a blood clot has broken off from former President Richard M. Nixon's phlebitis-damaged left leg, floated through his heart and destroyed a dime-sized area in his right lung without causing any chest pain, Mr. Nixon's doctor said here today.

The Beatrice Foods Company reported yesterday that net earnings and earnings per common share for both the second quarter and first six months, ended Aug. 31, reached record levels for the 23d consecutive year as company sales exceeded $1-billion for the second consecutive quarter.

Pete Gogolak, the New York Giants' place-kicker, was instrumental in alerting the Darien, Conn., police to a burglary going on in a neighbor's home on Tuesday. which led to the shootout that left two of the alleged robbers dead and a third seriously wounded on the Connecticut Turnpike.

Attorney General William F. Hyland is investigating the use of a controversial power-point bullet that has been adopted in recent mbnths by the state police and a growing number of municipal police forces.

Secretary of Defense James R. Schlesinger said today that the United States was not contemplating military action against the oil-producing countries in the Middle East, but rather was seeking a solution to rising oil prices through "amicable discussions."

Delegations of white and black students planned to sit down tomorrow with a private arbitrator to "try to hash out" the racial problems that have erupted into violence at Hyde Park High School in the first two weeks of forced integration of the city's schools.
President Ford is sympathetically considering proposing tax relief for lower-income workers to help them cope with inflation, White House officials said today.

A SCANDALOUS WOMAN AND OTHER STORIES. By Edna O'Brien. 151 pages. Harcourt Brace Jovanovich. $6.95. There is a sadness that squirms beyond recognition in Edna O'Brien's stories. To her heroines, the bed is a bier for defunct hopes. Hopes are made to be dashed.
John A. Bradley, a retired reporter for The New York Times, died here yesterday in a hospital. He was 79 years old. Mr. Bradley had worked for the Times for 21 years befor his retirement in 1965.

Proclaiming the death of any prospects for long-range, masstransit legislation in this session of Congress, leaders of a House-Senate conference proposed today a watered-down version of stopgap legislation that would not save New York City's 35-cent fare.

United States District Judge J. Robert Elliott overturned today the murder conviction of former Lieut. William L. Calley Jr. and ordered him released "forthwith" from incarceration at Fort Leavenworth in Kansas.

Israeli Air Force planes today attacked guerrilla targets for the second consecutive day. A military spokesman said the raid was similar to yesterday's, 15-minute attack. The planes struck today at the Arkub area, a stronghold of Al Fatah, the biggest Palestinian guerrilla organization.
Although most securities have suffered sharp declines in recent months, new investors are coming into the market to take advantage of what they believe to be good buys.

A House Armed Services subcommittee today began a proceeding that could lead to disciplinary charges against Representative Michael J. Harrington for his release of secret Central Intelligence Agency testimony on Chile.
The Celanese Corporation announced yesterday that it had reached an agreement in principle with Solvay Cie, S. A.,, a large chemical manufacturer based in Brussels, to sell Solvay

The American Express International Banking Corporation has found irregularities involving perhaps "a few million dollars" in securities accounts of a small number of clients of its Basel, Switzerland, branch, it was learned yesterday.

Just after the American Geographical Society was founded in New York in 1852, one of its first efforts was a daring campaign for the construction of a railroad all the way from the populous East Coast, across the wild and unexplored interior of the United States, to the distant Pacific Coast.

The migration of World Football League teams into the Deep South and reports of "floods of red ink" all over the league continued yesterday as the New York Stars officially announced their sale and shift to Charlotte, N. C., effective immediately.

Despite a warning that it would "tear the Congress all to pieces," the House Rules Committee today sent two rival proposals to reorganize House committees to the floor for what is expected to be a long and bitter fight next week.

Quietly, the owners of the Cleveland Indians are approaching a historic decision - the selection of Frank Robinson as major league baseball's first black manager. "Discussions have been held," a source close to the thinking of the Indians' owners confided yesterday. "But nothing will be announced until after the season ends."

The two gubernatorial candidates are planning new sets of television commercials for extensive schedules of electronic stumping, with the Wilson campaign budgeting $1.2-million for TV advertising and the Carev camp renoting that i can afford about half that much.
The Secretary General of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries said today that the world might face a 12 per cent rise in the price of oil next year, spread out on a month-to-month basis.

The West German cabinet refused today to ratify the European Common Market decision to raise farm price supports by 5 per cent until its eight partners agree to drop protectionist measures. It also called for a review of the bloc's agricultural policy.

The case of Sandino Hernandez, the jockey who was apprehended last Friday after he was alleged to have been in possession of a battery,'was referred yesterday to the office of the Nassau County District Attorney by the New York State Racing and Wagering Board.

" Book prices in the trade are relatively high precisely because the sale of the average trade book in low," William Jovanovich, the chairman of Harcourt Brace Jovanovich, Inc., observed a decade ago.

Today is Yom Kippur, the holy day on which Jews both seek atonement for their own acts of violence and read the Book of Jonah to renew their prophetic commitment to oppose the violence of all surrounding Ninevehs.

Foreign Minister George Mavros of Greece rejected today an offer by Secretary of State Kissinger to mediate in the Cyprus crisis. "I don't see the role of Henry Kissinger as a mediator entrusted by us and Turkey with the job," the Greek Minister said during a news conference here.

Two scientists have calculated that gases released by aerosol cans have already accumulated sufficiently in the upper air to begin depleting the ozone that protects the earth from lethal ultraviolet radiation.
The chairman of the Presidential Clemency Board said today that there might be thousands of men now in hiding or living abroad who fear they are "draft delinquents" bu-t who are not.

Moving to avoid an undercount in the 1980 census, the Department of Commerce plans to set up a committee of blacks to advise the Bureau of the Census on how to improve its counting techniques among blacks.

Representatives the nine European Common Market countries and of Arab League nations met here today amid suggestions that their joint efforts might help avoid a confrontation between oil producing and oil consum ing nations.

Prisoner exchanges in Cyprus have been suspended indefinitely because Turkish Cypriotes objected to requests by Greek Cypriotes to be repatriated to the Turkish-occupied north of the island, the International Red Cross said today.

State Education Commissioner Fred G. Burke denied diplomas yesterday to eight of nine Burlington high-school seniors who missed more than 30 days of school last year. He said the students must attend make-up classes sto complete course requirements for their diplomas.
The California Supreme Court accepted today former President Richard M. Nixon's resignation from the state bar.
William McCracken of Suburban carded a 77 today and became the early leader in the race for the New Jersey State Seniors Golf Association with a 151 total at the Baltusrol Golf Club.

Ellen Sustrin Meyers, a certified social worker with the Department of Social Services and its predecessor agencies for some 39 years, died Tuesday in the Brookdale Medical Center, Brooklyn. She was in her sixties and lived at 374 Mayfair Drive South, Brooklyn.

Seven jurors and three alternates who heard the Wounded Knee case have sent a letter to Attorney General William B. Saxbe asking that the Justice Department not appeal the dismissal of charges against two Amercian Indian Movement leaders.
The United States Army's disaster survey team today estimated the death toll from last week's hurricane here to be considerably lower than that announced by the Honduran Government.
President Ford is sympathetietically considering proposing taxi relief for lower-income workers to help them cope with inflation, White House officials said today.

The Senate Rules Committee concluded its two-and-a-halfday interrogation of Vice President-designate Nelson A. Rolckefeller today, with Mr. Rockefeller refusing to commit himself on how he would apply the doctrine of executive privilege should he succeed to the Presidency.

The Federal Trade Commission Was rejected the initial legal maneuver of a group of 193 major. United States corporations to kill a controversial program requiring them to report on the profits and sales of the different products they manufacture.
A $50-million, 20-story hotel, the first new one in lower Manhattan since the turn of the century, will be built as the final component of the World Trade Center.

The exportation of coal, the nation's most abundant fuel commodity, is running into scattered opposition because of growing uncertainty, particularly among utilities, over the nation's ability to meet its immediate energy needs.

Najma Ayashah's concert of North Indian dance at the Cubiculo on Tuesday evening was tastefully selected and performed. She was assisted by Sabah Nissan, who gave a short history of Kathak dance and described each work before the program began.
The United States had a record monthly deficit of more than $1.1-billion in its trade with foreign countries in August, the Commerce Department reported today.

About 70,000 members of the Tuareg nation, nomads who have never recognized the borders that cut across the desert through which they drive their cattle, have been swept into Niger by the drought and famine of the last years and show no signs of wanting to leave.

Alberto Erede, who had not conducted at the Metropolitan Opera for 20 years, was back with the company on Tuesday night for its first performance of "Turandot" of the season. The Italian conductor had not previously led the Puccini work here before.

Friends and acquaintances of Nelson A. Rockefeller challenged yesterday his assertion that his family did not wield "colossal economic power," but they agreed that the Vice President-designate exercised little or no personal control of the companies in which much of his $218-million fortune is invested.

Final figures today showed that the auto industry's domestic car sales in the Sept. 11-20 period totaled 193,184 units, a decline of 4.1 per cent from the 201,447 units sold in the year-earlier period. The Ford Motor Company was the last to report its sales, and they were higher than estimated yesterday, rising 41.8 per cent to 63,093 units from 44,256 units in midSeptember, 1973.
The Basque terrorists who killed Premier Luis Carrero Blanco of Spain last December say in a book just published that they also contemplated killing Secretary of State Kissinger at the same time.

Overcoming a 5-0 deficit in the first inning and a 12-9 deficit 'in the 11th, the St. Louis Cardnals moved back into first place in the National Leaoue East tonight by beating the Pittsburgh Pirates, 13-12( in a 3-hour 41minute struggle.

Capt. Robert Ryder modestly admits to being an athlete of sonle repute. However, his athletic prowess in baseball arid football wasn't what prompted a committee of race track and State Racing Commission personnel to designate him thoroughbred horseman of the year for 1974.

Senator Henry M. Jackson, Democrat of Washington, asked today that the Bureau of Land Management preserve the remnants of a free-roaming band of horses that was captured in a controversial roundup near Howe, Idaho, in February, 1973.
More than 3,000 policemen, many with tears in their eyes, attended funeral services today for Patrolman Harold Woods, who died Sunday of wounds suffered during a supermarket holdup early last week.
The National Gallery of Art in Washington has acquired one of the extremely rare paintings of the 17thcentury French artist Georges de La Tow.

Top-seeded Chris Evert beat Kathy Pigeon, 6-0, 6-0, last night in the first round of the $50,000 Virginia Slims women's tennis tournament. In the other late match, fifth-seeded Julie Heldman disposed of Dianne Fromholtz, 7-5, 6-7, 6-4.
Defendants in the Watergate cover-up trial, scheduled to get under way Tuesday, renewed today their pleas to the Supreme Court for a delay.

Danny White, the quarterback playing for injured John Huarte, hit on 14 of 27 passes for 170 yards in leading the Memphis Southmen to a 17-3 World Football League victory over the Shreveport Steamer tonight.

It was a man's world at the Queens branch of Abraham Straus the other evening, when the store, anxious to introduce its male shoppers to its expanded men's department, put on a snappy little fashion show.

The state police began an investigation today of an incident in which the Governol's limousine, carrying Acting Gov. S. Howard Woodson Jr., exceeded the speed limit and passed by a trooper trying to flag down the vehicle.

Farmers in the major corn and soybean areas of the Middle West were attempting today to assess the damage the crops haire suffered in the last four nights from one of the earliest killing frosts on record.
Despite a brief rally at noon, prices on the American Stock Exchange and the over-thecounter market closed mixed yesterday.

The House Ways and Means Committee completed today another round of work on its big tax bill, adding to the already complex measure 12 special-interest amendments, most of which affect only one company or one industry.
Two old women were found murdered today in the bedroom of their apartment on the sixth floor of a center for the aged.
Raul Ramirez of Mexico, seeded No. 7, and Harold Solomon of Silver Spring, Md., seeded ninth, were upset tonight in first-round play of the $100,000 international open tennis tournament.

Judge Gerhard A. Gesell of United States District Court here refused a request today from a New York law professor that the pardon President Ford granted former President Richard M. Nixon be declared unconstitutional.

For the third day in a row soybean prices jumped the 20cent-a-bushel limit on the Chicago Board of Trade yesterday. At the close, however, distant deliveries showed easting tendencies in contrast to Monday and Tuesday's firm closings.

The Somers Town Board voted last night to rezone a controversial 57-acre site from residential to commercial use, starting a new dispute in a town already split over an investigation into zoning irregularities.

Fire, believed to be the work of an arsonist, broke out yesterday in a dilapidated four-story Brooklyn tenement where disgruntled residents complained afterward of neglect, poor service and deterioration permitted by the landlord-the City of New York.

The Westinghouse Electric Corporation announced today it was halting investment in Uranium Enrichment Associates, a joint corporate venture to determine the possibilities of private industry entering the uranium enrichment business.

Representatives of major oil companies and independent service stations clashed today at a hearing on a bill designed to eliminate company-owned service stations in New Jersey.

Asserting that most airlines have been making an improper, indirect profit from their antiskyjacking procedures, the Civil Aeronautics Board ordered reduced passenger surcharges for airport security today.

The stock market yesterday received the bullish news it had been awaiting for months, a reduction in the prime rate by several leading banks, and after an initial burst of enthusiasm only managed to finish mixed in heavy trading.

Three world records were shattered today, the opening day of the 99th Grand Circuit meeting at the Red Mile here. Nero, driven by Joe O'Brien, won the $34,845 Meadowlands stake race with a combined time of 3:53 3/5 for the two elimination heats.

The Environmental Protection Agency declared to day that re ent experience had demonstrated conclusively that the so-called "scrubbing" technique for removing sulphur gases from smokestacks was effective ind reliable.

From professional football player to retailer of women's sportswear is hardly a logical sequence of events. Yet it has worked out well for Kaal Farra, a former reserve kicker with the Chicago Bears who saved enough money while on the team to open his ownshop.

A Middlesex County Court jury today returned two guilty verdicts against Frederick Krug, a 27-year-old East Brunswick man, on charges of kidnapping and murdering Phyllis Thomson, 28, on Sept. 2, 1973.

Yom Kippur began last night with rabbis here delivering sermons that emphasized the ethical, moral and spiritual values of the day and the need for men and nations to apply them in achieving a world peace.

Tom Seaver, the New York Mets' high-salaried righthander, put his ailing left hip, injured in Montreal a week ago, to the test tonight in the opener of a twilightnight double-header with the Phillies.
The United States today contributed $4- million more to the financially troubled International Commission of Control and Supevision, thereby deferring a financial crisis for about two more months.
Two young women, one a student at Brooklyn Community College, the other a student at Bronx Community College, were found strangled Tuesday night in their apartments in Brooklyn and the Bronx.

Turkish political and military leaders reacted today with dismay to the vote by the United States House of Representatives to cut off military aid to Turkey until substantial progress is made toward a military settlement in Cyprus.

The Dutch oil tanker Metula, caught on rocks in the Straits .of Magellan at the tip of South America since Aug. 9, was freed today by tugs, the Chilean navy said.

A retired official of the Civil Aeronautics Board testified yesterday that Representative Bertram L. Podell had urged the C.A.B to help a small Florida airline obtain approval of a route to the Bahamas.
The French Cabinet set a $10.1-billion ceiling today on spending for oil imports next year and ordered cutbacks in industrial and home heating consumption.

HILTON HEAD ISLAND, S. C., Sept. 25 (AP)-The three favorites survived the opening round of match play today in the 20th annual United,States Golf Association senior tournament. The qualifying leader, Ed Tutwiler of Indianapolis, eliminated Erv Parent of Seattle, 2 and 1, over the 6,665-yard Harbour Golf Links course.

John McCarten, writer for The New Yorker magazine for 40 years and its film or drama critic for about 20 of them, died of cancer yesterday at Mount Sinai Hospital. Mr. McCarten, who had lived in Dublin for the last six years, was 63 years old.

The accidental discovery of a child's skeleton last month in a lime-packed suitcase in the basement of a Bronx tenement led last night to the arrest of a 30-year-old man who was charged with having killed his 8-year-old son more than four years ago.

Sun Ock Lee, a Korean dancer who now lives in New York, presented a recital of traditional Korean dances and modern compositions that blended Western and Oriental idioms, Tuesday night at Japan House.

The case of Sandino Hernandez, the jockey who was apprehended last Friday after he was alleged to have been in possession of a battery, was referred yesterday to the office of the Nassau County District Attorney by the New York State Racing and Wagering Board.

United States District Judge J. Robert Elliott overturned today the murder conviction of former Lieut. William L. Called Jr. and ordered him released "forthwith" from incarceration at Fort Leavenworth in Kansas.
Ray Billows, a 60-yearold golfer from Poughkeepsie, won the New York State men's senior championship by five shots at the Grossinger Country Club today with a 54-hole total of 233.

The overwhelming approval by the House of a binding cutoff in military aid to Turkey until "substantial progress" is made toward a Cyprus settlement dramatizes American revulsion against the massive Turkish aggression on the island. The 307-to-90 vote was also aimed at forcing Administration compliance with laws that mandate such a cutoff when a recipient country misuses American military assistance.
Just before the main race at Belmont Park yesterday, the rain came down in a heavy burst. It made no difference to John Greer's Foolish Pleasure.

Secretary of Defense James R. Schlesinger said today that the United States was not contemplating military action against the oil-producing countries in the Middle East, but rather was seeking a solution to rising oil prices through "amicable discussions."

A 74-year-old woman who had reportedly been identified by Calvin Jackson as one of the 10 women he told the police he had murdered at the Park Plaza Hotel said yesterday that Mr. Jackson was not the man who had attempted to kill her.

Shearson Hayden Stone, Inc, a new brokerage house formed between Hayden, Stone, Inc., and Shearson, Hammill Co., Inc., said yesterday that it had obtained $5-million in new loans from the First National City Bank and the Continental Illinois National Bank and Trust Company - raising its;, bank debt to $19.2-million.

BOSTON-We buried Donald Brown in May. He was murdered by three men who wanted to rob the supermarket manager he was protecting. Patrolman Brown was 61 years old, six months from retirement. He and his wife intended to retire to Florida at the end of the year. Now there will be no retirement in the sun, and she is alone.
President Anwar el-Sadat moved today to relinquish the Premiership, appointing First Deputy Premier Abdl Aziz Hegazi to take over the post and form a new Cabinet.

John V. N. Klein, the Suffolk County Executive, today proposed what he described as a $473.5-million "standstill" budget for fiscal 1975, saying the 14 per cent rise in spending had been caused by inflation rather than new programs and would mean a substantial increase in property taxes.
The mountain state of Hunza, which says it is the original Shangri-La, has lost its last vestige of independence and become part of Pakistan.

Proclaiming the death of any prospects for long-range, masstransit legislation in this session of Congress, leaders of a House-Senate conference proposed today a watered-down version of stopgap legislation that would not save New York City's 35-cent fare.
Senate and House negotiators have agreed on legislation to revoke controversial "no-knock" powers of Federal narcotics agents and the District of Columbia police.

Next week's annual meeting of the World Bank and International Monetary Fund is not expected to produce any important decisions or actions, a high Treasury official said today.

The bicentennial convention of the United Steelworkers of America voted today to give $290,000 in raises to its 25 directors and three international officers, including a $15,000 raise for the union's president, I. W. Abel.

Over the years it has seemed that through one default or another Manhattan has rarely boasted an Indian restaurant of almost unfailing distinction. In traditional places where the food is passably cooked, the ventilation is often execrable.

The State Commissioner of Education today upheld the dismissal of a Sayreville High School janitor who had called a teacher a "no-good little punk" and who had been accused of performing his job duties inefficiently.
In a difficult time-pressure battle, Viktor Korchnoi and Anatoly Karpov adjourned the fifth game of their final Candidates Match here in the House of Unions tonight.
A judge dismissed a murder charge today against a Federal narcotics agent who fatally shot a man fleeing a 1972 raid on a suspected drug laboratory in a mountain cabin.

Members of the Israeli civil guard will be permitted to carry their weapons while attending Yom Kippur services in synagogues this year, according to a special ruling handed down by Chief Rabbi Shlomo Goren.

By any yardstick of reporting and bookkeeping, the 47 per cent rise in violent crime in the past five years constitutes an appalling record. The Nixon Administration's much-touted war on crime and the obedient legislative response by a "get-tough" Congress can now be put down as predictable failures.
The New .York Stock Exchange said yesterday that it was suing the Controller of the Currency, James E. Smith, for having given bankers approval to 'sell stock under automatic investment plans.

The establishment of a Guglielmo Marconi Award to mark the 100th birthday this year of the radio pioneer was announced yesterday by Dr. Joseph E. Slater, president of the Aspen Institute for Humanistic Studies.

Defense Secretary James R. Schlesinger said that the United States was seeking a solution to rising oil prices through "amicable discussions" and was not contemplating military action against the oil-producing nations of the Middle East. However, he said that inflation, brought about in part by oil price increases, could upset the relative military balance between the Western alliance and the Soviet Union.
Doctors accused the Food and Drug Administration today of laxity in. dealing with manufacturers applications to market drugs that have been questioned on safety grounds.
The Battle for First Place was resumed in the American League last night, but in New York most of the headshaking was still over the Battle of Shea Stadium among the 46,448 fans Tuesday night.
The American Kennel Club, for the first time since it was organized in 1884, hired a woman field representative last year - Mrs. Irene Nail of Fort Worth.
Nelson Rockefeller told the Senate this week that he paid not one shiny dime of Federal income taxes for the year 1970.

A secretary testified under a grant of immunity today in Superior Court that a Passaic landlord she worked for paid an arsonist $700 to set a fire last year in three buildings that killed a woman and three children.
The Honduras Emergency Committee, under the direction of the Honduran consulate, has been set up at St. Francis Xavier Roman Catholic Church, at 30 West 16th Street.

John N. Nassikas, chairman of the Federal Power Commission, told a Congressional committee today that there had indeed been potential conflicts of interest in the ownership by commission employes of stock in energy companies.

Two more computer makers--Honeywell, Inc., and the Memorex Corporation-joined other major manufacturers in raising rental prices. Honeywell said it was lifting its domestic rental and service charges in a range from 2 to 10 per cent, effective Oct. 1 except where contracts require 90-day notification.

Dr.Robert S. Evans,. hematologist and one of the senior faculty members at the University of Washington School of Medicine, was killed today in a three car collision near here. He was 62 years old and lived in Redmond. a suburb.

Dr. Norbert Goldenberg, a Physician and newspaper publisher, died yesterday at his home in Teaneck, N.J. He was 65 years old. Dr. Goldenberg, who specialized in thoracic surgery, was president and publisher of Aufbau, a local German-Jewish weekly.
Four persons were killed and five were wounded in a renewed rocket attack by insurgents on the outskirts of Phnom Penh last night, the military police reDorted today.
The cut in the prime lending rate initiated by the Morgan Guaranty Trust Company proved a fillip yesterday to segments of the credit markets.

Zelmo Beaty, whose career in professional basketball spans 11 years, has left the Utah Stars of the American Basketball Association to play with the Los Angeles Lakers of the National Basketball Association. Rumor had been rife for weeks that the move was imminent.
The city's Rent Guidelines Board is expected to decide tomorrow on a major modification of the highly controversial rent-rise limits affecting some 400,000 apartments here.

The lawsuits instituted by legal services groups against food-stamp administrators in seventeen states and the United States Department of Agriculture to force them to bring the eligible poor and near-poor within the program are actions that never should have been required.

The Cabinet of Premier Takieddin Solh of Lebanon resigned today. Mr. Solh submitted his resignation to President Suleiman Franjieh at the last meeting of the 22-member Cabinet, which was formed 14 months ago.

Former Secretary of State Paul ....Sherwin today was granted a stay of sentence in his bribery-conspiracy conviction until the State Supreme Court decides-whether to hear his case.

The CBS radio network announced yesterday that it would drop at yearend the daily fiveminute feature, "Dear Abby," a radio version of Abigail Van Buren's newspaper column of personal advice, for a new series entitled "The American Woman." "Dear Abby" has had a 12-year run on the network, on the air Mondays through Saturday.

The blood clot that traveled from former President Richard M. Nixon's left leg to his right lung sometime in the past is responding satisfactorily to anticoagulation therapy, Mr. Nixon's doctor said here today.

Three world records were shattered today, the opening day of the 99th Grand Circuit meeting at the Red Mile here. Nero, driven by Joe O'Brien, won the $34,845 Meadowlands stake race with a combined time of 3:53 3/5 for the two elimination heats.
The General Motors Corporation and the Ford Motor Company today here found not guilty in Federal District Court of price-fixing in the sales and leasing of mars to fleet customers.

The special Watergate prosecutor, at the request of the White House, is investigating many of President Ford's appointees to high office to assure that they are not tainted by the Watergate scandal, officials close to the investigation disclosed today.

After a bitter two-hour debate, the United Steelworkers of America biennial convention endorsed today a proposal to raise dues for several hundred thousand steelworkers. The delegates approved an amendment removing a current $10 ceiling on monthly dues from the union's constitution.

Edmund A. Rossi, who was president of the Italian Swiss Colony Winery for 27 years, died Tuesday at a hospital in Pacifica, Calif. He was 86 years old. Mr. Rossi's father, Pietro Carlo Rossi, was one of the founders of the winery.

Johnny Miller, headed for a record-smashing year on the pro golf tour, may not qualify to represent the United States in next year's Ryder Cup matches because of a technicality in the eligibility rules.

The former director of tile Alabama Department of Public Safety told a Federal judge today that Gov. George C. Wallace had repeatedly instructed him not to obey one of the judge's orders regarding the hiring of black state troopers.

A special scientific committee has been formed to assess for the National Academy of Sciences "on an urgent basis" what action might be taken with regard to the possible threat of aerosol can propellants to the stability of the atmospheric ozone layer.

Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz said yesterday that he planned to present his criminal case against the Dairylea milk cooperative to an Albany County grand jury "sometime in October."
Ann S. Petluck, a lawyer and social work administrator specializing in immigration and refugee work, died Wednesday at University Hospital. She was 66 years old and lived at 441 East 20th Street.

Esposito, Brooklyn Democratic leader to Alex Rose, Liberal party leader.

Edith Logan Dilworth, widow of Dewees Wood Dilworth, an investment broker, died yesterday at her home in Southampton, L.I. She was '80 years old and lived also in Aiken, S.C.

Federal District Judge Robert Ward rejected a suit brought by 214 New York National Guard members who sought release from their final year of duty because their home units had been called to duty during the 1970 mail strike in New York City.

A 38-year-old former convict who had been charged with the slaying of a freelance film producer here last year, and whose case was declared a mistrial late Wednesday night, will be retried in the next few weeks, the Manhattan District Attorney's office said yesterday.

Partly as a result of former President Nixon's illness, the Senate of the United States is now acting quickly to give the Government control over his tape recordings and other official documents, which could be destroyed under the Ford-Nixon agreement in the event of Mr. Nixon's death.

Charles O. Filtley, never one to hide his light under a bushel basket, said yesterday he hoped his Oakland A's would, meet the New York Yankees in the American League playoffs rather than the Baltimore Orioles because the Orioles' pitching is so solid.
China's grain harvest last year dwarfed all previous records, exceeding 250 million tons, Hsinhua, the official press agency, reported today.

The White House will provide data to delegates to tomorrow's conference on inflation show ing that two-thirds of the present $85-billion defense budget is "discretionary" money. The label means that the spending is not mandated by either law or contract.

The French reacted with anger bordering on outrage today to West Germany's rejection of a 5 per cent increase in guaranteed prices for Common Market farmers as the nine member nations hastily agreed to an emergency meeting next Wednesday in Luxembourg to try to deal with the crisis.

A resident of the SherryNetherland Hotel, on Fifth Avenue at 59th Street, was robbed last night of jewelry of "substantial value," the police reported.

The Democratic and Republican leaders of Congress met today with President Ford and Secretary of State Kissinger and agreed to support a weaker version of legislation to suspend military aid to Turkey than the House voted Tuesday.

The Federal Energy Administrator, John C. Sawhill, said today he had ordered the agency to seek refunds of about $40-million in windfall profits that he said oil companies made from a loophole in energy regulations.

A 27-year-old former convict, identified by the police as the much-sought elevator robber who had created a one-man crime wave by holding up dozens of apartment-house residents over the last three months, was arrested yesterday after an investigation that had made him the leading target of detectives in three precincts.
The head of the Soviet delegation to the World Energy Conference said today that despite his nation's huge oil resources the Soviet Union cannot quickly become a major exporter of oil.
Nikolai Polokous, who as Coco the Clown brought laughter to British circus audiences for 60 years, died yesterday in a hospital here. He was 78 years old. Mr. Polokous, son of a Russian clown,
Roy Emerson, the defender, lost his secondround match tonight in the $100,000 International tennis tournament to another Australian, Ross Case, 6-2, 6-2.

The militant Popular Front for the Liberation of Palestine announced today its withdrawal from the Executive Committee of the Palestine Liberation Organization, which is the main grouping of guerrillas, in a rift over peace moves.

While American attention may be focused on President Ford's much-publicized national economic "summit" this weekend, a more momentous meeting in deep privacy at Camp David, Md., will address the problem that is more seriously worrying the world's economic and political leaders-oil and money.
Shareholders of the Dictaphone Corporation were urged hy directors yesterday to reject the offer of Northern Electric Company to purchase for $12 a share in cash any and all shares of Dictaphone.

A personal appeal by House Speaker Carl Albert has helped save $9-million in aid for financially troubled Eisenhower College in upstate New York. West Germany will propose next week a World Investment Bank to absorb the huge amounts of currency being amassed by the oilproducing countries, an official of the Finance Ministry said today.

Speculative buying on fears about the crop size pushed prices of soybeans and corn up their daily limits yesterday. For the beans it was the fourth 20 cents a bushel daily limit rise this week, on the Chicago Board of Trade.

R. H. Macy Co., operators of the world-known New Yorkbased department store chain, reached a record level of sales for the fiscal year that ended Aug. 3, but profits dropped 10.6 per cent.

A Soviet destroyer of a type armed with guided missiles reportedly exploded and sank recently in the Black Sea in what is believed to be the worst peacetime naval disaster since the loss of the United States submarine Thresher in 1963 with a crew of 129.
