Despite Watergate, a new President and well-publicized gubernatorial and Senate contests, voter apathy in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut is expected to increase as part of a national "pattern of diminishing participation," the Census Bureau reported today.

Priestess, businesswoman, soiled dove, neurotic-the prostitute has been seen in many different guises. Now, in "Lovers, Friends, Slaves" Martha L. Stein, M.S.W. has restored to the working girl not only respectability but status: she sees her as a "paraprofessional sexual therapist."

Bill Ryan found the muddy field to his liking yesterday and the Wagner halfback scored all three touchdowns as the Staten Island school upset Lafayette, 22-0, in a Public Schools Athletic League opener on the winner's field.
The nation's retail industry is having nervous tremors over the state of its inventories. Four months are left in the industry's fiscal year in which to achieve its anticipated sales of $135-billion.

A tangle over paperwork yesterday delayed the departure of a 37-year-old Chilean who charged that he had been forcibly abducted from Chile and brought here by Federal agents for alleged drug trafficking but was then found to be the wrong man.

It is possible to gauge the solemnity of a political event in America by the number of wives required to be present. At the recent resignation-inauguration, for example, it was wonderful to observe the crowd of wives who had been dusted off and brought to the East Room to shed a tear, beam with pride, etc.

PUBLIC television will be offering some interesting programs this season, but also it will not be offering some. A number of operas--among them, "La Traviata," the Brecht-Weill "Seven Deadly Sins" and Stravinsky's "L'Histbire du Soldat," which WNET in New York had hoped to produce-have been scratched.

The social changes that are altering America's religious landscape are beginning to have an impact on the real estate market. In Westchester County alone, there are literally or figuratively "For Sale" signs in front of buildings and land with a total value of more than $10million.
Sarah Caldwell's production of "Ariadne auf Naxos" returned, essentially unchanged, to the New York City Opera repertory yesterday afternoon.

A Federal narcotics agent who had been indicted for murder after shooting and killing a fleeing suspect in a controversial drug raid in 1972 was ordered cleared of all charges here this week by United States District Court Judge Samuel Conti.

Ron Blomberg supplied two home runs as a designated hitter and one as a pinchhitter today as the Yankees dramatically swept a doubleheader from the Cleveland Indians and forced their way to within a half-game of first place in the American League East title race with three games left to play.

William J. Called Jr., the only one among 25 officers and enlisted men found guilty by military courts of the My Lai massacre, has found his relief in a civilian court. The former Army lieutenant was ordered released from prison last week by United States District Court Judge R. Robert Elliott in Columbus, Ga.

The Navy is accelerating development of a low cost, multimission fighter to reduce the number of aircraft types on carriers and to fill the alleged "fighter gap" caused by the cutbacks in the F-14 program.

The days of mailing bill payments without stamps on the envelope may be drawing to a close. Sanford K. Bronstein, former president of the bankrupt Cedars of Lebanon Hospital of Miami, went on trial here this week accused of misappropriating $525,000 of the hospital's funds.

THE 'special genius of American musical comedy doesn't lie in its stars, though God knows that Ethel Merman and Mary Martin and Bobby Clark and Victor Moore have had a thumping great deal to do with it. It doesn't even lie in the songs, for all that the American musical stage has fired off Gershwin and Kern and Rodgers and Berlin scores like rockets around the world.

The City Planning Commission is about to begin an 18month study of zoning in Bay Ridge. The comprehensive study of the neighborhood will concentrate on analyzing housing conditions, community facilities and city services.
Leonard Vander Veld, president of the Jersey City Printing Company, printers and binders of telephone books, died Friday at his home, 6 Spencer Road, Glen Ridge, N. J. His age was 62.

The tendency in Latin America toward violence and terrorism to solve political problems once again has involved a United States Government official. Terrorists in the Dominican Republic have abducted Barbara A. Hutchison, 47 years old, United States Information Service director there, and at least eight other persons, and demanded a $1-million ransom from the United States and the release of 38 political prisoners from Dominican jails.
The city's first Dynamitron, an electric accelerator that can break down the elements of a variety of objects for analysis, is being installed at Brooklyn College.

The former head of a Brooklyn antipoverty program and another man scheduled to go on trial this week in a case of attempted murder and kidnapping were arrested with two other men in Queens late Friday night and charged with possession of hijacked truck cargoes worth more than $250,000.
PARAMUS-Antique and new dolls, plus their houses and furnishings and historically oriented miniature rooms, will be on exhibit next month at the Bergen County Museum of Art and Science.
The ?? of a small synagogue in Oceanside has been chosen to head two national groups that deal with contemporary Jewish problems.

The second annual Lyndon Baines Johnson Foundation award was presented jointly yesterday to Franklin A. Thomas, president pf the Bedford - Stuyvesant Redevolopment Corporation, and former Mayor Ivan Allen Jr. of Atlanta "for their contributions to the betterment of urban life."
The Rev. Jesse L. Jackson announced yesterday plans for a conference early next year among black, Jewish, Arab and Latin religious leaders.

The first hospital stay for 77year-old Mamie Storms was to donate a kidney to her middle-aged son. The transplant operation was performed at Peter Brent Brigham Hospital here yesterday. Mrs. Storms is believed to be the oldest kidney donor.

Calvin Culliver broke up the middle for 85 yards to start Alabama to a 23-10 football victory over Vanderbilt today. The Crimson Tide was beginning the defense of its Southeastern Conference title. The loss was the first in three games for Vanderbilt.

Patricia Eleanore Lewis, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. David W. Lewis of Oradell, N. J., was married yesterday morning to Col. Nicholas K. Bodnar, U. S. M. C. He is a son of Mrs. George Bodnar of New Haven and the late Mr. Bodnar.
TWO years ago, when Mrs. Yekaterina Furtseva, the Soviet Minister of Cultural Affairs, was visiting New York, she was taken on a private visit to the Museum of Modern Art.

WASHINGTON-At 8 A.M. this Tuesday, barring any last minute changes, the cars will start pulling up at the United States Courthouse on Pennsylvania Avenue. First the court staff and the press; then the defendants and their lawyers; then the prosecutors, who have waited 14 months for this day, ever since the special Watergate prosecution was established.
Two policemen have been suspended here as a result of the fatal shooting Monday of a black man who was being chased by the officers, who had warrants for the victim's arrest.
Is Wonderwoman as tough as Superman? No, according to a recent study by the Liberty Mutual Fund Insurance Company. Women are less able to handle physical labor than men.
Marie V. Duff, a Roman Catholic writer and poet, died yesterday in a nursing home in Queens. She was 87 years old and lived at 162-24 Crocheron Avenue, Flushing.
Two gunmen hijacked a light plane last night and forced the pilot to take them on a bombing mission over Northern Ireland, the police said .today.

EAST ORANGE-The second phase of a new program to provide housing for juveniles in need of supervision will begin this week under the direction of the Children's Aid and Adoption Society of New Jersey.

Ten years after President Johnson signed the Economic Opportunity Act on Aug. 20, 1964, declaring it "the policy of the United States to eliminate the paradox of poverty in the midst of plenty," poverty is in much less danger than the Office of Economic Opportunity. The House voted in May to repeal the act and transfer remaining O.E.O. programs to other agencies, and the matter is now before the Senate.

The Banca Privata Italiana, part of the, group run by Michele Sindona, has been put into liquidation, the Bank of Italy announced today. The decision followed efforts by a consortium set up to save the bank.

TRENTON - A controversial bill that calls for the establishment statewide housing - construction code is scheduled for a public hearing here on Oct. 9. Action by the State Senate is expected to follow soon there-after.

Call it a renaissance or a robbery - or maybe just a cruel double-twist of good fortune and bad. Whatever it was, Princeton pulled out a 6-6 tie with Rutgers today in college football's oldest rivalry and then was unable to kick for the extra point because both goal posts had been torn down.

MONTGOMERY, Ala.-The latest Gallup poll arrived here Friday just in time to catch George Wallace as he headed out of state once again in search of his political future. George Wallace is running; recovered from another of those little infections that periodically attack his partially paralyzed body. It is not clear at this point just what he is running for, but he is running.

Curtailing his schedule because of his wife's surgery, President Ford assigned Nelson A. Rockefeller, the Vice-President designate, today to substitute for him, on a planned three-day Western trip next week.

Every year is an "aster year," and every autumn seems to be specially favored with those flowers that were named for the stars. But this is a special year for the purple asters, especially those big, spectacular ones called New England asters.

The week-long Jewish Festival of Succoth, or Feast of the Tabernacles, begins at sundown tomorrow. Leaders of major Jewish groups, in messages for the holiday, stressed the festival's theme of thanksgiving and happiness.

KINSHASA, Zaire, Sept. 28 (AP)-George Foreman announced today that he would resume full training early next week for his world heavyweight title fight with Muhammad Ali scheduled for Oct. 30 (Oct. 29 in the United States). Foreman has been staying in town and will move his entourage back to his camp at N'Sele, 40 miles away, on Monday.
The Social Security Administraction has notified a 73-yearold Bronx woman, whose husband of 40 years died seven ears ago, that she will no longer receive widow's benefits.

A 14-year-old youth was arrested last might for disrupting services at a synagogue in the Bensonhurst section of Brooklyn and assaulting an elderly man who tried to eject him from the temple, police reported.

Joseph Garneau Ringwalt Sr., former chairman of the Joseph Garneau Company, Inc., wine importers here, and a past president of the National Association of Alcoholic Beverage Importers,died Friday in Yonkers. .

" AMARCORD" ("I remember" in the vernacular of Romagna) is Federico Fellini's 13th feature and as full of marvels as anything he's ever done. It takes place in the early 1930's in a small Adriatic resort town that seems to be Fellini's recollection of Rimini, where he was born and grew up, although it's sometimes as exotic as the ancient Rome of "Satyricon" and as familiar as the Rimini Fellini remembered in "I Vitelloni."

But things have gotten so bad for me now, I can see myself living on the streets, and I'm scared."

Governor Wilson ordered the State Civil Service Department today to stop collecting ethnic information on state employes. The department had been collecting the information in efforts to show it was complying with equal-opportunity standards, but some conservatives had protested that the program threatened to set up a "quota" system for ethnic balance in state jobs.

"Amarcord," Federico Fellini's latest film, apparently his biggest success since "La Dolce Vita," is, says the director, about "a tiny little village with people suffocating in it, with one year representing a whole life span." In the vernacular of Romagna, the. area of Italy that Mr. Fellini comes from, "Amarcord" means "I remember," and this is Mr. Fellini's look back at his adolescence in the nineteen-thirties.

BERLIN-The one piece of encouraging news that can be reported from a Europe heading into a winter of discontent-marked by inflation, social tension and political instability-is that West Berlin is alive and well and still prospering a hundred miles inside Communist East Germany.

The Securities Industry Asso-; ciation disclosed today that it had asked the New York Stock Exchange to revise substantially upward its proposal to increase minimum fixed commission rates by an average of 8 per cent on orders between $5,000 and $300,000.
Nearly half the population of Newark would be eligible for Government medical assistance under the terms of a bill adopted today by the State Senate, according to one reliable estimate.

Yields declined on Treasury bills auctioned today in both the 91-day and 180-day maturities. The average rate for the three-month bill was 6.39 per cent, down from 7.00 per cent for the preceding week.

The 32-year-old law secretary to a State Supreme Court justice was found shot to death in his office in the State Supreme Court Building here this morning.

With the approaching Bicentennial, there is a lot of talk about American art. Almost every proposal includes an American art show, and the rummaging and ransacking of museum cellars and attics have already begun. For too long, Americans have thought of their native work as a poor second to European sources. But the best American work reveals a fresh vision, gentle insights, incisive reporting and surprising beauties.
The Senate Watergate committee, its mission over and its files closed, officially went out of business today, 19 months after it was created by the Senate.

Democratic party factions that have been warring most of the summer about minority participation in party affairs will meet here Oct. 10, hoping to resolve their differences before the Democratic charter conference in Kansas City in December.

Wall Street, which has already seen 122 brokerage houses disappear in the last two years, lost another oldline company yesterday. White, Weld Co.. the big investment banking firm, announced plans to take over G. H. Walker, Laird, Inc. This company, which traces its origins back to St. Louis nearly 75 years ago, itself went through a merger a little more than a year ago.
The two major groupings of oil-exporting nations refused invitations to attend the joint annual meeting of the International Monetary Fund and the World Bank, informed sources have disclosed.
Humane groups and law enforcement officials asked Congress today for legislation to curb the growing problem of dogfighting and attendant gambling and other illegalities.

Arnold S. Rinaldi, an architect with offices in Hempstead, L.I., died Sunday in Mercy Hospital, Rockville Centre, L.I., after a cerebral hemorrhage. He was 49 years old and lived at 53 North Long Beach Avenue in Freeport, L.I.

Five protesters, affiliated with a group headed by Philip F. Berrigan, the former priest and antiwar leader, scaled a 254-foot natural gas storage tank today and unfurled banners proclaiming an "international week of concern for political prisoners in South Vietnam."

Clyde King's contract as manager of the Atlanta Braves has been extended through the 1976 season. The soft-spoken King had been named interim pilot of the National League club on July 24, relieving Eddie Mathews.

Former President Richard M. Nixon will not be medically fit to travel to Washington for one to three months to testify in the Watergate cover-up trial, Mr. Nixon's doctor said here today.
The point of "National Town Meetings," a new series carried Sundays at 4:30 P.M. on the Public Broadcasting Service, is to "rekindle the spirit of participatory democracy in the United States."

The Rev. Dr. Edward S. Frey, who retired in April as head of the Commission on Church Architecture of the Lutheran Church in America, died yesterday, apparently of a heart attack, at his home at 120 Adams Avenue, River Edge, N. J.

Elmendorf Farm's Big Spruce, the winner of the Marlboro Cup in New York two weeks ago, and Harry T. Mangurian's Desert Vixen, a leading filly, head a list of six American thoroughbreds which the Laurel race track president, John D. Schapiro is considering for invitations to the Washington D. C. International to be run here Nov. 9.

Smoldering controversy over the proposed merger of the Thermal Power Company and the Natomas Company, both of San Francisco, flared into legal action today when one of a number of disgruntled brokers and stockholders filed a class action suit in Superior Court here.

Joseph Shure, a senior vice president and director of Bache Co., stockbrokers, and resident manager of its New Haven office, died yesterday of a heart attack in Woodbridge, Conn., where he lived. He was 68 years old.

The Great Atlantic and Pacific Tea Company, Inc., operated profitably in the second quarter and first half of this fiscal year, in contrast to yearearlier deficits. Ethiopia's military rulers tonight rescinded the appointment of two generals to top posts, causing speculation that there was a power struggle in the military council running the country.

Premier Bulent Ecevit, whose coalition Cabinet collapsed two weeks ago in a dispute over Turkey's Cyprus policy, abandoned today an attempt to form a new Government.

Jerry Koosman concluded his finest season in five years last night when he pitched the Mets to a 5-2 victory last night over Philadelphia that prevented the Phillies from taking sole possession of third place in the National League's Eastern Division.

At the age of 10, Antonio Vitali became interested in wood-carving. Now 55 years later, the Italian-born Swiss designer is still putting this talent to use, creating wooden toys for children.

Senators Jacob K. Javits and Claiborne Pell flew back to Washington today to report on a total of 10 hours of talks with Premier Fidel Castro and other Cuban leaders about improving relations between the United States and Cuba.

When the Quintet of the Hot Club of France caught the attention of the jazz world almost 40 years ago, it was primarily because of the playing of Diango Reinhardt, the Belgian gypsy guitarist, the first non-American Jazz musician to be an influence on American jazzmen. Stephane Grappelli, the violinist in the quintet (which also included two other guitarists and a string bass), gained some recognition, but was always overshadowed by Mr. Reinhardt's presence.

Viktor Korchnoi and Anatoly Karpov adjourned the seventh game of their final Candidates Match for the right to play for the world championship in a level position after 44 moves tonight in the House of Unions. Karpov, who leads the match with two victories to Korchnoi's none, can afford draws, but Korchnoi must even up before 24 games are played or lose the contest.

With celebration still fresh in their minds, the New York Giants learned yesterday that two injured regulars on offense, Ron Johnson and Tom Mullen, probably would not play against the Atlanta Falcons Sunday at Yale Bowl.

The superior court's Appellate Division refused to overturn a Board of Public Utility Commissioners ruling rejecting a 34 per cent rate increase for the Monmouth Consolidated Water Company. The company claimed that the Board miscalculated its financial position in granting only a 9 per cent increase on Oct. 15, 1973, to raise an additional $599,773 in revenues.

JoAnne Carner, aided by an eagle on the seventh hole, won her sixth tournament this year with a threestroke victory today over Donna Caponi Young in the $35,000 Portland Golf Classic. Mrs. Carner finished eight under par with a 71-211.

Directors of Metro-GoldwynMayer, Inc., authorized today a cash tender offer in midOctober for all of its outstanding 5 per cent convertible debentures due in 1993 and a proposed offer early next year to exchange outstanding common stock for a callable new issue.

The heads of the World Bank and the International Monetary Fund presented today worried views of the world economic situation for both rich and poor nations as the two institutions opened their annual meeting.

When Howard R. Topoff flew to Panama recently, he took along a 50-pound generator hooked to a household vacuum cleaner. After 10 days of sweeping, Mr. Topoff and his assistant, Raymond Mendez, returned last week from the tropics with their mission accomplished: The half million army ants they vacuumed up are now on view at the American Museum of Natural History.

Cynthia Gregory, one of the country's leading young ballerinas and a principal dancer with the American Ballet Theater. plans to dance in Cuba next month. She will be the first major American artist to perform there since Washington and Havana broke off diplomatic relations in 1961.
A Jewelry salesman was robbed yesterday of jewels valued at $195,000 by two armed men, one of whom was wearing a police uniform, the police said.
Seymour B. Durst, owner of the 123 Hotel, at 123 West 44th Street, said yesterday that the hotel would remain open despite an announcement earlier by the operator that he planned to abandon it today.

Seven persons were killed last night when a flash fire ripped through a rooming house above a South Side tavern. Two persons were injured. The blaze, which fire officials said was of "suspicious origin," swept through the upper floor of the two-story brick building in only 10 minutes.

The Health Department has released the names of 19 more restaurants and food stores in the city accused of having violated the Health Code after their owners failed to correct infractions that persisted through Br two inspections.
Bridget Della Connorton, widow of Patrick Connorton and mother of Dr. John V. Connorton, a former Deputy Mayor, died Sunday in the Mary Manning Walsh Home She was 83 years old.

In his most slashing attack of the campaign so far, Governor Wilson charged yesterday that State Senator Mary Anne Krupsak, the Democratic candidate for Lieutenant Governor, was "soft on crime" and had "voted for dirty books and dirty pictures."

A legislative measure that would guarantee the right of a child to express a choice between living with a father or a mother in a legal matrimonial proceeding received final legislative approval here this evening in the Assembly by a vote of 65 to 1.

Congress finished work today on a $7.1-billion railroad retirement financial reorganization bill and sent it to President Ford.

The Foreign Minister of Kuwait, in an address tonight to the General Assembly, rejected any link between the energy and food crises and defended the oil-producing countries against the charge that their prices had caused worldwide inflaten.

Prime Minister Pierre Elliott Trudeau's new Government, bolstered by a strong parliamentary majority won in the July elections, outlined today a legislative program concentrating on control of inflation through restraints on spending and the expansion of production.
The Senate voted by 72 to 16 a series of restrictions on foreign aid that would cut off military aid to Chile, stop fertilizer aid to South Vietnam and reaffirm its cutoff on military aid to Turkey.

President Ford gave unqualified support today to a longterm, $11-billion mass-transit bill and won the support of 22 Mayors and eight business and labor leaders in helping to press for legislation during this session of Congress.

The Senate Finance Committee is considering a plan to impose a 10 per cent tariff on the price of imported oil, informed Senate sources said today. A copy of the proposal was made available to Reuters.

Trenton was added today to the Labor Department's list of major labor areas with substantial unemployment. The jobless rate in Trenton rose to 6.7 per cent of the work force in August, a resuit primarily of cutbacks in fabricated metals, and eletrical machinery, the Government said.

Julio Vasquez, the suspect arrested in the dismemberment murder of Police Officer Patrick V. Kelly, was sent to the Bellevue Hospital Center for a psychiatric examination after his arraignment yesterday.
Fred J. Rosenau, retired board chairman of the country's largest manufacturer of children's dresses, died Monday at his home near Philadelphia. He was 87 years old and lived in Rydal, Pa.

Phillips--has been withdrawn by the Government, primarily because Mr. Phillips's credibility has been brought into question.

Just as the report of the bipartisan select committee on reorganization of the House of Representatives finally got to the floor for debate, superbaron Wilbur Mills tried to yank it back behind the closed doors of the Democratic Caucus to give it an indecent private burial.

Wall Street's experiment to extend trading by 30 minutes a day in an effort to produce more revenue for hard--pressed stockbrokers got under way here yesterday, but the reaction among brokers--despite a strong increase in Big Board trading--was mixed.
The state's Public Advocate, Stanley C. Van Ness, filed a petition with the Federal Power Commission today to block construction of a proposed liquefied natural-gas storage facility in Woodbridge.

Richard Stone, a Miami and Tallahassee businessman, appeared late tonight to have won the Democratic nomination for the Senate in Florida.

Andy Etchebarren got the winning run across for the Orioles in both games today. After driving in the winning run as a ninth-inning pinch-hitter in he 7-6 victory over the Detroit Tigers, the Baltimore catcher was the man holding the telephone and relaying information through the last half of the 10th inning in Milwaukee, as the Eastern Division title was clinched for the Orioles by the 3-2 defeat suffered by the New York Yankees.

In 1960, three men were convicted of killing a patron of a New Jersey tavern. Shortly after the jury verdict, two of the men recanted their prior statements implicating the third man and said that the third man had been an unwilling participant in the murder.

The Fitzgerald family of East Orange, which has already contributed one member to the United States Olympic track and field team, has two more at home with similar ambitions. Gale Fitzgerald, senior member of the clan at age 23, placed 19th for the United States in the women's pentathlon at Munich in 1972 and is now in Texas studying for her doctorate and preparing for next year's Pan-American Games in Brazil.

A convicted murderer, his Wealthy father and a lawyer were indicted today on charges that they conspired to kill three persons who had been witnesses in the trial that resulted in the murder conviction and a life sentence.

Dr. Leonard W. Larson, president of the American Medical Association in 1961 and an advocate of a sound system of voluntary prepayment for medical services, died Monday at Bismarck, N.D. He was 76 years old.

The Museum of Natural History will become a diorama of living diversions Saturday when it plays host to the community to celebrate its fifth annual West Side Day. Beginning at 10 A.M. the museum's four floors will be the setting for steel band concerts, marionette shows, movies and live dancing.

Frank Robinson will be named playing manager of the Cleveland Indians tomorrow, thereby becoming the first black manager in major league baseball history, United Press International reported yesterday. Robinson's salary will remain at its present $173,000 level, automatically making him the highest-paid manager in the history of baseball.
State troopers patrolled the New Jersey Turnpike today ready to hand out summonses to enforce the anti-noise code recently adopted by the New Jersey Turnpike Authority.

The New York Mets unveiled their fifth -general manager yesterday, the lowkeyed Joseph Anthony McDonald, a loyal and original Met. But McDonald, who had been the team's director of minor league operations, spoke frankly about his team and his role.

The Pakistani Government said today that if guerrillas in Baluchistan province did not respond to an Oct. 15 deadline to come down from the hills, "then we will have to hit them with whatever we have got."

Two men were shot to death early yesterday in an East Side nightclub after two gunmen burst in and reportedly called out, "Little Rabbit, where are you?" A State Supreme Court jury has acquitted the man it knows as Louis Velazquez of a murder charge while convicting him of robbery and possession of a weapon.

In the last 47 years, the Pittsburgh Pirates have had either 17 or 20 managers, depending on how you count Daniel Edward Murtaugh, who has taken the job four times and given it back thrice. Over that span they have won two world championships, both under Murtaugh's direction; two National League pennants, both under Murtaugh; and three half-pennants, two under Murtaugh.
Portugal's armed forces have been placed on full alert as a precaution against a coup, following the resignation yesterday of President Antonio de Spinola.

Senate and House conferees worked out today a compromise to end a deadlock that had threatened to scuttle campaign spending reform legislation.

Scientists at the University of Texas in Austin announced yesterday that by using a new device that heats gas by means of intense turbulence they had achieved temperatures about 10 times higher than those within the sun.

The area of former President Richard M. Nixon's right lung that was damaged by a blood clot that broke off from a vein in his phlebitis-damaged left leg has partly healed and no new blood clots have lodged in either lung in the past week, Mr. Nixon's doctor said here today.

The restoration of normal relations with Cuba is something this newspaper has long advocated; but we don't think Senator Javits' and Senator Pell's weekend in Havana was a very good way of furthering that goal. Last Friday, the two Senators, one a New York Republican and the other a Rhode Island Democrat, accompanied by a large party of journalists flew to Cuba in a kind of spectacular with Marxist-Leninist variations.

A Federal judge told a Government prosecutor yesterday that he was "completely outraged" at the treatment of a Chilean jailed here by mistake and then kept in isolation by narcotics agents despite a release order.

The offices occupy the 13th floor of a gleaming building in St. James's, one of London's ivoried neighborhoods. and its windows frame hazy views of green parks, the spires of Parliament and the cupolas of Whitehall.
The New York Yankees finally shouted their last hurrah tonight when they were defeated by the Milwaukee Brewers in 10 innings, 3-2, and fell out of the race for their first pennant in 10 years.

A large group of youths armed with chains, sticks, knives, pipes, a dagger and a zip-gun rampaged on a southbound IND "F" train in the Borough Park section of Brooklyn yesterday morning, threatening passengers before being ejected by transit policemen at the Avenue I station.

As expected, routinely and by voice vote, the Senate yesterday confirmed the nomination of Richard L. Roudebush, former United States Representative from Indiana, to be the Veterans Administrator. The former lawmaker,

The board of Merrill Lynch Co., Inc., the holding company for the nation's largest stock brokerage firm, approved yesterday a formal plan and agreement to acquire the Family Life Insurance Company of Seattle.

Despite a clear and widespread wish to cooperate, important differences emerged today among the world's leading industrial nations on how to cope with the massive problem caused by higher oil prices and other financial strains in the world's economy.
Air travelers were granted a measure of relief yesterday from relentlessly rising fares when the Civil Aeronautics Board approved a 25 per cent winter discount for many domestic flights.
Treasury bills rose in yield yesterday, following sharp susained declines during the preious three weeks. Both the three-month and six-month ills added some 50 basis points.
The Venezuelan Government today increased the taxes it charges United States and other foreign oil companies operating here, and said the increase Would be retroactive to Jan. 1.
A two-run homer by Mike Jorgensen of the Montreal Expos in the eighth inning sank the St. Louis Cardinals, 3-2, tonight and dimmed their chances for a National League East Division championship.
The White House is going ahead with three social evetns that were on the schedule before Betty Ford became ill. Mrs. Ford's daughter Susan, 17 years old, will help as hostess.

Total United States reserve assets rose $548-million in August to a total of $15.46-billion with a surge in convertible foreign currency holdings, the Treasury Department reported today. Reserve assets at the end of July were $14.91-billion.
The Defense Department reported today that in the second quarter of this year the projected cost of 42 major weapons programs increased by $16.9-billion, largely because of inflation.

Controversy over the Air Force's intercontinental B-1 nuclear bomber is expected to intensify with new Pentagon estimates that each aircraft will cost $76-million, an increase of $14.5-milion over the previous estimate.

President Ford's scheduled testimony before a house subcommittee would mark only the second time that an incumbent President had appeared in person before a panel of Congress, according to research done last year by the Library of Congress.

Frank Robinson will be named playing manager of the Cleveland Indians tomorrow, thereby becoming the first black manager in major league baseball history, United Press International reported yesterday. Robinson's salary will remain at its present $173,000 level, automatically making him the highest-paid manager in the history of baseball.

Viktor Korchnoi is having so much trouble getting anything out of his openings against Anatoly Karpov in their final candidates match here in the House of Unions that he is reduced to playing out end games of any kind, favorable or not.

President Nguyen Van Thieu tonight denied allegations of Corruption recently made against him but rhetorically offered to resign from office if, as he put it, "the entire people and army no longer have confidence in me."
The acting administrative director of New Jersey's courts reported today that $327,000 had been paid out of a special fund to clients fleeced by their lawyers. Arthur J. Simpson Jr.,

The Federal Energy Administration, John C. Sawhill, warned oil refiners today not to raise prices to recover any costs they may have entered on their books under a so-called double-dip provision of the crude oil allocation regulations.

Former Unites States Attorney General Ramsey Clark charged yesterday that Senator Jacob K. Javits had accepted large campaign contributions from "representatives of the most powerful special interest lobbies."
Dermot Morrah, an expert on British royalty and ceremony who held the title of Arundel Herald Extraordinary, died yesterday. He was 78 years old. He leaves his wife and two daughters..
The Department of Labor is imposing permanent rules to protect plastics workers against cancer by restricting the amount of vinyl chloride to which they may be exposed. Page 26.

By volunteering to appear before a committee of the House of Representatives to answer questions about the pardon he granted to Richard Nixon, President Ford has set an admirable example of open and responsive government. Such readiness to be accountable to Congress gains in significance by its contrast to the Nixon Administration's defiant custom of hiding behind the stone wall of executive privilege.

Stefan Cardinal Wyszinski, the Archbishop of Warsaw, told the Synod of Bishops of the Roman Catholic Church today that the Communist bloc was still a fertile field for evangelization despite official efforts there to discourage it.

ALLEGAERT--Beatrice C. in Laconia, N. H. September 30th. Widow of Pierre H. Allegaert Mother of Winthrop J. Allegaert, Scarsoale, N.Y. and Mrs. Beatrice ?? Officer, Hanover, N.H. Services at St. Joseph's Church in Laconia, N.H. Friday at 2 P.M.
A 25-cent can of soda has turned into an $875 headache for the handlers of a trotter who finished second in a race at Batavia Downs last Sept, 5.

Seward, Neb. -- Many of "F.D.R.'s trees" still shade the Great Plains. Franklin Delano Roosevelt, seeing the choking black dust that billowed from the Plains over other parts of the country in the early nineteen-thirties, authorized the planting of a 20O-milewide strip of "shelterbelts" of trees that stretched a thousand miles from the Dakotas southward through the Texas Panhandle.
Bob Robertson of the Pirates. swung at a pitch, hit a tworun homer and called it fate. Some might look at Manager Danny Murtaugh and call it Irish luck or just plain genius.
The body of Mrs. E. B. Reville, kidnapped yesterday by three gunmen, was found in the trunk of her car on a dirt road west of here late today, the Federal Bureau of Investigation said.
A proposal to strip the President of power to order wiretaps in foreign intelligence investigations without advance Federal Court approval is causing sharp divisions in Congress.
The computer industry has long been described as a young man's business. Apparently the board of Honeywell, Inc., took that into consideration yesterday when it shook up top management.
Dr. Edward J. Bloustein, Rutgers University president, called today for a massive lobbying of the Legislature to try to stave off a budget crisis at the university.
When the New York Public Library received $368,000 last year f-om the estate of a man named Martin Radtke, officials wondered who he was.
A State Supreme Court judge dismissed charges in Queens yesterday against five persons indicted last June in connection with the alleged use of stolen engines by the Lee Myles Transmissions Company.
School officials broke up a brief scuffle between white and black students in the South Boston High library today. There were no injuries.
The Dominican left, moderate to radical, has totally disassociated itself from the seizure of the Venezuelan Consulate and the kidnapping of the head of the United States Information Service here.

James W. Gunter, a reporter and editor with Stars and Stripes, the Army newspaper, died, apparently of a heart attack, Monday .evening at his home in Odenwald, near Darmstadt, West Germany. He was 53 years old.

Governor Byrne endorsed proposed legislation for Federal public service employment to offset rising unemployment, which he said was "as bad or worse" in New Jersey than anywhere in the country. "Our latest figures show that the unemployment rate in New Jersey has reached 8.3 per cent," Mr. Byrne told the House Select Subcommittee on Labor in Washington.

Leading chain organizations across the nation registered a gain of 11 per cent in sales volume In August, compared with August, 1973, according to Chain Store Age. For the first eight months of the year, sales were 11.7 per cent ahead of the corresponding period of 1973.

A man identified as a major supplier of heroin and cocaine in the metropolitan area was sentenced yesterday to a maximum of 15 years in prison for scheming to import 300 pounds of narcotics in 1970 and 1971.

The Indonesian state oil company, Pertamina, said yesterday, that it had decided not to raise petroleum prices this quarter, marking the first quarter since the oil crisis began in October that the company has not announced price increases.

Seven hours after winning an eventful day game, 7-6, from the DetroitTigers, the Baltimore Orioles emerged tonight 'as champions of American League East when the New York Yankees lost their night game in Milwaukee.

Betty Ford's doctors reported today that she was regaining her strength and had a "very favorable day." The President's wife underwent surgery for breast cancer Saturday at the Bethesda Naval Hospital.

Tourism fell substantially this year in most of the world's developed countries because of the oil crisis and the worsening international economic situation, the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development has reported.
Gilles Villemure, unable to get the National Hockey League's New York Rangers to renegotiate his contract, is retiring, his attorney said yesterday.
Joseph Satkin, a 49-year-old Passaic landlord, was found guilty today of arson, conspiracy and the murder of a woman and three children who died in a fire set last year in three buildings he owned.
The trial of the Watergate cover-up case began today, bringing to a court of law the events that caused a two-year national trauma and then, on Aug. 9, forced Richard M. Nixon from the Presidency.

The ideological and personality divergences inside Portugal's military leadership have finally broken the new Government apart, removing the thin facade of pragmatic unity which gave the Portuguese people their best hope for achieving a stable democratic system. In his dignified but emotional speech of resignation, President Antonio de Spinola warned that the country was headed toward chaos, toward "new forms of slavery." Ominously enough,
Representative William L. Hungate said today that President Ford would testify before a House subcommittee next week, no later than Thursday, about his pardon of former President Richard M. Nixon.
No less than artists or works of art, collections, too, acquire their aura of legend, mystery and scandal. This was certainly the case with the colelection of Joseph H. Hirshhorn.

The Securities and Exchange Commission filed fraud charges yesterday against three executives of the North American Philips Corporation, alleging that they had bought Magnavox shares on the basis of inside information shortly before Philips announced an offer for all the shares of Magnavox.

An 81-year-old woman and her three grandchildren, caught between the bureaucracies of the city's public housing and public assistance agencies, escaped eviction when the Department of Social Services turned over $716 yesterday to the New York City Housing Authority.

Judge Sylvestor J. Ryan of the United States Court for the Southern District ruled on Monday in favor of The Hunting World in connection with a five-year-old suit filed against that New York store by Aber crombie Fitch. Abercrombie had charged that the Hunting World infringed on the "Safari" trademark owned by Abercrombie.
Connecticut's three major electric power companies overcharged customers in the last year by $11-million, United States Representative Ella T. Grasso said today.

Hudson County Prosecutor James O'Holleran said today his office had begun extradition proceedings against Arthur W. Smith, the California truck driver suspected of raping five Hudson and Union County women last sib month while he allegedly was in New Jersey on long-distance truck deliveries.
Deputy Defense Secretary William P. Clements Jr. today accused North Vietnam of "total disregard" of the Vietnam peace agreement and indicated support for South Vietnam's requests for more aid.
Cigarette smokers would help finance the fight against cancer under a proposal that would put an additional 2-cent tax on each pack of cigarettes.
The city yesterday paid the highest interest rate ever, 7.79 per cent, in the sale of $420.4million in one-year bond anticipation notes.

Traders in commodity futures could feel the chill in the air yesterday in the Midwest and the Northeast, and they did not need precise weather news to tell them that frost was damaging more crops. The result was a resumption in the strong price rise in soybeans.

The European Economic Community tonight ended a potentially destructive conflict touched off by a veto by West Germany, last week of price Increases for, the community's 10 million inflation-squeezed farmers.
The Times Square Theater Center, the discount-ticket outlet at Broadway and 47th Street, is extending its halfprice ticket service to the financial district, Mayor Beame announced yesterday.

The Environmental Protection Agency announced today regulations designed to limit the discharge of water pollutants from steam - driven power plants. Over industry objections, the agency is requiring installation of cooling towers on most plants to reduce discharges of heated water into streams and lakes. Only small, old plants would be exempt from the regulation.

A majority of American women now favor efforts to improve their status in society, according to a nationwide poll released yesterday. The poll, conducted by The Roper Organization, Inc., showed that 57 per cent of the women questioned now give a clear vote of confidence to efforts to change or strengthen their status, while only 25 per cent are opposed.

The Federal Government yesterday dropped its tax charges against two members of the staff of former Queens District Attorney Thomas J. Mackell. The men had been accused of having failed to report income of approximately $168,000 they had gained from an illegal getrich.nuick scheme.

Iran has offered to purchase 36 McDonnell Douglas Phantom jets similar to the latest version of the United States Air Force F-4E model of the twin engine, two man, all-weather weapons system, the company said. Terms of the purchase were not disclosed but industry sources estimated the sale price to be in excess of $150-million.
A rookie, Willie Spencer, scored five touchdowns tonight to lead the Memphis Southmen to a 47-19 rout of the Jacksonville Sharks that ran their World Football League winning streak to nine.
Gilles Villemure, the tough little Ranger goalie who announced his "retirement" on Tuesday, said last night, "I'm going back to work tomorrow."

Governor Wilson yesterday announced a new state mentalhealth program that he said would provide for careful follow-up and treatment of all patients released from state mental institutions into community facilities for rehabilitation.

If someone wants to tell the story of America, culturally, socially and politically, from 1945 to 1974 "through song, dances, sketches, slides and original radio broadcasts," he should think about doing something else-unless he has more theatrical imagination than is demonstrated in "See America First."
Miron Kaciupsky admits he probably has no legal ground on which to fight the redevelopment agency that wants him out of his unmechanized, one-car-at-a-time, bucketand-hose car wash here.
Isrtel is in a stronger military position now in relation to Egypt and Syria than before the outbreak of the war a year ago, according to American experts.

Many a small ad agency starts out handling only local advertisers and never goes any further. Not so Van Leeuwen Advertising of New Haven, founded in 1968, which graduated to regional and then national accounts.

Nelson A. Rockefeller made his first public appearance in a Vice-Presidential-like role today, substituting for President Ford at a university in Utah and a convention here despite what the former New York Governor described as his "suspended" status.

James Driver Sr., who had been a member of the stereotype department of The New York Times since 1945, died Monday evening in Lydia E. Hall Hospital, Freeport, L. I. He was 67 years old and lived at 304 Martin Place, Bellmore, L. I.

The west German central bank said today that West Germany had a basic balance-of-payments deficit in August of $420-million, in contrast to a revised surplus of $189.9-million in July. The deficit was the first this year. The bank put the August, 1973, payments surplus at. $812.9-million.

A substantial cutback in oil consumption by the main importing countries has been suggested by the United States as the first step in a strategy to force down world prices. Some European officials said Secretary of State Kissinger had mentioned a 15 per cent cutback at meetings in Washington with British, West German, French and Japanese ministers last weekend.
Senator Thomas P. Eagleton told the Senate Foreign Relations Committee today that a vote to confirm Peter M. Flanigan as Ambassador to Spain "will disgrace the United States."

The Los Angeles Dodgers got a chance, in 1974, to replay their disappointing season of 1973, and this time they made it come out right. In 1973, with a fundamentally young squad stressing speed and pitching, they led the Western Division of the National League by as much as 8 1/2 games in mid-July.

The dancers of Jose Coronado's company spent an inordinate amount of time lying on the floor of the Cubiculo during Mr. Coronado's dance concert on Tuesday evening. Creative use of stillness is one thing, but this looked like an attack of sleeping sickness.

The Jewis Documentation Center, which Simon Wiesenthal runs here for tracing Nazi criminals, lost the equivalent of nine months operating expenses through the collapse last month of are Austrian bank.

China today praised the Arab countries' use of oil as a political weapon. Speaking in the General Assembly, Chiao Kuan-hua, a Deputy Foreign Minister, declared that a "historic pioneering action" taken by the Arabs could have enormous impact in the third world's struggle against "imperialist plunder and exploitation."

Henry Aaron, whose first swing this season resulted in the home run that tied Babe Ruth's career mark of 714, lined a solo shot over the left-field fence in his final swing of the season tonight for home run No. 733.

House of Representatives voted tonight to cut by more than three-quarters the amount of money sought by former President Richard M. Nixon to pay for his pension and official expenses as a private citizen.

Television needs another sports show about as urgently as radio needs another rock-music station, but logic has rarely been triumphant over opportunism in the broadcasting industry. So now, on the Public Broadcasting Service, of all places, there is a 13-week series of half-hours called "The Way It Was."

With Ron Johnson a doubtful starter because of an ankle he sprained in last Sunday's game, Doug Kotar figures to be seeing more action at running back against Atlanta this Sunday in the Yale Bowl, and he welcomes the extra work.

Parents of patients at the Willowbrook Developmental Center on Staten Island testified in Federal Court in Brooklyn yesterday that their children had deteriorated physically, mentally and emotionally while at the center.
A House panel considering a, Federal ban on dogfighting for sport was told today of an Illinois fight in which pigeon blood was poured over one of the dogs to illustrate its desire for blood.
President Joaquin Balaguer of the Dominican Republic has decided to exert additional pressure on the leftist terrorists who are holding seven hostages in the Venezuelan Consulate here.

The prices for most meats dropped sharply last week, lowering the over-all cost of feeding a family here, but consumer agencies interpreted the price decline as a portent of bad things rather than a sign of a trend to lower prices.
Prof. Spyridon Marinatos, former inspector general of Greece's Archeological Services, has died in a fall on the Aegean island of Thera. He was 73 years old.
A committee on judges' conduct found yesterday that a Supreme Court justice who had called some of his colleagues "outright thieves," "fakers" and "lazy" had failed to prove his charges.

A substantial cutback in oil consumption by the main importing countries has been suggested by the United States as the first step in a strategy to force down world prices. Some European officials said Secretary of State Kissinger had mentioned a 15 per cent cutback at meetings in Washington with British, West German, French and Japanese ministers last weekend.

One boy was killed and at least six others were severely burned at the Rhode Island training School tonight when they were trapped in a windowless day room that they had set fire, school officials said. Officials said two boys, placed on punishment detail for setting fire to a mattress earlier in the day, barricaded the dayroom with pool tables.

Anatoly Karpov adjourned the eighth ?me of his final candidates watch for the world championship a pawn ahead in a minor-piece ending with Viktor Korchnoi after 41 moves here in the House of Unions tonight.

The first clear warning of the impact that the new oil prices could have on world economics and politics was sounded last January by Walter J. Levy, the oil economist. He laid out the figures on what oil would cost the consuming countries, and pay the producers, and concluded that urgent steps were necessary to avoid "international economic disorder."

Prices on the American Stock Exchange closed lower again yesterday but those in the overthe-counter market rose on profit taking. Overall, there was no news that could be construed as encouraging investment.

Billie Goodson Pierce, who with her husband, De De Pierce, led the Preservation Hall Jazz Band in the nineteen-sixties, died Tuesday in New Orleans. She was 67 years old. Mrs. Pierce played the piano and her husband, who died Nov. 23, 1973, played trumpet and comet.

The Public Service Commission today approved by a 3-to-2 vote a water-rate increase totaling $948,869 a year for the New Rochelle Water Company. Earlier, the P.S.C. had granted the company a $400,000 interim increase and added $548,869 in the Dermanent rise.
The City Council today approved substantial raises for themselves, Mayor Kenneth A. Gibson and several top administration officials.

Governor Byrne signed into law today the so-called "right to conscience" abortion bill permitting physicians, nurses and hospitals to refuse to perform elective abortions, but he acknowledged that the controversial measure "may go too far."

House and Senate conferees agreed today on a compromise bill to increase education benefits for Vietnam-era veterans by 23 per cent. In addition, the measure would establish a loan program of $600 for each veteran and would extend the maximum duration of benefits for under-graduates to 45 months from the present 36.

A 5-year-old boy, left first by his mother in care of his sister and then by his sister in care of friends who then allegedly left him alone, died yesterday of smoke inhalation after fire broke out in the Manhattan apartment he shared with all of them, the police said.

ACKERMAN-Dorothy M. Beloved mother of Yvette Brownstein and the late George. Adored grandmother Services Friday, 11;45 A.M. Schwartz Brothers "Forest Park Chanpels" Queens Blvd. 76th Rd., Forest Hills.

The Museum of the American Indian, the repository for the most comprehensive collection in its field, is the object of a broad-based state investigation into its deaccession, investment and financial policies.

It would probably be an oversimplification to say that a brawl in a hotel lobby had cost the New York Yankees their last chance for a division title. But that suspicion lingered today as the Yankees ended their dramatic season in second place and put their dream in mothballs for the winter.

Representative Edward I. Koch formally asked Congress and the Federal Government yesterday for both administrative and criminal investigations into the Dairylea Cooperative's admitted adulteration of milk between 1967 and 1973.

Detective Robert Leuci, the prosecution's major witness in a: bribery trial of three suspended detectives, yesterday told the jury that he had rejected the idea of reporting what he knew about police coreruption to his superiors in the department.
Blood serum containing hepatitis, albeit a Harmless strain, was spilled in an air shipment to Washington's National Airport last January, the Federal Aviation Administration disclosed today.

To the Editor: Consuming less oil will not bring down world oil prices. The cartel cuts production, as it has done this summer. And the longer the cartel governments are permitted to accumulate revenues, the easier for them to manage future cutbacks or embargoes.
Citing a recent increase in the number of grounded and floundering bats reported in the city, the Department of Health has warned people not to handle the flying mammals, as they may well be rabid.

Republican candidates appear headed for a sweeping victory in Alaska this year despite the scandals under the Nixon Administration. With the election five weeks away, Democratic candidates seem to be searching frantically for some means of reversing the trend.

In a broadened concept of its regulatory power, the Securities and Exchange Commission asked a federal court here today to require Mattel, Inc., the nation's leading toy manufacturer, to name as a majority of its board of directors persons unaffiliated With the company or with any other with which it does business.

The publicity extravanganza that opened in Federal Courthouse here this week is the most inherently unfair trial in many a year The accused faced the wrong charge in the wrong place before the wrong judge.
The Mobil Oil Corporation announced yesterday it was reducing its gasoline price by 2 cents a gallon effective today. The action reflects lower crudeoil costs in September, the company said,

The election next month will quicken an evolution on Capitol Hill that, in the view of many members of Congress and others, could have revolutionary consequences. Congress, the nation's oldest institution, is getting younger. As a result, it could be entering a period of reform.

Attorney General William B. Saxbe urged Congress today not to "overreact" to the Watergate scandal by requiring Federal court approval of wiretaps that are designed to provide foreign intelligence or "national security" information for the President.

China today praised the Arab countries' use of oil as a political weapon. Speaking in the General Asseinbly, Chiao Kuan-hua, a Deputy Foreign Minister, declared that a "historic pioneering. action" taken by the Arabs could have enormous impact in the third world's struggle against "imperialist plunder and exploitation."

After the Watergate dam broke in the spring of 1973, Peter M. Flanigan was one of the few top-level aides of President Richard M. Nixon who was regarded almost from the beginning as having been "clean."

A study by the New York State Health Department indicares that women exposed early in pregnancy to oral synthetic hormones, such as those in ?? control pills or certain pregnancy tests, may face an increased risk of bearing infants with birth defect.
Sidney L. Jones, Deputy Assistant to the President, said yesterday that "I do not think our system will really function with double-digit inflation-at least the market system we know today."
States and localities with substantial unemployment will receive $350-million to create an estimated 73,000 public service jobs, Secretary of Labor Peter J. Brennan said today.
Israel returned to Syria today a soldier who strayed into Israeli-held territory last month. But the Syrians did not free three Druse civilians in exchange, as had been expected.

Parliamentary elections will be held in Greece Nov. 17, the Government announced tonight. The Greek Cabinet, meeting under Premier Constantine Caramanlis, approved a constitutional law that stipulates that within 15 days after the election the government will announce the date for a referendum of the future of the monarchy.

District Attorney Nichoias Ferraro of Queens said yesterday that his office intended to reargue the dismissal by a State Supreme Court justice of charges against five persons indicted last June in connection with the alleged use of stolen engines by the Lee Myles Transmissions Company "or go to appeal immediately."
President Ford said that his wife, Betty, was "feeling much, much better" tonight after a 90-minute hospital visit during which the Fords telephoned their sons in Massachusetts and Utah.

-Despite what is described as President Ford's reluctance to force out White House holdovers, the exodus of Nixon appointees accelerated today with announcements of six resignations, including that of the Rev. Dr. John McLaughlin, the controversial Jesuit priest.

BULBS, BUDS AND BUSHES Autumn is coming In and the weather from here on in, we're told, will become steadily colder, But let us all pray that the frost will not come too quickly, for the sixth annual Bryant Park Flower Show will open its six-day run today.
The election next month will quicken an evolution on Capitol Hill that, in the view of many members of Congress and others, could have revolutionary consequences.
Nurul Amin, former Vice President of Pakistan, died here today after suffering a heart attack. He was 80 years old.
The House of Representatives, battling for the third day over how .o streamline its committee structure, voted by a wide margin today to retain the controversial House Internal Security Committee.

The United Auto Workers union and the Chrysler Corporation have dropped a four-day workweek experiment at a parts depot in Tappan, N.Y. Both sides said the employes decided after two months they didn't like the program.

Federal health care programs are often biased in favor of city dwellers and suburbanites, In testimony before a House says the co-chairman of the Appalachian Regional Commission. subcommittee yesterday Donald W. Whitehead said that the Government had failed to "recognize the financial and technical poverty of rural America" and that the result was a dearth of medical care outside big city areas.
Tom Van Arsdale and Fred Boyd combined for 35 points tonight as the Philadelphia 76ers surged from a half-time tie to beat the New York Nets, champions of the American Basketball Association, 109-89.

Senator waiter P. Mondale, Democratt of Minnesota, said Moday that financial commitments to his unannounced Presidential campaign surged in the week following the withdrawal announcement from the race of Senator Edward M. Kennedy.

The Shah of Iran arrived here today on the last leg of a 17-day tour of five Asian and Pacific nations. Upon his arrival at New Delhi airport with Empress Farah, Shah Mohammed Riza Pahlevi received one of the warmest welcomes that India has accorded a visiting dignitary.

A 5-year-old boy, left first by his mother in care of his sister and then by his sister in care of friends who then allegedly left him alone, died yesterday of smoke inhalation after fire broke out in the Manhattan apartment he shared with all of them, the police said.

A White House lawyer who worked as special counsel to former President Richard M. Nixon has been added by the prosecution to its list of coconspirators in the Watergate cover-up trial, sources familiar with the case said today.

The crowd outside Casegie Hall on Tuesday evening pushed and shoved, there was excited talk, and clearly it was a Big Event. Was it a Horowitz recital? Karajan and the Berlin Philharmonic? No, it was Virgil Fox, who was giving the dedicatory concert of the new Rodgers electronic organ.
Jeanne Mendelson Loeb of New York and Sarasota, Fla., widow of George A. Loeb, a stock analyst, was married yesterday evening in. Sarasota to F. Samuel Knox of Cincinnati and Sarasota.

Senator Hubert- H. Humphrey complained today about price increases that have pushed the cost of a hamburger to 75 cents in the Senate cafeterias. The Minnesota Democrat said in a statement that he could not understand why it was cheaper to eat in the House cafeterias, where hamburgers cost a dime less.

A White House lawyer who worked as special counsel to former President Richard M. Nixon has been added by the prosecution to its list of coconspirators in the Watergate cover-up trial, sources familiar with the case said today.

The United States has suggested a substantial cutback in oil consumption by the main importing countries as the first step in a determined strategy to force down the world price of petroleum, which has quadrupled in a year.

David C. Devan, former financial chief for the Penn Cen. trial Transportation Company, took the witness stand under subpoena here-yesterday but failed to shed much new light to help a jury decide whether Goldman, Sachs Co., the prestigious investment banking house, should be made to reimburse three investors who lost money on Penn Central commercial paper when the railroad went bankrupt.

The Department of Transportation estimated yesterday that its seven-point "Action Plan" to aid this country's ailing overseas airlines could mean a $149-million increase in revenues for Pan American World Airways by the end of 1975.

Secretary of the Treasury William Simon insisted in testimony before a House subcommittee today that Robert C. Bowen, an oil executive on loan to the Government, "didn't participate in policy decisions."
About 400 ranchers and dairymen herded hundreds of calves before a bulldozed trench today and then scrapped plans for a mass slaughter after an 11th-hour appeal from the White House.

In choosing an opening lead from three small cards, bridge players are divided, like Gaul, into three parts. The majority group, including almost all rubber bridge players and the largest segment of tournament players, leads high. We can call them traditionalists.

Governor Byrne said today that if a state trooper stopped his limousine for speeding he would expect the officer to give his driver a ticket. Mr. Byrne made the remark at his weekly news conference when questioned about an incident last week in which the Governor's limousine, carrying Acting Gov. S. Howard Woodson Jr., was observed exceeding the 55-mile-an-hour speed limit.
The collapse of the Italian Government-probably next week was seen as virtually inevitable in political circles tonight.
The Senate upheld the Ford Administration tonight by voting to shelve-at least until after the November elections-this year's controversial $2.5-billion foreign aid bill. The vote was 41 to 39.
STOCKTON, Calif.-He sits behind his desk in a tan business suit, talking of computers, multi - million - dollar budgets, in-service training, personnel requirements and management objectives.

The former Chilean army commander who was assassinated in Buenos Aires Monday said in a recent letter that Chile's military rulers had been trying to sail his "professional image" because of his service to the Goverinment of President Salvador Allende Gossens.

The whiteminority Government of Rhodesia was denounced before the Roman Catholic Synod of Bishops today as "a political absurdity." The speaker was a white Rhodesian prelate, the Most Rev. Donal Raymond Lamont, Bishop of Urnmtali.

Community Planning Board 4 voted last night to ask a bankruptcy referee to give it more time to consider a proposal by the French and Polyclinic Health School and Medical Center to use its New Yorker Hotel property as a temporary shelter for families made homeless by fires and other disasters.

About a year ago, John V. N. Klein, the Suffolk County Executive, was showing a foreign visitor around the area. "Suffolk is a microcosm of America," he proudly told the visitor, who seemed impressed by the rows of suburban houses and acres of shopping centers.

The three major networks said yesterday that they will carry live television and radio coverage of President Ford's scheduled Oct. 10 appearance before a House Judiciary subcommittee, where he will be questioned about his pardon of former President Richard M. Nixon.

Governor Wilson yesterday announced a new state mentalhealth program that he said would provide for careful followup and treatment of all patients released from state mental institutions into community facilities for rehabilitation.

Factory orders, inventories and shipments rose in August, the Commerce Department reported today. New orders for manufactured products increased $2.93-billion, or 3.4 per cent, to $90.45billion on an adjusted basis. Unfilled orders rose $4.74-billion, or 3.5 per cent, to $139.36. billion.

"If I only had known before I signed the papers what I know now, I would have acted differently," said a woman who was divorced recently. "It's not only the emotional anguish-it's also the financial details that you don't always think of at the time."

NIAMEY, Niger-An extensive international relief effort has substantially ended the famine in Niger, one of the countries most tragically afflicted by last year's catastrophic drought that spanned the African continent immediately below the Sahara.

He said after the game he believed the injury was only a bruise, but the extent of the injury was discovered before practice today.

Secretary of State Kissinger received a $50,000 gift from Nelson A. Rockefeller when Mr. Kissinger left Mr. Rockefeller's staff to join the Nixon Administration, a spokesman for the Secretary of State said tonight.
Mary Watkins Cushing, former dance critic of The New York Herald Tribune, died yesterday at her home, 106 East 85th Street. She was in her 80's and formerly lived in New Canaan, Conn.

Elizabeth J. Horton, a teacher, was married yesterday afternoon in Gardiner, N. Y., to James D. Silbert, a lawyer. Both the bride and her husband are of Gardiner and New York. Rabbi Julius Rosenthal performed the ceremony at the bridegroom's home.
A 27-yard field goal in the last second of play - a field goal Dallas claimed was no good - gave the Minnesota Vikings a 23-21 victory over the Cowboys today.
The Supreme Court will return for a new term tomorrow with a partly disabled Chief Justice and a backlog of more than 1,900 cases.

A young man and young woman from New Jersey who fell asleep in their van, with a charcoal stove still burning, were found dead here yesterday. The couple, both college students in Delaware, apparently died of carbon-monoxide poisoning, the police said.

An unusual galaxy of local and Federal prosecutors joined yesterday to announce that 150 persons have been charged since last February for importing and distributing 300 pounds of cocaine with an estimated street value of $35-million.

Indian fertilizer experts are concerned about the long-term adequacy of fertilizer supplies, which are a key to continued raising of Indian food production to support a population that is expected to increase by at least 13 million annually for the foreseeable future. Fertilizer plant in India. Because of a chronic shortage, India is exploring the possibility of extracting fertilizer from coal.
Harold Hayes is the host of "The Roundtable," a new series, on Channel 13 at 7:30 P.M.

The Bog, the most infamous sideshow at theautomobile race track here, will be filled in with gravel, police and track officials decided today after a night-long outbreak of destruction that included the burning of a stolen Greyhound bus. Spectators watching the U.S. Grand Prix from the burned wreckage of a stolen Greyhound bus at Watkins Glen, N.Y.

Two of four former members of President Georges Pompidou's Cabinet running in parliamentary elections lost here today. Meantime Gaullist party lead. ers were in a central committee meeting soul-searching over their "lack of boldness" as their power continues to drain away.

Sayers's detective is an adaptation of "Murder Must Advertise," in which the breezily arch hero confronts bright young sophisticates, the drug scene and the advertising profession, among other blotches on the social fabric.

A ptotest at Tulane University and Newcomb College over what the students said was inadequate service in offering them gynecological examinations and prescribing birth control pills has ended after the administration agree to increase student gynecological services.

There used to be a saying about corporate advertising (slightly revised here for genteel readers) that it was like dropping coffee on a dark blue suit--makes you feel nice and warm, but nobody notices it.

Fair skies and lower temperatures are forecast for the Metropolitan area today, but there is a chance of showers from New England to the northern Appalachians and the eastern lake region. Snow flurries are expected in northern Michigan. Thundershowers will be scattered from the Southern Plains States to the southern plateau region, while the Pacific Coast and most of the West will be clear.

Newsweek magazine said yesterday that the former White House chief of staff, Alexander M. Haig Jr., approached Vice President Ford nine days before the Presidency of Richard M. Nixon ended about a possible pardon for Mr. Nixon.
The Defense Department appears to have changed its policy on whether deserters will be courtmartialed for refusing alternative service after signing up for the President's "earned re-entry" program.

New York's Italians, Irish, Poles and a smattering of other groups-the white ethnic people who wire probably the most alienated in the city under the Lindsay administration-are fashioning a more pleasant, but still uncertain, relationship with the Beame administration in City Hall.

Herbert D Williams, a retired investment banker, died Friday at his home, 242 East 72d Street. He was 96 years old. Mr. Williams attended the Wharton School of Finance. He had been associated with Price, Waterhouse and Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner Smith.

The first major revision of the United States copyright law since 1909 has finally been approved by the Senate. The measure would help to bring creativity into line with technology. It would go a long way toward insuring the survival of individual composers, dramatists and authors, and raise the standard of protection to that already existing in most nations of the Western world.

Officials have disclosed that the Ford Administration, faced with what it considers almost certain Senate rejection of the treaty former President Nixon signed in Moscow last July to limit the underground testing of nuclear weapons, is seeking to broaden the agreement to include peaceful nuclear tests.

Has anyone ever heard Rudolf Firkusny give a poor recital, or even a so-so one? Perhaps, but in this listener's experience, the Czech-born pianist is not only one of the finest now performing, but also a remarkably consistent one.

The police cleared the area around the Venezuelan Consulate this morning, touching off rumors that an agreement had been reached between the Government and terrorists who have been holding hostages in the consulate for nine days.

Julie Ann Osler, daughter of Mrs. Henry Sonenblick and the late David Saul Osler, was married here yesterday afternoon to Jonathan Dolger, son of Dr. and Mrs. Henry Dolger. The ceremony was performed in Temple Israel by Rabbi Martin Zion.

Luther H. Hodges, who rose from a tenant farm to the Governor's Mansion in North Carolina and the Cabinet in Washington as Secretary of Commerce, died yesterday, apparently of a heart attack, in Chapel Hill, N. C. He was 76 years old. Luther H. Hodges

The National Association of Purchasing Management reported over the weekend that in a survey 68 per cent of purchasing agents said they were "concerned or worried" about the economy in the next 12 months. The remaining 32 per cent said they were either "optimistic or satisfied" about business activity.

But given their children's ages, an eavesdropper might blink at this supermarket comment. Former President Richard M. Nixon recuperated from his bout with phlebitis and blood clots at his home today, with the decision on his subpoenaed testimony in the Watergate cover-up trial still up in the air.

When New York's topranked stars meet in Manhattan they are almost always out for blood. Once a year, however, they meet on a social occasion, and the results are less important though not unimportant.

The Oakland A's defeated the Baltimore Orioles, 5 to 0, in Oakland yesterday and evened the American League championship playoff at one game foroeach team.

The battle lines are already being drawn over a recently introduced Assembly bill that would permit food stores to sell beer and wine. The measure has the backing of the New Jersey Food Council, which represents the state's supermarket chains, but is likely to run into opposition from retail liquor dealers and tavern owners who are not eager for more competition.
A Manhattan man was arrested yesterday on a murder charge in the shooting death last June 3 of 70-year-old Ernest Graf in a watch shop in Manhasset, L.I.

Senate hearings into the propriety of procedures of the Department of Transportation and the Civil Aeronautics Board have been abruptly postponed because two senior Senators said the hearings might upset efforts to save Pan American World Airways from financial collapse.

Millions of Portuguese abandoned their traditional day of rest today and worked in their factories, offices and shops while schoolchildren and older students hosed, scraped, scrubbed and washed away five months of political graffiti and posters from buildings and monuments.

The crisis in Italy that has followed the fall of the Rumor Government is a symptom of a wider malaise that is rapidly overtaking the Western democracies in Europe. The impact of a staggering increase in oil prices on top of already soaring inflation and rising deficits in payments abroad has sent governments reeling everywhere.
