A national organization of young hospital doctors said today that it would seek to expand collective bargaining between doctors and hospitals for better patient care and working conditions.

MIDDLEBURG, Va.-The dramatic and divisive issue of secret operations abroad has again been raised by the recent exposures of the United States role in Chile. These operations have been challenged as an illegal and immoral form of diplomacy impermissible in an open society. They have been derided as antiquated holdovers from the cold war, and have been denounced as acts of the executive not open to Congressional or popular judgment.

A bill to extend the concept of public financing of election campaigns to gubernatorial primarines is scheduled for a vote tomorrow in the Assembly. Only the Assembly has scheduled a session tomorrow.

Fleetwood Mac is a British rock band that dates to 1967. It started as a blues group, splitting off from John Mayall, and over the years it shifted in 'personnel and gradually evolved into a purveyor of a blend of rock styles. It wasn't the most striking band, maybe, but it was respected, did well commercially and gave pleasure.

It was business as usual for the New York Giants today in a 14-7 loss to the Atlanta Falcons at Yale Bowl. Doug Kotar of the Giants crosses the goal line pursued by Clarence Ellis of the Falcons. Kotar ran 53 yards on the play midway in the first quarter in New Haven. Bill Arnsparger, Giants' head coach, during closing moments of game with the Falcons. Giants lost, 14-7.

Five thousand Atlantans gathered in a sunny downtown park here today in a citizens' rally intended to show racial harmony and a firm faith in Atlanta, the progressive Southern city that likes to say it is "too busy to hate." Ninety-five per cent of those present were black.

New Jersey residents disapprove of President Ford's pardon of former President Richard M. Nixon by a margin of nearly 2 to 1, and most believe the books on Watergate should not be closed, according to a statewide poll by the Eagleton Institute of Rutgers University.

Susan Elizabeth Norman, who is with Boston University's School of the Arts as coordinator of student activities and alumni affairs, was married yesterday afternoon in Hopkinson, Mass., to Marc Aaron Blumenthal, director of the Learning Guild, an educational consulting organization in Boston.

" Who wound him up?" was the widespread reaction among politicians to Governor Wilson's surprisingly strong attack on the Democratic state ticket and particularly State Senator Mary Anne Krupsak, the News only woman stateNews wide candidate on Analysis the major party tickets.

A new elementary school in the Bronx that was opened just last month was heavily vandalized over the weekend by youths who apparently made repeated forays into the building, doing damage estimated at $50,000 "at a minimum," the police said last night.

Mayo A, Shattuck, vice president of the State Street Investment Corporation and a former deputy treasurer of Harvard University, died Saturday at Massachusetts General Hospital in Boston. He was 48 years old and a resident of Hingham, Mass.

In an offshoot of this city's school integration problems, South Boston, the city's Irish stronghold, rose up in protest today against the Boston Police Department's elite corps, the Tactical Patrol Force.

Charles W. Gleason, who retired in 1973 as chairman of the Green Point Savings Bank of Brooklyn and was former president of the Savings Bank Association of New York State, died Saturday at the Creek Club in Locust Valley, L.I., where he lived. His age was 80.
Stock prices here plunged to a two-year low last week, driven by growing concern over Japan's economic prospects and by the continuing decline on Wall Street.

The establishment of regular terminals for express buses that carry passengers between Manhattan and points in the four other boroughs is recommended in a study prepared for the city's Transportation Administration.

Barney Bookman is a 72-year-old farmer in the lovely Yorkshire Dales with a son who doesn't want to be a farmer, 50 beef and dairy cattle, 120 acres he's worked all his life, and a problem. For him, the British election this Thursday is all about the fall in the price of livestock.
The marriage of Joan Blair, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Adrian Blair of Winter Park, Fla., to Donald Schuler, son of Mr. and Mrs. George Schuler of Larchmont, N.Y., took place yesterday afternoon.

Chris Evert defeated Virginia Wade, 6-3,. 5-7, 6-1 in the final of the $50,000 Virgihia Slims tennis tournament ' today. Miss Wade had to play two three-set matches to get to the final, while Miss Evert won her semifinal by default when Evonne Goolagong withdrew because of the death of her father.
Forty-seven alleged underground labor leaders arrested in Barcelona have been plotting to extend a wave of illegal strikes to Spain's biggest industrial factory, the police said today.

Martha Fisher Donovan, wife of Robert J. Donovan, an associate editor of The Los Angeles Times, died today of cancer at the Washington Hospital Center. She was 62 years old and lived in Chevy Chase, Md.
Owners of the Black National Network, the first black-oriented radio network owned and operated by blacks, are planning to expand their coverage with a black news service.

On the first anniversary of the October war, the consensus of American, British and Soviet experts is that the long-term strategic balance in the Middle East is weighted against Israel. This view, highly placed sources said, does not contralict a more optimistic assessment of Israel's position prepared by American intelligence For president Ford before his talks last month with Premier Yitzhak Rabin of Israel.

Only avid fans of professional football can understand the complex line-up of forces that determines United States foreign policy. The two arch-rivals, who recently clashed in the Chile bowl, are the isomoralists and the detenteniks.

Ebe Stignani, considered aclassic mezzo-soprano; died yesterday. She was 67 years old. Miss Stignani was born in Naples and made her debut there at the San Carlo Opera House in 1925. Over the next 30 years, she performed at principal opera houses in Europe, the United States and in South America. She retired in 1957.
Hannah Dunlop Colt, who was active in social and edunational activities-in Westchester County for many years, died on Friday at her home, 20 Oriole Avenue, Bronxville, N. Y. She was 91 years old.

If Lou Duva has his way, the local professional boxing club, the grass roots of the sport for so many years until television sand other reasons killed it, will enjoy a renaissance. And to prove his point, the Totowa resident is putting his money where his feelings are.

The Venetian Festival currently in progress at the Kennedy Center is giving audiences a chance to sample some music not normally encountered in this country. This evening something really rare was presented at the Opera House--Domenico Cimarosa's "II Mercato di Malmantile," also known as "La Vanita Delusa."
Senator George McGovern, Democrat of South Dakota, has spent six times more than his Republican opponent in his bid to win re-election to a third term.

CAMBERLEY, England-Behind the high unemployment figure, the disastrous trade balance, the devastated stock market, the 20 per cent rate of inflation, and the occasional Irish Republican Army bomb at an army base or a national monument, Britain still' has 'the look of a country enjoying prosperity unparalleled in her history.
Dr. Robert L. Moore, emeritus professor of mathematics at the University of Texas, died Friday. He was 91 years old. Dr. Moore taught here at Texas from 1920 until his retirement in 1969.
Since Medicaid opened the Treasury spigot in 1967, growing numbers of Americans have placed their aged parents in nursing homes. The result has been a national scandal.

Venezuela has launched a national crusade to defend the high price of oil and other raw materials. President Carlos Ondres Perez, who heads the cam paign, delivered a strong attack against industrialized nations this weekend for using "economic totalitarianism" against developing countries.
Some subtle changes have been taking place in French-American relations since President Valery Giscard d'Estaing came to power fourand-one-half months ago.
Two women whose ordina??ion as Episcopal priests has been held invalid say they will ??efy current church orders by celebrating the eucharist at a special service on Reformation sunday, Oct. 27.

Caspar W. Weinberger, Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare, said today that he could trim the department's budget by $3-billion to $4-billion if Congress allowed him to eliminate some programs he thought had outlived their usefullness.

At the Senate hearings on Nelson Rockefeller's nomination for Vice President, there was a solemn discussion of whether his family's money gave it power. Mr. Rockefeller dismissed that notion as a "myth." He hoped it would be "exposed and dissipated."
Al Geiberger ended an eight-year drought today by Shooting a final two-underpar 69 to win the $135,000 Sahara invitation golf tournament by three shots.
John P. Cahill the son of former Gov. William T. Cahill, was sentenced to 10 days in the Ocean County Jail yesterday after pleading guilty to assault, drunken driving and possession of marijuana.

A 75-year-old Bronx woman was raped yesterday in her ground-floor apartment by two teen-age youths who after tying her up with cloth belts also may have robbed her, the police reported.

Wallace L. Clapp, a vice president of Insurance Magazine who retired in 1971 after 50 years with the publication, died on Friday in Mountainside Hospital, Glen Ridge, N. J. He was 74 years old and lived at 11 Gordonhurst Avenue, Upper Montclair, N.J.

The two-year struggle by the IU International Corporation to acquire the Airborne Freight Corporation seemed lost this weekend, when the board of the freight forwarding company rejected the latest offer by IU. But IU said it had not given up.

The Jets, who have not beaten the Dolphins since 1971, take on the National Football League champions tomorrow night at the Orange Bowl with the kickoff at 9 P.M. Channel 7 will televise the game in New York.

The St. Louis Cardinals continue to surprise. After spotting the 49ers a 9-0 lead, the defensive-minded Cards rushed back and battered San Francisco, 34-9, for their fourth straight victory. The last time St. Louis opened with four straight victories was in 1966.

Arthur D. Koppel, who retired last year as head of the Arthur D. Koppel Company, real estate mortgage brokers, died Saturday at his home, Scarswold Apartments, Garth Road, Scarsdale, N.Y. He was 83 years old.

Chile is quietly buying supersonic jet fighters and attack planes from the United States in a multimillion-dollar arms deal, a Chilean Air Force source said today. Foreign sources say that the aircraft purchases are being made for defense and not for use against Government foes.

Citicorp, the holding company that owns First National City Bank, announced yesterday that it opened 15 offices in four out-of-state cities-Denver, New Orleans, Phoenix and Salt Lake City-that will offer a number of services offered by bank branches.

Plans to provide secure facilities for mental patients who are potentially dangerous to others or to themselves were announced yesterday by Governor Wilson and State Senator Ralph J. Marino, chairman of the Senate Committee on Crime and Correction.

The outflow of savings from savings and loan associations abated in September from the near-record August level but remained large, the United States League of Savings Associations estimated today. According to a new sampling system that has proved accurate, the league estimated the outflow of last month at $650-million, compared with $1.2-billion in August and $340-million in September last year, when money conditions were also tight. George P. Stratigos, founder and owner of George's Bakery in Rockville Centre, L. I., died Friday in Mercy Hospital. He was 80 years old and lived at 99 Woodland Avenue in Rockville Centre.

The massive renovation of Cooper Union's landmark Foundation Building on Coop. er Square-started nearly two years ago-is virtually complete and the 115-year-old building reopened officially yesterday with the return of the Cooper Union Forum, the oldest free public lecture series in the country.

President Ford said today that the reaction to his economic program proposals so far had been favorable.
William J. Kennedy Jr., president of Printing Pressmen's Union No. 2, said yesterday that pressmen employed at The Long Island Press had voted to authorize a strike against the newspaper.

The Senate approved a compromise package of political reforms today that would give the Democratic and Republican Presidential nominees $20-million each in taxpayer funds to wage their 1976 campaigns. The vote was 60 to 16.

To the Editor: In the midst of a fiscal crisis in operations, it is folly to undertake a bankrupting capital-intensive project like the Second Avenue subway, which is now sure to exceed $2 billion, with excavation costs alone totaling $10million a block for vast stretches.
Film cameras, which used to grind in profusion on the sidewalks of New York, are a rare spectacle these days. But a new effort is being made to lure back the movie industry.

New Jersey psychiatrist predicted today that if state prisoners were shifted to Ancora Psychiatric Hospital, pregnancies among patients would "skyrocket," patient deaths from overdoss of illegal would increase "significantly," and anxiety among patients would rise.

President Ford and the Polish Communist party leader, Edward Gierek, stressed "friendship" and "friendly ties" between the United States and Poland in their first meeting today. The "friendship" is to be documented tomorrow by Mr. Ford and Mr. Gierek in a joint declaration of principles.
Denis Potvin, last season's rookie of the year, will play in the Islanders' opening game of the 1974-75 season in Montreal against the Canadiens tonight despite a hairline fracture of his left hand.
School district officials and other local government officers pleaded yesterday for relief from limitations on their taxing power imposed by the State Constitution.

Kursat Onder knew he was adjusting when he started to dream in English. It happened fast only three weeks after he got off the plane from his native Turkey.
More than 2,000 Hispanic children stayed away from nine elementary schools here today in protest against an impending cutback in bilingual classes.

In an unexpected turn of events, the conspiracy and fraud trial of Stanley Goldblum ended today when he pleaded guilty to five counts of conspiracy and fraud that could bring him a prison sentence of 30 years and fines totaling $36,000.

Paul G. Hoffman, the automobile executive who headed the United Nations Development Program and who was the first administrator of the Marshall Plan after World War II, died yesterday in his sleep. sleep.

Britain's second election campaign of 1974 is ending as it began-in paradox. The three big parties agree that the nation is heading for its most severe economic testing since World War II; but the voters seem massively indifferent to this rerun of the February contest and highly skeptical that the balloting tomorrow will produce a government capable of ruling effectively.

Paul G. Hoffman was an exuberant exponent of all that is best in the American tradition. A highly successful salesman and corporate executive, he never lost sight of the reality that "free enterprise" was viable only to the extent that it genuinely served the interests of human freedom and social responsibility.

One of the partnerships that captured the first PanAmerican Invitations Pair Championship in Mexico City during the weekend has few bridge peaks left to scale. Bob Wolff and Bob Hamman of Dallas have won both the World Team Championship and the World Pair Championship, a claim to fame shared only by the French stars Pierre Jais and Roger Trezel.

Senator Howard W. Cannon, chairman of the Senate Rules Committee, has asked Vice President-designate Nelson A. Rockefeller to supply "detailed background information" about the financial gifts he has made to his aides and associates.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 8--Deputy Defense Secretary William P. Clements Jr. said today there was a "strong possibility" the Administration would ask Congress early next year for additional military aid for South Vietnam.

Prices on the American Stock Exchange continued to rise yesterday for the second consecutive day as traders remained convinced that President Ford's speech, which was delivered after the close, would have some encouraging news.
GENERAL ASSEMBLY Meets at 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M. to hear Bangladesh, Iraq, the President of Somalia, Sri Lanka, Cambodia, Libya, Lesotho, Chad and Malta in general debate.

John Gentile of the Round Hill Club of Greenwich, Conn., captured the ninth Port Jefferson open today by a stroke with a 36hole card of 142 over the par-72, 6,810-yard Harbor Hills course. He collected $1,200 in the $5,000 event.
Samuel Savitz, founder and owner of the Strand Stitching and Pleating Corporation, 255 West 36th Street, died yesterday at University Hospital. He was 64 years old and lived in Hollis, Queens.
Senator Henry M. Jackson, Democrat of Washington, and four other Democratic Senators called today for a reduction of one million barrels a day in the use of imported oil.

The six left-wing terrorists holding seven hostages in the Venezuelan consulate here have accepted an offer of safe conduct out of the country, the United States Ambassador, Robert A. Hurwitch, announced late today.
The body of aman tentatively identified as a Wall Street stock clerk was found in a parked car yesterday afternoon in Forest Hills, Queens. The body had two bullets in it.

WASHINGTON -- Before they question President Ford, House Judiciary Committee members ought to look at an obscure clause in Article II, Section 2, of the Constitution. It says that the President may pardon "except in cases of impeachment."
Free minibus service to transport out-of-town buyers from midtown hotels to the garment district will be opened next Tuesday.

At Gracie Mansion yesterday, Mayor Beame presented Walter Lippmann with the city's highest honor, the Bronze Medallion. The presentation came two weeks after Mr. Lippmann's 85th birthday celebration on Sept. 25.

Former Secretary of State Paul J. Sherwin and two co-defendants apparently lost their two-year fight to stay out of prison today when the State Supreme Court denied a hearing on their appeals and instead ordered the defendants to surrender at noon Friday.

WASHINGTON, Wednesday, Oct. 9--Secretary of State Kissinger took off for Cairo early this morning to start a Middle East tour aimed at setting a time and a framework for a new round of Arab-Israeli negotiations.

This month's issue of Blair Ketchum's Country Journal is its sixth and William S. Blair, its publisher, was down from Battleboro, Vt., yesterday looking as pleased as punch about the way things are going.
Early in the fourth quarter last night, more than half of the 17,986 persons at Madison Square Garden walked out on the Knicks, some in disgust. The Knicks were losing, 93-68, at the time.

The Hessische Landesbank Girozentrale has freed itself of any responsibility for rescuing the International Credit Bank of Geneva, centerpiece of a financial empire now being investigated by Israeli and Swiss authorities as well as the interests of Baron Edmond de Rothschild.
A 27-year-old city sanitation worker wanted in the shooting of a police officer during a Bronx burglary on June 22 surrended to the police here yesterday and was charged with attempted murder.

Two of the better-known series of poetry readings will start the new season this month. On Monday, the Poetry Center of the 92d Street Y.M.-Y.W.H.A. begins the year with a reading by Robert Penn Warren.

In the career of Eisaku Sato, as in the recent history of Japan, triumph has followed on defeat and defeat on triumph.

The dilapidated 103-yearold Tweed courthouse, the city's major monument to municipal corruption, has been placed on the National Register of Historic Places, Paul O'Dwyer, City Council President, said yesterday.

A series of four $100,000 races highlights this final week of the 72-night Yonkers Raceway meeting. Known as the Sire Stakes, the series offers colts, fillies and geldings bred in New York State.

The insolvency of the Franklin National Bank comes just one year after the failure of the United States National Bank in San Diego and against a background of a generally rising incidence of banking collapses in recent years.
Rain today forced postponement of the second-day matches in the 1974 Tokyo open tennis tournament. Play will be resumed tomorrow.
President Ford called on the American people today to adopt a variety of voluntary energysaving measures, including driving 5 per cent less and washing the laundry in cold water.

Clarence C. Simoni, who was general manager of the packings and frictions materials division of the Johns-Manville Corporation at his retirement in 1963, died on Monday in Stamford, Conn. He was 75 years old.
Fordham University has threatened to "seriously consider" giving up the rolling turf and Gothic turrets of its Bronx campus and moving to Westchester because of a dispute with the Federal Government.

Robert G. Robinson, a World War I Medal of Honor winner, was found dead Saturday night in the garden outside his rural cabin 10 miles north of here. He was 78 years old.

Betty Ford's personal physician plans to assemble a team of medical specialists to chart her treatment for breast cancer. "The management of a breast-cancer patient is so controversial now that we want the very best experts we can find," said Dr. William Lukash, personal physician to President Ford and his family.

The New York State Council on the Arts has replaced David Payne as acting program director for the performing arts with Hugh Southern, who will take a leave of absence from his job as executive director of the Theater Development Fund.

The chances are that Bill Arnsparger, the New York Giants' coach, will be coy all week about naming the starting quarterback for the game against the Eagles in Philadelphia on Sunday. So it could be a time of insecurity for Norm Snead and Jim Del Gaizo.

The revolution that triumphed 15 years ago in Cuba under Fidel Castro is still going on in some remarkable and some peculiar ways.

Brig. Gen. Cunningham C. Bryant will become the first black commanding general of the District of Columbia National Guard, the Pentagon announced today. He will be promoted to major general, the Pentagon said.

Secretary of State Kissinger and three key Senators agreed today on a new formula to salvage a compromise that would allow the Soviet Union trade benefits in return for a liberalized policy on emigration of Jews and others.
Dr. Henry Joel Cadbury, a prominent Quaker and Biblical scholar, died Monday at Bryn Mawr (Pa.) Hospital. He was 90 years old and lived in Haverford, Pa.

The Santa Maria will "float" up Fifth Avenue Monday during the annual Columbus Day Parade when 100,000 marchers are expected for festivities that start at noon at Fifth and 44th Street in celebration of an earlier trip in 1492. To delight youngsters there will be 50 bands, decorative floats, and clowns.

PRAGUE, Oct. 8 (AP)--A rejuvenated Czechoslovak hockey team took a 2-0 lead in the first 10 minutes and went on to hand Team Canada a 3-1 defeat today in the final game of its European visit.
Three more sugar companies raised their prices yesterday, indicating a general industry trend that is expected to mean higher prices for many products made with sugar.

An official of the World Football League reported today that he was talking to three groups of potential purchasers for the Jacksonville Sharks, but warned that the W.F.L. team would die in a few days unless a deal was completed. "At this point there has been no firm offer to purchase the club," said Chuck Rohe, the W.F.L. official who is managing the Sharks for the league.

The bludgeoned body of a missing 15-year-old high school girl was found here today in a wooded area near one of the largest shopping centers in Rockland County, about block from her home.
The House Rules Committee today blocked the six-year, $11.8-billion mass-transit bill, with a tie vote, 6 to 6, with three absences, denying the bill access to the House floor.

Denis Potvin, last season's rookie of the year, will play in the Islanders' opening game of the 1974-75 season in Montreal against the Canadiens tonight despite a hairline fracture of his left hand.

Soybeans and corn plunged the daily permissible limits yesterday in futures trading on the Chicago Board of Trade, just as they did on Monday. Wheat futures, however, held firm at the close in nearby deliveries, indicating some underlying buying strength.
The Central Park Zoo, with its 472 animals and birds has a new director. He is Robert Beach, a 42-year-old New Yorker who has been with the Parks Department for 16 years.
Now that the exciting part of the hockey season is over--the exhibitions-the National Hockey League will begin the yawning part todaythe regular season.

President Ford, urging a "new mobilization" against inflation, proposed today a broad, basically conservative program ranging from reducing oil imports to a one-year tax increase for corporations, as well as many private citizens.

After simmering for a month, the lid appears about to blow off the Boston school situation. The Boston police, severely tested, stretched and drained by four week of keeping peace are now showing severe signs of strain. South Boston High, standing virtually empty since the opening of school, has become the symbol that is sparking resistance to the court-ordered integration plan in other areas of the city where compliance had been relatively peaceful.

Officers from the Essex County Sheriff's Department fanned out through 14 local communities and towns in five adjoining counties before dawn today in a massive effort to arrest 126 adults and 14 juveniles for the sale of narcotics.

An income tax heretofore limited to out-of-state residents who work in New Jersey would be extended to residents of the state to pay for public schools, if a suit filed in Superior Court yesterday is successful. The suit was filed by Jersey City.

President Ford's appearance before Congress to explain his pardon of former President Richard M. Nixon was postponed tonight and rescheduled for next week so that a jury could be picked and sequestered for the Watergate cover-up trial before Mr. Ford testifies.

An earthquake rocked the eastern Caribbean today, damaging churches and other buildings on Antigua and St. Kitts in the Leeward Islands. There were no immediate reports of death or serious injury.

OSLO, Norway, Oct. 8 (AP)--The Nobel Peace Prize for 1974 was awarded today to former Premier Eisaku Sato of Japan and to Sean MacBride of Ireland, the United Nations commissioner for South-West Africa.
The District Attorney's office is investigating a charge' that two defendants indicted with four others in the kidnapping of an undercover Policeman were beaten by police officers after their arrest.

Bill Virdon, who guided the Yankees to a secondplace finish in the American League East, was named major league manager of the year by The Sporting News yesterday. Virdon was selected in a poll of the big league managers conducted by the sports weekly. Billy Martin of the Texas Rangers was the runner-up.

Congress gave a restrained reception today to President Ford's "grand design" to cure the nation's economic ills. Key members of the Senate and House hailed the spirit of the economic programs the President outlined to a joint session of Congress.

The House of Representatives, ending a six-day floor fight over how to reform itself, approved late tonight a drastically scaleddown reorganization plan that would make few changes in the existing committee structure. The vote was 203 to 165.
A suburban Baltimore housewife gave birth today to quintuplets, four girls and a boy, at University of Maryland Hospital here.

Political leaders took varying views yesterday of former Gov. Nelson A. Carey, Democrat-Liberal candidate for Governor, said "gifts given for faithful service would be looked at with less question if they were made a matter of public record at the time."

Toward the end of President Ford's speech yesterday, when he was asking all of the American people to become "volunteer inflation fighters and energy savers," he pointed out a lapel button on his jacket.

Plans for the establishment of an Office of Hispanic Affairs, regarded as a major concession made to the city's Spanish-speaking community by Mayor Kenneth A. Gibson after last month's racial disturbances here, appear to be languishing in a morass of bureaucratic red tape and opposition.

Rockefeller's money has been a powerful force in New York for many years, whether it was manifested in a $550,000 gift to a longtime aide, the dispensing of the presidency of Rockefeller Center to another, the financing of the Republican party in the state, or the building of the World Trade Center as part of an effort, led by his banker brother, to give New York City a second skyline downtown.

The Government today lifted martial law throughout Greece, except for areas along the Greek-Turkish border and five islands in the Aegean off the coast of Turkey.

Morgan Co., Inc., and the Charter New York Corporation showed, however, that profit margins had declined in the first nine months, while the rate of return on stockholders' equity was higher.

Citing Biblical exhortations to "forgive us our debtors," Governor Wilson today defended the $550,000 gift by former Governor Nelson A. Rockefeller to his aide, Dr. William J. Ronan, as "a gift to a friend out of love."
The modest program at the Cubiculo on Tuesday evening by Barbara Berger and Betty Salamun had a likable ingenuity if not a powerful creative surge. It was nicely conceived and well danced.

President Ford at the lectern at his news conference yesterday in the White House Rose Garden. He said he was sure inflation would be beaten.

The Supreme Court agreed today to hear arguments on the constitutionality of the Regional Rail Reorganization Act passed last year by Congress. The court set a hearing for Oct. 23 on an appeal from a decision by a panel of three Federal judges in Philadelphia striking down key portions of the act.
Joseph Roisman, first violinist of the Budapest String Quartet, died at his home in Washington yesterday of a heart attack. He was 74 years old.

The defending champion, Gwenn Hibbs of Long Beach, Calif., shot a 77 today and shared the first-round lead in the annual women's senior amateur golf championship.

A record low turnout in the November elections for Congress is Indicated, the Gallup Poll said yesterday. In two surveys last month, the poll found that 42 per cent of the public had "a lot" or "some" interest in the elections, a drop of 7 percentage points since a comparable time in the last off-year elections of 1970, with 58 per cent having "little" or "no" interest In 1970.

The Allied Chemical Corporation reported yesterday an earnings increase of Ill per cent for the third quarter and a 46 per cent increase in sales. The sharp gain lifted ninemonth earnings above those for any previous full year.

Special agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation and investigators of the Brooklyn District Attorney's office uncovered two bodies yesterday afternoon buried in shallow graves in a social club in Brooklyn.

Viktor Korchnoi, a pawn ahead, adjourned the 10th game of his final candidates match for the world championship with Anatoly Karpov after 41 moves here in Tchaikowsky Hall tonight.

Frank M. Lario, former solicitor for Winslow Township, testified under cross-examination today that the township placed no legal restriction on how the state could use land deeded to New Jersey for a mental hospital in 1951.

Stephen P. Marion, an associate professor of chemistry at Brooklyn College, died Monday. He was 63 years old. Professor Marion, on the Brooklyn College staff since 1931, had been an early experimenter in the use of television as a teaching aid. From 1959 to 1961 he directed an experimental television program and in 1967 coordinated a project for the use of television facilities in teaching chemistry.

Thousands of workers went on strike in Barcelona and two other Spanish cities today, many over new labor contracts. Strikes are illegal in Spain.

Nathan Teitel's "Figures in the Sand," which opened last night at St. Clement's, consists of two strange, unrelated one-act plays. Each shares actors (Carol Teitel and Kevin O'Connor), a director (Nick Havinga) and proximity to a beach.

Bayger dismissed two charges of sodomy and two charges of sexual abuse in State Supreme Court, freeing Willie E. Smith, who had been accused of attacking another prisoner during the riot.

President Ford, whose new economic program has been atracked in some quarters over the last 24 hours as too weak, declared today that his proposals could achieve "a meaningful reduction in the rate of inflation" by early next year. President Ford at the lectern at his news conference yesterday in the White House Rose Garden. He said he was sure inflation would be beaten.

The 1974 Nobel Memorial Prize in Economic Science was awarded yesterday to Dr. Gunnar Myrdal and Dr. Friedrich A. von Hayek-two 75-year-old social economists who have won international recognition for differing views.

Lawyers appealing the triplelier conviction of Rubin (Hurricane) Carter won a legal victory yesterday when a New Jersey judge ordered the Passaic County prosecutor to turn to the defense previously secret police records.
A Supreme Court judge ruled today that the Stockton Unified School District had artificially separated the races and ordered it to desegregate the city's 28,000 elementary and high school students.
Encouraged by President Ford's plans for meeting inflation, traders on the American Stock Exchange and in the over-the-counter market sent prices sharply higher yesterday in stepped-up trading.

Alderman Thomas E. Keane, second in power to 'Mayor Richard J. Daley in Chicago's government, was found guilty today by a Federal District Court jury of mail fraud and conspiracy. Alderman Thomas E. Keane arriving at Federal Court, Chicago, yesterday.
A 34year-old airline employee has been arrested by agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation on charges that he stole 20 pounds of pure platinum worth $440,000 from a flight shipment.

Vice President-designate Nelson A. Rockefeller's expected replies to questions about his financial gifts will be made public by the Senate Rules Committee, its chairman said today amid growing indications that Mr. Rockefeller's confirmation, once apparently assured, was likely to become increasingly controversial. Howard W. Cannon, chairman of Senate Rules Committee, with Nelson A. Rockefeller at recent hearing.
The Cuban Government notified Senators Claiborne Pell and Jacob K. Javits today that it was releasing four United States citizens from prison as a gesture of goodwill to the two legislators.
The Senate voted today to cut off military aid to Turkey, then a few hours later bowed to threats of a Presidential veto and voted to delay the cutoff.

A circuit judge has agreed to the first step in a public defender's attempt to have former President Richard M. Nixon; his daughter, Julie Eisenhower, and her husband, David, testify in the trial of a man accused of writing $4-million in bad checks.

Mayor Beame announced a proposal yesterday that could lead to the creation of Garment Center West, a galaxy of new, efficient loft buildings and truck terminals west of Eighth Avenue, to revive the city's sagging apparel industry.

Dr. Abraham I. Rosenstein, who had been on the staffs of Morrisania, Mount Sinai and Flower-Fifth Avenue Hospitals, died yesterday, apparently of a heart attack, at his home, 18 East 77th Street. He was 71 years old.

A 31-year-old West German woman was reported doing well today after undergoing what is believed to be the world's first fallopian tube transplant to enable her to have more children.

Thirteen Senators from coastal states introduced legislation today calling for a delay in Government offshore oil and gas leasing plans. In introducing the resolution, Senator John V. Tunney, Democrat of California, said it was intended to halt Interior Department plans for leasing at least 1O million acres of offshore areas until the environmental impact could be measured and coastal development plans drawn up.

ABC-TV has canceled two of the Friday night series it introduced in September, "The Texas Wheelers" and "Kodiak," and has shifted programs in the Friday and Saturday night schedules in an effort to improve its ratings.

A House judiciary subcommittee approved today legislation designed to save 13 states from the threat of a Federal lawsuit challenging the legality of their fund-raising lotteries.

The Lockheed Aircraft Corporation has received a $275.1-million Navy contract for 46 submarine hunting planes. The American Publishing Company has awarded a $24-million contract to the McCall Printing Company, a unit of Norton Simon, to print the American Home Magazine, starting with the January, 1975, Issue. The contract is for six years.

Federal investigations into the alleged appointment of political favorites to career Civil Service jobs have uncovered wide spread "abuse" of the Federal hiring system during the Nixon Administration, the chairman of a House Civil Service sub. committee reported today.

The underrated Americans placed Hale Irwin and Jerry Heard in the semifinals of the. llth Piccadilly World Match Play golf tournament today, but most of the thunder was provided by Gary Player and a revivified Tony Jacklin.

A plainclothes officer wash shot and critically wounded on the City College campus last night, apparently by a youth he' had chased off the campus the day before. According to the police, the officers, Sgt. Harry Murray, 42 years old, of the Wakenhut Security Service, was on duty last night when he spotted the youth and trailed him to Shephard Hall, at 138th Street and Convent Avenue.

As Poles turned on color television sets to watch their leader touring the United States this week, the Polish Government basked in an image of political stability, economic prosperity and friendship with most of the world.

The Justice Department has censured two assistant United States attorneys in the Eastern District of New York for their a handling of the extortion-conspiracy case against Angelo D. Roncallo, the Long Island Representative who was acquitted last May.

A strange sequence of events that started as far back as summer training camp has led to a change in quarterbacks for the New York Giants this week.
John Czarnecki, a triple bug apprentice jockey, made It look easy at Belmont Park yesterday by winning with the first mount of his race-riding career.
The Senate agreed tonight to put off until next month legislation providing money to pay for former President Richard M. Nixon's pension and other expenses.

Three scientists whose innorations began the modern Science of cell biology nearly 30 years ago and who have made numerous major contributions since to understanding the inner. workings of living cells have been awarded the 1974 Nobel Prize for medicine or physiology.

The Chase Manhattan Corporation, the holding company that owns the Chase Manhattan Bank, reported yesterday that its third-quarter earnings rose 8.3 per cent despite the downward revision in the value of the bonds in its trading account that the bank disclosed last week.
The Most Rev. Theodore Foley, Superior General of the Congregation of the Passion, died Wednesday in Rome at the age of 61.

Secretary of State Kissinger said tonight that after five hours of talks with President Anwar el-Sadat of Egypt he was "encouraged" by progress made toward reaching a formula for the next round of Arab-Israeli negotiations.

Most commodity futures exchanges were quiet yesterday before the release of the Government crop report after the close of trading. Before a crop report many traders even their positions and remain on the sidelines until the figures are made public.

After an East Division championship that still kept the team in the red, and two playoff games in-which 44,-000 seats went begging, the Baltimore Orioles' ownership is considering selling the team if a new stadium isn't built.

Clary Anderson, football coach at Montelair State hasn't had a losing season in 32 years of coaching, but this year he established a personal record as the Indians opened with four straight victories. In the four games, Montclair State scored 98 points and allowed 21, the last victory against Cortland State Saturday when the Indians triumphed, 27-7.
Betty Ford will return to the White House tomorrow afternoon, 13 days after having undergone surgery for removal of her right breast at Bethesda Naval Hospital.

President Giovanni Leone, who has conducted more than three days of consultations on the formation of a new coalition government, asked the President of the Italian Senate today to explore the chances of ending the political crisis.
A Federal court judge has extended a temporary restraining order prohibiting a citizens' group from promoting boycotts to protest busing to achieve racial integration in Denver's public schools.

San Clemente and Key Biscayne, though no longer the Western and Florida extensions of the White House, are still being maintained at a cost inappropriate for any former chief executive in a democratic nation, not to mention one who resigned under a cloud. As private residences of Richard Nixon, their extravagant staffing at public expense is at once ludicrous and offensive.

The governing Labor party led by Prime Minister Harold Wilson has won Britain's second general election this year. With more than three-quarters of the vote counted this morning, the extent of the victory was not clear but it was a narrow one.

Damage from early frosts have further reduced the outlook for corn production 277 million byshels, to a total 16 per cent below last year's crop, the Agriculture Department reported today. The reduced crop dims consumer hopes for a levelingoff in the food-price spiral.

The Senate voted by 72 to 2 today to help Pan American World Airways with its financial problems by requiring that "discriminatory" postal-rate and landing-fee practices against the airline be stopped.
Soviet-bloc officials said today that the Soviet Union and four of its East European allies were considering the resumption of diplomatic relations with Israel some time next year.
On commercial television, the fare is still more fraudulent sociology. On public TV, it's serious anthropology. Names change, but the basic patterns remain remarkably steady.
Clyde C. (Slim) Williams, who traveled in the nineteen-thirties by dogsled from Copper Center, Alaska, to Washington, died yesterday. He was 93 years old.
Organized-crime figures are investing in real estate, motels and bars, especially in the Wildwood area in Cape May County, Attorney General William F. Hyland said today.

The Senate yesterday passed legislation that will outlaw credit discrimination based on sex or marital status. The passage followed similar action by the House Wednesday night. The antidiscrimination provision was one of many amendments to a Federal deposit insurance bill, and applied tc all types of consumer credit both personal and commercial.

New York City and New York State agreed to hire 120 additional city investigators a month to track down welfare cases in which an allegedly absent father may actually be available to support his family.

Danny's Brown Jug, at 1122 First Avenue, is not so much a restaurant as a pub. Give it one more decibel and it would be not so much a pub as a joint. Eating there could newer be called dining, but if you can take uninterrupted assault and battery by the sound of music.
A management consultant firm headed by former Deputy Mayor Edward K. Hamilton has been hired by New York State to make a study of its controversial state Department of Mental Hygiene.

ANDREWS--Mary. on Oct. 9, 1974. Retired teacher clerk of PS 1, Long Island City, Daughter of the late John and Mary Andrews. Reposing at Joseph L. Montera Funeral Home, 48-19 Vemon Blvd. Mass of Chrlstlan Burial, Sat. at 9:30 A.M., at St. Mary's RC Church. Interment Calvary Cemetery. Visiting hrs 2-5 and 7-10 PM.

Hundreds of coal miners returned to their jobs today, ending strikes touched off by roving pickets protesting so-called immoral textbooks used in Kanawha County schools. The protest, led by clergymen, cooled off after a day of violence in which one school was dynamited, and one was firebombed.
Wholesale prices remained almost unchanged over-all in September, the first month in almost a year in which they did not rise substantially. The rise was only one-tenth of 1 per cent.

Mayor Kevin H. White lashed out at President Ford today for his antibusing statement yesterday, saying the President had "fanned the flames of resistance" to school integration and possibly contributed to the endangerment of Boston's schoolchildren.

The late-night incident involving Representative Wilbur D. Mills has demolished his staid image among voters in the Second Congressional District and also his prospects for an easy re-election, politicians here agreed today.
The state has approved plans by the National Park Service to create a salt marsh along the shore of Fire Island National Seashore, Governor Wilson said today.

Obviously confident that he is the front-runner in the gubernatorial race, Representative Hugh L. Carey repeatedly praised his Democratic running mates in campaigning yesterday in Nassau County as he has done even in upstate areas where the popularity of some of his running mates is at least questionable.

Israeli Army units, using helicopters, observation planes and command cars, searched ravines and dry river beds between Jerusalem and Jericho today, rounding up several hundred young Israelis who last night renewed attempts to establish unauthorized settlements in the occupied West Bank of the Jordan River.

Joan Kennedy was ordered today to appear in Fairfax County traffic court Nov. 6 to answer a charge that she was driving under the influence of alcohol' when her automobile struck another near here. Mrs. Kennedy, the wife of Senator Edward M. Kennedy, Democrat of Massachussets,

Mary Joan Glynn, the 45-year-old vice president of communications at Bloomingdale's, will become president of the Simplicity Pattern Company Inc. on Jan. 1. "I love Horatio Alger stories. She's going from errand girl to president without marrying the boss's son,"

The Exxon Corporation has shut down all its oil and gas fields in Libya as well as its liquified natural gas plant there in a three-way dispute between Libya, the oil company and the Italian Government. The dispute started when the Libyan Government ordered Exxon's Libyan subsidiary to raise the export price of the LNG from 49 cents a million British thermal units to $1.62.
"Only a few cities - Chicago, Philadel delphia, New York, Boston-have kept the structures built by immigration, have retained the real ethnic blocs that support the whole fabric of those communities.

District Attorney Richard H. Kuh of Manhattan said yesterday that the members of his office were not "partners of the police" and ordered his 200 assistants to scrutinize police performance from arrest through court testimony for possible misconduct.
The Dow Chemical Company formally terminated its agreement yesterday to merge the General' Crude Oil Company into Dow.
Probably the only neutral observers-exclusive of the officials, of course-attending tomorrow's Ivy League football struggle between Dartmouth and Princeton

Stock prices soared yesterday for the second consecutive session in the heaviest trading of the year and the fifth largest in exchange history. The advance was broadly based, with gains of a point or more commonplace throughout the list.

The State Welfare Inspector General, William F. Meyers charged yesterday in a report that there were grave irregularities at two nursing homes in Queens, and he accused the City Department of Social Services of "callous indifference" toward the elderly poor.
Dr. William J. Ronan said yesterday that there was nothing "immoral or illegal" about his accepting a gift of $550,000 he had borrowed from Nelson A. Rockefeller over a 17-year period.

The State Board of Elections will start a civil proceeding in Supreme Court here tomorrow against 62 candidates for public office who, the board said today, failed to file reports of campaign receipts and expenditures or who filed late reports,
The governing Labor party led by Prime Minister Harold Wilson has won Britain's second general election this year.
The Hotel Taft, one of the better known tourist meccas of' the Times Square area, has changed hands.

The House of Representatives is not distinguishing itself in these pre-election days. Two of the most important bills that it has had before it throughout the session-and that were considered almost sure to passare suddenly in deep trouble. A measure to provide long-term Federal assistance to mass transit systems, and another drastically to control strip-mining, have been held up not because there has been mounting opposition in the House, but because of bungling in committee.
Gen. George S. Brown, the chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, said today that the inflationary pinch on the defense budget could force significant changes in military forces and strategy.

Herbert W. Kalmbach, a principal fund-raiser and former personal lawyer for Richard M. Nixon,.. has filed, a motion for the reduction of the 6-month to 18-month sentence he is serving for Watergate-related crimes.

With Secretary of State Kissinger meeting Egyptian leaders in Cairo, the Communist party newspaper Pravda today chastised Egypt for a new economic policy that opened the country to Western economic investment and influence.

Seventy-one per cent of those surveyed believe former President Richard M. Nixon should be questioned at San Clemente, Calif., about the Watergate cover-up even if he is too ill to travel to Washington for the trial of his former aides.

The city and the state agreed yesterday to hire 120 additional city investigators a month to track down welfare cases in which an allegedly absent father may actually be available to support his family.

New' Jersey environmentalists and legislators today hailed the Senate passage yesterday of a bill that would give virtual veto powers to the states over the construction of deepwater ports on their coasts.

A former Trenton State Prison psychiatrist suspected of plotting the murder of his former wife and two other persons is healthy enough to stand trial on the charges, Judge A. Jerome Moore of Superior Court ruled today. The suspect, Dr. William King, 53 years old, of Rydal, Pa., is suffering from a heart condition, his lawyer said, and a trial would put a strain on him.
The best place to remember that New York is a seaport is on Pier 16, sitting on a bench, watching the East River go by. The benches on Pier 16, in fact, may be the best benches in the city.
It could be a difficult Sunday for the Giants and the Jets, who between them have won only two of eight games. Both are three games behind the undefeated leaders in their divisions.

Senator Jacob K. Javits yesterday accused Ramsey Clark, his Democratic opponent, of taking "a fuzzy and ambiguous position on the problems of the Middle East" and of gambling on the survival of Israel.

Paul J. Sherwin, the former New Jersey Secretary of State who was scheduled to begin serving a two-year sentence for bribery and conspiracy yesterday, won a stay at the last minute of at least four days.

The people who survived months of floods in Bangladesh are now facing starvation. According to final official estimates, more than half of the country was inundated by floods affecting 35 million people, or nearly half the population During the worst flood.
About half of the late Jacque line Susann's estate, estimated to be worth $1.5-million, will ultimately go to charity, according to the novelist's will.

The Cities Service Company of New York City today agreed to sell off a large group of its service stations in Massachusetts and New Hampshire in settlement of a Federal antitrust suit, the Justice Department announced.

When heavily armed policemen and soldiers took up positions around the Plaza of Tlatelolco a week ago yesterday, there were no demonstrators to mark the anniversary of the 1968 massacre there, when the Mexican Army shot down more than 250 people and crushed a student protest movement.
William F. Hyland, the State Attorney General, said today that his office was investigating the possible embezzlement of funds from the 1969 campaign of former Gov. William T. Cahill.

Researchers near the plant where plutonium was first produced as atomic bomb fuel have discovered that,. with surprising efficiency, this highly toxic element is picked up from the soil by plant roots.

Scientists are juggling plant genes, squeezing juice out of leaves and growing microorganisms on manure in a wide-ranging assault on one of the most fundamental problems of the world's food shortage--how to get more protein for more people.

Carole Meyers, trailed by her husband, Martin, who often goes shopping with her, bubbled up to Viola Sylbert in Henri Bendel's fur salon the other day. "What I want is something very casual, an everyday coat, nothing princess-y looking," she explained.

The Senate has started an investigation of condominiums that could lead to the first significant legislative effort to control alleged abuses associated with this increasingly popular form of housing.
An American woman official freed from 13 days as a captive of leftist guerrillas, says she was treated "like a lady and a diplomat" and grew to like her kidnappers.
The Polish Communist party chief, Edward Gierek, told the General Assembly today that his country and the United States were "opening up new opportunities" for further cooperation.

President Ford qualified his support for repeal of the oil depletion allowance today by saying it should be linked to removal of Federal controls on oil prices. That statement, issued by the White House,

School officials here and representatives of the State Department of Education agreed tonight to continue the city's Federally financed bilingual teaching program while they determined how many Hispanic children should be allowed to remain in the classes.
Prime Minister Indira Gandhi, worried about food shortages and India's economic drift, drastically overhauled the nation's Cabinet today.
The financially troubled World Football League announced tonight it was removing the Jacksonville and Detroit franchises from the remainder of its 1974 schedule.

The Port Authority of New York and New Jersey agreed yesterday to do the engineering and design work for preparation of a 500-acre strip along the New Jersey shore near Ellis and Liberty Islands as the site of the future Liberty State Park.

With United States Senator James L. Buckley at his side, Governor Wilson today accused Repretentative Hugh L. Carey of advocating public-employe strikes and posing "a clear and present danger" to the voters of the state.
A gentle Indian Summer sun ins bathed the Iowa prairies all this week, and the bright skies offered an ideal setting for harvesting soybeans, hunting ducks, watching football games and politicking.

Viktor Korchnoi tried everything at his disposal in the style of Bobby Fischer, but he could not win his 10th final-candidates-match game with Anatoly Karpov and it ended in a draw. Thus Karpov kept his two victories-to-none lead in the contest.

Britain's governing Labor party has won the general election. With more than threequarters of the votes counted, Prime Minister Harold Wilson's party took seat after seat from the Conservatives and was assured of a working majority in the House of Commons. Computers had predicted a five-vote majority. [Page 1, Column 8.]
Leonard Riggio grew up in Brooklyn and didn't quite graduate from New York University. His father, Steve, was once a welterweight prize fighter and cab driver.

If ever there was a time when the President of the United States needed the help of the best objective scientific minds to help him grapple with the problems of food, fuel, transportation, housing and many other things, it is now; but he is a little short-handed.
A management - consultant firm headed by former Deputy Mayor Edward K. Hamilton has been hired by New York State to make a study of its controversial Department of Mental Hygiene.

A 24-year-old man who, the police, said, has a history of psychiatric trouble was arrested last night and charged with the fatal stabbing of a 66-yearold woman who was his neighbor in a West Side single-roomoccupancy hotel.

Three of the most quicktempered figures in professional basketball were back in hot water yesterday as a :result of their conduct in interleague preseason games between the National Basketball Association and the American Basketball Assotiation.
Distressed by what it called the city's "unbelievable" staff cuts, the Public Library announced yesterday that three large neighborhood branches would close indefinitely on Nov. 18.

Charging that there was inefficiency, waste and costly duplication of effort, a management consultant firm today gave the Hudson County Board of-Chosen Freeholders a plan for a drastic overhaul of the county's $72-million-a-year operation.
The Senate yesterday passed legislation that will outlaw credit discrimination based on sex or marital status. The passage followed similar action by the House Wednesday night.

The United States Department of Justice notified Representative Edward I. Koch, Democrat-Liberal of. Manhattan, that it could not decide if it should prosecute the Dairylea milk-adulteration case because it had not received sufficient information from the Department of Agriculture.
The popularity of Secretary of State Kissinger has plummeted among Israelis since the 1973 Middle East war, according to a poll published today by the newspaper Haaretz.

A major scandal erupted in Israel following the collapse of the central European business conglomerate of Tibor Rosenbaum, a prominent financier.
The Union Carbide Corporation said yesterday it would spend $21-million to develop a tungsten mine and mill 50 miles northwest of Alamo in Lincoln County, Nev.

Controversial legislation to dismiss criminal charges against any Federal defendant who is not brought to trial within 100 days after arrest, already approved by the Senate, cleared its first hurdle in the House today.

Hundreds of jubilant Chinese - Americans paraded through Chinatown yesterday to celebrate the 63d anniversary of the 1911 Nationalist revolution that ousted the Manchu Dynasty and led to the founding of the Republic of China under Sun Yat-sen.

The House Judiciary Committee has begun a broad investigation into Vice President-designate Nelson A. Rockefeller's possible involvement with a derogatory biography of Arthur J. Goldberg published when Mr. Goldberg was his Democratic opponent for the New York governorship in 1970.
The Circle in the Square last night formally opened its season at its Joseph E. Levine Theater with Peter Nichols's brilliant if deathly comedy, "The National Health."
Several demonstrators and three American newsmen were attacked by Saigon policemen today as anti-Government street protests continued to rain momentum.
Dr. William J. Ronan said yesterday that there was nothing "immoral or illegal" about his accepting a gift of $550,000 he had borrowed from Nelson A. Rockefeller over a 17-year, period.

Representative Wilbur D. Mills acknowledged today that he was a passenger in a limousine stopped by the police early Monday morning, for reckless driving and he attributed previous denials of his presence in the auto to a misunderstanding with his aides.
Senior United States District Judge Roger T. Foley, a pioneer in the Nevada legal profession, died last night at the age of 88.

The once-familiar voice of Eleanor Roosevelt, captured on long-ago newsreel disks as well as in later taped reminiscences, was heard again at Hunter College last night as part of a multimedia celebration on the eve of today's 90th anniversary of her birth.

When the Rangers take on Toronto tonight at Maple Leaf Gardens in the second game of the National Hockey League season for both teams, the situation will be remarkably similar. Both New York and Toronto played new expansion clubs. to open their seasons, both had to come up with big third periods to win and both look on tonight's game as a truer indication of what's in store for them this season.
A Roman Catholic religious order and the American Jewish Committee plan three inter-reli gious study missions to Jerusalem and Rome to investigate "the Jewish roots of the Roman Catholic Holy Year."

Four Democratic candidates, including the gubernatorial nominee, Representative Hugh L. Carey, addressed an audience of 250 older men and women last night in the Educational Alliance Building, at 197 East Broadway.

A vice president of the Northrop Corporation has admitted in a deposition that the defense contractor maintained a secret political slush fund of up to $1.2million, according to documents filed in Federal District Court here this week.

Elaine K. Siris of Rye, N.Y., national chairman of the United Jewish Appeal's women's division, was married yesterday noon to Norman Winik of Harrison, N.Y., in the Jewish Community Center of White Plains by Rabbi Maurice Davis.

The Soviet Union has repeatedly rejected requests -tat United States newsmen be nemitted to view the launching of Soviet astronauts during next year's joint space effort. But Russian newsmen wil Ibe able to view the lift-off of the American astronauts from .Cape Canaveral.

State Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz and Borough President Robert Abrams of the Bronx engaged in a vigorous debate before a City Club luncheon at the Biltmore Hotel yesterday in the first face-toface confrontation of their contest for Mr. Lefkowitz's post.
In older musical histories Ives was discussed, if at all, as a composer who performed interesting experiments despite being trapped in the cultural backwaters of New England and New York City.

The House of Representatives narrowly defeated a compromise measure that would have enabled the President to delay until Dec. 15 a cutoff of military aid to Turkey. After the. 187 to 171 vote, Republican Congressional leaders said that the President would definitely veto a resolution continuing appropriations for foreign aid, which contains the disputed provision suspending aid to Turkey.
