The Securities and Exchange Commission sued the Sunshine Mining Company here yesterday for failure to make full disclosure and obtained a settlement in less than two hours.

, wife of Stavros Niarchos, the Greek millionaire and shipowner, who figured prominently in the international jet set and was considered one of the world's most beautiful women, died yesterday at her home in Paris. She was 45 years old, and there were conflicting reports about the cause of her death.

The New York State Controller's office, contending the State has been consistently overcharged by the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey for office space in the World Trade Center, has refused to pay more than $3-million in rent bills and is continuing to withhold payments at a rate of $115,000 a month.

Dahlia may have been somewhat fretful at her reception at quarantine after she arrived from France Tuesday night, but that experience has not affected her status as the 3-1 favorite in today's Man o' War at Belmont Park.

A special legislative Narcotics Study Commission today urged the decriminalization of the use Of small amounts of marijuana in New Jersey, making its use a civil matter no more serious than a parking violation.

Prompt action yesterday in diverting subway service to another line helped prevent subway trains of the Seventh Avenue IRT line from being stuck in the Clark Street tunnel under the East River after a small fire broke out.

The nation's electric utilities, hit hard by rising costs and slower growth in energy consumption, have cut back , their construction budgets by 18 per cent for the next four years, a new study shows.

Vice President-designate Nelson A. Rockefeller provided a more detailed look at his gifts and loans last night, making public a list of 20 present and former public officials and staff assistants to whom he had given a total of $1,972,078 over the last 17 years.
The Council on Wage and Price Stability held its first meeting today, promised "vigorous use of public hearings" and said its initial price investigations might concern sugar and antifreeze:

The television variety show, which went into a decline as a prime-time staple when rock became the dominant form of popular music, will be making something of a comeback this winter when the networks make their midseason changes.

The New Jersey Turnpike Authority proposed new toll rates yesterday that would increase the cost of trips for most New Jersey residents by 37 per cent and increase the cost of traveling the length of the highway by 54 per cent.

Joseph Balzano, president of the Housing Authority Patrolmen's Benevolent Association, angrily walked out of a meeting with Housing Authority officials yesterday. He charged the authority with refusing to add manpower to protect the lives of its patrolmen in the face of "a 100 per cent increase in crime in the last eight years"

In bridge as elsewhere it is not always easy to identify a phantom. If you sacrifice in four spades against four hearts and go down one or two tricks doubled, you can reasonably hope to show a theoretical profit, depending on the vulnerability.

Archie Griffin of Ohio State and Joe Washington of Oklahoma have been parttime runners so far this season, not because they are hurting or are unable to do their job, but because they and their teammates have been doing too good a job so far.

The Albany Police Department has established an internal affairs unit to investigate complaints of misconduct against police officers, almost a year after the State Investigation Commission recommended it.
Yields rose on Treasury bills auctioned today in both the 91-day and 180-day maturities. The average rate for the three-month bill was 7.722 per cent, up from 6.698 per cent in Monday's sale.

Alvin Purple is the playboy of the southern world, an unprepossessing young Australian who, for absolutely no reason brought forth by the makers of the movie that bears his name, is irresistible to women.
Viktor Korchnoi and Anatoly Karpov adjourned the 11th game of their final Candidates Match for the world championship in a difficult rook-and-minorpieces end game here in Tchaikowsky Hall tonight.
Attorney General William B. Saxbe today ordered a 30-day extension of furloughs for draft evaders who were in prison until President Ford announced his "earned re-entry" program.

SIKAR, India-The earth is parched. The wheat crop has withered. The tough farmers, who eke out a living on the flat plains of the Rajahthan desert, are alarmed. "The families 'at one meal now," says Chandra Das, a 50-year-old father of six.

John D.'Ehrlichman and H. R. Haldeman contended in legal papers made public today that they urged President Nixon in the summer of 1972 to make' "a full and complete disclosure" of the Watergate affair.

When the Legislature ignored the State Education Department's valid and urgent plea for reform of the city's Community School Board election procedures, it left in limbo the next round of balloting on May 1, 1975. Lack of proper preparation and supervision of these elections has been underscored by disclosure of irregularities, with their resultant confrontations, which in some instances required intervention by the courts.

Operations at Willowbrook, the state institution on Staten Island for the mentally retarded, were assailed yesterday at the convention here of the New York State Association for the Mentally Retarded.

The chairman of the Federal Home Loan Bank Board, Thomas Bomar, announced today a proposed regulation lifting some restrictions on the acceptance of payment orders by Federal savings and loan associations.

In a further move toward lower interest rates, two of the nation's largest banks-the First National City Bank here and the First National Bank of Chicago-yesterday cut the rate they charge on loans to their best corporate customers.
Two kittens scrambling for balance on a fence rail at Belmont Park caught the attention of Dahlia yesterday, and racing's top glamour girl craned her neck to watch.

The publishers of a derogatory biog. raphy of Arthur J. Goldberg said today that publication had been arranged by one of Nelson A. Rockefeller's close political associates, who offered to purchase. 100,000 copies for distribution, mostly without charge, in the 1970 campaign for Governor of New York.

the general convention of the American Lutheran Church elected the Rev. Dr. Fred W. Meuser today as vice president and received a proposal that it budget $26.2-million for the work of the church in 1975.

Einar G. Chindmark, chief photographer of The Hartford Times for 31 years, died last night at Hartford Hospital. His age was 62. He retired in May. Mr. Chindmark began his newspaper career at The Times as a copy boy 46 years ago this month. In 1943 he was named chief photographer.

Farming, a steadily declining occupation on Long Island, was honored and highlighted here today. Massive tent pitched on the grounds of the Old Bethpage Village Restoration to house such exhibits as huge vegetables not usually seen in supermarkets;

When the American sculphe left an enormous body of work--drawings and paintings as well as a considerable number of sculptures--that had seldom or, in some cases, never been exhibited in his life-time.

Arthur Ashe and Tom Gorman posted straight-set victories today to give the strongly favored United States a 2-0 lead over the Commonwealth Caribbean team in a first round series of the 1975 American Zone Davis Cup.

Bach is still holding the fort against the rock disk jockeys poised for an assault upon WNCN-FM in New York. The attempt by its owners to change the format of the station--one of the few on the radio dial playing classical music--is now before the United States Court of Appeals in Washington. The contending petitioners and the Federal Communications Commission have filed memoranda that will determine the future sound of WNCN.

Secretary of State Kissinger flew to Damascus this morning and then to the Jordanian capital late tonight to seek support for his efforts to get a new round of Arab-Israeli negotiations started and to maintain momentum toward a Middle East settlement.

Ruth Dayan began the working part of a 10-day visit to New York yesterday at her usual pace - jet speed. She spent much of the time recounting some of her experiences as the dynamic director of Israel's craft movement.

Governor Wilson completed an upstate campaign tour today, maintaining in his sober, methodical style that the party's Buckley wing was safe, that the Duryea split was ended and, that the Rockefeller shadow was not lengthening over him once again.

At a time when the New York Giants need a big kick somewhere, Pete Gogolak conceded yesterday that he was "in a slump." "I'm very much concerned," the usually dependable 32-year-old place-kicker said of a regular season in which he has converted only one of five field-goal attempts.

Leonid I. Brezhnev. the Soviet Communist leader, urged today that the Middle East peace talks in Geneva be reconvened at "the earliest date." He contended that further delay would mean sitting "on a powder keg which might blow up at any moment."
Ramsey Clark turned his campaign to an attack on soaring food prices and agricultural monopolies in low-key appearances yesterday in New York City and upstate areas.
The Rev. Philip A. Potter, a West Indian Methodist minister, who is head of the World Council of Churches, took issue here today with Pope Paul VI's recent strictures against violence and revolution.

A Federal grand jury in Rochester is investigating the legality of bank loans totaling $200,000 to six officials of the carpenter's union, allegedly arranged by executives of the now-bankrupt Stirling Homex Corporation.
The City Center Joffrey Ballet swung into repertory Thursday night at the City Center with Robert Joffrey's "Remembrances" and two ballets by Gerald Arpino, Viva Vivaldi!" and "Trinity."

When it first comes out, the art of Alexander Liberman has a way of looking too sleek for its own good. It is the work of someone who has looked at everything, who knows exactly what can be done with any given materials, and who is not at all a fool.

A former partner in a large Wall Street law firm has been charged with misappropriating more than $1.5-million in fees paid his firm. Joel Dolkart, a former partner in Simpson, Thacher Bartlett, one of the country's 20 largest law firms, was arraigned Thursday in Manhattan tan Criminal Court on charges of grand larceny, forgery, criminal possession of forged instruments and falsification of business records.

Tomorrow at 1 P.M., Directions," a production of ABC News, presents an unusually compelling half-our called "Simon Wiesenthal: A Conscience for Our Time." Mr. Wiesenthal, who has earned an international reputation for locating and helping bring to trial the men who ran the Nazi death camps, is interviewed at his home in Vienna and at the ?authausen concentration camp, from which he was freed in May, 1945.
Steve Hamas, an athletic star at Pennsylvania State University who turned to professional boxing and once defeated Max Schmeling, died today at Northport Veterans Hospital. He was 67 years old.

METROPOLITAN OPERA, Puccini's "Turandot," 2; Berg's "Wozzeck," 8. NEW YORK CITY OPERA, New York State Theater, Gilbert and Sullivan's "The Mikado," 2; Puccini's "Tosca," RUTGERS CHAMBER ENSEMBLE, Carneqle Recital Hall, 2:30. LOS ANGELES PHILHARMONIC, Carnegle Hall, 8.

Despite a brief period of profit taking in the first hour, prices rose for the fifth consecutive session in active but slightly decreased trading on the American Stock Exchange yesterday. Similar conditions prevailed in the over-the-counter market.
A panel of outside experts has advised the Food and Drug Administration that the so-called Dalkon Shield appears to be about as safe as other commonly used 'intrauterine contraceptive devices.

A 24-year-old man who is accused of stabbing an elderly woman to death in a shabby Upper West Side Hotel on Thursday was described by neighbors yesterday as a very bright and articulate person who began acting erratically several months ago.

September sales of New York's seven largest stores showed the smallest monthly gain in the last six months, all but reversing a strong business trend that has been one of the city's brightest economic indicators.

Following is the text of a letter sent yesterday by Vice President-designate Nelson A. Rockefeller to the chairman of the Senate Rules Committee, and of the list of recipients of gifts and loans from Mr. Rockefeller as released by him. The list includes several corrections regarding transactions reported as gifts.
The letters keep comingfrom Japan and London and Greenwich--most of them with checks fluttering out of them.

Michael Chinigo, 66 years old, a longtime foreign correspondent for the now-defunct International News Service and United States newspapers, died today from a bullet wound in the head suffered two months ago. The police said then that the wound had been self-inflicted.

The publishers of a derogatory biography of Arthur J. Goldberg said today that publication had been arranged by one of Nelson A. Rockefeller's close political associates, who offered to purchase 100,000 copies for distribution, mostly without charge, in the 1970 campaign for Governor of New York.
Atter promising to appeal at his office for the first time since he had a run-in with the police early Monday morning Representative Wilbur D. Mills, Democrat of Arkansas, calledin sick today.
Mayor Beame accused the New York Public Library yesterday of "budgetary brinkmanship" in its threat to close three large branches because of staff cuts.

The decision overturning the will of Pearl S. Buck, the deceased Nobel Prize-winning author, has been appealed to the State Supreme Court. Frederick Pope, a Brattleboro lawyer representing the executors of the will, filed the appeal this week.

Leonid I. Brezhnev, the Soviet Communist leader, urged today that the Middle East peace talks in Geneva be reconvened at "the earliest date." He contended that further delay would mean sitting "on a powder keg which might blow up at any moment."

The Oakland A's, two-time champions of the baseball world who generate extracurricular controversies as naturally as they breathe, start trying to win their third straight World Series tomorrow as they face the Los Angeles Dodgers at 4 P.M., New York time.

A former Secretary of Agriculture, Orville L. Freeman, said today that a combination of Arab oil money, American technology and fertile African land could ease the world food situation and create profits for all concerned.

Canada. which recently imposed severe import quotas on American beef and livestock, has protested to Washington against a White House proposal to place retaliatory restrictions on Canadian exports to the United States in the same categories.

Vice President-designate son A. Rockefeller provides nore detailed look at his gifts ind loans last night, making public a list of 20 present and former public officials and staff assistants to whom he had given approximately $2-million over the last 17 years.
New quotas proposedd for creditors of Bankhaus I. D. Herstatt have been made official, the office of the independent negotiator, Gunter wogelsang, announced today.
Suzanne Marie Hickey, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. W. Norman Hickey of Short Hills, N. J., was married there yesterday evening to John Thomas Galvin 4th, son of Mr. and Mrs. Galvin 3d of Baltimore.

A 74-year-old woman, shot and critically wounded as she stood over her grandson's grave, died yesterday at Perth Amboy General Hospital. The police said they were certain the shooting had been done by the woman's sonin-law, who committed suicide seconds later. The two bodies were found Wednesday night a few feet apart at Holy Rosary Cemetery in Woodbridge.

The city's Water Commissioner, Charles Samowitz, voiced alarm at suggestions that New York's water supply could be jeopardized if the controversial Tocks Island Dam on the Delaware River was not built. "Maybe it's a ploy--maybe it's their way of enlisting our support for the dam," he said.
Andrzej Wajda's "The Possessed," which had its America premiere last night at the Yale Repertory Theater, is a deep excavation into the heart of Dostoyevsky's masterpiece.

Don Bies won the $2,000 prize for the day's low score of 67 and shared the lead with three other American pros and a Japanese after the second round of the $300,000 Pacific invitation golf tournament. His four-under-par performance on the 7,187-yard Tobu Country Club course today gave Bies a 36-hole total of 140, two under par, and a tie with Hubert Green, Jim Simons, Bob Menne and Kosaku Shimada.
A Government spokesman said today that the Saigon police had denied involvement in the attack yesterday on a correspondence of CBS. The correspondent, Haney Howell, remained hospitalized today.

High-ranking United States Government officials said tonight that they had recieved reports from sources in the oil industry of a major petroleum discovery in Mexico. The information is subject to confirmation by Mexican authorities. The Americans say that the new field may hold 19 billion barrels of oil, more than half the known reserves in the continental United States and roughly twice the 9.6 billion barrels reported at Alaska's North Slope near Prudhoe Bay.
Three bombs exploded toinight in two London military clubs, sending scores of men and women in evening dress fleeing into glass-strewn streets. One person was injured.

Prime Minister Harold Wilson and his Labor party have been returned to power by the voters with a hairline margin of victory over all other paities. It was a qualified, somewhat grudging, mandate for Mr. Wilson, far short of the seats he sought in the 635-member House of Commons.
PORT WASHINGTON, N. Y.-Napoleon, who commanded the finances of a nation as well as its armies, once ordered his astounded tailor to patch a pair of riding breeches that were worn through at the seat.

The General Foods Corporation, one of the nation's largest marketers of coffee, said yesterday that it had cut the prices to retailers for three of its brands--Maxwell House, Yuban and Max-Pax--by 5 cents a pound to

In a further move, toward lower interest rates, two of the nation's largest banks-the First National City Bank here and the First National Bank of Chicago--yesterday cut the rate they charge on loans to their best corporate customers.

Betty Ford, looking radiantly happy, returned to the White House today after two weeks in the hospital. "It's great to be home," she said softly, her face wreathed in smiles. More than 150 White House officials and employes, gathered on and below the South Portico, applauded warmly as the smartly dressed First Lady stepped off the helicopter on the South Lawn, her husband by her side.
More than a third of the teachers inevolved in the city's troubled bilingual education program for Hispanic students stayed away from their jobs today in support of a boycott of the program.

Prisoners and officials at the Camden County Jail told a legislative study commission today that the 190-inmate facility on the sixth floor of the combination city hall and county courthouse was crawling with vermin and so overcrowded that dozens of inmates must sleep in the floor.

For the second time this year, the British people have delivered an indecisive verdict in a general election. They voted to continue in office the seven-month-old Labor Government of Prime Minister Harold Wilson but provided it with only a minuscule majority in the House of Commons.
Senator Edward J. Gurney, who is charged with conspiracy, bribery and perjury, said today that the Federal Government wanted to humiliate him by trying to fingerprint and photograph him.
The Protestant voters of Northern Ireland expressed their determined opposition to sharing power with Roman Catholics by returning to office all but one of their candidates in the British elections.

The front yard of the Brooklyn Civic Center, at Court and Montague Streets became San Salvador for a time yesterday as a modernday Christopher Columbus debarked from a 50-foot model of hjs 117-foot flagship, Santa Maria, and took formal possession of the island in the names of Their Most Catholic Majesties.

Max L. Grant, millionaire industrialist and philanthropist, died today. He was 85 years old. Mr. Grant invented the fare collection meter used by many transit companies and eventually took over Grant Money Meters.

A report on the United States Grand Prix, at Watkins Glen, N.Y. The International Team Motocross motorcycle championships, at Husqvarna, Sweden, and the world Lumberjack championships, at Hayward, Wis., will also be seen.

It was Stark Young who once suggested that the special poignancy of Eugene O'Neill's plays had nothing much to do with the quality of the writing, but that the plays and the characters seem to have been torn out of O'Neill by force.

The nation's top business leaders forecast today an increase in unemployment next year to 6.5 per cent but said they felt the country would avoid a serious recession. The forecast, released at the two-day meeting of the Business Council that opened today, also predicted a leveling of the rate of inflation to 8.5 per cent next year, down from about 11 per cent this year.
Maurice Mermey, who retired in 1970 as vice chairman of Edward Gottlieb Associates public relations, died Thursday in Larchmont, N. Y., where he lived. His age was 73.

Allan Dudley Cruickshank, a nationally known ornithologist who has been described as "a modern Audubon with a camera," died yesterday in a Gainesville, Fla., hospital. He was 67 years old and lived in Rockledge, Fla.

It was as if someone played a bad joke on Tom Neville, but he really had no one to blame but himself. "When I got out of college in 1965, I could have signed with the Patriots or the Steelers," Neville,

The General Assembly elected five countries to the Security Council todaySweden, Italy, Guyana, Tanzania and Japan. The five will serve for twoyear terms beginning on Jan. 1. They will replace Austria, Australia, Indonesia, Kenya and Peru, whose terms exDire at the end of this year.
In its first economic report following yesterday's national election, the Government said today that Britain's trade position had deteriorated in September.

John W. Ingram, the Federal Railroad Administrator, is expected to be offered a top job with the Chicago, Rock Island Pacific Railroad, possibly on Monday, when directors of that financially failing system hold a special meeting in Chicago.
Frank Sloan Wile, former United States Consul General in Zurich and Llechtenstein, died Monday in Walter Reed Hospital, Washington. He was 49 years old and lived in Kensington, Md.

the general convention of the American Lutheran Church elected the Rev. Dr. Fred W. Meuser today as vice president and received a proposal that it budget $26.2-million for the work of the church in 1975.

A vice president of the Northrop Corporation has admitted in a deposition that the defense contractor maintained a secret political slush fund of up to $1.2million, according to documents filed in Federal District Court here this week.
The House of Representatives narrowly defeated today a compromise measure that would have enabled President Ford to delay until Dec. 15 a cutoff...

Cook Industries, Inc., one of the major grain companies which was prevented recently by the Government from exporting a total of 125 million bushels of wheat and corn to the Soviet Union, issued its unaudited report yesterday for the first fiscal quarter, ended Aug. 31.

A representative of the New York City Department of Water Resources will attend hearing at the Delaware Water Gap in Pennsylvania tomorrow to protest any reconsideration of the amount of water available to the city from the upper Delaware River.

To the Editor: One of the measures that should be considered in the fight against inflation should be restrictions on the issuance and use of credit cards and checking accounts, or demand deposits. The use of "plastic money" and personal checking accounts has contributed greatly to the achievement of our trillion-dollar Gross National Product by not only increasing tremendously the volume of our money supply but also increasing the velocity of our money.

NOVI SAD, Yugoslavia-Yugoslavia recently went through a period of official triumph concerning the successful consolidation of the League of Communists, the liquidation of all attempts at "factional differences of opinion" in the party and the reintroduction of orthodox Marxism and Leninism into all spheres of society.

The attorney for Paul J. Sherwin, the former New Jersey Secretary of State, said today that he would appeal Monday for an emergency stay of his client's one-to two-year sentence for bribery and consdiracy.

Egyptian sources said pointedly today that the outcome of the talks last night between President Anwar el-Sadat and Secretary of State Kissinger could not be assessed until the results of Mr. Kissinger's visit to Israel were known.
A City Council committee was advised yesterday to exercise caution in considering a bill that would require systems that recycle excess heat in all new buildings to conserve fuel.

The New Jersey Turnpike Authority proposed new toll rates yesterday that would increase the cost of trips for most New Jersey residents by 37 per cent and increase the cost of traveling the length of the highway by 54 per cent.
Classes resumed yesterday at New Utrecht High School in the Bensonhurst section of Brooklyn, but the normal attendance of about 4,300 students was cut by 50 per cent, school officials said.
After complaining that he should have been rehired as soon as the regular season ended, Manager Earl Weaver was retained by the Baltimore Orioles yesterday for at least another season.

In a gesture of cooperation with President Ford, the House of Representatives passed by a vote of 329 to 20 today a resolution setting $300-billion as the "target" spending ceiling for the Federal budget for the fiscal year 1975.
Representative Hugh L. Carey said yesterday that school busing was now an "outmoded tool" in New York City and that the emphasis should be on providing quality education for all children.

As President Ford suggested in his speech to Congress, one of the more effective ways to curb inflation is to make a concerted attack on the governmental and private institutional arrangements that prop up prices and protect cushy situations for the benefit of a few producers at the expense of all consumers.

The New York State Controller's office, contending the state has been consistently overcharged by the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey for office space in the World Trade Center, has refused to pay more than $3-million in rent bills and is cqntinuing to withhold paymeAts at a rate of $115,000 a month.

ATHENS-The solution of the Cyprus crisis is essentially predicated on three things: continuation of a Caramanlis regime in Greece; maintenance of some kind of cogent government in a confused Turkish political situation; and a successful American diplomatic intervention that produces tangible evidence of a desire for compromise on Turkey's part.

GHANZI, Botswana-Travelers in the Kalahari Desert know they are in Ghanzi District when fences begin to appear on either side of the desert road. With the exception of an occasional track that veers off to one side, there are no other signs of habitation until the road rises slightly toward a cattle quarantine station.

On a recent evening, Carole Schreck sat at the kitchen table in her small studio apartment on East 89th Street and remembered. Her memories weren't always pleasant. They were of the days when she was in the same situation that Betty Ford is in now-physical rehabilitation following a radical mastectomy.

Despite a 110-94 preseason victory over the New York Nets before a crowd of 9,149 in the Nassau Coliseum tonight, Coach K.C. Jones of the Washington Bullets wasn't too pleased with his team's performance.

Woodie Thompson, Johnnie Williams and Kary Baker each ran for more than 100 yards as Miami defeated University of the Pacific, 35-6, tonight. Pacific was held to two field goals before an Orange Bowl crowd of 15,184, the poorest turnout for a Miami game since World War II.

Seven defendants were named yesterday in a series of indictments involving the alleged sale of $2.6-million in stolen securities and $186,000 in hijacked cloth, as well as an alleged scheme to sell $12-million in stolen United States Treasury bills.

The resignations of two mainstays of the White House staff of Richard M. Nixon have been accepted by President Ford, it was announced yesterday. The winemakers of the Sauternes region of France are sure that they make one of the great wines of the world and it vexes them no end that their work goes largely unnoticed by the people who should be their customers.

The Kitchen-that worthy locale for new music and video experimentation now at Wooster and Broome Streets-opened its third music season Wednesday with the first of three consecutive evening programs of works by Tom Johnson.

Senator Jacob K. Javits urged here today the creation of regional labor-management productivity councils as a means of fighting inflation. He said that they should be patterned on similar agencies established during World Was II, which he said "played a valuable part in the war production effort,"

The Sixth Congressional District zigzags across southern New Jersey as if it were torn from the pages of a political text on classical gerrymanders. At its worst, the district is the suburban situation carried to the extreme: hodgepodge housing tracts and miles of shopping centers and commercial developments crowding the sides of its. major highways where farmland once produced much of the state's corn and dairy products.
Francis J. McIntee, who retired in 1972 as president of Consolidated Color Press, Inc., 50 West 17th Street, died yesterday at his home, 85 Mountain Avenue, New Rochelle, N. Y. He was 72 years old.

Pope Paul VI attends most of the full sessions of the Synod of Bishops, facing the Bishops. When he hears a speech that impresses him by Its spirituality, he greets the speaker, arms extended forward, palms upward, hands fluttering slowly.
Secretary of State Kissinger's departure from Cairo this morning was delayed half an hour after one of his bodyguards was accidentally wounded as the Air Force 707 jet was taxiing for its take-off.

Hale Irwin, a 9-1 shot at the tee-off yesterday, has reached the final of the Piccadilly World Match Play golf tournament, almost inevitably against Gary Player. And the reason he's there, Irwin said, is that part of the gallery cheered when he three-putted today, and "that made me mad."

As pre-World Series workouts go, the Oakland A's staged a tumultuous one today, even by their well-established uninhibited standards. There was a clubhouse fistfight between Rollie Fingers and John Odom that resulted in a five-stitch scalp wound for Fingers when his head hit the sharp edge of a locker cubicle.
The constitutional amendment providing for the appointment of a Vice President should be repealed because it is unworkable, Senator Howard H. Baker Jr., Republican of Tennessee, said today.

The campaign in the 26th Congressional District is in many ways a rerun of the local election in 1972, offering the voters a clear-cut choice among a liberal Democrat, a moderate Republican and a Conservative party candidate.
John H. Krey, long associated with investment banking concerns in this city, died Thursday evening in a hospital in Richmond. He was 73 years old and lived in Richmond.

Treasury Secretary William E. Simon, said today the Administration was willing to accept legislation ending the oil depletion allowance and had no intention now of abandoning price controls on oil. But he added that the White House intended to change the price control system in a manner that, experts say would add $4.4-billion to the nation's petroleum costs.
The Securities and Exchange Commission proposed today to require increased disclosure of relationships between registered corporations and their independent public accountants.

In a sweeping attack on the Western press, a senior Soviet commentator has charged major American, British, Frenct and West German newspapers and especially The New York Times --.with conducting a "violent campaign" against detente.

The British election yesterday froze for any near future the hopes of the Liberals of breaking out of their perennial small-party status. The Liberal revival, which took on substance in last February's elections, virtually collapsed yesterday.

John E. Heyke Jr., board chairman and chief executive officer of the Brooklyn Union Gas Company, died, apparently of a heart attack, at his home in Locust Valley, L.I., yesterday. He was 64 years old.

Former President Richard M. Nixon has accepted a Justice Department offer to continue defending him in civil suits that allege improper political harassment while he was in office, a spokesman for Mr. Nixon's attorney said today.

John Patterson, Sr., the Baptist preacher from Dalton, Ga., gained his second windfall of the week tonight at Yonkers Raceway when he scored with Chief Rival in the $100,000 New York Sires Stakes Pace for 3-year-olds colts and geldings.

GTE Sylvania, Inc., will acquire the Philco name and distribution rights for home entertainment products made by Philco-Ford and sold in the United States and Canada, according to an agreement announced by the companies.

Executone, Inc., and Local 431 of the International Union of Electrical Workers reached agreement yesterday on a twoyear contract, ending a strike that began Oct. 1.

The stock market yesterday finished its best week in history. Some bullish economic news enabled the Dow Jones industrial average to climb 10.09 points yesterday to 658.17 and sent its advance for the week to 73.61 points, its largest weekly gain ever.

Seven terrorists granted political asylum by Panama after they released seven hostages they had held in the Venezuelan consulate in Santo Domingo in the Dominican Republic were under medical observation at Santo Tomas Hospital here today.
A New York City lawyer and an Alabama merchant have been indicted by a Federal grand jury on charges they bilked retail stores in nine states of more than $700,000.

Frank Sinatra's hour-long live telecast last night from Madison Square Garden turned out to be quite a show, both for television watchers and for those actually at the Garden. It was certainly a high point in Mr. Sinatra's career, and it came, of all eves, on the eve of Columbus Day.

Y., and a stepson of Bayard Foster Pope Jr. of New York.

Mayor Beame was honored at a testimonial dinner at the Americana Hotel by the City of Hope as "its man of the year." The award cited the Mayor's concern for "the sick, the poor and the disadvantaged." The dinner was sponsored by the 93 auxiliaries of the City of Hope, located near Los Angeles and devoted to various phases of medical research. Milton Berle, the entertainer, was master of ceremonies.

Jane Stuart Vander Poel of Verona, N. J., daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Halsted B. Vander Poel of Rome, was married yesterday in Gladstone, N. J., to Dr. Martin Palmer of New York, son of Mr. and Mrs. Irving T. Palmer of New York.

Charles A. Schmutz, former president of Standard Poor's Corporation, publishers and financial advisers, died Saturday in Community Hospital, Glen Cove, L.I. He was 74 years old and lived at Mill Neck, L.I.; Lake Mohonk, N.Y., and St. Petersburg, Fla.

The New York Giants tried a face-lifting for their offense with Jim Del Gaizo at quarterback today, but the wrinkles of despair continued in a 35-7 defeat to the Philadelphia Eagles.

A spreading outbreak of infectious hepatitis at the Navy's training center here that has hospitalized more than 100 recruits forced a sharp curtailment of San Diego's weekend celebration of the Navy's 199th birthday.

This poses a potentially thorny problem for the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries, where all the member countries, except Saudi Arabia, are determined to keep the price of oil at the present range of $10 to $12 a barrel and safeguard their revenues against worldwide inflation.

Dr. A. Irving Hallowell, professor emeritus of anthropology at the University of Pennsylvania and a past president of the American Anthropological Association, died last Thursday at his home in Wayne, Pa. He was 81 years old.

Electricity rates of the nation's 50 largest utilities rose by an average of 55.4 per cent during the first half of this year. James (Doc) Counsilman, swimming coach at Indiana University, was named yesterday as head coach of the 1976 United States men's Olympic swimming team. Counsilman coached the highly successful men's team in the 1964 Games.

Under prodding from a House committee alarmed about airline landing accidents, the Federal Aviation Administration has agreed to speed work on a proposed rule requiring use of an automatic warning device on all this country's airliners.
The net income of the Xerox Corporation rose by 6.5 per cent to $82-million, or $1.04 a share, in the third quarter of 1974, the business equipment company reported yesterday.
An "ironclad" contract prevents the A's from being moved out of Oakland, or from being sold to anyone who would move them out, before 1987, the OaklandAlameda County Coliseum, said today.
After the news conference yesterday morning and before the celebration party last night, Dr. Paul J. Flory sat by his pool in Portola Valley, Calif., trying to relax. He did not sucMen ced.

An American chemist whose ideas and techniques made possible the wide range of plastics and other synthetic polymers in common use today and two British astronomers who have investigated the distant reaches of the universe received 1974 Nobel Prizes yesterday.

Twenty-two Columbia and Barnard students have established a coed communal residence hall to replace what one of the students called the "cold and inhuman experience" of dormitory life.

Gloom returned to Wall Street yesterday after four days of soaring stock prices, but of far greater longrange significance to the securities industry and the investing public is the comprehensive stock market reform legislation now up for final passage by the House of Representatives.
The Dow Chemical Company reported yesterday that its third-quarter profits were up 129.3 per cent and nine-month net was 100.4 per cent ahead of last year.
A report urging the establishment of offtrack betting in Nassau County next was submitted today to the New York State Racing and Wagering Board for approval.

More than 150 Hispanic parents and students picketed City Hall this afternoon, voicing concern about the future of the public-school system's bilingual education program for more than 3,000 pupils at nine grammar schools.

A seven-day strike by teachers in the Bellmore-Merrick Central High School District ended today when both the Board of Education and the union accepted fact-finders' recommendations for a new two-year contract.

Governor Wilson's campaign aides reported a cut of onethird in their candidate's television-commercial budget yesterday, and Representative Hugh L. Carey listed a net deficit of $360,000 in his gubernatorial campaign.

A woman subway rider was shot in the thigh early yesterday when a pistol in the pocket of a man sitting across from her accidentally discharged as the train lurched into a station in the Bronx, the Transit Authority Police reported. All foreign buyers of American feed grains and soybeans are being told to restrain their purchases or run the risk of having to deal with tighter export controls, United States officials said today.

Carter Hawley Hale Stores, Inc., of Los Angeles announced yesterday that it had revised the terms for the purchase of a large block of shares of the House of Fraser from Scottish and Universal Investment, Ltd., of Merger Glasgow, Scotland.

Frank Kowalski, a former Democratic Representative from Connecticut and a retired Army colonel, died Friday of a heart ailment at the Walter Reed Army Medical Center. He was 66 years old and lived here.

A young man calling himself "Black Samson" and shod in black boots adorned with pink polka dots, stole a Sanitation Department truck loaded with garbage yesterday in the Bedford - Stuyvesant section of Brooklyn and subsequently rammed it into a Transit Authority bus.

As a result of incorrect information from the police, Karen Robinson, vice president of the Fairleigh Dickinson University student body, was listed in The New York Times as being among 25 students arrested in a drug raid on dormitories and residences on the Madison campus of the university Monday morning.

The policeman in the threepiece gray flannel suit knew that the London police force, with 28,000 people, was the second largest in the world-after the force in New York, which has 31,000.

State legislators and farm owners from South Jersey were unsuccessful today in an 11th-hour bid to defeat or modify a migrant-labor reform bill that would hold the state's produce growers responsible for the activities of their crew leaders.

JERUSALEM-One bit of good news Secretary Kissinger brought to Israel at the start of this week was that United States production of tanks and armored vehicles was being considerably increased and would soon rise to three or four times the rate prevailing two years ago.

Bradley Dewey, the chemical engineer, industrialist, inventor and management man, whose work ranged from developing gas masks and synthetic rubber to sealants for metal cans an plastic film for packaging ood, died on Monday at his home in New London, N.H. He was 87 years old.

To build something new with city aid, arts institutions move through the equivalent of a giant 71-step board game with municipal officials, according to a detailed outline in the report of .the Mayor's Committee on Cultural Policy.
The Agriculture Department said today that it had begun a monitoring program in three Northwestern states after high DDT levels had been detected in some sheep that grazed on sprayed rangeland.

Court papers submitted yesterday in Federal District Court in Brooklyn maintained that Anthony Abbatemarco, reputed underboss of the Joseph A. Colombo Sr. Mafia "family," was psychologically unfit to testify before a Federal grand jury.

When President Ford appears voluntarily before a House Judiciary subcommittee tomorrow to explain why he prematurely granted Richard Nixon an unconditional pardon, his questioners should not allow the commendable Presidential gesture to overshadow the need for specific answers.

The northbound lanes of the West Side Highway were jammed with cars and then temporarily closed to traffic last night as once again the northbound section of the roadway-the Henry Hudson Parkway - between 72d Street and 96th Street was closed.
Arthur Ashe, Ilie Nastase of Rumania and Biorn Borg of Sweden advanced to the third round of the Spanish open tennis tournament today.
G. Gordon Liddy, a member of the original Watergate break-in team, was released from jail today on a $5,000 bond after his attorneys promised a Federal judge that he would not flee the country.

Governor Wilson said yesterday that Representative Hugh L. Carey as Governor would be "a disaster for the State of New York who would triple state income taxes for-people earning more than $25,000 a year..

The significance of Amintore Fanfani's attempt to form his fifth Cabinet and Italy's 37th postwar Government is clear: If he fails to reconstruct a viable ministry from the ranks of Italy's democratic parties, the next Government is virtually certain to include representatives of the most powerful Communist party in the Western world.
The Pottsville Club, a historic landmark referred to in several John O'Hara novels, burned today. Officials said arson might be involved.

Rick Wakeman, a classically trained keyboard player who has been part of two British rock groups, Strawbs and Yes, is now off on his own. Monday night he brought his new band, a symphony orchestra, small chorus and some props to Madison Square Garden.
Congress sent President Ford legislation today to put as much as $8-billion in Federal funds into the depressed housing market, making it easier for homebuyers to find credit.
Tom Phelan, former chief facilities engineer for the NBC television network, died Sunday at Jersey Shore Medical Hospital in Neptune. He was 66 years old.
A rookie goalie, Ron Low of Washington, survived 16 shots by the Los Angeles Kings in the final period tonight and preserved a 1-1 tie for the Capitals in their National Hockel League home opener.

Police Commissioner Michael J. Codd issued a new set of internal departemntal regular tions yesterday, overturning an automatic suspension rule that had been a foundation of the department's anticorruption machinery since shortly after the police scandals of the mideighteen-nineties.

Paul W. Morency, who retired in 1967 as president of Broadcast Plaza, Inc., died today at his home in Avon. He was 74 years old.
The House passed today and sent to President Ford a bill authorizing $200-Million for Amtrak, the national passenger train corporation, for the current fiscal year.

Secretary of State Kissinger's latest mission to the Middle East has elicited yet another expression of intent by Saudi Arabia to work for a lower world oil price. This time the pledge came from King Faisal him self,
A three-alarm fire spread through four storefronts on Lee Avenue near Ross Street in the Williamsburg section of Brooklyn last night, forcing the relocation of 35 tenants.
Mexico tonight announced that she will seek observer status in the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries as a result of important new oil discoveries in the southeast part of the country.
Charley Winner wanted to make one thing perfectly clear: he wasn't talking about last Sunday's disaster.
After a long controversy, Secretary of the Army Howard H. Callaway has ordered a curb on spying by Army intelligence on United States civilians.

Spain's biggest industrial plant, the SEAT automobile works, is confronted, like the rest of the country, with the problem of navigating between a political system trying to perpetuate itself and a leftist opposition trying to bring it down.
With a burst of feasting and merrymaking, Moslems today wound up the holy month of Ramadan, the season of sunrise-to-sunset fasting that is one of the pillars of their religion.

A top Federal transit official warned yesterday that it could easily take an extra five years beyond the 1981 target date to finish the Second Avenue subway if the city used its Federal transit aid largely to meet operating deficits.

Olivia Newton-John and Ronnie Milsap, two performers who never worked the cramped stage of the Grand Ole Opry;took major honors in last night's Country Music Association's awards, the first ever held at the lovely new Opry building.
Harold Long Williamson, a retired United States Foreign Service officer, died Sunday at his home in Bedford Hills, N.Y. He was 83 years old.
Col. John S. Griffith, an aviator who served in the two world wars, died Monday at Central Suffolk Hospital, Riverhead, L. I. He was 75 years old and lived on Ogden Lane, Quogue, L. I.

Gov. Francis W. Sargent requested President Ford today to send Federal troops into Boston and mobilized two National Guard military police units totaling 400 men in the wake of reneed racial violence in the schools.

Laurance S. Rockefeller said today that he sent a telegram to President Nixon in August, 1972, urging Mr. Nixon to allow Eastern Airlines, in which the Rockefellers have an interest, to acquire Caribair, an airline based in Puerto Rico. Seven months later, Mr. Nixon reversed a decision by the Civil Aeronautics Board and approved the acquisition.

President Ford's veto of a measure to cut off military aid to Turkey was sustained when the House of Representatives failed by 16 votes to readopt the measure by a twothirds majority. The House Appropriations Committee then drafted a compromise measure that would let the President delay the cut off until Dec. 10.
Prime Minister Zulfikar Ali Bhutto said today that organized tribal insurgency against the Government in the troubled province of Baluchistan "has come to an end."

Men, many of them bewildered and confused about their role in society today day, are seeking help from family and marriage counselors in greater numbers than at any time in the past. The increase in men initiating and actively participating in counseling consultation is not yet of major proportions but, according to both private practitioners and associations, the trend is a noticeable one.

A chart published in these columns yesterday listed 15 common stocks held by the United States Olympic Committee and gave the prices of those stocks on Oct. 31, 1972, June 30, 1974, and Sept: 30, 1974.

" Blacks have no choice," Basil A. Paterson was saying the other day by way of explaining why he thought the overwhelming number of blacks who vote would cast their ballots for Representative Hugh L. Carey. The low-keyed assessment, by one of the state's leading Democrats, summed up the prevailing attitude among many leading Democratic politicians and focused on the historic position of black voters in the state, the majority of. whom are Democrats.

A State Supreme Court justice yesterday annulled the nomination of Angelo Del Toro and ordered a new primary election Oct. 25 for the Democratic party's candidate in the 72d Assembly District in East Harlem.

A spokesman for the Chilean Government said today that Jonathan Kandell, a correspondent of The New York Times, was denied permission to enter the country because of his "tendentious" dispatches in previous visits.
Elizabeth du Gue Trapier, an authority on Spanish art, died yesterday in Hightstown, N. J. She was 81 years old..
It was a replay of last Wednesday night in Montreal, but the Islanders gave it a new ending tonight as they defeated the Canadians, 6-3, before a crowd of 11,479 at Nassau Coliseum.
John D. Erhlichman opened his defense it the Watergate coverup trial today by placing the blame for the cover-up and for his own disputed actions squarely upon former President Richard M. Nixon.
The Supreme Court agreed today to consider the Government's complaint that the mutual fund industry is illegally restricting the resale of its shares and fixing resale prices.

Outraged by a budget cut ordered by Mayor Beame that led to a decision to close their neighborhood library, 100 Greenwich Village community leaders met at the Jefferson Market Library last night to organize a fight to save the library, which many of the leaders had fought to bring to the neighborhood seven years ago.

Despite tough gun laws, there are an estimated total of 1 million illegally possessed pistols in New York City, according to a special state study released today, which recommends that prompt, effective measures be taken to "reduce the menace."

In an action brought by two Connecticut consumer groups and United States Representative Ella T. Grasso, two of the state's major power companies were enjoined today from applying higher rates approved last week by the State Public Utilities Commission.

Stock prices tumbled yesterday for the second consecutive session in less active trading as bearish economic developments depressed the market. The Dow Jones industrial average dropped 16.11 points to close at 642.29, its low for the day. Its high for the day was set at 1:30 P.M., when the average was off 2.74 points at 655.66. Yesterday's loss in the Dow was the largest since Aug. 23, when it fell 17.83 points.

Frederika Fox, a former editor for yogue, House and Garden, House Beautiful, Good Housekeeping, Harper's Bazaar and Woman's Home Companion magazines, died Tuesday in Connecticut after a long illness. She was 72 years old.

Charles Aznavour has composed, according to his biography, some 1,000 songs. (He'll be there until Oct. 27.)

The ban on trading in the securities of Avis, Inc., ordered on Oct. 1, has been terminated, the Securities and Exchange Commission announced yesterday. The ban had been imposed because of unsubstantiated rumors of the possible purchase of I.T.T.'s majority interest in Avis.

Residents here voted overwhellingly tonight to establish a Village of Harrison with the same borders as the town, a move intended to bar the Purchase community from seceding by forming its own village.

C. Clark Stover, a member of the law firm of Gifford, Woody, Carter Hays, died Tuesday at New York Hospital. He was 62 years old and lived at 31 Warwick Road, Colonia, N. J. -Mr. Stover attended Amherst College and the Harvard Law School.

After a delay of about three years in complying with regulations of the Environmental Protection Administration requiring them to convert their air polluting incinerators to dry compactors, the 2,400-apartment Elchester Cooperatives have agreed to make the conversion.

" If me must wait for hope, we will wait for it singing." Those words, from Oscar Matoa's "Zamba de los Humildes" ("Song of the Poor"), summed up the concert Tuesday night at Hunter College Playhouse by the Chilean folksong group called Inti-Illimani.

The Hollywood film companies that produce prime-time television series are up against an economic crisis, brought on in part by inflation, whose effects may show up on the television screens next September unless the television networks substantially increase their payments for shows.

At Armagh Women's Jail in Northern Ireland, women prisoners, including supporters of both Roman Catholic and Protestant militants, released a prison warden and four women officers as hostages. Personal income increased $8.8-billion in September but for the first nine months of 1974 the booming growth began to slacken, the Commerce Department reported today. The $8.8-billion increase was bigger than the August gain of $6.7-billion but the August figures had been influenced by retroactive payments to Federal employes in July.

Judge Anthony J. Travia, saying he wanted "a little rest" and more time for his family, announced yesterday his intention to resign from the bench of the Federal Court for the Eastern-District of New York at the end of November.

President Ford, campaigning for Republican candidates in the Middle West, said today that massive Democratic victor ries in November's Congressional election could create a "legislative dictatorship."

Outraged by a budget cut ordered by Mayor Beame that led to a decision to close their neighborhood library, 100 Greenwich Village community leaders met at the Jefferson Market Library last night to organize a fight to save the library, which many of the leaders had fought to bring to the neighborhood seven years ago.

John W. Dean 3d led off the Government's case in the Watergate cover-up trial today with three and a half hours of testimony in which he implicated four of the five defendants in the cover-up. John W. Dean 3d arriving by car in the rain yesterday to testify in the Watergate cover-up trial in Washington.

The opening days of the Watergate conspiracy trial have already provided proof that former President Richard Nixon, though unindicted thanks to a technicality and immunized by a premature pardon, is in fact the irremovable principal figure in the dock. The prosecution's description of Mr. Nixon's active role in the cover-up set the stage for what can only be described as Mr. Nixon's trial in absentia.

A syndicate headed by First National City Bank appeared to Have won the largest bond sale in the city's history yesterday, but then lost out to its rival syndicate when the city Controller found a mistake on First National City's bid.

The Toronto franchise in World Team Tennis has been sold to Hartford interests and another franchise may be sold, 'but the league plans to continue operations with 16 teams in 1975, Frank Fuhrer, president, said today after two days of meetings. "Nobody made any money this year, but I don't think anybody expected to," he said. He identified the Hartford purchasers as Bert Hoffman and Phyllis Morse. The franchise was sold by John Bassett.
A compromise drug-control bill containing a repeal of the controversial no-knock law was passed by the Senate and sent to President Ford today. By voice vote with no debate,
Apparel retailers; producers and textile companies had the biggest increase in debts among bankrupt businesses of any American industry in the first seven months of 1974.

Senator Howard W. Cannon chairman of the Senate Rules Committee, said today that he does not plan to resume hear ings on Vice President-desig nate Nelson A. Rockefeller's nomination until after the Nov 5 Congressional elections, de spite Mr. Rockefeller's request for "immediate hearings." Nelson A. Rockefeller at a news session here yesterday. The Vice President-designate regretted that he would not have "a proper forum for at least another month."

The United States-Soviet trade and economic council, winding up its annual meeting here, predicted today that American exports to the Soviet Union in the 1976-80 period, which encompasses the next Soviet five-year plan, would total $9-billion.
The Eastman Kodak Company announced yesterday that, although its sales for the first nine months ran well ahead of the year-earlier pace, net income declined--as it has all year.
Portugal's Council of State approved the appointment of five new members to the governing military junta tonight to replace Gen. Antonio de Spinola and three of his conservative supporters.

Mayor Beame and the leaders of four unions representing 165,000 city workers agreed yesterday to set up a joint productivity program aimed at getting better service without spending more of the city's money.

Students at Yale University have updated the traditional campus diversion of fitting a maximum of human bodies into an enclosed space by taking the sport out of telephone booths and Volkswagens and into the library. Students at Cross Campus Library at Yale enjoying-if that's the word-stuffing themselves into a study cubicle Tuesday night.

C., Ltd., Montreal. Brown Root, a subsidiary of the Halliburton Company, is sponsor of the joint venture, which comprises the design and engineering of Asarco's new electrolytic zinc refinery.

Despite Warnings of another Presi. dential veto, Congress approved legislation today that would immediately cut off military aid to Turkey if she shipped any American equipment to her forces on Cyprus.

A line-up change, one player's traumatic reaction to it, and an owner's inspirational speech were the main topics among the Oakland A's tonight after their 5-2 victory over the Los Angeles Dodgers had given them a 3-1 grip on the World Series.

Doctors are experimenting with a memory-erasing drug that can rid a surgical patient of unpleasant recollections about. the operating room. The drug, called lorazepam, is still. experimental and available only for medical research.
Britain's highest court ruled unanimously today that a workingmen's club in industrial Lancashire was entitled to apply a color bar on membership since it is a private place.

OAKLAND, Calif., Oct. 16--California's first World Series threatened to become a short one tonight, when the Oakland A's outmaneuvered the Los Angeles Dodgers, 5-2, and moved to within one game of their third straight championship.
I. J. Alexander, a writer and advertising man, died yesterday at New York Hospital of cancer of the liver. He was 69 years old and lived at 350 West 55th Street.

The United States Department of Agriculture has started an inquiry to determine if the adulteration of millions of quarts of milk by the Dairylea cooperative from 1967 through 1973 had any adverse effects on the federally financed school lunch program and other Federal programs in which dairy products are used.

Invoking the name of the man who built the Erie Canal, City Council President Paul O'Dwyer criticized yesterday a zoning scheme that he said would inhibit waterborne commerce in the Clinton area on the West Side.

David L. Yunich, chairman of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, produced new deficit estimates yesterday to show transit and bus fares soaring to 60 cents in 1975 if there was no Federal subsidy.

The. signs hanging on the locker room wall tell the story: Lawrence 21, Mountain Lakes 20, Morristown 13, Red Bank 11. Those numbers represent streaks extended by four of New Jersey's top scholastic teams this season. And, if past performance serves as an indication, this time next week the signs should read: Lawrence 22, Mountain Lakes. 21, Morristown 14, Red Bank 12.

After an almost continuous 15-week climb, the cost of feeding a family of four here held virtually steady last week, but the city warned consumers about getting their hopes up. Market experts said prices were likely to resume their upward pattern next week.

The Soviet Union is objecting to the cost of maintaining United Nations buffer forces between Israeli and Egyptian troops in the Sinai Peninsula, and between Israeli and Syrian troops on the Golan Heights.
The Health and Hospitals Corporation announced yesterday that the state would reimburse city hospitals $25-million in Medicaid payments to cover an eight-month period in the current fiscal year.

Leon Jaworski, the outgoing special Watergate prosecutor, and his former top assistant, Philip A. Lacovara, said today that "substantial evidence" would soon be made public showing that former President Richard M. Nixon had played a major role in the Watergate cover-up.

Britain's election has demonstrated once again how difficult it Is for a third force to make an effective national challenge to a well-established two-party system. What Is possible-and what happened in BritainIs a series of limited challenges by relatively small special-interest parties which under certain circumstances can have substantial impact on national policy and even on political stability.

Four prisoners who escaped from the Camden County jail Tuesday night "are still at large," officials said yesterday. The men escaped from their sixth-floor cells by climbing down a makeshift rope of bedsheets to a fourthfloor window. Then they apparently broke a window, re-entered the building and continued down a stairway.

President Ford deplored today what he termed the "shocking and wasteful" protest slaughtering of calves by farmers in Wisconsin at a time when the nation was trying to increase its food supply.

Tom Okker and Bjorn Borg, the top-seeded players, swept to the fourth round of the Spanish open tennis tournament today, but fifth-seeded Arthur Ashe and Brian Gottfried of the United States were toppled.

William T. Seawell and Charles C. Tillinghast Jr., the Chairmen, respectively, of Pan American World Airways and Trans World Airlines, signed an agreement yesterday exchanging rights to serve more than a dozen cities in Europe and Asia.

Eimei Yamashita, Japan's Vice Minister of International Trade and Industry, gave forecast.

A fire swept through two floors of a ninestory downtown hotel here early today. The police said that 16 people had been killed and about 30 injured. Several died leaping, from the fourth and fifth floors; others perished from burns or suffocation.
YOUGHAL, Ireland -- Perhaps the most important thing about the Irish Republican Army is that hardly anyone, except its enemies, ever talks about it, although everyone knows about it.

At Armagh Women's Jail in Northern Ireland, women prisoners, including supporters of both Roman Catholic and Protestant militants, seized a prison warden and four women officers as hostages. The inmates were acting in support of men prisoners who set the Maze prison camp on fire to protest detention by the British authorities without any trial. [Page 1, Columns L-2.]

The Freedom of Information Act was passed by Congress in 1966 on the assumption that the public should have broad right of access to information about the workings of its Government. The act hasn't functioned particularly well since it went into effect because of the Federal Government's use of a variety of obstructionist tactics ranging from forcing those seeking information into long and costly litigation to plain old bureaucratic foot-dragging.
A leading liberal economist told Congress today that President Ford's proposed tax program was "questionable on equity grounds."

A strike by 93 per cent of the faculty and a simultaneous student boycott virtually brought classes to a halt on the 3,500-student Rider College campus near Trenton. The walkout followed a breakdown in year-long negotiations in which 120 members of the American Association of University Professors sought to gain a 13.5 per cent increase in salaries, a greater voice in college administration and a closed shop.

WASHINGTON--The Chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee, Wilbur Mills, who has long been regarded as one of the hardest working members of Congress, is now the butt of jokes. A minor driving violation uncovered an apparent peccadillo, arid the wags of Washington snicker: "The strippers of the. Mills grind slowly."
Prices on the American Stock Exchange and the over-thecounter market continued to decline in light trading yesterday for the second straight session.

Then: He grabbed his hat from his head, dashed for the tiny, John Shirley-Quirk, baritone, being made up for his roles and, at right, as himself. He.. appears as traveler, fop, gondolier, hotel manager, barber and leader of players.

With European Communist parties in greater apparent disarray than at any time since World War 11, party representatives from 28 countries convened here today to make arrangements for a full-scale Communist meeting.

The Mexican government announced today that it was assuming control of International Telephone and Telegraph's Mexican subsidiary, Indetel, following several months of "cordial" negotiations with the United States conglomerate.

Don Highsmith scored two touchdowns tonight and led the Charlotte Hornets to a 27-0 World Football League victory over the Chicago Fire.

The American Cancer Society said yesterday that it was continuing to recommend radical surgery for most cases of breast cancer, despite the preliminary findings of a nationwide study indicating that less extensive surgery may give as good results in early cases of the disease.

E. F. Hutton Group, Inc., parent of the brokerage house, said yesterday that 'third-quarter earnings rose more than fivefold to $732,000, or 16 cents a share, from $125,000, or 3 cents a share, a year earlier.

WASHINGTON.-- Any President's legitimacy results from responsibility for political stability and unity (United) and for imperial expansion (States). A President believes that being concerned with these responsibilities is the very meaning of the law and the Constitution.

John Gianelli walked off the Monmouth College court Tuesday night more knowledgeable and aware of what it take to be the overpowering center the Knicks lack.

Maury John, former national basketball coach of the year who led Drake University to the National Collegiate Athletic Association finals in 1969 and former head coach at Iowa State University, died last night of cancer. He was 54 years old.
Oil men offered the Govern ment $1.4-billion in cash immediately on 149 offshore leases today, plus a "buy now, pay later" gamble on eight others.

Representative and Mrs. Wilbur D. Mills in Little Rock, Ark., last night after air trip from Washington.

Apartment-house landlords demonstrating outside the midtown offices of the Saudi Arabian Mission to the U.N.

President Ford's appearance before the House Subcommittee on Criminal Justice to answer questions about his pardon of former President Richard M. Nixon will be televised today, beginning at 10 A.M., by Channels 2, 4 and 7.

A United States district judge says the Government cannot remove aged; blind and crippled persons from Federal disability rolls without first giving them a hearing.

Horses galloped by, fierce winds blew, walls appeared and disappeared and a nonexistent dinner was consumed, all at the conjuring of Marcel Marceau, the French pantomimist, who explained his art and demonstrated it to 500 students yesterday at City College.

The optimistic noises about a reduction in oil prices that accompanied Secretary Kissinger's Mideast travels undoubtedly need to be taken with a barrel of salt. Mr. Kissinger's diplomatic offensive and other forms of "jawboning" are unlikely to have much effect so long as the fundamental power balance and supply-demand situation remain unchanged.

The Amateur Athletic Union approved legislation today to suspend any American track and field athlete who violates travel - permit moratoriums before national championships and .. international meets.

Margaretta (Happy) Rockefeller, the wife of the Vice President-designate, underwent surgery yesterday for removal of , her left breast after she discovered the existence of a suspicious nodule in a self-examnation two weeks ago.

The Securities and Exchange Commission announced today the temporary suspension of its recently adopted uniform short-sale rule governing securities in the consolidated transaction reporting system. Richard H. Kuh, the Manhattan District Attorney, yesterday called for the abolition of sheriff's jury panels. His proposal was immediately attacked by the Appellate Division of State Supreme Court as "demogogic."

Representative Wilbur D. Mills apologized to his constituents tonight in his first speech and first formal appearance since he was involved in an incident with a former nightclub stripper in Washington on Oct. 7.

Dr. Peter F. Curran, director of the Division of Biological Sciences at Yale University, died of a heart attack last night at his suburban home. He was 43 years old.

Fowler, chairman of the Goldman Sachs International Corporation and a former Secretary of the Treasury, predicted yesterday that short-term interest rates would probably decline to between 9 per cent and 10 per cent by early next year and that they would continue in this range for four to six months.
